KAUFMAN--Joseph L. Our friend and partner whose memory and contribution to our firm, The American Stock Exchange, and the securities industry will live on. All of us were proud to have worked with a special human being who lived by the motto of "your word is your bond." He represented the purest form of integrity and honesty. The customer was always treated fairly and with respect. He will be missed. Cohn, Delaire and Kaufman

FLUG--Alfred. Our deepest sympathy to our dear son-inlaw, Robert, on the loss of his father, Alfred. We know what an impact your father had on you; and always enjoyed hearing you lovingly tell your funny stories about him. He will always be an inspiration for you. The Hirsch Family

RYAN--Edward Francis, decorated WWII Marine Fighter Pilot, Brokerage Executive and Active In Catholic Church. Edward Francis Ryan, 87, a 37 year resident of Short Hills, NJ, died peacefully at home on Saturday, December 26, 2009. A Funeral Mass will be held at 11:15am on Saturday, January 9, 2010 at St. Rose of Lima Church, 50 Short Hills Avenue, Short Hills, NJ. Entombment will be at the St. Rose of Lima Mausoleum. Visitation will be at the Bradley, Smith & Smith Funeral Home located at 415 Morris Avenue in Springfield from 2 to 4pm and 7 to 9pm on Thursday, January 7th and Friday, January 8th. Born in Stamford, CT, Edward Ryan was the son of Michael and Agnes Ryan. He attended the Wharton School of Business of the University of Pennsylvania where he was President of his class, given the Spoon Award, a member of Sigma Chi and manager of the Mask & Wig. Upon graduation in 1943, he entered the United States Marine Corps aviation program and was trained as a night fighter pilot. Mr. Ryan flew the F6F-N and was assigned to VMF(N) 533. He participated in the Okinawa campaign and the occupation of Japan. He was awarded two Distinguished Flying Crosses and seven Air Medals. Following WWII, Mr. Ryan joined Merrill Lynch and was assigned to the Altoona, PA office where in 1947 he met and married Lois Jean Stewart. Mr. Ryan spent 37 years with Merrill Lynch and retired in 1983 after serving as Chief Financial Officer and as a Director. In addition, he served as Chairman of Merrill Lynch Leasing and Merrill Lynch Government Securities. After retirement, Mr. Ryan served on the Arbitration Panel of the New York Stock Exchange and was a Director of several mutual funds. Mr. Ryan was also a Trustee of The Moore School of Electrical Engineering at the University of Pennsylvania and the Hahnemann Hospital and Medical College in Philadelphia. Mr. Ryan was a lifelong supporter of the Catholic Church. He was a longtime member of the Finance Council of the Archdiocese of Newark, was a Trustee and Chairman of the Finance Committee for the National Shrine in Washington DC and in 2002 was awarded the Papal Medal "Pro Ecclesia et Pontifice" for his dedicated service. Mr. Ryan was a Knight of Malta, a member of The Knights of Columbus and the American Legion Post 140. Edward was preceded in death by Lois, his wife of 59 years, brother Robert and sisters Barbara and Mary. He is survived by a daughter Janet of Berwyn, PA and three sons, Richard of Ashburn, VA, Michael of Basking Ridge, NJ and Ted of Madison, NJ. Mr. Ryan was also blessed with 14 grandchildren and two great-grandchildren. The family requests that in lieu of flowers, memorial donations be made to the Loyola Retreat House, 161 James Street, Morristown, NJ 07960.

Officials were trying to determine on Monday how a man who walked through the wrong door on Sunday afternoon turned the busiest terminal at Newark Liberty International Airport into a human traffic jam on one of the busiest travel days of the year. Flights from Terminal C at Newark were halted after a passenger told Transportation Security Administration officials that the man went the wrong way through a one-way door at about 5:20 p.m.

BASS--S. Kermit, passed away peacefully in Los Angeles, CA on New Year's Eve, December 31st, 2009. He was 89 years old. Son of William and Cecile, Mr. Bass proudly served in the U.S. Cavalry during World War II. He went on to become a prominent designer and manufacturer in the women's fashion world, working with icons such as Stanley Blacker. He loved, but sadly outlived, two wives, Sylvia and Mela. He is survived by his grandchildren, Andrew, Carrie, and Rachel, his children, Michael and Esther, and his great-grandson, Logan, as well as his sister, Rita. He was predeceased by his beloved granddaughter, Tracy, and his brother, Elliot. Mr. Bass was a former member of the Seawane Country Club in Hewlett, NY and Boca Grove Country Club, in Boca Raton, FL. Donations can be made to: Jonsson Cancer Center Foundation, Box: 951780, Factor Building, Room 8-950, Los Angeles, CA 90095-1780.

WOHL--Peggy (Richman), passed away January 3, 2010. Beloved wife of Harold, mother of Fran Zimmerman and Judy (Lester) Henner, grandmother of six and great-grandmother of ten, sister of Fred and Rita Richman. Shiva will be observed at 70 Briarwood Lane, Lawrence, NY until Sunday morning.

POPISH--Lawrence Charles. "Larry" died suddenly on January 2. Cherished son of Helene and Abe. Devoted brother to Nancy. Charity and kindness was the essence of his character and personality along with a keen intelligence. Our hearts are broken. We will remember him for all eternity. Services Wednesday, 11:30am, at "The Riverside", 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave.

KATZ--Sigmund, died Saturday, January 2, at 95 after a brief illness. He was born February 20, 1914 in Brooklyn, NY and led a long and productive life. Professionally, he was a chemical engineer and inventor. He invented the process of bonding porcelain to metal for the dental laboratory industry. He and his wife, Gerry, also worked out many of the technical procedures for creating porcelain to metal prosthetics. They were happily married for 59 years, and had two children, Robert (deceased), and Sarah who will miss him terribly. He is also survived by his sister, Helen Cytryn, and many nieces and nephews. Funeral services will be held on Tuesday, January 5 at 2:00pm at Bernheim-Apter-Kreitzman Suburban Funeral Chapel, 68 Old Short Hills Rd., Livingston, NJ 07039. Sarah will hold Shiva at her apartment Wednesday, Thursday and Friday from 3-8pm.
FRIEDE--Anita. Our special sister, aunt and teacher. We will remember you always with love. Elaine, Steve, Shelley and Jeff
WOHL--Peggy. Sincerest sympathies to Harold and the entire family. With love, Bernie Weiss and family

SMITH--Bagley, of Washington, DC, died January 2nd. Survivors include his wife of 26 years, Ambassador Elizabeth Frawley Bagley; six children, five grandchildren and a sister. The family will receive friends on Wednesday, January 6 from 12 to 2pm and 5 to 7pm at O'Donovan Hall, Georgetown University. Funeral services will be held on Thursday, January 7th, at 10:30am at Holy Trinity Catholic Church, 3513 N Street NW. Memorial contributions may be made to National Rehabilitation Hospital, Attention Dr. Paul Rao at 102 Irving Street NW, Washington, DC 20010 or to National Institute of Neurological Disorders and Stroke, Attn: Dr. Steven Warach, 31 Center Drive, MSC 2540, Bethesda, MD 20892-2540. Services by Joseph Gawlers Sons.

COOPER--Wyatt E.,January 5th, 1978. Daddy and Carter within us always. Gloria and Anderson

KAPLAN--Sylvia, died January 2, 2010 in Rockland County. Devoted mother to Sonia (Jack) and Stan (Ruth); adoring grandmother to Lauren, Amy, Matt and Scott. A kind woman with a big heart who loved life, and bestowed unconditional love to her family.

The evening before he was sworn into office, Barack Obama stepped out of Blair House, the government residence where he was staying across from the White House, and climbed into an armored limousine for the ride to a bipartisan dinner. Joining him in the back seat were John Brennan, his new counterterrorism adviser, and two foreign-policy advisers, Denis McDonough and Mark Lippert. The three men with the president-elect were out of breath, having rushed more than a mile from transition headquarters on foot after failing to find a taxi in Washington's preinaugural madness. As the motorcade moved out, they updated Obama on gathering evidence of a major terrorist plot to attack his inauguration. After a weekend of round-the-clock analysis, the nation's intelligence agencies were concerned that the threat was real, the men told him. A group of Somali extremists was reported to be coming across the border from Canada to detonate explosives as the new president took the oath of office. With more than a million onlookers viewing the ceremony from the National Mall and hundreds of millions more watching on television around the world, what could be a more devastating target? ''All the data points suggested there was a real threat evolving quickly that had an overseas component,'' Juan Carlos Zarate, President George W. Bush's deputy national security adviser for combating terrorism, told me in November. As the inauguration approached, signs of a plot ''seemed to be growing in credibility and relevance.'' Another senior Bush official involved in those tense events a year ago said last fall that protecting the new president was not enough. Even a failed attack would send a debilitating message to the world. ''If something happens on the podium and there's chaos,'' this official told me, ''that's the first time you see the new president, and you really don't want that.''

House Democratic leaders will meet on Tuesday to begin discussing plans to merge their version of major health care legislation with the bill adopted by the Senate on Christmas Eve. But leadership aides in both chambers say there are no plans for a formal conference committee to reconcile the two measures. The Senate passed its bill on a party-line vote, 60 to 39, and the Republican leader, Senator Mitch McConnell of Kentucky, promised that he and his caucus would do everything in their power to stop it from becoming law.
NASS--Harold, WWII veteran died January 4. Survived by Lily, Max and granddaughter Eva.

VIVIANO--Margaret, 95, died December 31, 2009 in New York City. Survived by her sister-in-law, Shirley Viviano of Baltimore, MD and loving nieces and nephews. Funeral services on January 6, 2010 at 10am at Our Lady of Peace, 237 East 62nd St., New York, NY.

From deep inside a cubicle on the first official workday of 2010 for the hats-and-noisemakers crowd, a question came to mind: How did the people who worked while the rest of the city partied on New Year's Eve spend their Monday? Were they still slaving away, if you can use that word about people who orchestrate ball drops in Times Square and mastermind fireworks displays in Central Park? Jeffrey A. Straus, the chief executive of the company that produces the New Year's Eve celebration at 1 Times Square, was not in his office, high above where it all happened as the clock ticked down the final moments of the old year. He was working, he said, but from home, in Armonk, N.Y.

FELLERMAN--Betty, on January 3. Survived by her husband Marvin Gottstein, her stepchildren Shari (Arthur), David (Kim), and Robert (Maura) and her grandchildren Allison, Dana, Andrew, Evan, and Ian. Graveside service Tuesday, 10:30am at Mt. Hebron Cemetery in Flushing.
WOHL--Peggy. Congregation Beth Sholom records with sorrow the passing of its esteemed member. May her memory be for a blessing.
GROBERG--Marcia. 1/5/2005. You are always in my heart, even though you're far away. David Levidow

President Lee Myung-bak, left, renewed a proposal on Monday that South and North Korea open liaison offices in each other's capitals to facilitate dialogue. Such offices would be the first standing channel of official contact between the governments, which remain divided by a heavily armed border after the 1950-53 Korean War ended in a truce rather than a permanent peace treaty. The two countries maintain a military hot line. North Korea did not immediately respond to Mr. Lee's offer.

FLUG--Alfred. You were and continue to be an inspiration to me and the entire family. Your love, drive, generosity and dedication to family will live within us as an example. We love you. Your grandson and great-grandson Owen and Alex Mazon

FLUG--Alfred, 94, died at his home in Palm Beach, FL, on December 30, 2009. Dad, you died exactly the way you lived your life, on your own terms. You've been there for us in your inimitable way since we were born and never asked for anything in return, I could go on, but I think Sinatra said it best, You loved, you laughed and cried, you had your fill, your share of losing and now, as tears subside you'd find it all so amusing to think you did all that and may I say, not in a shy way, oh, no, oh, no, not you, you did it your way. I love you dad, Robert. Also survived by his daughter Carol, daughter-in-law Ellen, grandchildren Danielle, Racquel (Jim) and Owen, great-grandchildren Juliette, Jasper, and Alexander, and companion Elena.

LANDMAN--Peter, 71, passed away on January 3, 2010 after a valiant 14 year fight with lymphoma. Adored husband of Carole, beloved father of Stacey, Howard and Felicia Landman. Very loved Poppy of Reid, Morgan, Sylvie and Mason. Heart and soul of Camp Kennybrook for 45 years. Beloved brother-in-law, brother, uncle, cousin and friend. The family is ever grateful for the extraordinary medical care and compassion given by Dr. Morton Coleman, Dr. Gary Raises, and White Plains Infusion Center Nurses, Michelle Bean and Kathy Duffy. Donations to Lymphoma Research Foundation, 115 Broadway, New York, NY 10006 would be greatly appreciated. Services Wednesday, 10am, January 6 at Riverside Chapel, 21 West Broad St., Mt. Vernon, NY.

GALLAGHER--John P.,of City Island, NY passed away at home on December 30, 2009. The son of the late John E. and Joan E. Gallagher, John was born in the Bronx on March 16, 1954, and spent much of his life in Brewster and North Salem, NY. John worked as a Senior Estimator at Granite Construction Northeast in Tarrytown, NY, and outside of work was an avid boater. He is survived by children Robert and Catherine; sisters Ellen, Peggy, Ginger, Teresa and Joan; and eight nieces and nephews.

Finally, two years after he was the surprise hire and after a season in which he was stripped of everything but the headset he wore on the sideline, Jim Zorn was fired by the Washington Redskins early Monday morning. The firing put an end to what rapidly devolved into a season-long public humiliation of Zorn, and it cleared the way for another rebuilding in Daniel Snyder's decade of ownership. Hours later, The Washington Post reported that Mike Shanahan, a former Broncos coach, had arrived in suburban Virginia to meet with Snyder.

KLEINHANDLER--Nathan, 94, of Boynton Beach, FL, formerly of Flushing, beloved husband of 71 years to Florence, left behind a loving, devoted family of sons, Neil and Chester, sister Millie Bahn, daughters-in-law Naomi and Solange and granddaughters Mariel and Ashley. Nathan, a retired CPA, will be missed by all those privileged to have been touched by his wisdom, friendship, kindness, humor and love.

The Jets announced Monday night that Casey Johnson, a daughter of the owner Woody Johnson, had died earlier in the day in Los Angeles. The cause of the death was undetermined. She was 30. ''The Johnson family is mourning its tragic loss, and asks for privacy during this very difficult time,'' the team said in a statement.

APPLETON--Bernard S.,known his entire life as Bob, passed away peacefully at home on January 1, 2010, exactly two weeks shy of his 85th birthday. Throughout his long and productive life, Bob brought wisdom, compassion, wit and generosity to everything and everyone in his world. In every capacity, in every role, whether it be family or community or business, he fulfilled it far beyond expectation. He served his country with honor, his principles with conviction, and his family with immeasurable love and devotion. His warmth and spirit and knowledge have touched lives on every continent, and will continue to do so for generations to come. He was a student, a teacher, a benefactor and a mentor. As engineer and inventor, he never offered problems, only solutions, and found success at every turn. As a singular member of his community, he spread his personal brand of philanthropy over an area too wide to ascribe. As the hub and heart of his family, he sheltered and nurtured us all. He will be dearly missed and always loved by his wife of 57 years, Helen; his daughter, Elizabeth, and son, Dennis; their spouses, Mark and Leslie; his two grandchildren, Hilary and Seth, the next generation to carry on all he loved and cared for, and the ultimate pride and true joy of his life; and his honorary and extended families in Germany, Italy, Japan, around the world and across this country. Funeral services will be held at 1:00 on Wednesday, January 6, at Boulevard-Riverside Chapels, 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, NY. In lieu of flowers, the family would appreciate contributions to a charity reflecting his kindness and character. We miss you so much, Bopo Harry Daddy Bob.

MANASSE--Claus George, 80, passed away on January 3rd, surrounded by his loving family. He was the kindest, gentlest man who inspired devotion in all who knew him. Claus was also a brilliant, highly educated man who could be counted on to provide the answer to any historical question. On the professional front, Claus' considerable talents benefited many organizations, where he served as Chief Financial Officer. We will miss you always, and we know how fortunate we were to learn from your illustrious example. Claus was a beloved husband, father, father-in-law, grandfather, brother and uncle. He is survived by his wife Ellen, his children Michael and Karen, his grandchildren Joshua and Hannah, and his sister Renata Manasse Schwebel. A memorial service and celebration of his life will be held at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue on Tuesday, January 5th at 9:30am. In lieu of flowers, the family has requested that donations be made to the universities that so enriched Claus' life: Massachusetts Institute of Technology and the University of Chicago Booth School of Business.

FABRICIUS--Dr. Walter. Dr. Walter Fabricius, 72, on December 27, 2009, after a brief illness, surrounded by his loving family. Dear father to daughters Daniela Fabricius and Stephanie Weidenbecher, and grandfather to Lucas Weidenbecher; beloved husband of Dagmar, and brother to Bernhard and Guenther. Dr. Fabricius was the President of Fabricius and Company, a financial and investment services firm he established after a long and illustrious career that included serving as Managing Director at Deutsche Bank, J.P. Morgan, and Auda Advisor Associates. He earned his doctorate in Constitutional Law from the University of Mainz, Germany, following degrees in Law and Economics from the Universities of Heidelberg and Munich, Germany, and studies at the Institut d'Etudes Politiques in Paris and the Gordonstoun School in Scotland. After practicing law for several years in Mannheim and Heidelberg, Germany, Dr. Fabricius joined the offices of Deutsche Bank in Germany in 1973. His fluency in German, English, and French, coupled with his gift for cross-cultural diplomacy, were great assets to Deutsche Bank, which sent him to New York in 1976. There he became integral to the growth of Deutsche Bank's presence in the United States. While with Deutsche Bank in New York, he served as Executive Vice-President and Head of the Corporate Finance Group of Deutsche Bank Capital Corporation, before becoming Managing Director and Head of the Asset Management Products Group of Deutsche Morgan Grenfell. In 1996, after more than twenty years with Deutsche Bank, he joined J.P. Morgan as Managing Director of the International Private Client Group. In 1999, he became Managing Director of Auda Advisor Associates, helping to expand the firm from a small company managing the wealth of the Harald Quandt family to a major provider of alternative investment products. He devoted himself full time to Fabricius & Company in 2007, and relished its location at the iconic Rockefeller Center. Born March 17, 1937 in Berlin, Germany, Dr. Fabricius was an heir of Carl Johann Freudenberg, who in 1849 founded Freudenberg & Co., which remains one of the largest and oldest family-owned companies in Germany. Dr. Fabricius grew up in the Freudenberg family home in Weinheim, Germany, and served on the company advisory board for two decades. He was heir also to a storied history of German arts and culture; his parents were from Munich's Herzogpark district, where his grandfather Walter Courvoisier, a Swiss composer, was a friend and neighbor of novelist Thomas Mann. Walter Courvoisier's father-in-law and mentor was Ludwig Thuille, himself a renowned composer and intimate friend of Richard Strauss. Having spent his earliest childhood in wartime Germany, Dr. Fabricius was of a generation that wished to rebuild the reputation of their country and promote strong international relationships. He often spoke of this and lived by example, working in both official and personal ways to strengthen ties between his birth nation and his country of residence. Dr. Fabricius is remembered as a natural diplomat, a trusted advisor, and a generous friend; a frequent trans-Atlantic traveler, his suitcase was always heavy with gifts for lifelong clients and loved ones. He was known for his elegance of manner and style, and brought to his work and life old-world discretion and charm. He possessed a boundless, youthful energy, and was an innovator in developing modern financial tools such as the industrial revenue bond. He was a consummate networker with a wide and impressive array of clients whom he treated with familial warmth, who in turn trusted his prudence, experience, and intelligence. To his daughters he was a source of unconditional love and support, of patience and wisdom, a model of integrity, a teacher and storyteller, a proud father who openly adored his girls. To his wife he was simply everything a prince, a partner, and the love of her life. Dr. Fabricius was a mentor to many, and touched many lives with his boundless willingness to lend an ear or offer help. He treated all who crossed his path with equal dignity and respect. Dr. Fabricius had an extraordinary ear for music and language, and loved to play the piano for his daughters or show off his talent for making puns and imitating dialects. He was a passionate and knowledgeable listener of jazz and classical music, and an experienced connoisseur of wine and cuisine. He also took great pleasure in making and editing home movies using the latest available technologies. Weekends were spent tending the garden at the family's house in East Hampton, where he also played handyman. Dr. Fabricius was beloved, trusted, and admired by a wide circle of family, friends, and colleagues, among whom he famously never forgot a birthday. He left us too suddenly and all too soon, but leaves behind a legacy to aspire to.
APPLETON--Bernard. Our family will always treasure the special lifelong friendship and memories shared. We will miss you dearly. All our love to Helen, Dennis and Liz. The Rosner Family

WILLARD--Timothy L. (Tim), age 45, of New York City died December 28, 2009 at his home. Everyone that Tim touched knew him as a kind, loving, considerate person who put the interest of others always ahead of his own. He is survived by his mother Lawanda Corbett, father Fred Willard and brother Trever Willard. A memorial service in New York City will be planned for February.

I actually hadn't intended to write today's column; it was a bit of an accident. Originally when I booked my Central America trip I thought I would travel through Honduras, Nicaragua and Costa Rica, and my plan in Costa Rica was to write something narrowly about its success in health care. But then I chose to spend a bit more time in Honduras and Nicaragua, and everybody seemed to be out of Costa Rica for holiday travel. Since my return flight was from Costa Rica, I went anyway but figured I probably wouldn't be able to write. (And, frankly, my daughter had come along for the trip in part because of the promise of going to Costa Rica; I didn't want to be the one to tell her that she would get the Honduran slums and impoverished Nicaraguan villages, but no Costa Rican beach or jungle....)Then a Times researcher, Hilary Howard, sent me the Happy Planet Index report, which I read while driving around the country. The report got me thinking about Costa Rica and happiness. So I poked around, perused the data, and the column took shape. Originally, I thought I would frame the column more in terms of Latin and Caribbean countries doing unusually well in happiness surveys; I was fascinated by the idea that this reflected a cultural emphasis on building social capital as opposed to financial capital. But although it's an interesting theory, I never found much evidence for it, and so I focused on Costa Rica and the gains it made in education after abolishing its army.

THURSDAY'S PUZZLE - It's time to discuss the Gödel Incompleteness Theorem, or at least the crossword equivalent. What do you do when you exhaust your skill and memory and still end up with a blank square or two, the emptiness mocking you, the sense of accomplishment, of completion, denied? Can you love a puzzle you can't complete?
The United States beat Canada, 6-5, in Saskatoon, Saskatchewan, to capture its second gold medal at the World Junior Hockey Championship.
David Brandon will take over in March as Michigan’s new athletic director with a five-year contract if university regents approve the move on Jan. 21.

For Democrats who see their political prospects this year as a tossup between catastrophic and merely horrible, there is hope on the horizon from a most unlikely source. No, not Rush Limbaugh, who recently praised his medical experience in the government-mandated, heavily unionized health care system of Hawaii. Mahalo to him.

Kelly Clark, the 2002 Olympic gold medalist in the halfpipe, became the first snowboarder to snare a spot on the 2010 United States halfpipe team by winning the United States Snowboarding Grand Prix at Mammoth Mountain, Calif. It is the third consecutive Olympic berth for Clark, who finished fourth at the 2006 Winter Games in Torino, Italy.

Talks between the players and management of the Cleveland Orchestra broke down on Wednesday, and the musicians threatened to go on strike on Jan. 18. Susan Boyle prevailed in the final week of music sales for 2009, holding at No. 1 on the Billboard album chart for a sixth week. Her "I Dreamed a Dream" (Syco Music/Columbia) sold 137,000 copies, according to Nielsen SoundScan. Its 3.1 million sales gave Taylor Swift's "Fearless" (Big Machine) a run for its money as the best-selling album of the year, but in the end Ms. Swift prevailed. "Fearless" holds at No. 5 on the latest weekly chart with 60,000 sales, but her total for the year was 3.2 million. ( An article about album sales for the year is here.)

Sec. Clinton gave an excellent speech on development today. She has a longtime interest in poverty issues, and President Obama's mother was a pioneer in microfinance, yet so far the Obama administration hasn't been particularly engaged in global poverty issues. It took forever, after all, to get an administrator for USAID, the aid agency. In contrast, President Bush never seemed very interested in global poverty, but he left a quite impressive legacy there -- with Pepfar, the AIDS effort; the President's Malaria Initiative; and his Millennium Challenge Corporation directing aid to countries with good governance.

Mr. Kupferberg, 86, has had two strokes over the last year, which have left him blind -- although he still manages to regularly post video jokes to YouTube -- and the tickets for the concert, which is being produced by Hal Willner, will help pay his medical expenses. Among the others performers are the singer John Kruth; Ed Sanders, Mr. Kupferberg's fellow Fug; and Peter Stampfel of the Holy Modal Rounders (who also played on early Fugs albums). Tickets are $75 to $125 and are available at stannswarehouse.org or (718) 254.8779.

Responding to Jim Manzi (and myself) on the subject of Europe's falling share of global G.D.P., Jon Chait points out that the gap between America's economic performance and Europe's over the last 30 years narrows dramatically if you look at G.D.P per capita, rather than just at overall economic growth. In other words, much of the widening gap between the U.S. and European shares of global G.D.P. can be chalked up to America's population growth since the 1970s, rather than increasing per person wealth.

The New York City Ballet has always wanted a fall repertory season at the theater it shares with New York City Opera at Lincoln Center. Now, the ballet's wish is coming true, because of the economic needs of the opera. This September, the ballet will perform for four weeks in advance of its usual "Nutcracker" run, which starts in late November. The opera, in turn, will get $9 million in relief from its building payments, part of the $100 million gift given by the oil magnate David H. Koch toward the renovation of the theater, which was named after him and was completed in November. Read more about the arrangement.

It's not only famous authors whose life-threatening maladies can be diagnosed centuries after their deaths, but a medical expert at the University of Palermo in Italy says that he has also found evidence of medical afflictions in the subjects of some of the world's most famous paintings, including the Mona Lisa, The Times of London reported. Vito Franco, a professor of pathological anatomy at the university, told The Times that he had spent two years examining people depicted in art masterpieces for evidence of disease and illness. Among his diagnoses, Dr. Franco said that Mona Lisa may have had high cholesterol, possibly evinced by a buildup of fatty acids under her skin, as well as a benign tumor in her right eye. He also said that the 5-year-old Infanta Margarita depicted in Velázquez's painting "Las Meninas" might have had McCune-Albright syndrome, a genetic disease that affects bones, and the Virgin Mary in Piero della Francesca's "Madonna del Parto" has a goiter on her neck.

Clint Dempsey gave England and the world a look at his skill when he scored a stunning goal in Fulham's 3-2 loss at Stoke City in the English Premier League on Tuesday. It was the Cottagers' second straight loss following a run of six matches without a loss that had pushed the club to the middle of the pack.

Symphony orchestra musicians, in public, at least, rarely cast aspersions on other orchestras. But the principal flutist of the Chicago Symphony Orchestra had some less than complimentary things to say about the Los Angeles Philharmonic, according to a newspaper report. The flutist, Mathieu Dufour, had been on leave and was performing with the Philharmonic temporarily -- a fairly common occurrence when first-chair players are considering a move. Mr. Dufour has decided to stay at his Midwestern job, The Chicago Sun-Times reported on Tuesday, quoting him as saying that the Los Angeles Philharmonic has "no tradition there - no tradition of sound and no tradition of working together as a dedicated ensemble. Maybe they will have that someday in the future."

Amid all of the Washington news Wednesday morning, we forgot to flag this bit of news: a Merrill Lynch executive is weighing a bid to unseat Senator Kirsten E. Gillibrand in this fall's Democratic primary, The New York Times's Michael Barbaro reported, citing three people close to the executive.

By now, it should come as no surprise that "The Hurt Locker," the film about bombs over, in and around Baghdad, has been named the year's best by Metacritic, the online review aggregator. Kathryn Bigelow's gutsy feature has won kudos from nearly every critical group, from New York to Los Angeles to the digital realm, which as we all know, long ago stopped being the domain of pajama-clad mouth-breathers and is now the domain of everyone. Though in the march toward The 10 -- and the lock step to The One -- awards from peer groups are more predictive, professional accolades are helpful, to be sure, if only because they encourage people to actually see the movie. "The Hurt Locker," which was released in the summer, has made just over $16 million globally, or about what "Avatar" took home in an afternoon.

Whether or not, as a timely movie title predicted, 2010 proves to be the year we make contact with intelligent alien life, it has already brought us something equally as improbable: the promise of Hole's first shows in 11 years. The Guardian reported that Hole, the vintage-1990s grunge-rock band led by Courtney Love, announced on its Facebook page that it would play three European shows next month, starting with a performance on Feb. 17 at the Shepherds Bush Empire in London. The concert dates are also listed on a Web site for "Nobody's Daughter," an album that was once planned as a solo project for Ms. Love but was rebranded as a Hole album last year (and is still without a label or a release date). The Guardian said that the new lineup of Hole would include Ms. Love, the guitarist Micko Larkin, the bassist Shawn Dailey and the drummer Stu Fischer. It was unclear if Ms. Love's former bandmates Eric Erlandson (who has previously declared "there is no Hole without me") and Melissa Auf der Maur (who has said of Ms. Love, "She's a nutbag and I really do care about her") would be involved.

President Obama awoke on Wednesday to a dispiriting reality: Less than a year after taking office on the strength of a historic Democratic sweep, his party is facing a shifting and perilous political environment that could have big implications for this year's midterm elections and his own agenda.

Updated | 3:44 p.m. Two Chinese movies have been pulled from the Palm Springs International Film Festival to protest another film about the Dalai Lama and Tibet, Agence France-Presse reported. The Chinese movies "Nanjing! Nanjing!" (also known as "City of Life and Death"), about the Japanese occupation of Nanjing in 1937, and "Quick Quick Slow," were withdrawn, according to China's state-run Beijing Times, because the Palm Springs festival plans to screen a movie called "The Sun Behind the Clouds: Tibet's Struggle for Freedom." That film, a documentary by Ritu Sarin and Tenzing Sonam, follows the Dalai Lama for a year, and its description in the festival's program said that it chronicled "the 2008 protests in Tibet, the long march in India, the Beijing Olympics and the breakdown of talks with China." A representative for "Nanjing! Nanjing!" said that the films were pulled on the order of China's ministry of foreign affairs, its film bureau and the consulate general of China in Los Angeles.

Though the real-life Bob Barker is better known for his affability and gentleness toward people with no conception of what things cost, a ship named for Mr. Barker, the longtime "Price Is Right" host, had its first confrontation with whalers on Tuesday, The Associated Press reported. The Bob Barker, a 1,200-ton vessel operated by the Sea Shepherd Conservation Society, the activist group featured on the Animal Planet series "Whale Wars," was among the ships that tried to stop a Japanese whaling mission in waters near Antarctica. Mr. Barker, 86, donated the money for his namesake ship after meeting the Sea Shepherd founder Paul Watson through a fellow animal advocate. "He said he thought he could put the Japanese whaling fleet out of business if he had $5 million," Mr. Barker told The A.P. "I said, 'I think you do have the skills to do that, and I have $5 million, so let's get it on.'" Sea Shepherd describes itself as an anti-poaching organization, and says it enforces the United Nations World Charter for Nature by intervening in whaling missions.

The Bagger has been enjoying breaking out the sports terminology during this awards season, finding out who's in the pole position or who's pulled off a hat trick. The wild card/dark horse/Cinderella at the dance this week may be "Up," which was nominated for best picture by the Producers Guild of America on Tuesday. Pixar's hit, about Carl, a 78-year-old widowed grump - played by Ed Asner - who turns his house into a floating bucket list quest, bringing a precociously annoying boy (Jordan Nagai) along for the ride, was hailed by many critics as an adult-worthy animated tale. The first five minutes of the film, which wordlessly captures Carl's entire life with his wife, from meet-cute to wedding day to funeral, with images that rifle through cinematic classics, was especially sophisticated. Manohla Dargis called it "filmmaking at its purest." Also, it makes everyone cry.

It was almost 30 years ago that I led a management buyout of what was then a failing International Harvester factory in Springfield, Mo. As it is now, the economy then was in the tank and capital was next to impossible to come by. I was convinced that our only hope was to open the books and teach every employee how to think like an owner. As I explained in my first post, things have worked out pretty well for the company we created, SRC Holdings.

The SXSW Film Conference and Festival in Austin has chosen an opening-night film likely to excite many of the fanboys it often attracts: the fanboy-themed action film "Kick-Ass." Aaron Johnson stars and Matthew Vaughn ("Stardust," "Layer Cake") directs. The film will release nationwide on April 16 from Lionsgate.

Autism Clusters Probably Not Linked to Environment | The 10 places in California where there appears to be an uptick in the number of children with autism may be linked to parents' ability to get help for their children rather than a specific environmental risk, according to a new study by the University of California, Davis, that was published in The Journal of Autism Research. Among the 10 clusters are the Sunnyvale-Santa Clara area, the San Carlos-Belmont area in San Mateo County and Sacramento. "I don't think you have to worry about something in the neighborhood harming children," said Irva Hertz-Picciotto, the project's lead investigator. [The San Jose Mercury News]

Expect challenging, exciting and “sometimes just plain cockamamie new works” at the sixth annual “Under the Radar” festival which begins tonight at the Public Theater. This year’s festival, produced by Mark Russell, includes well-established figures like Richard Maxwell and the highly regarded Philadelphia troupe Pig Iron, Charles Isherwood writes. Also check out works from newer contributors, including “Silver Stars,” a song cycle derived from the experiences of gay men from Dublin to New York, as well as “The Wind-Up Bird Chronicle,” a multimedia adaptation of the Haruki Murakami novel directed by Stephen Earnheart, and “John Cassavetes’ Husbands,” a theatrical adaptation of the 1970 film about middle-age malaise.

“With every new generation, popular art changes,” Stephen Sondheim said in a recent interview. “Already there’s a generation that thinks the Beatles are old-fashioned, which I find screamingly funny.” There’s little doubt of Sondheim’s staying power today and the same can be said for another artist of his generation — Elaine Stritch. Ms. Stritch, who is almost 85, is presenting “At Home at the Carlyle: Elaine Stritch Singin’ Sondheim ... One Song at a Time” an all-Sondheim program with six musicians at the Café Carlyle beginning this week. Her approach to Sondheim “is a dramatic no-holds-barred wrestling match between the singer and the song, in which there is little doubt about the outcome,” writes Stephen Holden. “Because Ms. Stritch is a ferociously age-defiant theatrical force, “Singin’ ” doesn’t fully evoke the savage, canny dramatic eviscerations one can expect in a show that may well be legendary after its run concludes on Jan. 30.”

There’s nothing like a little taste of the West Coast to warm a cold New Yorker. “If the Dos Toros Taqueria just off Union Square brings to mind the sort of fresh, quick and cheap eating found at Mexican joints in the San Francisco Bay Area, that’s by design,” writes Oliver Strand. “It was opened by brothers Leo and Oliver Kremer, two natives of Berkeley, Calif., who worshiped Gordo Taqueria, a local favorite founded in 1977. Dos Toros is something of an homage.” There are only three items on the menu: a taco, burrito and quesadilla, with a variety of possible preparations. Hint: say yes to the guacamole. Go for the “simple and succulent food, stripped-down cooking served in Spartan conditions. Just like at Gordo, Dos Toros has a short menu, high standards and such satisfying fare you don’t mind the hospital lighting.” Also look out for other Left Coast details: “the biodegradable corn-based utensils, the aggressive composting policy, the disarmingly nice staff.” It will make you feel like you’re in sunny California, at least until you walk back outside.

In December the publishing industry was shocked when the Nielsen company announced it was shutting down Kirkus Reviews, the venerable journal of prepublication book reviews used by many buyers as a hint at what might become best sellers and a source for finding neglected gems. On Tuesday it appeared that a white knight might be lurking in the wings. Eric Liebetrau, the journal’s managing editor, said in an e-mail message that Nielsen and Kirkus were “in the process of working out an arrangement with an acquiring company to continue the publication of the magazine.” He said he had no further details about the identity of the acquiring company, but said news was expected by the end of the month. “We will definitely publish a second issue in January,” Mr. Liebetrau wrote, “and then reassess the situation and hopefully continue publication in February and beyond.” Kirkus, a biweekly founded in 1933, published nearly 5,000 reviews a year.

As “Avatar” knocks down box office records, the film has hit another, less estimable milestone: it has become the fastest-pirated movie, according to one tracking firm’s figures. The Times of London reported that “Avatar,” starring Zoë Saldana, right, was illegally downloaded 500,000 times in the first two days of its release and 980,000 times in the first week, citing figures from the Web site TorrentFreak.com, which tracks usage of the file-sharing tool BitTorrent. In the days leading up to the film’s release last month, its director, James Cameron, seemed confident that the 3-D effects would essentially make it immune to piracy, telling The Times of London, “You can pirate a 3-D movie, but you can’t pirate it in 3-D, so you can’t bottle that 3-D experience.” But the TorrentFreak.com numbers seem to tell a different story: “Avatar” was illegally downloaded far more often than its closest competitor, the “Twilight” sequel “New Moon,” which was downloaded 610,000 times in its first week of release. Still, 20th Century Fox, which released “Avatar,” seemed unconcerned that piracy would hurt box office grosses, which last weekend surpassed $1 billion in worldwide ticket sales. “Bootleg copies are unlikely to have much impact,” a studio spokesman told The Times of London. “Seeing the movie in 3-D in a cinema offers an experience that cannot be replicated.”.

The new musical “American Idiot,” based on the Grammy Award-winning album of the same name by the band Green Day, will move to the St. James Theater on Broadway this spring, in time to be eligible for the 2010 Tony Awards. With a book by Green Day’s Billie Joe Armstrong and Michael Mayer, who is also directing, “American Idiot” is scheduled to begin preview performances on March 24 and open on April 20, according to a statement from the producers on Tuesday. The musical, which centers on three young male friends whose lives take decidedly different turns, had a run last fall at Berkeley Repertory Theater, starring John Gallagher Jr., right, who won the Tony Award for best featured actor in a musical in 2007 for “Spring Awakening.” The Broadway cast was not announced in the statement on Tuesday. The lead producers are Tom Hulce and Ira Pittelman, who, with Mr. Mayer directing, also led the “Spring Awakening” team.

Walter Mosley, below, the crime novelist best known for his Easy Rawlins mysteries, has adapted his novel “The Tempest Tales” into his first play, “The Fall of Heaven,” which will have its world premiere at the Cincinnati Playhouse in the Park from Jan. 23 to Feb. 20. The play centers on Tempest Landry, described in a playhouse statement as a streetwise young man from Harlem who is accidentally killed and finds himself in a dispute in heaven with St. Peter, who ultimately sends him back to earth in hopes that Tempest will recognize his mistakes in life. If he does not, heaven will collapse and Satan will reign supreme. Marion McClinton is directing the production; he is best known for his direction of plays by August Wilson, including the Broadway production of “King Hedley II,” for which he was nominated for a Tony Award. David Gallo, who won a Tony in 2006 for best scenic design for the musical “Drowsy Chaperone,” is designing the set. Leland Gantt will star as Tempest. Mr. Mosley is scheduled to hold a discussion of the play at the theater on Jan. 14.

The spirit of Horton Foote, the Pulitzer Prize-winning playwright and screenwriter, will live on in a playwriting award that will be given for the first time this fall. The Horton Foote Prize, whose creation was announced Tuesday and was endorsed by Mr. Foote before his death last March, will be awarded every other year to “an American playwright who has written an original work of exceptional quality,” its organizers said in a news release. The competition will invite 65 resident theaters to submit a work by an author who has written at least three original full-length plays that have been produced by professional theaters; selection committees will choose a short list of finalists; and the winner will be determined by a group of four artistic directors Mr. Foote closely worked with: André Bishop (of Lincoln Center Theater), James Houghton (Signature Theater Company), Michael Wilson (Hartford Stage Company) and Andrew Leynse (Primary Stages). The $30,000 prize will be supplied by the Greg and Mari Marchbanks Family Foundation of Austin, Tex.; Ms. Marchbanks is also the founder and executive director of the prize committee.

Lory Roston, renowned public relations professional, successful venture capitalist, lover of Jack Russell terriers and pretty young women, friend, curmudgeon, and long-time denizen of New York's Upper West Side, died at home on Tuesday, December 22, 2009. He was 81. Friends and family will gather at 11am on January 10th at Union Field Cemetery in Ridgewood, New York, to celebrate his remarkable journey, which began in Welch, West Virginia, passed through Palo Alto and his beloved Stanford, and brought him to New York City, where he had a helluva ride.

DONOHUE--Lorraine (Renee), of Maplewood, New Jersey on Sunday, January 3, 2010. Beloved wife of the late Robert J. Donohue, after a sudden illness at home surround by her family. Renee was born Lorraine Elena D'Auria on December 5, 1928 in Newark, New Jersey to Joseph D'Auria and Christine Federici D'Auria. She graduated from Mount Saint Dominic Academy in Caldwell, New Jersey in 1946 and in 1950 from Marymount College, Tarrytown, New York with a BA degree. Upon graduation, Renee joined the Executive Training Program at Hahne & Company, Newark, New Jersey. On February 7, 1953 Renee married her college sweetheart, Bob at Our Lady of Mount Carmel Church in Orange, New Jersey. Renee was a devoted mother, grandmother, friend and member of her community. She was a longtime member of Our Lady of Sorrows Roman Catholic Church in South Orange. Her nurturing and caring spirit was the essence of her life. Renee was a resident of Maplewood, New Jersey for forty-five years. Renee is survived by her four children, Suzy Donohue of New York City, Peter & Karen Donohue of Avon, Connecticut, Margot and Domenic Fronsaglia of Chestnut Hill, Massachusetts and Robert and Maribeth Donohue of South Orange, New Jersey. Seven adoring grandchildren, Robert and Ryan Donohue, Nicholas, Chris, and Elizabeth Fronsaglia, Madeline and Margaret Donohue. The family will be receiving friends at the William R. Dangler Funeral Home, 309 Springfield Avenue, Summit, New Jersey on Thursday, January 7, from 4-8. The Funeral Mass will be celebrated Friday, January 8, 11:00am at Our Lady of Sorrows R.C. Church, 217 Prospect Street, South Orange, New Jersey 07079. Interment will follow at Gate of Heaven Cemetery, East Hanover. In lieu of flowers the family would appreciate that contributions be made in Renee's memory to Memorial Sloane-Kettering Cancer Center, P.O. Box 27106, New York, New York 10087 or to New York Presbyterian Hospital Cornel Medical Center, Department of Neuroscience, Attention Dr. Frank Petito/Stroke Research, 525 York Avenue, New York, NY 10065.

RUSSO--Lynne Sawdon, beloved wife, mother and grandmother, passed away on Christmas Eve, 2009. Her husband and family were by her side at W. Marion Hospital in Ocala, Florida. Lynne dek Russo was born on May 2, 1939 in New York City, the daughter of Frank B. Sawdon, an advertising executive and Minerva Fedyn Sawdon, who remarried Paul W. Williams, a former U.S. Attorney and Supreme Court judge. Lynne married Henryk de Kwiatkowski, an Aviation Entrepreneur with whom she had six children. She later remarried Maurizio Candotti Russo, vice president of Idelson Gnocchi Publisher Ltd.. Lynne and Maurizio moved to Ocala in 1999, where Lynne founded Minerva Stud Farm and dedicated the final years of her life to her husband, children and horse breeding business. Lynne purchased Danzig for de Kwiatkowski, the world's Top Leading Sire and advised on the purchase of Calumet Farm. She is survived by her husband Maurizio and her six children: Michelle Corsini, Nicole Timonier, Conrad de Kwiatkowski, Arianne de Kwiatkowski, Stephan de Kwiatkowski, Alexandra "Lulu" Gilardini and fifteen grandchildren. May Lynne rest in peace with God for she has blessed many souls with her love.

There is something cinematic about riding a bicycle through New York traffic with its speed, lights and danger. For the rider, street scenes can open up in flashes between stopped cars, creating a kind of stuttered approximation of film. No wonder, then, that many riders, like Luke Stiles and Chris Thormann, have tried to capture these scenes with a camera. From the backs of scooters and the tops of skateboards, Mr. Stiles, 36, a software developer and former racer, and Mr. Thormann, 25, a bicycle messenger and alleycat rider, have been shooting ''Empire,'' a film about everything that is ''fun, scary and exciting'' about bicycling in the city without brakes. ''It's in the sub-sub-subgenre that is fixed-gear action sports videos,'' Mr. Stiles explained. A profile in the latest issue of Cog magazine chronicles the project, which Mr. Stiles and Mr. Thormann hope to complete by this spring.

(Planet Green) BIG CHEF TAKES ON LITTLE CHEF Little Chef may be something of a British institution, but this chain of old-fashioned roadside cafes has been on the brink of financial collapse for years. To the rescue: Heston Blumenthal, above, a three-Michelin-star English chef who experiments with low-temperature and sous-vide (under vacuum) cooking methods at his flagship restaurant, the Fat Duck, in the village of Bray in Berkshire. This series follows Mr. Blumenthal as he tries to revive Little Chef -- and classic English food -- in only six months. In ''Conviction Kitchen,'' at 10, the chef Marc Thuet and his wife and business partner, Biana Zorich, try to open a high-end restaurant in just three weeks. Their staff: 24 ex-convicts with no culinary experience. 6 A.M. (Fox News Channel) FOX & FRIENDSMitt Romney, former governor of Massachusetts, discusses his political aspirations. Senator Byron L. Dorgan, Democrat of North Dakota, announced abruptly on Tuesday that he would not seek re-election this year -- a clear sign of the difficulties Democrats will face in defending their large Congressional majorities in the midterm elections. Mr. Dorgan, who is completing his third term, has been regarded for months as one of the most vulnerable Democratic incumbents. Gov. John Hoeven, a popular Republican, has been weighing a run for Senate, and recent polls indicate he would easily defeat Mr. Dorgan, who nonetheless remains well-regarded by voters.

The Packers were 11-5. The Arizona Cardinals were 10-6. The Packers pummeled the Cardinals last Sunday, 33-7. Yet the Packers must travel to Arizona for a wild-card matchup Sunday. Is this fair? The Cardinals earned a home playoff game by winning their division. But this is a concept left over from an outdated model. A division title was a greater accomplishment before realignment in 2002. Back then, divisions consisted of five teams. But when the league moved to the four-team division format, division titles became more abundant.

FRIDAY'S PUZZLE - Friday and Saturday crosswords are not for the weak of heart, but if you're not working through them yet, you'll get there in time. They're satisfying in a different way than the themed puzzles that appear Monday through Thursday. Like a good single-malt scotch, perhaps, it's an acquired taste that you gradually grow into and then get to feel smug and sophisticated. With crosswords, there is little definitive evidence of a link to liver problems, but please solve responsibly.

It's funny just how quickly 126 days can pass, especially with college football's propensity for scheduling games two, three, even four nights a week. Yet as we stand on the doorstep of the B.C.S. National Championship Game, that is how long it has been -- a few days past four months -- since Sept. 3, when South Carolina edged North Carolina State, 7-3, in the season's first prime-time game. Perhaps it takes 126 days for the cream to rise to the top, as tonight's title game pits the clear Nos. 1 and 2 in the F.B.S.: Texas, winners of the Big 12, and Alabama, the SEC champs.

From diner breakfast to hotel brunch, challah seems to be the bread of choice for making French toast. This is a good idea in principle, but -- like nearly all 21st-century bagels -- most of the nation's challah is the merest shadow of the beautiful eggy bread that Jews used to reserve for special occasions: a recurrent image in Isaac Bashevis Singer's stories is the family so wealthy that it eats challah during the week rather than just on the sabbath.

There were at least two surprises in the Directors Guild of America nominations announced on Thursday: the inclusion of Quentin Tarantino over, say, Clint Eastwood, whom the guild has favored in the past (though Mr. Tarantino was included for "Pulp Fiction"), and the nod for Lee Daniels, who becomes the first black director nominated by the guild and certainly the first openly gay black director. Perhaps this will ease Mr. Daniels's, or his boyfriend's, agita about awards season.

Books have been born all over Brooklyn's Fort Greene. Richard Wright labored over "Native Son" here while sitting on a hill in Fort Greene Park; a bench there now bears his name. He lived nearby, as did Marianne Moore, and several contemporary writers have roots in the neighborhood, including Colson Whitehead, Jhumpa Lahiri and Nelson George. For a tour of this literary hub (or to take the free workshops the New York Writers Coalition holds here to help people find their inner author), hop the subway to DeKalb Avenue or a nearby station. Bring pen and paper, in case the muse strikes.

Environmental groups were full of praise on Thursday when the Environmental Protection Agency proposed the strictest standards to date for smog. Although automobile tailpipes have traditionally been a major source of the smog problem, the auto industry said that it had largely dealt with that issue. Ground-level ozone reductions, the carmakers said, were more likely to come from stationary sources like power plants.

Digital television gave, but it also took away. Digital TV brought us high-definition TV, and if you can get a signal, perfect reception. But one of the things that the switch to digital TV removed is the ability to watch TV while you're on the move.

NBC executives held discussions with both Jay Leno and Conan O'Brien Thursday about the future of the network's late-night lineup. New York's Cheim & Read gallery opens its 2010 season on Thursday night with a blockbuster show featuring the work of two stars of the photography world: Diane Arbus and William Eggleston. "In the Absence of Others" shows rarely seen Arbus images of empty interiors and artificial landscapes. (The Moment was lucky to get one of her images, shown below.) She shoots the spaces with the same candid, documentary style she used in her images of people. In the Eggleston show, "21st Century," viewers quickly fall in love with his color and composition and simultaneously feel a pang for the quietness of each image, whether it's a doorway or a roll of printed fabric. From Cuba to Kentucky, California to Paris, Eggleston's eye is unwavering, and his bold strokes of captured color light up the pigment print like fire. This is American photography at its best.

President Obama on Thursday ordered a series of steps to improve the government's ability to collect, share, analyze and act on intelligence of terrorist threats, saying the findings of a government review of the attempted airline bombing on Christmas Day revealed significant shortcomings in national security.

John M. Deutch, a former director of the Central Intelligence Agency, is stepping down from Citigroup's board, the bank disclosed in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission on Thursday. Mr. Deutch, 70, who has been a Citigroup director for 12 years, told the board on Monday that he would not stand for re-election at the bank's next annual meeting, scheduled for April 20.

He smells a conspiracy to force him to resign and warns his enemies of a tough fight. Predictions of his imminent departure from the presidential palace regularly make the rounds here, although they seem to be inevitable in a society rife with rumors and speculations.

With considerable reluctance, Howard Stern discussed on air the absence of Artie Lange, the comedian and frequent contributor to "The Howard Stern Show" who has been on an indefinite hiatus from the program since December. On Thursday morning's broadcast of his Sirius XM show, Mr. Stern said at first that he felt uneasy and "weird" discussing a report about Mr. Lange that appeared Thursday in the Page Six column of The New York Post. "Artie's demons run deeper than I ever knew," Mr. Stern said, praising Mr. Lange's contributions to the show before saying, "Artie's alive, by the way -- it was a suicide attempt." Mr. Lange, who also appeared on the television series "Mad TV" and in films like "Dirty Work," has discussed his illegal drug use in his standup comedy and a book, "Too Fat to Fish." After several of his standup shows were canceled, including a performance scheduled for New Year's Eve, his representatives said earlier this month that he had been hospitalized. A representative for Mr. Stern did not reply to a request for further comment.

The justice ministry of Switzerland said Thursday it would probably decide this month or next whether it will grant a request by the United States to extradite Roman Polanski, Agence France-Presse reported. The ministry's spokesman, Folco Galli, told Agence France-Presse: "We are preparing our decision. It could be January, it could also be in February. I am not going to be more precise." Mr. Polanski, who fled the United States in 1978 after pleading guilty to having sex with a 13-year-old girl, was apprehended in Switzerland in September. He spent several months in a jail near Zurich before posting $4.5 million bail in December, and is now under house arrest in his chalet in Gstaad. On Wednesday, a written request from Mr. Polanski to be sentenced in absentia was presented to a Los Angeles County Superior Court judge. The judge, Peter P. Espinoza, has scheduled a hearing on Jan. 22 to consider the request.

According to Guinness World Records, the world's most expensive perfume is the designer Clive Christian's limited edition No. 1, at $250,000 for a 50-milliliter bottle. That's fine, but all that really matters is whether his scents are any good. Set aside No. 1 Imperial Majesty ($215,000 for 500 milliliters) and Monogram ($14,500 for 30 milliliters), and we're left with three Clive Christian masculines, all of which are slightly offbeat and rather good.X For Men, created by the talented avant-garde perfumer Geza Schoen under Christian's direction and launched in 2001, has one of the strangest drydowns I've ever experienced. It starts out as a delightful retro, channeling the aftershave used decades ago in Italian barbershops - delicious, aromatic pine with bark of burnished cinnamon. About five hours later, after that burns off, the scent that remains is neutral human breath, warm and strange - and incredibly, almost upsettingly intimate. The barber is inches away, squinting as he trims your sideburns. If you find that he's a bit too close, simply reapply after a few hours and the '50s-era pine will return and endure.

"An Education" leads the "long list" of nominees released Thursday morning for the Orange British Academy Film Awards, better known as the BAFTAs, or the stiff upper lip version of the Oscars. Lone Scherfig's film about a British schoolgirl, played by Carey Mulligan with an adorable pixie-worthy haircut, and her dashing older lover, played by Peter Sarsgaard with a gleam in his eye, earned 17 spots, including best picture, best director and six acting nods, which account for basically its entire cast.

In The New York Times's Week in Review last Sunday, the rock star Bono offers a list of 10 ideas for the next decade. Right there at the top of the list, before improved democracy or better global nutrition, is a call for the return of cars with sex appeal.

Governor Proposes New Budget Priorities | In his final annual address to state lawmakers in Sacramento, Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger proposed a constitutional amendment that would ensure no less than 10 percent of the state's general fund be allotted for higher education and no more than 7 percent for the state prison system. Education leaders hailed the proposal, while some questioned the governor's plan to cut prison costs by privatizing prison services. It has been five years since the state provided more money to public universities than prisons, and the plan faces obstacles. If it fails in Sacramento, watch for it to become part of a ballot initiative. [The New York Times, The Los Angeles Times]

Winter in Hong Kong brings a flutter of migratory wings. The question of what makes a good teacher has been a subject of hot debate in recent weeks. For evidence look no further than the divided reaction to a study Teach for America released about its participants and Amanda Ripley’s article in this month’s issue of The Atlantic. Tonight Cabinet, the art magazine based in Brooklyn, is presenting a more creative take on the issue with “Darcy Lange: The Art of Teaching.” The program will include a viewing and a discussion of a current exhibition of video work by Mr. Lange. In the 1970s, this New Zealand artist took his camera into schools in Britain to record daily events in the classroom. After the screening, a discussion about pedagogy and art will be led by panelists including Kelly Baum of the Princeton University Art Museum, Simon Critchley, a philosophy professor at the New School and Jeff Dolven, an English professor at Princeton. Drinks will be served.

After its debut in August, the Asphalt Orchestra, a brain-child of Bang on a Can, was described by Anthony Tommasini as “part parade spectacle, part halftime show and part cutting-edge contemporary-music concert.” If you missed hearing this radical 12-member band the first time, then you’re in luck tonight, because they are performing a free show at the David Rubenstein Atrium at Lincoln Center beginning at 8:30 p.m. Listen out for an eclectic mix of songs by Björk, Zappa, Mingus and others.

For those of you who found the London apartment in “An Education” swoon-inducing or the Los Angeles bungalow in “A Single Man” as enticing as the very chic clothes, then head to Greenwich House’s newest exhibition, “Studio Pottery and Mid Century Style,” at 6 p.m. tonight. The show features a meticulous recreation of an American living room around 1960. The exhibition will include ceramics from the late 1950s and early to mid-1960s by Peter Voulkos, Gertrude and Otto Natzler as well as furniture by Florence Knoll, Eero Saarinen, Eames and others, not to mention textiles and lighting. To kick off the event, guests are invited to dress up in their own “Mad Men”-inspired frocks and nibble on period food and drink while they take in the stylish scene.

A consortium of producers plans to transfer the Off Broadway production of “The Orphans’ Home Cycle” by Horton Foote to Broadway in the fall, rather than rush the show to Broadway this spring as had been discussed in recent weeks, two theater executives involved in the decision said on Wednesday. The producers had an opportunity to move into the Neil Simon Theater this spring for a limited run, but decided they needed more time to prepare the transfer, said the executives, James Houghton and Michael Wilson, who are the respective artistic directors of the Signature Theater Company and Hartford Stage. The play, a co-production now running at Signature through March, was the last work by Foote before he died last year, and is based on the lives of his parents and relatives in Texas in the early 1900s; the intention is to transfer the full cast, including Bill Heck and Maggie Lacey, above. Daryl Roth, a lead member of the consortium planning the Broadway transfer, said that the producers wanted more time to lock in group ticket sales, scale the production from the 160-seat Signature space to a larger theater, and develop a marketing plan for “Orphans,” which is a three-part play that runs nine hours and lacks star actors.
A ship named for Bob Barker, the former “Price Is Right” host, had its first confrontation with whalers on Tuesday, The Associated Press reported.

Whether or not, as a timely movie title predicted, 2010 proves to be the year we make contact with intelligent alien life, it has already brought us something equally improbable: the promise of Hole’s first shows in 11 years. The Guardian reported that Hole, the vintage-1990s grunge-rock band led by Courtney Love, above, said on its Facebook page that it would play three European shows next month, starting with a performance on Feb. 17 at the Shepherds Bush Empire in London. The concert dates, including ones in Milan and Amsterdam, are also listed on nobodysdaughter.com, a Web site for “Nobody’s Daughter,” an album that was once planned as a solo project for Ms. Love but was rebranded as a Hole album last year. (It is still without a label or a release date.) The Guardian said that Hole’s lineup would include Ms. Love, the guitarist Micko Larkin, the bassist Shawn Dailey and the drummer Stu Fischer. It was unclear if Ms. Love’s former bandmates Eric Erlandson and Melissa Auf der Maur would be involved.

Viola Davis, below, recently seen suffering up a storm in the film adaptation of “Doubt” (a performance that earned her an Academy Award nomination, among other plaudits), will not be getting a reprieve any time soon. She will join the cast of the coming Broadway revival of “Fences,” by August Wilson, in which she will play the put-upon spouse of Denzel Washington, the show’s press representatives said on Tuesday. The revival of “Fences,” which won the Tony Award for best play and the Pulitzer Prize for drama in 1987, is to begin previews at the Cort Theater on April 14 and open on April 26. ... Press representatives for the Roundabout Theater Company’s coming production of Terrence McNally’s “Lips Together, Teeth Apart,” said that Lili Taylor (of “Six Feet Under” and “I Shot Andy Warhol”) had joined the cast, which also includes Patton Oswalt (“Big Fan”) and Megan Mullally (“Will and Grace”). The production, directed by Joe Mantello, begins previews at the American Airlines Theater on April 9 and opens April 29.

Two Chinese movies have been pulled from the Palm Springs International Film Festival in California to protest another film about the Dalai Lama and Tibet, Agence France-Presse reported. The Chinese movies “Nanjing! Nanjing!” (also known as “City of Life and Death”), about the Japanese occupation of Nanjing in 1937, and “Quick Quick Slow Slow,” a short film, were withdrawn, according to China’s state-run Beijing Times, because the festival plans to screen a movie called “The Sun Behind the Clouds: Tibet’s Struggle for Freedom.” That film, a documentary by Ritu Sarin and Tenzing Sonam, follows the Dalai Lama for a year, and its description in the festival’s program said that it chronicled “the 2008 protests in Tibet, the long march in India, the Beijing Olympics and the breakdown of talks with China.” The Beijing Times called the movie a “Tibetan independence” film. A representative for “Nanjing! Nanjing!” said that the films were pulled on the order of China’s ministry of foreign affairs, its film bureau and the consulate general of China in Los Angeles.

Symphony orchestra musicians, in public at least, rarely cast aspersions on other orchestras. But the principal flutist of the Chicago Symphony Orchestra had some less than complimentary things to say about the Los Angeles Philharmonic, according to a newspaper report. The flutist, Mathieu Dufour, had been on leave and was performing with the Philharmonic temporarily — a fairly common occurrence when first-chair players are considering a move. Mr. Dufour has decided to stay at his Midwestern job, The Chicago Sun-Times reported on Tuesday, quoting him as saying that the Los Angeles Philharmonic has “no tradition there — no tradition of sound and no tradition of working together as a dedicated ensemble.” He added, “Maybe they will have that someday in the future.” Los Angeles has fine musicians, he said. “But we have achieved a very strong common purpose and set of aims in Chicago that they do not have or do not yet have there.” Deborah F. Rutter, the Chicago orchestra’s president, called Mr. Dufour’s decision “great news.” A spokesman for the Philharmonic, Sophie Jefferies, said: “We’re very sorry to see him go and wish him all the best. He is an amazing player.”.

8 P.M. (TCM) TCM MEMORIAL TRIBUTE: JENNIFER JONES Turner Classic Movies devotes the evening to the work of Ms. Jones, who died on Dec. 17. Born Phyllis Isley in Tulsa, Okla., she became a Northwestern University sorority girl and married Robert Walker in 1939. The couple tried to find success as actors. Ms. Jones modeled and, in a final effort to achieve her dream, auditioned for David O. Selznick. A star was born when she won an Oscar for ''The Song of Bernadette'' (1943), her first role as the newly minted Jennifer Jones. So was a love affair -- with Selznick. This salute begins with ''Duel in the Sun'' (1946), starring Ms. Jones, above with Gregory Peck, in an Oscar-nominated role as Pearl Chavez, who comes between a rancher's good and evil sons. In ''Beat the Devil'' (1954), at 10:30, she joins Humphrey Bogart and Gina Lollobrigida in John Huston's spoof about a group of cons on their way to Africa to lay claim to uranium deposits in Kenya. In ''Madame Bovary'' (1949), at 12:15 a.m., she plays Flaubert's romantic country girl who sacrifices her marriage, and destroys lives, in her quest for true love. The evening ends at 2:15 with ''Indiscretion of an American Wife'' (1954), starring Montgomery Clift and Ms. Jones as a Philadelphia housewife who can't disentangle herself from her Italian lover. 9 A.M. (Fox Business Network) FOX BUSINESS Liz Claman and Shibani Joshi report live from the Consumer Electronics Show in Las Vegas on the latest trends in 3-D television, smart phones, e-readers and other nifty gadgets. The all-day coverage includes interviews with Alan R. Mulally, the chief executive of Ford Motor Company; Josh Silverman, the president of Skype; and Tom Rogers, the chief executive of TiVo.

SHAPIRO--Moses David, on December 7, 2009, in Leonia, New Jersey. Born January 3, 1919, David revealed early promise as a pianist, and as a student of Isabella Vengerova he won competitions and entered Columbia College in 1935 as a keyboard and musicology student. In 1941 he was drafted into the army from graduate school, where he had been studying conducting with Carl Bamberger, and left the service with the rank of captain. Returning to civilian life, he became assistant conductor with Thomas Scherman's Little Orchestra Society, and married Madelyn Vose, an opera singer, with whom he toured the United States in a production of Menotti's The Old Maid and the Thief. He co-founded the New York Percussion Trio, which released an album, Holidays for Percussion, in 1958. In the following three decades the Trio gave over three thousand performances in schools, theaters and on television, promoting percussion music and commissioning new works by emerging composers. In 1961, he received a Fulbright cultural exchange grant, which was twice renewed, to teach western music in Korea and to conduct the Korean Broadcasting System Symphony Orchestra. In 1964 he conducted the Hong Kong Philharmonic Orchestra and wrote an award-winning series of radio broadcasts on the history of western music. After several years as a musical director with the San Francisco Opera, he returned to the Far East where he conducted several operas, including the premier of James Wade's The Martyred, in Korea. In 1973 he turned to the keyboard, and over the next thirty years, he participated in hundreds of performances with several chamber music groups, mastering a significant repertory of ensemble music. During this period he was also a voice coach and recital accompanist, a piano teacher, an instructor at the Mannes School of Music, and a member of many civic and cultural organizations, including the Bergen County Museum of Art and Science where he gave numerous performances. A person of wide intellectual interests and a deep devotion to the arts, he encouraged the efforts of performers and composers, in many domains and of diverse talents, to participate in the creative enterprise. These qualities, along with an exceptional degree of personal integrity and a gentle nature, earned the respect of his fellow artists and his family's admiration. He is survived by his brother Samuel, his sons Peter and Joseph, a granddaughter Lani Anna, his nephews Jon and Raphael, his nieces Susan and Anne, his cousin Michael, Amy Lee, and many other family members and friends who mourn his passing. A daughter, Caralyn Anne, predeceased him.

DeShawn Stevenson, one of numerous Washington Wizards who laughed at Gilbert Arenas when he cocked his fingers into a gun and playfully shot them as they stood in a circle before a game against the 76ers on Tuesday night, said that neither he nor his teammates should have reacted the way they did. ''But it's a situation where Gilbert always plays around,'' Stevenson said Wednesday after the Wizards fell to the Cavaliers, 121-98. ''I know him as always joking. At the time our team probably was laughing, but it's not a laughing matter.''

SMITH--Robert H. On behalf of George Washington enthusiasts everywhere, the Mount Vernon Ladies' Association expresses its heartfelt sympathy to the Smith family, and mourns the death of a true friend of American history, whose many achievements at George Washington's home will forever reflect his generosity, his vision and his patriotism. Time and time again, Bob Smith stepped forward to make a lasting impact on Washington's home, leaving a remarkable legacy of projects and programs. His passion for and unwavering support of our mission helped change the way Americans remember George Washington - and for that we are eternally grateful. The Regent, Vice Regents and Staff The Mount Vernon Ladies' Association

WEBBER--William Sr. We are deeply saddened by the loss of our ingenious and charismatic Chairman, William P. Webber, Sr. August 29, 1939 - January 5, 2010. Bill, we will miss your spirited leadership and will always strive to achieve your high standard for excellence. The staff and team, and your friends, at Landair with much love, and deep affection for you and your family: Bonnie, Karla, William Jr., Sean, Maura, Andrea, Carlos, and your beautiful grandchildren, Kyra, William, CC, Francesca, Aidan, Hamilton, Gray, and Sands.

HERMANSON--Lydia Stevens. With great sadness we report the death of Lydia Hermanson on January 4, 2010 at the age of 93. She was a mother, grandmother and great-grandmother beyond compare. Words cannot adequately describe her love and contributions to our family's well-being, but we will fondly cherish our memories of Didi. She was a talented cook, and her brisket was exceptional. She never appeared as a weekend guest without smoked salmon and a box of schnecken under her arm. An accomplished bridge player, she was known to bet sums upward of one dollar a hand in games with her many longtime friends. She was a sharp and tactful businesswoman who built the family business, Mr. Christmas, alongside her husband of more than 50 years, Merril. She cared for Merril devotedly until his death in 2000. We will never forget her kindness, giddy humor, stubborn optimism, generosity, and selflessness. Lydia is survived by her daughter and son-in-law, Linda and Robert Eder, her son Terry Hermanson, her daughter-in-law Susie Hermanson, her five granddaughters, Elizabeth Thede, Randy Steinman, Sarah Meister, Leslie Hermanson and Merril Hermanson, and her six great-grandchildren, Victoria Thede, Kate, Jill and Ally Steinman and Madeline and Lee Meister. In lieu of sending flowers, please consider making a donation in Lydia's name to the ADL, P.O. Box 96226, Washington, DC 20090-6226.
