AT Spin New York, a table tennis and social club on East 23rd Street near Park Avenue South, the clientele is as studiedly understated as the sprawling gray and green interior. On Monday night, after-work drop-ins, wearing tweed caps, high-tops and moth-eaten grandpa cardigans, contributed to an atmosphere as quaintly low-key as the sport itself. ''This place feels kind of old school to me,'' said Dan Shaked (far right, with paddle), ''like you're back to being a kid.'' A kid in an Andy Hardy movie, maybe, or something of a more recent vintage. ''I feel like Bill Cosby-meets-Freddy Krueger,'' said Selma (below), a staff member who goes by her first name only, as she showed off the striped sweater she picked up for a song at the Salvation Army. Dressed in plaid and a visored cap, Susan Sarandon, Spin's most prominent investor, looked like nothing so much as a newsboy. But it seems Ms. Sarandon has loftier ambitions. Surveying the hall, she remarked with a smile, ''This place will give me something to do in my old age.''

The first time I met Randy Johnson, I was 14 years old and he was playing for the Montreal Expos. I had a field pass for a game at Veterans Stadium in Philadelphia in April 1989. I asked him to autograph his baseball card, and he said he'd be right back. He never returned. Nine years later, I interviewed for a job as the Mariners beat writer at The Seattle Post-Intelligencer. The Mariners' clubhouse, at the time, seemed toxic. A promising team was crumbling quickly. The bullpen was terrible, the Kingdome was cramped, the personalities were rough. And Johnson was on his way out of town in a messy split from the Mariners.

WEINTRAUB--Allan. Born September 10, 1921, passed away January 5, 2010. He served in WWII as Lieutenant Jr. Grade US Navy Reserve Pilot in Squadron VC-85, Air Craft Carrier USS Lunga Point and participated in the pre-landings, landings and battles on Lingayen Gulf, Iwo Jima and Okinawa (7th Fleet). He earned the Distinguished Flying Cross, the Air Medal and three Stars in lieu of the second, third and fourth Air Medal. He is predeceased by his Parents David and Sydell Weintraub, his Sister Rosalie (Weintraub) Stone and Brothers Robert Weintraub and Stanley Weintraub. He is survived by his loving Nieces and Nephews; Debbie (Weintraub) and Ron Linder, Dan and Jan Weintraub, Penny Weintraub, June Weintraub, Robin Weintraub-LaBorwit, Scott and Nancy Weintraub, Jody (Weintraub) and Alan Perry, Donna (Stone) and Howard Gressman, Karen Weintraub. He is also survived by his great nieces and nephews Joshua, Matthew, Max, Jeremy, Mariah, Seth, Michael, Rachel, Trebor, Jennifer and Rebecca and his loving Sister-In-Law Barbara Weintraub. A Memorial Service will be held on Sunday January 7, 2010, 12pm at Beechers Funeral Home, 418 Bedford Rd, Pleasantville, NY 10570. 914-769-0001.

DAVIS--Betty, 84, wife of the late Lawrence S. Davis, died on December 31, 2009. Loving mother of Scott Davis, Vicki Gradinger and son-in-law Jeffrey. She lived in Manhattan and her love of the city was surpassed only by her love for her family. Her relationships with her four grandchildren Harlan, Alex, Carolyn and Brian along with the rest of her family were Betty's proudest possessions. She and Lawrence traveled the world together. Betty's charm, warmth and sophistication will be missed by all who loved her.

Bill Moggridge, a founder of the design firm IDEO who is widely credited with designing the look of the first commercial laptop, has been named director of the Smithsonian Institution's Cooper-Hewitt, National Design Museum in New York. Mr. Moggridge, who is to start in March, will be the first design practitioner to run the Cooper-Hewitt, bringing decades of experience as a businessman and industrial designer but none as a museum administrator. He replaces Paul W. Thompson, who left in July after eight years to become the rector, or president, of the Royal College of Art in London. (Caroline Baumann, the museum's deputy director, has been acting director.)

NOLAND--Kenneth. We deeply mourn the loss of Ken Noland a giant in 20th century art. The strength and beauty of his paintings will live on. Our deepest sympathy to his loving wife, Paige Rense, and his family. Leslie Feely

MEADOWS-ROGERS--The Rev. Arabella, a pioneering clergywoman in the Presbyterian Church, USA, died of pancreatic cancer at 60 on December 17, 2009, in New York City. Ordained in 1975, she served churches in New York City, West Delhi, NY, Durham, NC, and Grandin and Hunter, ND. In 1997 she became the first woman Executive Presbyter in the Presbytery of the Northern Plains, and subsequently, from 2003 until shortly before her death, she served as the first woman Executive Presbyter of the Presbytery of New York City. Born in Frankfurt, Germany, on July 15, 1949, the daughter of a U.S. State Department diplomat, the Rev. Meadows-Rogers grew up in Hungary, Argentina, Ecuador, and Pakistan, as well as Bethesda, Maryland. She received a B.A. degree from Duke University (1971) and an M. Div. from Union Theological Seminary in New York City (1974). She is survived by her husband of thirty-seven years, Dr. Robert Meadows-Rogers, an adjunct faculty member in art history at Fordham University; by their son, Matthew Meadows-Rogers; by their daughter Sarah Diaz and son-in-law, Roberto, and two grandchildren, Estrella and Juan Diego, of Fargo, North Dakota; by her father, Jordan Thomas Rogers of Mechanicsburg, Pennsylvania: by her three sisters: Elinor Rogers, Louisa Rogers, and Jane McIver; and by two nieces (Corinne and Louisa McIver), one nephew (Thomas McIver), three stepsisters and three stepbrothers. A Memorial Service of Witness to the Resurrection will be held at Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church, 73rd Street and Madison Avenue, New York, NY, on Saturday, January 9, 2010, at 1:00pm. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be sent in Arabella's name to Presbyterian Disaster Assistance, 100 Witherspoon Street, Louisville, Kentucky 40202-1396.

The special election for the seat will take place on Jan. 19.

HOLLIDAY--Pennie, 69, passed away on January 5, 2010 after a valiant six year fight with lung cancer. Loving companion of Herb, dear daughter of Florence, loving mother of Deena and Marc and their spouses, Stephen and Sheree, sister of Richard and Stephanie and survived by her adoring grandchildren, Andrew, Lauren, Max, Michelle, Danielle and Sam, and nephews Garett and Darren. Your strength and devotion will always serve to guide us and we will miss you greatly. Funeral services will be attended by family members. THE renovation problem that faced Nili Malach and Robert Poynter of San Francisco is not uncommon among those in an architecturally mixed marriage. Ms. Malach, a lawyer, is a modernist; her husband, who owns an advertising firm, is a traditionalist. The selling point for them, when they bought their three-bedroom, three-story house near the Castro district last year, was the view of the rolling hills and San Francisco Bay. They agreed that the first-floor kitchen, dining room and living room should be opened into one space. Their problem was how to blend their tastes, avoiding what Mr. Poynter considered the coldness of modern homes of steel and glass while still achieving the clean, open feeling of a modern design.

Baccoli, beloved grandmother of Jane Vogel Brickell and her husband Richard, Wendy Vogel and Allyn Vogel, adored great-grandmother of three. Please call "Bernheim-Apter-Kreitzman" at 1-800-938-6372 for information.

Some quarrels never seem to fade away, and the anti-Communist battles of the 1940s and 1950s are being fought long after most of the original antagonists are dead. Not only do the arguments over Alger Hiss and the Rosenbergs live on, but the question of whether Elia Kazan and Budd Schulberg made the classic 1954 film ''On the Waterfront'' to justify their naming names of former Communist associates seems to have found an especially robust and curious afterlife, with the deaths in recent years of Mr. Kazan, the film's director, Mr. Schulberg, its scriptwriter, and two actors, Marlon Brando and Karl Malden.

MURBACH--David. We mourn the loss of a dear friend. A member of the Garden Committee, David played an important role in planning and providing for the LongHouse gardens. He will be greatly missed. Jack Lenor Larsen and the Board of Trustees, Garden Committee, and staff of LongHouse Reserve.

A Cuban official said Wednesday that an American contractor detained last month in Havana for distributing communications equipment to community groups worked for ''the American secret services.'' The official, Ricardo Alarcón, president of the Cuban National Assembly, offered no evidence for his claim, which was disputed by Development Alternatives Inc., a company based outside Washington. It said it employed the American for a pro-democracy contract provided by the United States Agency for International Development.

ADAMS--William Healey, 63 years young, passed away on January 3, 2010, after a two and half year battle with ALS (Lou Gehrig's disease). In an email to his daughter on New Year's Day, he said he would "keep fighting." Surrounding his bedside were his wife of 38 years, Ellen (Dale), his two children, Brooke and Beau. Bill Adams was born in Charlotte, North Carolina on November 16, 1946, the son of Mary Frances (Healey) and Thaddeus Adams. He was predeceased by his parents and his two brothers, Thaddeus and Douglas. Bill Adams grew up in Charlotte, was a star athlete in high school and was recruited to play basketball at the University of North Carolina (Chapel Hill) by the legendary coach, Dean Smith. Upon achieving distinction as a freshman, Bill was excused from basketball by Dean Smith when the coach discovered that Bill had lost a kidney playing football in high school. Coach Smith remained a mentor and close friend throughout Bill's life. After graduating from UNC in 1969, Bill moved to New York where he joined the Bank of New York. In 1976 Bill Adams and Ellen moved to San Francisco, where he helped to open the corporate branch of the Chemical Bank. The Adams family, now including Brooke and Beau, moved back to New York in 1981. However, their experience of living in San Francisco was to draw them back in 1984. Prior to his current position as a managing director of Chilton Investment Company, he was the CFO of the Bank of San Francisco and managing director at Bankers Trust for its Pacific Rim private banking. Bill's athleticism was aptly demonstrated on the golf course. He loved the competition and the camaraderie inherent in golf. He was a member of the San Francisco Golf Club, the Cypress Point Club, the Burlingame Country Club and the US Seniors Golf Association. In addition, he enjoyed his friendships at the Pacific Union Club and in New York at the Brook and the Racquet & Tennis Club (where he was an accomplished squash player). While at UNC, Bill Adams was a member of Delta Kappa Epsilon fraternity and the Lodge. Despite being afflicted with ALS, Bill Adams established and was central to the William H. Adams Foundation for ALS Research, which actively supports ongoing research in the effort to find a cure for ALS. Since its formation in 2008, the Foundation has contributed over $1 million to fund cutting edge research under the sponsorship of Dr. Jeffrey Rothstein at the Packard Center at Johns Hopkins. One of Bill's most cherished moments was the August 31st, 2009 ALS fundraiser organized by the Adams Foundation and hosted by golf legend, Tom Watson. Bill Adams was devoted to his family, and their time together, both at home and traveling, was most important to him. He is survived by his wife Ellen, his two children, his daughter's husband, Zach Read, and two grandchildren, Isabelle and William ("Briggs") Read. There will be a memorial service at 3pm on Thursday, the 14th of January at St. Ignatius Church in San Francisco. In lieu of flowers, donations in Bill's memory can be made to the William H. Adams Foundation for ALS Research, Deutsche Bank Alex Brown, 101 California Street, 46th Floor, San Francisco, California 94111, attention: Lisa Walsh.
No longer are we going to run New York like a payday loan operation. GOV. DAVID A. PATERSON, in his State of the State address. [A29]

London was buffeted Wednesday by the heaviest snowfall in more than 20 years. Snow as deep as 18 inches, along with ice, shut down railroad services, airports and schools across southern England and nearly halted travel on major highways. The unusually frigid weather that has gripped Britain and Ireland since late December was expected to persist for at least another week. Two of London's three airports, Gatwick and Luton, were shut down entirely, and delays were reported at the largest, Heathrow. Economists estimated that the toll in lost productivity could exceed $1.6 billion.

A suicide car bomber killed six police officers in the capital of the Russian region of Dagestan on Wednesday. It was the deadliest such attack in months in a region where assassinations of police officers are a defining characteristic of the local militant Islamist movement. The bombing came five days after the police said they had killed a local militant leader.

RIDING a bicycle with headphones occupying both ears is not just dangerous, but also illegal in New York and many other states. And while it's O.K. to ride with just one ear plugged in, that's not always very pleasant. Gadget makers have devised a solution: compact speakers for MP3 players that are meant to be attached to a bicycle, either on the handlebars or elsewhere. The rider selects the songs, attaches the music player to the speakers, then listens and rides with ears wide open.

Peter R. Orszag, President Obama's budget director who recently announced his engagement, on Wednesday released a statement confirming that his previous girlfriend had a baby in November. The statement, which Mr. Orszag issued jointly with the woman, Claire Milonas, a shipping heiress from New York, said: ''We were in a committed relationship until the spring of 2009. In November, Claire gave birth to a beautiful baby girl. Although we are no longer together, we are both thrilled that she is happy and healthy, and we would hope that everyone will respect her privacy.''

People say a lot of things about Sean Avery, but no one can say he lacks a sense of the moment. He scored the first -- only his fifth goal of the season, ending a 19-game drought -- and assisted on the next three.

Updated | 6:36 p.m. "Precious: Based on the Novel 'Push' by Sapphire" was the big winner at the African American Film Critics Association in December, picking up awards for best picture, best director, best screenplay and best supporting actress, for Mo'Nique. But the film's star, Gabourey Sidibe, was snubbed as best actress in favor of Nicole Beharie from the lesser-known "American Violet." Following the vote, Roger Friedman of The Hollywood Reporter's Showbiz 411 blog reported that the tally had been manipulated by the group's president, Gil Robertson IV, to engineer a win for Ms. Beharie. In return, Mr. Friedman suggested that Mr. Robertson was to receive payments from producers affiliated with "American Violet," and wrote that the whole issue had sparked serious infighting among the group.

Richard Lindzen, the meteorology professor at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology best known for his longstanding rejection of research pointing to dangerous climate disruption from human-generated greenhouse gases, has been bluntly challenged over a popular paper in Geophysical Research Letters last year that he co-wrote with post-doctoral researcher Yong-Sang Choi. The paper, assessing tropical sea surface temperatures in relation to flows of energy into and out of the atmosphere, asserted that the climate system was far less sensitive to human actions than the predominant view had it.

Now that the House and Senate are trying to reconcile their separate health care bills, it seems worthwhile to compare the two bills on the elements most important to small businesses. There are crucial differences between the two. In general, small companies - or at least the most self-interested among them - are likely to prefer the Senate bill, which is more lenient on employers and insurers alike. Employees and those most concerned about the integrity of the reforms - whether they'll actually do what they're supposed to do - are likely to gravitate toward the House version.

Happy 75th birthday to Elvis Presley, who made it so gloriously tough for all the rock and pop stars in his wake to escape some precedent he had set. Sex appeal and grotesquerie. Ambition and inertia. Aggression and acquiescence. Class warfare and decadence. Innovation and schlock. Even an overbearing manager whose decisions were not always in his best interest.

One of the (stated) reasons that the Academy moved to 10 best picture nominees this year is to include more populist fare. (The unstated reasons, as Michael Cieply explores in a piece in this weekend's special Oscar section, have more to do with boosting the telecast's sagging TV ratings.) Movies like "Star Trek," which made both box-office-watchers and critics happy, would seem tailor-made for the 10. And "Star Trek" did get one of the 10 slots on the Producers Guild of America ballots, alongside another sci-fi favorite, "District 9." But, with a few exceptions, like "The Lord of the Rings: The Fellowship of the Ring," the Academy has historically shown little love to films that explore the futuristic great beyond, the could-have-been past or the alternate-reality present. It's not quite as strong as those fogies' anti-comedy bias, but it's there.

Perfectly apropos of the frigid winter that seems to have settled over the United States and parts of Europe, "Frozen in Time," by Studio Wieki Somers, opens Jan. 30 at Galerie Kreo in Paris. For this exhibition - which was inspired by a major ice storm in the Netherlands in 1987 - Somers, a Dutch designer, and Dylan van den Berg, her collaborator in the studio, took everyday objects - a stool, an architect's lamp, a vase - and covered them in UV Topcoat, a liquid resin that hardens, or "freezes," when exposed to sunlight, making the objects appear to be covered with a thick glaze of ice. For Somers, the subject was irresistible. "The half-transparent ice connected things in a matter-of-fact and extremely poetic way," she explained in the news release for the exhibition. It also added another layer of meaning to familiar objects - an idea that permeates Somers's work, like the Bathboat, a bathtub with the exterior of a rowboat, or the High Tea Pot, which is cast in porcelain from a pig's skull. "Frozen in Time" runs until March 20.

Maggie Gyllenhaal is not just a lauded actress and an enthusiastic Brooklynite, she is also something of an expert on how indie movies get sold and marketed, as the Bagger discovered over a recent lunch (at a family-run restaurant in Brooklyn, of course). In Ms. Gyllenhaal's latest, "Crazy Heart," the directorial debut of Scott Cooper, an actor, she plays the love interest of Jeff Bridges's alcoholic country singer; it also stars Robert Duvall as his old friend and features music by T-Bone Burnett. Yet it very nearly fell to the straight-to-DVD ranks before being scooped up and thrust into the Oscar race late in the year. Now Mr. Bridges is being touted as the best actor front-runner, and, in the year of the 10, the film itself is a dark horse for best picture. (But don't expect the movie's good fortune to be reflected in the fortunes of its couple. "Jeff always makes this joke," Ms. Gyllenhaal said, "like, oh they're going to get together in the sequel, and it's going to be called 'Crazy Liver.' ") Here is Part 2 of our conversation; Part 1, now updated with more answers, is here.

Wigs will never be the same after Charlie Le Mindu. Le Mindu, a 23-year-old designer known not just for his towering wigs but also for making clothes and accessories out of human hair, has set off a craze for avant-garde hair confections in London and around the world. Recently, Lady Gaga has been turning up in Le Mindu wigs. A native of Bordeaux, France, Le Mindu also has the distinction of being the only designer at London fashion week - or any fashion week, for that matter - to put on a show focused entirely on wigs. The Moment dropped by Le Mindu's East London loft for a chat over tea.

The first volume of Marvel's "Dark Avengers" series, written by Brian Michael Bendis and illustrated by Mike Deodato, enters our paperback list at No. 6 this week. This new team emerged from "Secret Invasion," an event mini-series that pitted Marvel's heroes against a race of alien of shapeshifters up to no good. The final blow to the alien threat was delivered by Norman Osborn, the former Green Goblin, who became admired through out the world. Alas, his bad behavior was not behind him. He assembled a team of Avengers who looked familiar - Wolverine! Spider-Man! Ms. Marvel! - but are actually super-villains. This collection, "Assemble," chronicles their story.

In Tuscany, a small chocolatier rolls out pieces of dark chocolate by hand onto slabs of marble to protect its rich aroma from heat, then molds them into half-moon-shaped cookies and bakes them in a wood-fired oven. The chocolate cantucci -- a sinful take on the traditional almond biscotti -- are available in central Rome, where they can be sampled, along with other regional specialties, at Paciotti Salumeria (Via Marcantonio Bragadin, 51/53; www.paciottisalumeria.it; 39-06-3973-3646), a delicatessen near the Vatican. The cantucci, which are specially baked for the Paciotti family, have some claim to being the most delicious chocolate biscuits in Rome.

Last year was miserable for private equity fund-raising in the United States. Special Visa Benefits Abused Immigrants | Victims of domestic violence are often deeply reluctant to press charges, fearing retaliation or simply hoping their abusers will change. Information, not censorship, is the best way to confront a perceived public-health threat from the big screen.

NEW YORK.

An appraisal on Dec. 31 about David Levine, the caricaturist for The New York Review of Books who died on Dec. 29, may have left the incorrect impression that the Russian writer Aleksandr Pushkin, the subject of one of Mr. Levine’s drawings, was homosexual. The description of Pushkin as “a gay man” was a reference to his demeanor, not his sexual orientation.
Gus Granneman, the Jets’ head equipment manager, has packed a truck full of cold weather gear for Saturday’s playoff game.
The swine flu vaccine is now plentiful across the country, and most states are encouraging people of all ages to get shots to prevent another wave of illness and deaths.

A dance review on Thursday about Pacific Northwest Ballet, at the Joyce Theater, misidentified the work described as “too conscious of its effectiveness, too short of inner life” while at the same time “its skill of construction, all sharply timed to the Reich score, is something rare today.” That work is “3 Movements” by Benjamin Millepied — not “Opus 111” by Twyla Tharp, another work on the program.

The Sports of The Times column on Wednesday, about the 1965 Orange Bowl game, between Alabama and Texas, the same teams that played in the Bowl Championship Series title game on Thursday night, misstated the given name of a tackle who helped stop Alabama’s Joe Namath at the goal line on the game’s pivotal play. He is Diron Talbert, who played at Texas from 1964 to 1966 — not Don, his brother, who played there from 1959 to 1961. The error was repeated on Thursday in a Sports of The Times column about Namath’s memories of the game.
The Delaware pediatrician who prosecutors say may have molested more than 100 patients showed a pattern of inappropriate touching, according to court documents.

A Sports of The Times column on Thursday, about Nick Saban’s place in history alongside Alabama’s past football coaches, misstated, in some editions, the circumstances under which Coach Gene Stallings left the program after the 1996 season. He resigned; he was not fired.

An article on Monday about SeeClickFix.com, a Web site that lets residents communicate with local government officials, misstated its use in The Local blogs at NYTimes.com. Only the blogs that cover communities in New Jersey use SeeClickFix; The Local blogs in Brooklyn do not use it.
David Tyree, who helped the Giants win a Super Bowl, has carved a niche for himself on the Baltimore Ravens by excelling on special teams.

The Advertising column on Thursday, about Consumer Reports’ review of 15 infomercial products, erroneously attributed a distinction to the PedEgg, a foot callous remover that the magazine recommended. PedEgg was one of two items recommended — not “the only item that passed muster.” (The Magic Jack, a phone device using voice over Internet protocol, was the other.).

An article on Dec. 2 about Shaya Boymelgreen, a star of the New York real estate boom who has fallen on hard times, misstated part of the address of one of his apartment projects, in Brooklyn’s Dumbo neighborhood. It is at 42 Main Street, not 402. A reader pointed out the error in an e-mail message this week.
President Obama will renominate Dawn Johnsen to lead the Justice Department’s powerful Office of Legal Counsel, along with his choices for five other jobs.

The Experience Necessary feature in some editions on Tuesday, about the master printer at Bowne & Company Stationers at the South Street Seaport Museum, misstated his surname in a passage in which he pointed out that his name is an anagram for Barrow Renter, and that he rents an apartment on Barrow Street. As the introduction to the article noted, he is Robert Warner, not Warren.

An article on Wednesday about a possible bid by Harold Ford Jr., a former congressman from Tennessee, for the Senate seat held by Kirsten E. Gillibrand misstated, in some editions, the amount of money Ms. Gillibrand had raised as of Oct. 1, the amount Mr. Ford raised during his run for a Senate seat in Tennessee in 2006, and the percentage of Mr. Ford’s total that came from New York. Ms. Gillibrand had raised $5.5 million as of Oct. 1, not $4 million; Mr. Ford raised $15 million in 2006, not $20 million; and a fifth, not a quarter, of that total came from New York. The article also referred incorrectly to the election of Hillary Rodham Clinton, who held the Senate seat before Ms. Gillibrand. Mrs. Clinton was elected 10 months after she moved to New York, not two years, and she moved to New York from Washington, not from Arkansas.
Ms. Jones was a prominent consumer advocate who worked to ensure that goods — from clothing to cereal to cigarettes — were safer, less expensive and more truthfully advertised.

Ben Silverman’s studio, Electus, is expected to announce its first distributor, Yahoo, for shows made in concert with advertisers.
With a late barrage of 3-pointers Thursday night the Knicks overcame the Charlotte Bobcats. With the victory they improved to 15-20 and moved in ninth place in their conference.
While President Obama did not create the intelligence system, he has now gotten a bitter lesson in its weaknesses despite the mea culpas and pledges of reform.

A recent incident involving Getty Images and the N.B.A. highlights how ports leagues have moved deeper into the information media business, but sometimes have their own self-interests in mind.

It may come as a surprise, but P.B.R. doesn’t just stand for a brand of beer beloved by hipsters; it’s also the initials of the Professional Bull Riders. Fans of either, or both, should head this weekend to the 2010 bull-riding invitational at Madison Square Garden. Converging on the Garden floor Friday through Sunday: 700 tons of dirt, the top 45 bull riders in the country and 2,000-pound bulls. Grab your cowboy hat and boots; ironic stance is optional. Tickets start at $10.

Would the Dude be the Dude if not for Jeff Bridges? It’s a question academics in the burgeoning field of Lebowski studies should ponder and one you can pose to Mr. Bridges himself this Saturday at the Film Society of Lincoln Center. Mr. Bridges, whose performance in “Crazy Heart” is being touted this year for an Oscar, will be on hand to discuss his long career, including his portrayal of the Dude in “The Big Lebowski” (1998) and his breakout in “The Last Picture Show.” That 1971 Peter Bogdanovich movie will be screened following the discussion.

Winter Jazzfest, Nate Chinen writes, “is for the moment the only real mainstream jazz festival in New York, and its lineup amounts to a temperature reading of the scene at ground level, where it’s most vibrant and volatile.” At five Greenwich Village clubs this weekend you can hear how “the aesthetic center of the music has broadened and loosened, yielding to many different strategies of rhythm, harmony and texture.” Check out the new wave of hybrid acts like Vijay Iyer, who will appear with his trio and whose “Historicity” “was the consensus pick among critics for best jazz album of 2009” as well as Darcy James Argue’s Secret Society, “an ultramodern big band,” the violinist Jenny Scheinman, the Claudia Quintet and more.
Adis Medunjanin, 25, came under intense scrutiny last year after traveling to Pakistan in 2008 with Najibullah Zazi, a Denver shuttle bus driver charged in a Qaeda bomb plot.

Israel launched several airstrikes on the Gaza Strip on Thursday, killing at least one Palestinian and wounding another, medical workers and the Islamist group Hamas said.

Susan Boyle prevailed in the final week of music sales for 2009, holding at No. 1 on the Billboard album chart for a sixth week. Her “I Dreamed a Dream” (Syco Music/Columbia) sold 137,000 copies, according to Nielsen SoundScan. Its total year sales of 3.1 million gave Taylor Swift’s “Fearless” (Big Machine) a run for its money as the best-selling album of the year; “Fearless” holds at No. 5 on the latest weekly chart with 60,000 sales, bringing its total for the year to 3.2 million. With no major new releases, Lady Gaga’s “The Fame” (Interscope) sold 82,000 last week to reach No. 2, Alicia Keys’s “Element of Freedom” (J) is third with 80,000, and Mary J. Blige’s “Stronger” (Geffen) is No. 4 with 62,000. Justin Bieber’s “My World” (Island) is No. 6 with 52,000 sales and the soundtrack to “Alvin & the Chipmunks: The Squeakquel” (Rhino) is No. 7 with 51,000.

The Tony Award-winning actor Norbert Leo Butz (below, in “Dirty Rotten Scoundrels”) has been cast in the role of Jeffrey Skilling, the disgraced former president of Enron Corporation, in the coming Broadway production of Lucy Prebble’s play “Enron.” Mr. Butz was last seen on Broadway as Bobby Gould in the 2008-9 revival of David Mamet’s “Speed-the-Plow.” “Enron,” which has been running to acclaim in London, was inspired by the financial collapse of the energy company whose name has become synonymous with corporate fraud. Many of the characters — like Mr. Skilling and Kenneth Lay — are based on former employees of Enron. (Mr. Lay was its chairman.) Directed by Rupert Goold, “Enron” is scheduled to begin previews at the Broadhurst Theater April 8 and open April 27.

The Palm Springs International Film Festival confirmed that two Chinese movies had been pulled from its lineup and would be replaced. The films, “City of Life and Death” (also called “Nanjing! Nanjing!”) and “Quick, Quick, Slow,” were withdrawn from the festival by China’s foreign affairs ministry and its film bureau in protest of another film, “The Sun Behind the Clouds: Tibet’s Struggle for Freedom.” That film, a documentary, chronicles a year in the life of the Dalai Lama, the exiled Tibetan leader. In a statement Darryl Macdonald, the director of the festival, said the films were withdrawn when the festival did not comply with a request from the Chinese to cancel screenings of “The Sun Behind the Clouds.” He added: “We cannot allow the concerns of one country or community to dictate what films we should or should not play, based on their own cultural or political perspective.” The festival said “City of Life and Death,” with Liu Ye, above, in a scene from the film, would be replaced with screenings of “For a Moment, Freedom,” an Austrian and French film about Middle Eastern refugees seeking European visas; and “Sticky Fingers,” a Canadian, French and Spanish comedy about inept gangsters. A replacement for “Quick, Quick, Slow” has not yet been announced.

The justice ministry of Switzerland said Thursday that it may decide soon whether to grant a request by the United States to extradite Roman Polanski, Agence France-Presse reported. The ministry’s spokesman, Folco Galli, told Agence France-Presse: “We are preparing our decision. It could be January, it could also be in February. I am not going to be more precise.” Mr. Polanski, who fled the United States in 1978 after pleading guilty to having sex with a 13-year-old girl, was apprehended in Switzerland in September. He spent several months in a jail near Zurich before posting $4.5 million bail in December and is now under house arrest in his chalet in Gstaad. On Wednesday a written request from Mr. Polanski to be sentenced in absentia was presented to a Los Angeles County Superior Court judge. The judge, Peter P. Espinoza, has scheduled a hearing on Jan. 22 to consider it.
“The People’s Choice Awards,” with Queen Latifah as host, attracted its largest audience in three years on Wednesday as 10.7 million viewers tuned in.

Talks between the players and management of the Cleveland Orchestra broke down on Wednesday, and the musicians threatened to go on strike on Jan. 18. That is the day before the orchestra is to leave for a residency in Miami. “That tour is in question,” Jeffrey Rathbun, the orchestra’s assistant principal oboist and the musicians’ chief negotiator, said in a statement. The players’ contract expired at the end of August, but they have agreed to continue rehearsing and performing. Management, citing salary cuts among staff members and the music director, Franz Welser-Möst, above, offered a three-year contract calling for a 5 percent cut in the first year, a restoration of that amount in the second and a 2.5 percent increase in the third. “We need the union to recognize the shared sacrifice throughout the institution and respond in kind,” Gary Hanson, the orchestra’s executive director, said in a statement. The players offered a salary freeze for this year. A spokesman for the players, Howard C. Landau, said they had made concessions in the past, “which is why we keep slipping in the rankings” in relation to salaries at other orchestras. “We just can’t keep slipping any further,” he added. “There’s no way we can stay competitive. Our musicians are going to leave for greener pastures.”.

FITNESS WALK IN FORT TRYON PARK Must another new year mean another resolution to hit the gym more often? For many of us, the fitness promise is as predictable as a New Year's Day hangover. Will it last more than a few weeks? Perhaps. But for those who quickly succumb to boredom on the treadmill, how about a new approach, a two-pronged resolution for 2010: Stay fit and see more of the city you call home by getting up and getting out in Fort Tryon Park, where Nancy Bruning leads a year-round fitness walk.

HARTMAN--Helene, affectionately known to friends and family as Chickie, lost her courageous battle with cancer on Sunday, December 27, 2009. She died peacefully at her home surrounded by her family. A graduate of Woodmere Academy and Bennington College, she also received an MA in Education. She is survived by her loving husband and partner of over 53 years Bill Hartman, her adoring children Peter Hartman, Valerie Hartman Levy, Jeannine Bartow Hartman and Jeff Levy, her four grandchildren, Haley Hartman, Charlie, Eli and Cate Levy and her brother, Robert Friedman. A memorial service and celebration of her life will be held at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue on Sunday, January 10th at 1:30pm. In lieu of flowers, the family has requested that donations be made in Chickie's name to The American Cancer Society or Calvery Hospital Hospice.

MEADOWS-ROGERS--The Rev. Arabella, a pioneering clergywoman in the Presbyterian Church, USA, died of pancreatic cancer at 60 on December 17, 2009, in New York City. Ordained in 1975, she served churches in New York City, West Delhi, NY, Durham, NC, and Grandin and Hunter, ND. In 1997 she became the first woman Executive Presbyter in the Presbytery of the Northern Plains, and subsequently, from 2003 until shortly before her death, she served as the first woman Executive Presbyter of the Presbytery of New York City. Born in Frankfurt, Germany, on July 15, 1949, the daughter of a U.S. State Department diplomat, the Rev. Meadows-Rogers grew up in Hungary, Argentina, Ecuador, and Pakistan, as well as Bethesda, Maryland. She received a B.A. degree from Duke University (1971) and an M. Div. from Union Theological Seminary in New York City (1974). She is survived by her husband of thirty-seven years, Dr. Robert Meadows-Rogers, an adjunct faculty member in art history at Fordham University; by their son, Matthew Meadows-Rogers; by their daughter Sarah Diaz and son-in-law, Roberto, and two grandchildren, Estrella and Juan Diego, of Fargo, North Dakota; by her father, Jordan Thomas Rogers of Mechanicsburg, Pennsylvania: by her three sisters: Elinor Rogers, Louisa Rogers, and Jane McIver; and by two nieces (Corinne and Louisa McIver), one nephew (Thomas McIver), three stepsisters and three stepbrothers. A Memorial Service of Witness to the Resurrection will be held at Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church, 73rd Street and Madison Avenue, New York, NY, on Saturday, January 9, 2010, at 1:00pm. In a late addition to President Obama's schedule, he welcomed Bill Clinton to the Oval Office on Thursday afternoon. The appointment, aides said, was simply an opportunity for the two men to check in with each other. It had been several months since the two presidents had gotten together.

''The Simpsons'' has been on the air longer than ''Gunsmoke,'' but that's not a reason to watch the show's 20th-anniversary special on Fox this Sunday night. Tributes to even the best shows can smother them in pomposity. ''The Simpsons 20th Anniversary Special: In 3-D! On Ice!'' is worth a look because -- as the self-mocking title suggests -- it doesn't make too big a deal of one of the most innovative, influential and irresistibly irreverent shows in the history of television. The event opens with a new episode, ''Once Upon a Time in Springfield,'' followed by an hourlong documentary by Morgan Spurlock, the director and star of ''Super Size Me.'' The writers make a few smirking references to the show's longevity -- Bart at the blackboard writes over and over, ''The world may end in 2012, but this show won't.'' Mostly it's a typical half-hour of animated lunacy and a reminder to apostates of why they loved the show in the first place.

Seiji Ozawa, the Japanese conductor, said Thursday that he has esophageal cancer and that he would cancel his concerts for the next six months to focus on treatment. Mr. Ozawa, 74, who currently conducts the Vienna State Opera, said at a news conference here that the cancer was diagnosed during a routine checkup late last year. He said he still felt healthy, and Japanese news reports said the cancer was detected before it had spread to other parts of his body.

The central bank of China on Thursday raised a key interest rate slightly for the first time in nearly five months, in what economists interpreted as the beginning of a broader move to tighten monetary policy and forestall inflation. After breaking stride a year ago during the global economic slowdown, the Chinese economy resumed galloping growth over the summer. Government investments, real estate construction and consumer spending are all rising briskly as a result of a surge in lending by state-controlled banks.

Leon Yao Liang, a Roman Catholic bishop who spent 28 years in Chinese prisons during Mao's rule for his refusal to renounce his allegiance to the Vatican, died on Dec. 30 in Xiwanzi, a town in north China's Hebei Province. Bishop Yao was 87 and had been ill with a severe cold for about two weeks before his death, according to Song Feng, the president of the Catholic Association of Xiwanzi Church.

A report in the ''Arts, Briefly'' column on Monday about the playwright and actor Sam Shepard was published in error. His arrest on charges of speeding and driving under the influence of alcohol occurred a year ago, not early Saturday morning. The Times regrets the error.

Back in November, with his team reeling, his players grumbling, the fans booing, it was hard to imagine that Eric Mangini would make it until the end of the season. Instead, he will make it at least two. On Thursday, the Browns' new president, Mike Holmgren, announced that Mangini would return for his second season, shocking many around the N.F.L. who assumed Holmgren would clean house. Holmgren was probably swayed by the four-game winning streak that raised the Browns' record to 5-11.

HERMANSON--Lydia Stevens. With great sadness we report the death of Lydia Hermanson on January 4, 2010 at the age of 93. She was a mother, grandmother and great-grandmother beyond compare. Words cannot adequately describe her love and contributions to our family's well-being, but we will fondly cherish our memories of Didi. She was a talented cook, and her brisket was exceptional. She never appeared as a weekend guest without smoked salmon and a box of schnecken under her arm. An accomplished bridge player, she was known to bet sums upward of one dollar a hand in games with her many longtime friends. She was a sharp and tactful businesswoman who built the family business, Mr. Christmas, alongside her husband of more than 50 years, Merril. She cared for Merril devotedly until his death in 2000. We will never forget her kindness, giddy humor, stubborn optimism, generosity, and selflessness. Lydia is survived by her daughter and son-in-law, Linda and Robert Eder, her son Terry Hermanson, her daughter-in-law Susie Hermanson, her five granddaughters, Elizabeth Thede, Randy Steinman, Sarah Meister, Leslie Hermanson and Merril Hermanson, and her six great-grandchildren, Victoria Thede, Kate, Jill and Ally Steinman and Madeline and Lee Meister. In lieu of sending flowers, please consider making a donation in Lydia's name to the ADL, P.O. Box 96226, Washington, DC 20090-6226.

Senator Ben Nelson, Democrat of Nebraska, has been under fire in recent days for winning plum provisions for his home state in exchange for voting for his party's health care legislation. But in a statement on Thursday, Mr. Nelson said he would fight for all states to get the same benefits as Nebraska. When Mr. Nelson, below, was negotiating with the Senate majority leader, Harry Reid of Nevada, over whether he would support the health care bill, he demanded that the federal government pick up the total cost of a proposed Medicaid expansion in Nebraska, even though other states would eventually have to share the cost of expanding their Medicaid programs.

Months before a national election, Prime Minister Gordon Brown appeared Thursday to have survived an attempt to unseat him by two senior figures in the governing Labour Party who had issued an unusual appeal for a secret ballot on his leadership. But the episode revealed a surprisingly tepid level of support for Mr. Brown as ministers rallied belatedly to his side after the dissidents -- the former cabinet ministers Patricia Hewitt and Geoff Hoon -- said Wednesday in a letter to Labour lawmakers that their party was ''deeply divided'' over his tenure.

HOBBS--John H. The trustees, faculty, and staff of The New School are deeply saddened by the death of John Hobbs, respected member of the Board of Governors of The New School for Social Research. John's deep commitment to higher education was demonstrated not only by his generous philanthropy, but also by the time, energy, and ideas that he contributed to ensuring the continued vitality of The New School. John was a deeply valued member of our community and his passion and dedication to our mission will continue to have great impact for future generations of students. We extend our sincere condolences to his family. Bob Kerrey, President, The New School Michael J. Johnston, Chair, Board of Trustees Susan L. Foote, Chair, Board of Governors, The New School for Social Research Michael Schober, Dean, The New School for Social Research

Eurostar train service between Britain and the Continent again faced significant disruptions on Thursday, just weeks after a breakdown stranded thousands of travelers at the start of the holiday season. A train to London from Brussels stalled in the tunnel Thursday morning and had to be towed out. Eurostar, which said it did not yet know the cause of the breakdown, said that service would be limited for several days and that there would be delays. It was unclear if weather played a part, but freezing weather and snow have been causing havoc with travel in Northern Europe for days.

A tree survives only so long after it is severed from its roots. The sad reminders of this are plentiful in the city. Sweet-smelling needles adorn the floors of countless living rooms. Brittle, rust-colored skeletons of wood decorate curbside trash piles. At some city parks this weekend the dead or dying Christmas trees will be ground into mulch. Even in a city accustomed to operating on a large scale, the numbers are eye-catching: Last year the Department of Sanitation collected 122,235 Christmas trees.

Interior Secretary Ken Salazar said Thursday that he would not leave the cabinet to run for governor of Colorado, and he urged John Hickenlooper, the mayor of Denver, to enter the race as a Democratic candidate. ''I have a job to do as secretary of the interior to implement President Obama's vision for a clean energy economy and to better protect America's great outdoors,'' Mr. Salazar, at right, said in a statement intended to clear up the speculation that he might leave Washington and return to Colorado.

Facing strong opposition from moderate Republican leaders, a group of conservative Republicans is proposing a watered-down alternative to a resolution that would have required party candidates to agree to at least 8 of 10 positions in order to win support from the Republican National Committee. The new resolution says the chairman of the committee is ''empowered to take into account a candidate's faithfulness to the Republican Party's conservative principles and public policies'' in determining whether a candidate should receive financial support from the party. In this new resolution, candidates would be automatically barred from receiving support from the national committee if they endorsed a Democratic candidate for office in 2010 or for president in 2012.

HOUSTON - Some things, no matter how much time has elapsed or how many milestones have been reached, will never change for the N.B.A. brothers Marcus and Carl Landry. Marcus, in his rookie season with the Knicks, is two years younger than Carl, of the Houston Rockets. Marcus will always want to challenge Carl as a barometer of his own maturation. And Marcus will eternally view Carl as a role model, leaning on him in more ways than one.

My Sunday column looks at the the ways religions have tended to perpetuate and sanctify the oppression of women, and I'm sure readers will be eager to weigh in. I'm confident of that because in fact this column originated as a blog item last month. I dashed the blog item off after reading the Jimmy Carter speech, and I was impressed by the breadth and passion of the comments on the blog.

The Hissing of Summer Lawns (or Lawn Owners) | When Joni Mitchell wrote her song about summer lawns it was the 1970s and the lawn was still the archetypical suburban landscape, even in dry northern California. But now that a 2006 state law restricting water use for landscaping is finally taking effect, local jurisdictions all over the state must figure out what to do about the issue by Jan. 31. Some are adopting the state's model ordinance on landscaping and water conservation; others, like Palo Alto and Menlo Park, are trying to come up with their own. Some of these severely limit the extend of lawns in new or remodeled corporate or residential landscapes. Wary of these possibilities and other more draconian drought-driven restrictions, homeowners in high-end lawn-bedecked suburbs like Atherton and Hillsborough are putting in their own wells as insurance against municipal water cutbacks.Taking It Slow and Easy in Sonoma | An Italian group recently honored Sonoma as a "slow city," providing the livability of a time gone by, with few if any chain stores, enough farmers' markets and a pedestrian- and bicycle-friendly ambiance. But the corollary of being slow seems to be being white and old and rich, judging by the town's demographics. Which raises some questions: What price is the town paying for its slow lifestyle? Does it mean that many people who work in Sonoma have to drive a long way to get there? Will it mean that the generation growing up in Sonoma will be unlikely to have the money to live there?

There's been an unrelenting string of commentary on Dot Earth, and in some other news outlets, from people passionately pointing to the cold conditions around the Northern Hemisphere and crowing about the end of global warming. Following up on my post from last week on the Arctic Oscillation, Ken Chang has written a Week in Review story with a bit more detail on the unusual atmospheric patterns behind the big, but very constrained, chill, and the dominance of warm conditions -- just not where a lot of Western media are situated. (As I wrote, it was raining in parts of Greenland about a week ago.) [UPDATE, 1/11: Richard Betts, the head of climate impacts at the Met Office, has written a commentary for the BBC amplifying on the confusion between weather (cold or hot) and climate. It's well worth a read, as is this column by Andrew Freedman at the Capital Weather Gang.]

Jose Calderon, the Raptors' point guard, returned from a long injury absence Wednesday. He must have been a welcome sight for Toronto fans, not just because he is back but because he looked more like the sensation who took over the team at the end of the 2007-8 season than the less efficient version he had become. He had eight assists and one turnover in 25 minutes off the bench.

The Clippers might have felt a little like Cinderella after their 102-91 home victory over the Lakers at Staples Center on Wednesday. It was their first victory over the Lakers since April 2007.

SECOND SUNDAY PUZZLE - Now that registration is open for the 2010 American Crossword Puzzle Tournament, you're probably looking forward to meeting and hanging out with fellow enthusiasts. There's a problem, though. What should you do if you encounter one of those inevitable gaps in conversation? How can you get past that awkward silence and establish your creds as a competitor to be reckoned with at the same time? Don't worry. Wordplay is here to help. Just say, "Myself, I prefer cryptic crosswords, of course." Now all you have to do is sit back and watch the ruckus.

Re "Times Standards, Staffers or Not" (Jan. 3): The clear intent of the freelancers' contract seems to be, "You will not accept anything of value not provided by The New York Times." What payers are covered as "current or potential news sources"? Is there any person or organization that is not at least a potential news source? Even a Stylite Monk sitting on top of a column for 30 years might serve as a source in a story about his motivations or experiences. The policy appears to me to be facially nonsense. A better idea? Have all writers disclose to The Times all investments over $500 and all receipts of value greater than $250, have the list available to me online and let me judge the extent, if any, that their coverage might be influenced. MARK TRENTACOSTECherry Hill, N.J., Jan. 3, 2010 ●It is surprising that The Times would rely solely upon 3M's reimbursement of travel expenses for Mary Tripsas to condemn her for violating policy, when 3M might have contributed instead to her Harvard Business School research budget (or had its proxy do so) and thus avoided the perception of a conflict. My experience has shown me that it is impossible to avoid all potential conflicts and that some conflicts may actually be productive. I agree that The Times should take a firm stand on the most egregious conflicts, but rather than focus obsessively on avoiding all conflicts, it should also consider the quality of the work produced.I think that it would have been more valuable if you had provided some commentary on the column that Ms. Tripsas wrote on 3M to assess whether and how her writing might have been influenced by the arrangement. That places a higher burden on the public advocate, but one that is appropriate, in my view.STEVE PERCOCOEast Falmouth, Mass., Jan. 3, 2010 ●The policy described in your column, that your that contributors "must be free of even the smallest hint of undue influence," goes beyond what I feel is necessary to ensure that the "readers have reason to trust our credibility." Frankly, I am offended that The the Times's editors would feel I am such a puritan and/or ignoramus as to assume that any junket given to a freelance reporter in an entirely separate matter would taint the reporter's credibility and objectivity, or that of The Times. I certainly don't discount the risk of such things happening. Rather, I think that The Times is taking the easy way out. I would respect The Times more if it would allow a limited amount of flexibility in such cases, and itself undertook to determine whether a freelancer's other activities threatened the credibility of what appeared in The Times. I recognize that part of the problem in the cases you cite is the fact that the freelancers didn't report their own conflicts, and that is a separate issue from the conflicts themselves. Nevertheless, I remain uneasy that you are unable to live with the mere existence of conflicts. It reminds me of the concept of "ritual uncleanliness" that notionally pollutes all who come in contact with it, which is unworthy of an intelligent and sophisticated society.I have no intention of canceling my subscription, nor of ceasing my regular visits to The Times's Web site, just because you have gone so far in depriving yourselves, and your readers, of useful contributors as to arguably lower the potential range of your coverage. But a regular and loyal customer nevertheless considers that you have done just that, and would be happy if you eased off just a little. DON THOMASCalgary, Alberta, Jan. 3, 2010 ●Rather than outright disqualification, wouldn't simple disclosure of the potential conflict - in or alongside the published column - do the job in many cases? That way the reader could decide what weight to give the potential conflict in evaluating the reliability of the information in the column and the worth of the columnist's opinion. JIM LUTHERMendocino, Calif., Jan. 4, 2010 ●When someone is on the staff of The Times, The Times undoubtedly pays for their travel to important conferences in the field they cover. But if they freelance they must pay for these trips with their own money?Sounds to me like it's unethical for The Times to hire freelancers, because it's a cheapskate way of transferring legitimate business expenses from The Times to the worker. The Times should cover these expenses themselves if the paper feels it is a conflict of interest for someone else to cover them (which I agree, it is). Forcing freelancers to pay those expenses when employees get them covered is not fair.ISABEL WALCOTT DRAVESManhattan, Jan 4, 2010●●Scientists and JournalistsRe "Stolen E-Mail, Stoking the Climate Debate" (Dec. 5): With some real intensive investigative research, maybe this is a "three-alarm story." One way or another, The Times needs to get this one right. If this is a fraud, The Times surely does not want to be the last to acknowledge it. We cannot afford to be wrong on climate warming. If the Associated Press can put 11 staff members on Sarah Palin's new book, The Times must have the staff to follow through on climate warming -- including giving the many highly respectable skeptics a sufficient platform for raising their issues, and sinking or swimming. MIKE BOURISMendocino, Calif., Dec. 6, 2009 ●Why is it that the media at large, and your column in particular, refers to supporters of the human-caused global warming theory as "scientists," but uses the term "skeptics" (not scientists) for any scientist who rebuts that theory? Are not the physicist Fred Singer and the climatologist Timothy Ball scientists (as well as skeptics)?Should you not describe the two camps as "supporters and skeptics," or simply scientists? By referring to one group as "scientists" and the other as "skeptics," you are boosting the credentials of one at the expense of the other. RONALD BREMNER Glen Ridge, N.J., Dec. 6, 2009 ●You missed a major opportunity to explore the difference in reporting on politics and science - and the challenges faced by reporters when science becomes politicized. I'm sure you know that there is broad scientific consensus on the science behind climate change. The latest I.P.C.C. synthesis report is quite clear about the cause and threat. At what point is it O.K. for a credible news organization to stop publicizing discredited theories and individuals? Does there need to be any verifiable proof at all? Or is it O.K. to give a few contrarians equal billing? At what point (if at all) did The Times stop quoting tobacco-industry-funded spokespeople? If we could find a few "scientists" to insist the sun revolves around the earth would we create a man-bites-dog controversy - and give them equal billing? SAM BOYKINQueens, Dec. 7, 2009 ● A deliberate conspiracy to cover up information is hardly ever the problem with The New York Times or any other media outlet. The problem is bias, which is not deliberate, but often unconscious. I have little doubt that The Times will be as conscientious and professional as possible, but because your information is necessarily limited and uncertain, you will tend to favor the data and the interpretations that support your belief in anthropogenic global warming. That's normal and natural. Bias is a powerful force operating on any journalist. This much has become clear as a result of Climategate: The myth, perpetrated by global warming alarmists, that we have serene, Olympian scientists on the one hand and ideologically driven skeptics on the other is now gone with the global wind. If we are honest and admit the inevitable presence of bias even in the aeries of science, then we must acknowledge that the skeptics have a vital role to play in the debate, especially since it is now clear that we cannot count on the global-warming advocates to check themselves. If nothing else, the skeptics can improve the science of global warming by finding problems for advocates in the science to solve. TUCKER LANDYFrankfort, Ky., Dec. 6, 2009

Monologue | Friday night on "The Jay Leno Show" on NBC: Well, in an effort to calm people down after this latest security problem, the White House said it is working even harder to find Osama bin Laden. A report in the Prescriptions column on Friday about Senator Ben Nelson’s role in negotiations over the Senate health care bill referred incorrectly to his position on Medicaid costs. Mr. Nelson, a Nebraska Democrat, told Senate leaders he opposed an increase in his state’s Medicaid costs, and suggested that all states be allowed to opt out of a proposed Medicaid expansion. Senate leaders proposed that the federal government pick up Nebraska’s full share of the new Medicaid costs, and Mr. Nelson agreed. He did not demand that the federal government cover those costs.

FRIEDMAN--Bernard, Ph.D.,of New York, died peacefully at home on January 6, 2010 at the age of 93. This beloved father, and long time loving husband 71 years of Florence, had a distinguished career as an educator in New York City. Bernard's legacy to all who knew him was his passion for living. He embraced life to its fullest. His love of art, music, nature, travel, languages, learning everything he could and most of all his family made him who he was-a modern renaissance man loved by all who knew him. Bernard is survived by his wife Florence; three children, Ruth Neabore, of New Jersey, Deborah Daves of Great Neck, Joseph of Cortland Manor, a brother Samuel of Arizona, grandchildren and great-grandchildren. "He was born with a gift of laughter." Services: Sunday, 10:00am, at Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 91st St. and Amsterdam Ave. Burial will take place at Cedar Lawn Cemetery in Paramus. Donations made to Visiting Nursing Hospice 225 W. 34th St. NYC 10122

William Tuohy, a foreign correspondent who was awarded a Pulitzer Prize for his coverage of the Vietnam War for The Los Angeles Times, died on Dec. 31. He was 83. He died after open-heart surgery at a Santa Monica hospital, said his stepson, Adam Wheeler.

CanWest Global Communications, the media company based in Winnipeg, Manitoba, sought bankruptcy protection for its national newspaper chain on Friday. The company owns the dominant daily newspapers in Vancouver, the Alberta cities of Edmonton and Calgary, Ottawa and Montreal, as well as The National Post, which is based in Toronto. CanWest, a broadcaster that became heavily indebted by its move into publishing as well as a deal to acquire several of Canada's leading cable channels, put many of its broadcasting assets under court protection in October. While the Asper family, which founded and controlled CanWest, hopes to maintain control of its television business, Friday's filing ends its role as the country's leading publisher. Along with the announcement of the court protection filing, CanWest said the newspaper unit's senior lenders had agreed to acquire the operation in a debt-for-equity swap. The lenders are a group that is led by the Bank of Nova Scotia and includes four of its rival banks.

The Seattle Seahawks jumped onto a slowly spinning coaching carousel Friday, firing Jim Mora after just one injury-riddled season. But the Seahawks' next move might be an even bigger surprise. ESPN reported that the Seahawks were pursuing University of Southern California Coach Pete Carroll. The Seahawks had asked for permission to talk with Minnesota's defensive coordinator, Leslie Frazier, who will interview Saturday, according to The Minneapolis Star-Tribune. That puts the Seahawks in compliance with the Rooney Rule, which requires teams to interview at least one minority candidate.

ADAMS--John, of Locust, NJ, age 87, born in Paget, Bermuda, the youngest of the four sons of Henry Coolidge Adams and Louise Scarritt Adams, died peacefully at home with his family on January 5. Jack served on the Naval Ship USS Idaho during World War II. He attended Columbia Business School and enjoyed a successful career in finance in a New York City utility company. A member of the Rumson Country Club and the Sea Bright Beach Club, Jack was an avid sailor and loved ocean racing which began in 1956 with the Newport-Bermuda Race. He also enjoyed many hours on golf courses and ski slopes. Jack in known by many for his wonderful, bright approach to life and great sense of humor. His enthusiasm and fine principles were evident in every endeavor. He is survived by Ellen Noonan Adams, wife of 63 years, daughters Mary Minturn Adams of New York, Ann Adams Royal. In lieu of flowers, the family requests donations be sent to All Saints' Memorial Chapel, P.O. Box 326, Navesink, NJ 07752. A memorial service will be held in the spring.
MARCOVE--Ralph C.,M.D. January 9, 2001. Loved and remembered. Christina and Laura
KURLAND--Sheldon. The family of Michael Lipstein extend our sincere sympathies to my sister Barbara, her daughters Amy and Wendy and her son Peter and their families on their sudden and sad loss.

COLLINS--Sister Mary de Sales, beloved member of the Sisters of Charity, Convent of Mary the Queen, died January 8, 2010. Sister was predeceased by her parents John and Mary (Kearns) Collins and her siblings John and Sr. Margaret Mary Collins, SC. She is survived by many loving cousins. Sister de Sales ministered for over 50 years in the adoption services of the New York Foundling and is fondly remembered by her "children" and their families. Reposing at the Convent of Mary the Queen, 35 Vark Street, Yonkers, NY on Sunday from 2-8pm, with a prayer service at 6:30pm. Funeral Mass Monday 10am at the convent. Interment will follow at Calvary Cemetery, Queens, NY. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Sisters of Charity Development Fund, 6301 Riverdale Avenue, Bronx, NY 10471 or The NY Foundling, 590 Ave. of the Americas, NY, NY 10011. Services by F. Ruggiero & Sons, Inc., 732 Yonkers Avenue, Yonkers, NY 10704 (914)375-1400. www.ruggieroandsonsfh.com.

A Swiss court ruled on Friday that the country's financial regulator broke the law last year when it ordered the investment firm UBS to hand over data on nearly 300 clients suspected of evading taxes to United States authorities. The Federal Administrative Court in Bern said that the Swiss Financial Market Supervisory Authority, known as Finma, had gone beyond its mandate.

THOMAS--Terrie Laverne Canada, of natural causes December 30, 2009, age 58. Lab technologist St. Luke's Roosevelt, Metropolitan, Coler Hospitals. Cum Laude graduate Hunter College. Survived: son Sean, daughter Aneka Roberts, brother Ron Canada.

10 P.M. (Planet Green) BIG RIVER MAN (2009) In April 2007 Martin Strel, above, a 52-year-old larger-than-life Slovenian with a fondness for horse-meat burgers, became the first person to swim the length of the Amazon, considered the world's most dangerous river. Mr. Strel -- a k a the Fish Man, a four-time world-record-holding endurance swimmer -- had already navigated the Mississippi, Danube, Paraná and Yangtze Rivers, braving blisters, sunburn, stomach illnesses, piranhas, anacondas, crocodiles and a parasitic fish in a quest to draw attention to the impact of pollution on these waterways. This latest documentary in the ''Reel Impact'' series follows Mr. Strel as he propels himself through more than 3,000 miles of the Amazon in 66 days to prove that one man can make a difference. John Maringouin directed. 10:30 A.M. (13) RELIGION & ETHICS NEWSWEEKLY Betty Rollins examines ''reverse missionaries'' from Nigeria, who are bringing their own brand of Christianity to the United States. Also, a profile of Charlene Wilson-Doffoney, an undertaker in Philadelphia, and an interview with Salam al-Marayati, executive director of the Muslim Public Affairs Council, about new airline security measures.

PEIMER--Helene Siegel, 86, formerly of New York City and New Rochelle, died peacefully in Los Angeles on December 26, 2009, after a long illness. She was the daughter of the late Lillian and Saul Siegel, of New York; and was predeceased by her husband of 42 years, Ralph Peimer, MD. She is survived by her three sons, Clayton (Susan) of Marquette, MI; Ronald (Roberta) of Bedford, NH; and Jordan, of Los Angeles, CA; by three grandchildren and one great-grandchild; as well as by her brother, Lloyd Siegel, of Washington, DC. Memorial contributions may be made, at her request, to the Laurel Canyon Dog Park, c/o Judith Kieffer, Executive Director, LA Parks Foundation, 11973 San Vicente Blvd., Suite 200, Los Angeles, CA 90049. The family plans a private memorial service in the spring.

HUTTON--Robert W.,died peacefully at home in Seattle on January 5, at the age of 88. Bob was a native of the northwest, a member and supporter of numerous local civic organizations, a successful business executive and a dedicated husband and father. With his wife Charlotte, Bob lived much of his life in the Seattle area, in addition to 25 years in Greenwich, Connecticut. Bob was born in Olympia, Washington on April 28, 1921 to George W. Hutton and Elsie Doragh Hutton. He grew up in Vancouver and Olympia, and graduated from Vancouver High School in 1938. He attended the University of Washington, graduating in 1943. At the University, he was a member of Chi Psi fraternity, the Senior Manager of the Crew, a member of Oval Club and Fir Tree, and a student of law and business. Following service as a Captain in the U.S. Army during World War II, Bob attended the Stanford Graduate School of Business, where he received an MBA degree in 1948. Bob's distinguished business career was focused in the cement industry. Following graduate school he worked for three years at the Seattle First National Bank, prior to starting Bellingham Builders Supply in Bellingham, Washington. He joined Lone Star Industries, at that time the largest producer of cement in the United States, in 1965 and became CEO, based in New York, 1972. He served as a Director of the American Mining Congress, as President of the Portland Cement Association, and was an active leader in the industry, throughout the world. An avid sailor, Bob campaigned a series of ocean racing sailboats called "Tatoosh," with notable national and international success. A highlight of his life was being selected to represent the United States in 1980 at the Sardinia Cup, considered at the time to be a World Championship of ocean racing. Tatoosh finished in second place overall, leading the U.S. team to victory. Bob is survived by his wife, Charlotte; their daughter, Ann Hutton of Friday Harbor, WA and her children, Meghan and Brianna; and their son, Tom Hutton of Atherton, California, his wife, Wende and their children Cameron and Rachel. A memorial service will be held at Epiphany Parish on Saturday, January 16 at 1pm, followed by a reception at The Seattle Yacht Club at 2:30pm. In lieu of flowers, please send any donations to the Pacific Science Center or a charity of your choice.

KURLAND--Shelly, 81, died Wednesday in Nashville, TN. Shelly was a Juilliard trained violinist with a masters degree in music, a career he first pursued at Cornell University. He arrived in Nashville in 1964 to teach at Peabody College, and before long was doing session and television work with Johnny Cash, Dolly Parton, George Jones, Bob Dylan, Neil Young and scores of others. A gifted musician and also a visionary, with the Nashville music scene changing in the 60's, he organized local string players into a collective to perform live and on recordings. His group, the Shelly Kurland Strings won numerous "Super Picker Awards", given each year to musicians who played on the most number one records. Shelly was born and raised in Brooklyn by his parents, Samuel and Beatrice, and for a short time by his Uncle Julius. He always said his childhood was spent going to violin lessons, where he dreamed of playing stickball. After retirement, Shelly traveled with his wife Barbara and doted on his children Amy, Wendy and Peter; their spouses Kelly Collom, Mark Zimbicki and Shannon Wood; and his grandchildren Peter, Zoey, Julian, Ben and Stephanie. He was a generous investor in his children's endeavors including The Bluebird Cafe, Darkhorse Theater and Homework Hotline. He added to the lives of Maureen Franklin, Hilarie Moore and Elina Sorakunnas. His sister Elaine (Murray) Koren of New York City survives him. He moved his family to London and Europe in 1968, took the entire clan to the beach every summer, and made more trips to Disney World than he cared to remember. It can be truly said that the Kurlands never run out of occasions for family dinners and Shelly never passed up the opportunity to pick up the check. Shelly was known for his sense of humor. He began his book An Adult Guide to the Orchestra: "The most important thing in a string player's life is where he sits. First chair outside is the star. Last chair inside is pathetic." Wherever he is, Shelly is first chair today. Persons wishing to commemorate Shelly's life are encouraged to contribute to Homework Hotline, 4805 Park Avenue, Nashville 37209.

Following he became a real estate investor with his wife, son and daughter. Memorial donations may be made to a charity of your choice.

COHEN--Melvin S.,Chairman Emeritus of Molina Fine Jewelers and Black, Starr & Frost. Melvin "Mel" Stephen Cohen passed away on January 1, 2010. He was born in New York City on July 11, 1919. He is survived by his beloved wife of 66 years Frances M. Cohen; loving daughters, Sallie (Michael) Goldwyn of Portland, OR and Gwendolyn Coleman of Los Angeles, CA, and five grandchildren Eli, Joshua, and Adam Goldwyn and Elizabeth and Warren Siroka. Mel received his undergraduate degree from New York University and a Master's Degree from Harvard School of Business. He served as an officer in the United States Army for four years. Cohen comes from a long line of distinguished jewelers. He joined his family's business, A. Cohen & Sons Corporation, in 1946 and he took it public in 1969, as the largest wholesale jewelry company in the country. This business was instrumental in saving the jewelry industry during the depression by creating a program that allowed jewelers who could not meet their financial obligations, to continue to purchase goods. Mel was a leader in the jewelry industry. He served as the president of the 24 Karat Club of New York in 1975 and as the Chairman from 1983 1985. He was the oldest living member of this prestigious organization. Cohen also served as the president of the American Jewelry Distributors Association, ORT Jewelry Industry and the Wholesale Jewelers Association. Cohen has been honored by many for his distinguished service to others: Honorary Kentucky Colonel, 1964 Man of the Year, Federation of Jewish Philanthropies, 1969 Human Relations Award, American Jewish Committee, 1970, Guardian of the State of Israel, State of Israel Bonds, 1972, Brotherhood Award, National Conference of Christians and Jews, 1974, Distinguished Community Service Award, Brandeis University 1977, Anti-Defamation League of B'nai Brith, Torch of Liberty Award, 1980. When Cohen was no longer involved in active corporate life, he served as a consultant to Fortunoff in New York and was vice chairman of District 65 UAW Health and Pension Plans. Mel was an avid golfer. He was a charter member of the International Golfing Society; he served as Treasurer, Glen Oaks Country Club in Old Westbury, NY and President, of the Biltmore Country Club in Phoenix, AZ. He shot a Hole-in-One at Glen Oaks on August 26, 1987 and he shot his age at least once every year between his 75th and 80th birthday. Mel and his wife Fran moved from Great Neck, NY, to Phoenix, AZ in 1982. There he served as the Chairman Emeritus for Molina Fine Jewelers from 1992 and Black, Starr & Frost from 2006, until his passing. Mel was loved and respected by many and he will be remembered for his passion, wisdom and story telling. His family would like to thank those that touched Mel's life at the Veterans Administration and the dialysis center at Scottsdale Healthcare. Memorial contributions may be made to ORT America (Organization for Rehabilitation through Training), 75 Maiden Lane, 10th floor, New York, New York 10038, or Scottsdale Healthcare Foundation Cancer Center, 1001 N. 92nd St., Suite 121, Scottsdale, AZ 85258.

Japan Airlines, the once-proud flagship carrier now crippled by $16 billion in debt, may soon file for bankruptcy protection as part of a state-led turnaround in one of the nation's largest corporate failures. Government officials said a final decision had not been made on the fate of the airline, Asia's largest. But they suggested that the carrier, which the state has already bailed out four times, would most likely undergo some form of court-led restructuring similar to a Chapter 11 filing in the United States -- a bold step for the new government of Prime Minister Yukio Hatoyama.

A house in Karachi where militants appeared to have been storing ammunition for terrorist strikes was destroyed in a deadly explosion early Friday morning, police officials said. Seven people were killed in the blast, which rocked the working-class neighborhood of Baldia on the western edge of Karachi. Amid the rubble, the police and rescue workers found a large cache of weapons, including suicide vests, automatic rifles and grenades.

The White House will not say when President Obama's State of the Union address will be delivered. The unemployment rate in the euro zone reached 10 percent in November, the first time in more than a decade, tempering hopes for a rapid recovery in the job market. Eurostat, the European Union's statistics agency, said on Friday that the seasonally adjusted unemployment rate in the 16 countries that use the euro rose to 10 percent in November, from 9.9 percent in October and 8 percent in November 2008. For the euro area, the rate was the highest since 1998, a year before the euro was introduced.

Eagles at Cowboys The Eagles parked in their designated spot for the playoffs. Andy Reid and Donovan McNabb have arrived again, regular visitors who always carry the same baggage. The Eagles' seventh playoff appearance in Reid's 10 seasons now appears as futile as all the others: last week's 24-0 loss to the Cowboys exposed the team's many weaknesses. The Cowboys have not won a playoff game since the 1996 season. Three-game winning streaks are the sports world's leading cause of amnesia.

Most football coaches get too much credit for victories and too much blame for losses. But, while Wade Phillips gets a hefty share of the blame, he gets nearly none of the credit. Phillips is seeking his first playoff victory in 10 seasons as an N.F.L. coach and the Cowboys are gunning for their first playoff victory since 1996. If they get it, there is a long line of recognition-seekers ahead of Phillips. Clip and save this handy Praise-Blame Allocation Chart: you can't tell the saviors from the scapegoats without it.

BRYANT--Brienin NeQua, 37, died peacefully at home on December 23, 2009 of breast cancer. Born in Atlanta in 1972, Ms. Bryant was raised in Manhattan where, at an early age, she developed a lifelong passion for performing and the theater. Upon graduating from Brown University in 1994, Brienin energetically pursued an acting career performing in productions at the Trinity Repertory Company in Providence, RI, the New York Shakespeare Festival, Yale Repertory Theatre, the Public Theater, Mark Taper Forum in Los Angeles, and Seattle Repertory Theatre, among others. Ms. Bryant appeared on television in episodes of Oz, Law and Order, Third Watch and Max Bickford and also had a role in the 2009 film Cold Souls starring Paul Giamatti. Ms. Bryant was a graduate of the NYU Graduate Acting Program where she received an MFA in 2000. Ms. Bryant is survived by her husband, Shael Polakow-Suransky; her mother, Linda; her brother, Kenneth, and numerous family members and friends.

The nation’s mobility rate fell last year to its lowest level since World War II, according to the latest census data. The current recession and lack of jobs are big factors, but the trend has been gaining force since the 1950s, when nearly one-fifth of all Americans moved every year.
