The Tony Award-winning actor Alan Cumming ("Cabaret") said Saturday that the coming Broadway musical "Spider-Man, Turn Off the Dark" in which he is set to star as the Green Goblin, would be significantly delayed and that producers had hit a financial iceberg last year. Previews were scheduled to begin next month, but speaking at a TimesTalk event, Mr. Cumming said: "No one's going to be there that day. We're just waiting." He said the show had hit "an iceberg of financial ruin" last year when producers could not raise enough money for the show, which is expected to cost upwards of $50 million. He said the producers should have taken down posters in the theater district that suggest the show is opening soon; the musical's Web site still says that previews start Feb. 25. The lead producer, Michael Cohl, who took over in November, has said that the production would take place on Broadway sometime this year. Mr. Cumming said it was "a really weird, frustrating thing to be waiting," but added that based on the music (by Bono and the Edge of U2), costumes and sets that he had seen so far, the musical would be "a new, very exciting experience" for Broadway audiences.

An article on Dec. 27 about the death of Edward M. Kennedy in August referred incorrectly to the assassination of his brother President John F. Kennedy, and a correction in this space last Sunday erroneously corrected the length of his tenure in the Senate. The president was assassinated in 1963, the year after Edward Kennedy was elected to the Senate — not the same year. And as the article correctly reported, Senator Kennedy served 46 years — not 47 as the correction said. (The correction also erred in stating that the length of tenure was incorrect in Mr. Kennedy’s obituary, in two other articles on Aug. 27 and Aug. 28 and in an editorial on Aug. 28 All four correctly reported the tenure as 46 years.).

An article last Sunday about couples who buy homes together before getting married misstated the income limits of the federal first-time home buyer tax credit. For purchases after Nov. 6, 2009, the full credit is available to married couples filing joint returns with modified adjusted gross incomes of up to $225,000, not $150,000; and for individuals with incomes of up to $125,000, not $75,000. (The lower numbers were the limits for purchases before Nov. 6.).

A chart last Sunday with the Keeping Score column listing baseball players who finished a decade in the top three in home runs and runs batted in gave incorrect information for the 1980s and the 2000s. MILLER--Robert Paul, 85, a native of Minneapolis, who lived in New York for nearly forty years, and made his home in Scottsdale since 1996, died there of natural causes on December 25, 2009. In a varied career spanning more than sixty years, Miller began as a radio broadcaster in 1943. A natural step forward took him into the fields of advertising and marketing. A few years later, he became the owner of an established Minneapolis advertising agency, which became known as Manson-Gold-Miller, Inc. Moving to New York in 1957, Miller became Chairman and CEO of American Paper. He retired in 1990 and wrote a novel, entitled, Zig/Zag. At an early age, Miller became actively involved in Jewish community affairs, particularly in fundraising for the Minneapolis Jewish Federation. In 1968, he was named Israel Bonds "Man of the Year." In 1970 Miller became president of Temple Emanu-El in Great Neck, Long Island, and was elected a life member of the Board of Directors of the Union of American Hebrew Congregations. Preceded in death by parents Hyman and Esther, wives Eleanor (Wilensky) of Minneapolis and Carolyn (Safran) from whom he was divorced, and brother Sonny Miller of Minneapolis. Survived by four daughters and grandchildren, sister Evelyn Berns of Los Angeles, and his longtime partner, Sally L. Appelbaum of Scottsdale and her extended family.

Rankings reflect sales, for the week ending Saturday, December 26th 2009, at many thousands of venues where a wide range of general interest books are sold nationwide. These include hundreds of independent book retailers (statistically weighted to represent all such outlets); national, regional and local chains; online and multimedia entertainment retailers; university, gift, supermarket, discount department stores and newsstands. An asterisk (*) indicates that a book’s sales are barely distinguishable from those of the book above. A dagger (†) indicates that some bookstores report receiving bulk orders. Among those categories not actively tracked are: perennial sellers; required classroom reading; text, reference and test preparation guides; journals and workbooks; calorie counters; shopping guides; comics and crossword puzzles. Expanded rankings are available on the Web: nytimes.com/books.

KNOLLENBERG--Bernhard Walter. Business entrepreneur, born December 20, 1924 and raised in Manhattan, only child of Bernhard Knollenberg and Mary (Young McClennen) Knollenberg and grandson of George Herman and Agnes (Steen) Knollenberg and of Edward and Mary (Bigelow Young) McClennen. The deceased, known to most as Walt or Knollie, was a graduate of Millbrook School for Boys, Millbrook, NY, '42, and a graduate of Yale University, New Haven, CT, '45 with a Bachelor degree in Electrical Engineering. After completing Midshipmen's School in New York, NY and Naval Training School (Pre-Radar) at Bowdoin College, Brunswick, ME, Ensign B. Walter Knollenberg served as LTJG until his honorable discharge from the U.S Naval Reserve. He was a graduate of Harvard Business School, Cambridge, MA, '50. Walter lived a private life and kept close ties with family. He lived in Old Lyme, CT and later in Killingworth, CT before retiring to Cape Cod, MA. His father, Bernhard Knollenberg, lawyer and partner at Lord Day and Lord, historian, author, Senior Deputy Administrator in the Lend-Lease Administration, was an influential person in his life, as was his grandfather, Edward Francis McClennen, lawyer and partner at Nutter McClennen and Fish. Walter is remembered by family, friends and professionals for his caring and personable demeanor. He is survived by his first wife, Pauline (Elaine Mutschler) Knollenberg, their three children, Peter Knollenberg, Mary Lee Fleischmann and Heidi Manice, nine grandchildren and one great-grandchild. He is also survived by family of his late wife, Ann. Remembrance prayers were offered by Walter's friend, Reverend David Deppen at an intimate private memorial gathering on the Cape, Saturday, December 19, 2009. B. Walter Knollenberg passed away on December 16, 2009, in Cape Cod, at the age of 84.

IN 1951, Jack Kerouac sat down at his typewriter and feverishly banged out -- on a 120-foot-long scroll, single-spaced and devoid of paragraphs -- all he could recall of his extensive road trips across America and Mexico. Raw and open, ''On the Road'' captured the restless energy of Kerouac's generation, and inspired a wealth of artists, writers and musicians to come. All it lacked, apparently, was pictures. For the last couple of years, Ed Ruscha (who, in the '60s, created a series of photographic books inspired by the romantic spirit of the Beats) has been working on that -- taking photographs, commissioning them from other artists, digging through piles of found images to create his own version of the epic novel. The result is a 228-page leather-bound artist's book that pairs Kerouac's words with Ruscha's visuals. All that's missing now is the $10,000 to buy it.

UNGER--Leona and Myron. Leona died January 3, 2010, aged 88; Myron January 8, 2010, aged 88. Devoted to each other for the 68 years they shared together. Both of their lives were dedicated to young people and public service - Myron as Guidance Supervisor for Staten Island, New York City Public School System, Leona as a senior administrator for the New York State Employment Service. In lieu of flowers donations may be sent in their names to Mahopac New York Public Library to buy books.

MURPHY--Anne H.,85, beloved mother, grandmother and great-grandmother died peacefully January 1, 2010 at 7:20pm PST in Carmel, California following a brief illness. She was born June 6, 1924 in Elizabeth, New Jersey, to the late Kenneth C. Hogate and Anna Ruth Shields. Raised in Scarsdale, New York she graduated from the Master's School and matriculated at Sarah Lawrence College, graduating in 1945. On May 14, 1945 at her parents' summer home in Quaker Hill, Pawling, New York she married Charles E. Murphy, Jr., a second lieutenant in the United States Marine Corps. After her husband completed law school and a second tour of duty with the Marine Corp they moved to Chappaqua, New York in 1952 and neighboring Mt. Kisco, New York in 1959 where they lived for the next 46 years. In 2005 they moved to Carmel, California to be closer to their sons. In April, 2007 her husband of 61 years died. She participated fully in the life of her community and had a particular interest in education and healthcare serving as a trustee of The Master's School and board member of Northern Westchester Hospital. She worked in the Fresh Air Project for inner city youth and was active with the Cub Scouts of America. She was President of the Northern Westchester Junior League. Besides generously giving of her time she gave generously to her philanthropic interests in education and healthcare. She is survived by two sons, Charles (Reva) of Berkeley, California, Kenneth (Diane) of Boise, Idaho, ten grandchildren and four great-grandchildren, and a sister, Barbara Ferrin of Palm Beach, Florida. There will be a memorial service at the Kittle House, 11 Kittle Road, Chappaqua, New York, 10514 on Thursday, January 14, at 4pm. In lieu of flowers, the family asks that donations be made to the Children's Scholarship Fund, 8 West 38th Street, 9th Floor, New York, NY 10018.

To the Sports Editor: During the investigation into the events involving guns and the Washington Wizards' Gilbert Arenas, the former N.B.A. player Jayson Williams was charged with driving while intoxicated in Manhattan. The timing of Williams's reappearance in the news last week was eerie. He serves as the perfect reminder of what can go wrong when an athlete ''jokes around'' with firearms. A limousine driver was killed by a shotgun at Williams's home in 2002.

MUNNAR, KERALA, INDIA, JAN. 18, 2009 My fiancée and I decided to escape the lowland heat and humidity of Kerala's coast for the mountains around Munnar. Our five-hour, bone-rattling bus journey ended on the side of a rocky road, where we were dropped off at a quaint, family-run homestay. Tomy, our gracious host, gathered our packs and poured us a cold, refreshing beer. He suggested we walk up the road to a lookout for sunset. Weary from our travels, we wondered if the excursion would be worth it, but soon the early wisps of sunset colors began stretching across the sky. In awe, we watched hills glow, and soon forgot all the trouble and aches it had taken us to get to that moment. MARK TIMBY, Portland, Ore.

SO much for subdued investment dressing. From the looks of the spring runways, designers are letting loose, sending out a dizzying lineup of prints, often clashing (Dries Van Noten, Derek Lam, Proenza Schouler), sometimes from head to toe (Givenchy, Miu Miu, Kenzo). If it seems a little wild, well, it is; apparently the old rule book went out the window with the Aughts. Do polka dots really go with paisley? Now they do. Can ikat honestly be paired with florals? Looks that way. How old is too old to wear an outfit covered in a naked-lady print? That's a tough one. ''Playing with prints and bold color was a way for me to be daring and optimistic,'' said Mr. Lam, whose eye-popping spring collection included star-spangled prints paired with sunshine yellow florals. ''I wanted to express the pleasure of a wild, carefree weekend by the shore.'' Hey, works for us.

COHEN--Melvin S.,Chairman Emeritus of Molina Fine Jewelers and Black, Starr & Frost. Melvin "Mel" Stephen Cohen passed away on January 1, 2010. He was born in New York City on July 11, 1919. He is survived by his beloved wife of 66 years Frances M. Cohen; loving daughters, Sallie (Michael) Goldwyn of Portland, OR and Gwendolyn Coleman of Los Angeles, CA, and five grandchildren Eli, Joshua, and Adam Goldwyn and Elizabeth and Warren Siroka. Mel received his undergraduate degree from New York University and a Master's Degree from Harvard School of Business. He served as an officer in the United States Army for four years. Cohen comes from a long line of distinguished jewelers. He joined his family's business, A. Cohen & Sons Corporation, in 1946 and he took it public in 1969, as the largest wholesale jewelry company in the country. This business was instrumental in saving the jewelry industry during the depression by creating a program that allowed jewelers who could not meet their financial obligations, to continue to purchase goods. Mel was a leader in the jewelry industry. He served as the president of the 24 Karat Club of New York in 1975 and as the Chairman from 1983 1985. He was the oldest living member of this prestigious organization. Cohen also served as the president of the American Jewelry Distributors Association, ORT Jewelry Industry and the Wholesale Jewelers Association. Cohen has been honored by many for his distinguished service to others: Honorary Kentucky Colonel, 1964 Man of the Year, Federation of Jewish Philanthropies, 1969 Human Relations Award, American Jewish Committee, 1970, Guardian of the State of Israel, State of Israel Bonds, 1972, Brotherhood Award, National Conference of Christians and Jews, 1974, Distinguished Community Service Award, Brandeis University 1977, Anti-Defamation League of B'nai Brith, Torch of Liberty Award, 1980. When Cohen was no longer involved in active corporate life, he served as a consultant to Fortunoff in New York and was vice chairman of District 65 UAW Health and Pension Plans. Mel was an avid golfer. He was a charter member of the International Golfing Society; he served as Treasurer, Glen Oaks Country Club in Old Westbury, NY and President, of the Biltmore Country Club in Phoenix, AZ. He shot a Hole-in-One at Glen Oaks on August 26, 1987 and he shot his age at least once every year between his 75th and 80th birthday. Mel and his wife Fran moved from Great Neck, NY, to Phoenix, AZ in 1982. There he served as the Chairman Emeritus for Molina Fine Jewelers from 1992 and Black, Starr & Frost from 2006, until his passing. Mel was loved and respected by many and he will be remembered for his passion, wisdom and story telling. His family would like to thank those that touched Mel's life at the Veterans Administration and the dialysis center at Scottsdale Healthcare. Memorial contributions may be made to ORT America (Organization for Rehabilitation through Training), 75 Maiden Lane, 10th floor, New York, New York 10038, or Scottsdale Healthcare Foundation Cancer Center, 1001 N. 92nd St., Suite 121, Scottsdale, AZ 85258.

BRILL--Frank. Veteran entertainment executive, Frank Brill, passed away December 15, 2009 at his home in Beverly Hills. He was 91 years old. Brill, born in New York City, began his career in Miami Beach as a dancer. He was one of the fabled "Lew Wasserman Boys" at MCA in New York and in the 1970s, he was the Vice President of Talent and Specials at ABC. Later in his career he was the Entertainment Head at Caesar's Palace in Las Vegas and held an executive position at Management 3. In 1970, Brill was the producer of the film "A Man Called Horse," and in the early 1980s, he was partnered with director Art Fisher in Fisher / Brill Productions. Brill was a tireless volunteer and supporter of Five Acres, a children's aid society, in Los Angeles, as well as countless other humanitarian causes. Funeral services will be private.

SMITH--Brian H.,Wine Educator and Author. Born, raised and educated in London, England, he received a master's degree from Queen Elizabeth College, University of London. Having developed an early passion for all things French and for food and wine in particular, he had the great good fortune to work with wine most of his life. He enjoyed 22 years as Professor of Wine Studies at the Culinary Institute of America. He authored "The Sommelier's Guide to Wine", and co-authored "Exploring Wine" and "WineWise"; the last received the James Beard Award 2009 for Best Beverage Book and the George Duboeuf Wine Book of the Year Award 2009. Although he lived happy and died happy, he sadly leaves behind his adored wife Polly Adema and cherished children Lauren and Drew. Also surviving are his father, Bernard W. Smith, and brothers Bernard, Ramon and Colin, all in England. His beloved and much missed mother, June Rose nee Hitchcock passed away in 2000. In celebration of his life, please raise a glass of sparkling wine and drink to all that he enjoyed.

Pop The annual GLOBALFEST is something like a whirlwind tour captained by a cosmopolitan disc jockey, hopping from Guadeloupe to Transylvania, Senegal to the Louisiana bayou, Paris to Siberia. Pragmatically it's an audition by a dozen world-music acts during the annual convention of the Association of Performing Arts Presenters. But it's held in a club -- the three rooms of Webster Hall, with overlapping sets -- with an audience that's not just there for business.

WASHINGTON -- There are many ways for a politician to make an exit. There is the resignation-in-disgrace exit (Richard Nixon) and the sex scandal exit (Larry Craig, Eliot Spitzer) and the kicking-and-screaming exit (Rod Blagojevich, the former Illinois governor who declared, ''I will fight, I will fight, I will fight,'' as he was about to be impeached). Some politicians (Hillary Clinton,Jon Corzine) have no choice but to make an exit -- the voters rejected them. Some make a dramatic exit (Sarah Palin) only to stoke questions about whether they are plotting a comeback.

STILL haven't managed to open those blister-packed headphones you got for Christmas? Perhaps you're waiting for the cuts on your fingers to heal before giving it another try. You are not alone. The packaging of electronics and other small items has reached the point of outrage. A person practically needs the Jaws of Life to open anything. Normal scissors aren't sharp enough to cut through the packaging, and attacking the plastic with a knife could have disastrous consequences.

and free -- dual-enrollment program is the City University of New York's College Now, which began in the 1980s at Kingsborough Community College in Brooklyn and expanded in 2001 to CUNY's 16 other undergraduate college campuses. Today, there are nearly 20,000 students from 350 public high schools in the five boroughs who are earning college credits through the program. Students apply to take courses through their high schools, and are admitted based on their grades or test scores. There is no fee for the courses, and textbooks are also free. They can earn up to 16 credits by graduation, which can be transferred to many colleges.

WALLING--Mrs. William Hayden English, age 89 died on January 7, 2010 at her home in Paris. Also known as Odette "Allaire" for her work in the French resistance (which included torture, then imprisonment in Ravensbruck) during WWII, Mrs. Walling was decorated by ambassador Duff Cooper himself - in the British embassy in Paris - with the king's medal for courage. The beautiful, brave, brilliant and understandably tormented Odette Walling is survived only by her son - Christopher Walling - of Block Island, Rhode Island and New York City. Services at 11am: January 15, 2010 at St. Roch, Paris 75001 followed by burial in the Walling family vault at Pere Lachaise.

An article on Nov. 22 about the Dutch province of Friesland included a number of errors. In reference to Friesland's history, it was the feudal lords -- not the Romans -- who had no success conquering the Frisians in the 13th and 14th centuries. The Frisians were mostly Germanic people, not just Saxons, who had migrated there in the fourth and fifth centuries -- not the first century. Friesland was considered an autonomous and proud region up to the 1500s -- not ''through'' the Middle Ages. And it fell to the Habsburg Empire -- not to the Holy Roman Empire -- at the beginning of the 16th century. Also, while Friesland's agrarian landscape is indeed dotted with terps, mounds measuring from a few to 20 feet high, terps are also found in the North Sea marshlands, encompassing parts of Holland, Germany and Denmark; the mounds are not found just in current-day Friesland. Of the towns whose squares and alleys the writer explored, it was Stavoren -- not Hindeloopen -- that had a more prosperous seaport than Amsterdam up until the 1400s, not the 1700s. And the neighboring towns Stavoren and Hindeloopen, in addition to having a thriving trade with Scandinavia, also had a robust trade with the Baltic countries -- but not with Russia. A reader pointed out the errors in an e-mail message on Nov. 29; this correction was delayed for research.

COOPER--Emily Brudno, of Dorset, VT died January 3. Born in Ohio, she raised her family in New York with husband Carl Leeds, d. 1957. She moved to Vermont in 1978 and married Malcolm Cooper, d. 2005. George Kramer sat hunched on his stool behind the counter of the small hardware store on Coney Island Avenue, gazing out the window at the passing traffic. He was bundled up in a heavy sweater, a maroon wool cap folded above his ears. Toward the back of the store, beyond Mr. Kramer's field of vision, Isaac Abraham was rifling through a cabinet. Mr. Abraham, the store's owner for many years, knows Mr. Kramer about as well as anybody, and he was about to give a demonstration. Quietly, he removed a faucet knob from the cabinet and hid it behind his back. Then he approached the counter and clapped it down with a flourish.

An article in some editions last Sunday about suggestions from prominent New Yorkers for ways to improve New York in 2010 misstated the age of Donald Trump, who said the city's guardrails needed fixing. He is 63, not 62.

''For a while there, we had to tell people that if they wanted to buy a $1 million condo, they were looking at a one-bedroom,'' said Pamela Liebman, the president of the Corcoran Group.

It's shaping up to be an auspicious year for Christian tourism, thanks to two infrequent religious events in Europe. A half-million people are expected to turn up in the German village of Oberammergau, about 50 miles south of Munich, for the Passion Play, a depiction of the life and resurrection of Jesus that is held once a decade. The five-hour play is performed in two acts, with a long intermission.

The region can be broken down along well-known lines -- income, race, politics, to name a few. And, it turns out, one or two questions about an area's Netflix movie rental history can draw boundaries just as sharp. A statistical analysis of last year's 50 most popular Netflix titles in more than 500 ZIP codes in New York City and the surrounding suburbs reveal which areas are alike -- and different -- in terms of cultural taste. For example, the top 50 titles in ZIP code 10024 on the Upper West Side were much like those in Chappaqua and Maplewood, N.J.

GOULD--Lyttleton Bowen Purnell Jr.,of Hadlyme CT, died on 30 December, 2009 at the age of 90. The son of L. B. P. and Isabel Howell Gould, he was born in New York City on September 10, 1919. He graduated from Hotchkiss School in 1939 and Yale University in 1943 where he was a member of DKE and Elihu. From 1941-45, he first served as a lieutenant in the U.S. Navy and skipper of a subchaser, then executive officer of a destroyer escort in the Pacific. On June 21, 1947 he married Mary ("Sis") Krech Jackson Gould. Consummate lifelong educator, from 1945-58 Lytt first taught general science, American history and geography, also coaching football and baseball at Landon School Bethesda, MD, and then culminated as Head of the Middle School. During this time in l955 he was also a founding member of the St. Francis Episcopal Church in Potomac, MD. In 1958, Lytt became the headmaster of Far Hills Country Day School, Far Hills, NJ, resigning in 1963 to become a founder and the first headmaster (1963-73) of Purnell School in Pottersville, NJ. Lytt's vision for Purnell was focused on preparing girls in grades 10 to 12 for a full-filling and rewarding life through building self-confidence in an educational environment and curriculum that allowed for the discovery and development of each individual girl's unique talents and character. For Lytt, Sis and several key friends associates and advisors the course to a successful life lead through a range of possibilities including but not limited to a college education. Many of the over 1200 alumnae who graduated from Purnell keep in touch with the Gould's, visited them and recall them both with great affection and gratitude. Valued for demanding and setting high standards for himself and others, and for broad knowledge of education and administration, Lytt served as a member of the board of Miss Porter's School, Holton-Arms School, Garrison Forest School, Briarcliff College, Purnell, and others; a trustee of Mystic Seaport Museum and Lyme Academy of Fine Arts; and on the class council and as alumni fund agent of Yale Class of 1943. Upon "retiring" Lytt helped Sis, a pioneer in riding and carriage driving for the disabled through NAHRA, found what became High Hopes Therapeutic Riding Inc. in Old Lyme, CT and hosted equestrian events for the Special Olympics in 1995. He was a member of Essex Yacht Club, Hamburg Cove Yacht Club, Beachton Yacht Club, Old Lyme Country Club, Headmistress Association of the East, and Yale Club (New York). A keen sailor, in the summer Lytt and Sis could be found in Maine on their yawl, Tamaqua, or in residence in Long Cove on Vinalhaven, where they were renowned for their hospitality to many family and friends as well as to visiting yachtsmen--and letting all comers use guest moorings in return for a nominal donation to Purnell School or High Hopes. He and Sis had a large circle of devoted friends, many from Yale or Purnell, to the ends of their lives. Sis predeceased Lytt as did his sister Harriet Gould Rogers. He is survived by his sister Nancy Gould Ripley; son, Lyttleton B.P. Gould III; daughter, Isabel Cynthia Gould; step-daughters, Lylee M. S. Krech and Kara B. Seymour; ten grand-children; and thirteen great-grandchildren. Memorial services will be at High Hopes, Old Lyme, CT on Saturday, 24th April at 1pm. Interment private. In lieu of flowers, memorial donations may be made to Purnell School, 51 Pottersville Rd., Pottersville NJ 07979.

POWERS--Charles. Son of the late Dolly (Davis) and Percy Powers. Beloved husband of Roz and father of Alexander and Gregory, died after a short illness in Alexandria, VA on January 3rd. He was 64. A former longtime executive with Porter Novelli Public Relations. Former deputy assistant secretary of public affairs in the Reagan Treasury Department, deputy assistant secretary for public affairs at the Transportation Department, and various government positions. Charles was a graduate of the McBurney School, University of Miami and NYU Film School. Remembered with love by the Davis, Friedman and Levine families.

NOLAND--Kenneth. The American Academy of Arts and Letters notes with sorrow the death of our esteemed colleague. He took the painter's best tools--line and color--and shaped with them an art that both challenged and delighted. He turned optical designs and illusions into luminous objects of contemplation that will endure.

As authorities described an intense manhunt that led to the arrest of a man accused of breaching security at Newark Liberty International Airport last weekend, several of the man's friends said on Saturday that he was simply a young man moved by love. Authorities said the man, Haisong Jiang, 28, slipped into a terminal's secure area on Jan. 3, shutting down one of the country's biggest airports, delaying flights and setting off a long search that eventually brought detectives from the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey to Lincoln Avenue in Piscataway, N.J., where he rented a room in a single-family house.

AT Hickoree's Hard Goods, a six-month-old online shop with a temporary bricks-and-mortar space in Williamsburg, customers can stock up on an eclectic array of elegantly designed, no-nonsense items: canvas and leather tool bags, timeworn work boots, vintage handkerchiefs and denim shirts, homemade ''tabac'' scented eau de toilette, hand-printed reproductions of 1930s W.P.A. posters, chambray ties and scarves, the perfect crew-neck sweatshirt, astronaut ice cream, Japanese toothpaste and jars of Brooklyn-made pickled goods -- essentially everything you would ever need to make it through the month of January. ''So many stores do the same thing,'' said Emil Corsillo, an artist and graphic designer who opened the shop with his brother, Sandy. (The two also design a line of industrial-looking neckwear called the Hill-side.) ''We're looking to do something different.''

CANTOR--Marjorie (Hoffman), 88 died peacefully on October 31st, 2009 in New York City. She is survived by her daughter Nancy and Nancy's husband Steve (Brechin), her son Richard and his wife Andrea (Lilienthal), her four beloved grandchildren Maddy, Archie, Andrew and Eliza, her sister, Muriel Brotsky and her sister-in-law, Ruth Bernstein. A lifelong New Yorker, a graduate of Hunter College and Columbia University Teachers College, Marjorie worked passionately and tirelessly to understand and aid individuals and organizations for whom she cared deeply. Beginning with her work with migrant farm workers in upstate New York, she continued doing pioneering research for diverse groups such as The Girl Scouts of America and Vista. Marjorie found her true calling during Mayor John Lindsay's administration as Director of Research and Evaluation of the New York City department for the Aging, where she was the principal investigator of the 1970 landmark cross-ethnic study ''The Elderly in the Inner City of New York'', as well as nine other large scale studies during her 40 years in the field of aging. A past president of the Gerontological Society of America, she was a nationally and internationally recognized leader in the field of aging. At her death, Marjorie was an Emeritus Professor and Brookdale Distinguished Scholar of the Graduate School of Social Service of Fordham University, where she had been Associate Director of the University's Third Age Center and Scholar in Residence at the Lighthouse International. Her most recent work with ACRIA, directly a groundbreaking study of older adults with HIV in New York City, continued her lifelong commitment to illuminating the lives of those she felt underrepresented in our society. As the author of more then seventy-five publications, Marjorie served as a consultant to numerous Federal, State and local agencies and boards, including the Council of Senior Centers and Services of New York and Elder Share the Arts. She participated in both the 1980 and 1995 White House Conference on Aging, The International Forum on Aging in Beijing and gave the keynote address on the Symposium on the Jewish Family at the First World Conference on Jewish Services for the Elderly in Jerusalem. She will be deeply missed by her family, for whom she served as a loving beacon and exemplar to her friends and by her colleagues in the field of aging. Please join us for a memorial service celebrating her life and work on Saturday, January 16, 2010, 3:00pm at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81st Street.

WARTELL--Burton, age 83, beloved husband of Gerry, devoted father of George Wartell, Debbie Chapman, Joel and Karen Wartell, Karen and Mitchell Weissberg, Jill and Stephen Goldfine, loving grandfather and "Poppy" of Adam, Jared, Alix, Bari, Jeffrey, Jamie, Jake and Jonathan. Loved by all; he will remain in our hearts and memories forever. Memorial contributions may be directed to the Boca Pointe Cancer Research Papanicolaou. Art In 1917, the year Franz Kafka found out that he had tuberculosis, he wrote a short parable about the mysterious interplay between form and change: ''Leopards break into the temple and drink to the dregs what is in the sacrificial pitchers; this is repeated over and over again; finally it can be calculated in advance, and it becomes a part of the ceremony.''

SINCE Olympia Le-Tan began making them as a hobby a couple of years ago, her jean jackets, embroidered with literary quotations and song titles, have appeared in the pages of Jalouse magazine and on friends like Lou Doillon and Paul Sevigny. Now the Parisian girl-about-town has teamed up with the French brand A.P.C. to create a collection of them. The washed-denim jackets, which are available for men and women, bear three different lines: ''The Heart Is a Lonely Hunter'' (the title of Carson McCullers's debut novel and one of Ms. Le-Tan's favorite books); ''Art Is for Mobsters'' (a personal belief of Jean Touitou, A.P.C.'s congenitally droll designer); and ''People Never Notice Anything,'' courtesy of Holden Caulfield.

Theater I saw ''ONCE AND FOR ALL WE'RE GONNA TELL YOU WHO WE ARE SO SHUT UP AND LISTEN'' at the 2008 Edinburgh Festival Fringe when my wife was pregnant, which was just about the worst possible timing. This frenetic piece of physical theater fearlessly portrays childhood as it really is, especially the parts that parents (and those looking toward parenthood) would rather not see.

HOBBS--John Howard. Words cannot express how much your friendship and counsel throughout the years has meant to me and the countless others who have been fortunate to have been touched by your life. I will forever cherish the endless hours we spent in the office and in meetings with friends and colleagues preparing for the next step in Jennison's journey. You have had a profound impact on so many aspects of my life. Know you will walk with me every step I take throughout the remainder of my life. A day does not go by that I am not grateful for what you have taught me and joyous for the friendship we shared. I will miss you dearly. My sincere condolences to daughters Meg and Kate, and the extended family. Karen Kohler

Dance It's a balletic sort of week in New York City. Sunday is the last day to catch Pacific Northwest Ballet, performing pieces by Twyla Tharp and Benjamin Millepied, at the Joyce Theater before the company heads back to Seattle. But there is a great deal of classical dance to see this week -- all of it from the NEW YORK CITY BALLET, which is presenting an unusual and compelling combination of two full-length works and two mixed programs. On Tuesday there is this season's final performance of Balanchine's witty and poetic ''Midsummer Night's Dream,'' with Sara Mearns and Gonzalo Garcia in the roles of Titania and Oberon. On Wednesday comes Peter Martins's ''Romeo + Juliet'' with its pared down, contemporary designs by the Danish artist Per Kirkeby (whose work was given a major exhibition last year at the Tate Modern in London). The wonderful Sterling Hyltin and Robert Fairchild dance the title roles that evening, and on Friday, Erica Pereira, recently promoted to soloist, and Allen Peiffer take those parts. And on Saturday a mixed-bill evening provides more reasons to head to Lincoln Center: namely Daniel Ulbricht, Tyler Angle and Mr. Fairchild as the blithe sailors in Jerome Robbins's ''Fancy Free''; Maria Kowroski and Joaquin De Luz in Balanchine's ''Prodigal Son''; and Ashley Bouder, who made a dazzling debut in this role at just 17, in the Balanchine-Robbins collaboration, ''Firebird.'' Tuesday and Wednesday at 7:30 p.m., Thursday and Friday at 8 p.m., Saturday at 2 p.m. and 8 p.m., David H. Koch Theater, Lincoln Center, (212) 870-5570, nycballet.com; $20 to $125.

Warren Beatty may have notched thousands of bedposts in his bachelor days, if a new biography is to be believed, but only once has it been with the benefit of matrimony. On the other hand, vows are apparently a necessity for an Israeli man who at age 50 has just been granted his 11th divorce. The BBC reports that the man, from Jerusalem, usually divorces after two years and immediately goes out bride hunting. Or perhaps bride reeling. ''I send out a hook in all directions, and the fish come on their own,'' the man, who was not named, said. According to the rabbinical court that announced the divorce, 11 is a record for Jews in Israel. The court praised the man's adherence to religious procedure. Under Jewish law, a man seeking a divorce grants his wife a ''get,'' which declares, ''You are hereby permitted to all men.''

THE NEWS The world's tallest building, the 160-story, 2,717-foot Burj Khalifa, officially opened in Dubai. BEHIND THE NEWS Begun five years ago at the height of a boom in Dubai, the tower opened at a bad time. Long the brash striver among the United Arab Emirates, Dubai in recent months has been so beset by debts and a real estate crash that it turned to Abu Dhabi for a $10 billion bailout loan -- and then renamed the building, begun as the Burj Dubai, in honor of the emir of Abu Dhabi, Sheik Khalifa bin Zayed al-Nahyan. The Burj's apartments and commercial space are said to be 90 percent sold, but at a cost: some other premium buildings in Dubai are lying half-empty.

The holiday tourists had barely left the city when a deep freeze brought out stylish New Yorkers in their bundled-up best, several wearing enormous possum circle collars on their way to work. Not even the ice sculptures in Boston -- Michelangelo sculpturing David on the Common; Winslow Homer's ''Fisherman'' in Copley Square -- could compete with the beauty of Mother Nature's slipcovering of the Bryant Park Fountain with eight-foot icicles. In the park's outdoor bar, a fire pit, electric heaters and free blankets were comforts to frosty fingers and toes.

HUTTON--Robert W.,died peacefully at home in Seattle on January 5, at the age of 88. Bob was a native of the northwest, a member and supporter of numerous local civic organizations, a successful business executive and a dedicated husband and father. With his wife Charlotte, Bob lived much of his life in the Seattle area, in addition to 25 years in Greenwich, Connecticut. Bob was born in Olympia, Washington on April 28, 1921 to George W. Hutton and Elsie Doragh Hutton. He grew up in Vancouver and Olympia, and graduated from Vancouver High School in 1938. He attended the University of Washington, graduating in 1943. At the University, he was a member of Chi Psi fraternity, the Senior Manager of the Crew, a member of Oval Club and Fir Tree, and a student of law and business. Following service as a Captain in the U.S. Army during World War II, Bob attended the Stanford Graduate School of Business, where he received an MBA degree in 1948. Bob's distinguished business career was focused in the cement industry. Following graduate school he worked for three years at the Seattle First National Bank, prior to starting Bellingham Builders Supply in Bellingham, Washington. He joined Lone Star Industries, at that time the largest producer of cement in the United States, in 1965 and became CEO, based in New York, 1972. He served as a Director of the American Mining Congress, as President of the Portland Cement Association, and was an active leader in the industry, throughout the world. An avid sailor, Bob campaigned a series of ocean racing sailboats called "Tatoosh," with notable national and international success. A highlight of his life was being selected to represent the United States in 1980 at the Sardinia Cup, considered at the time to be a World Championship of ocean racing. Tatoosh finished in second place overall, leading the U.S. team to victory. Bob is survived by his wife, Charlotte; their daughter, Ann Hutton of Friday Harbor, WA and her children, Meghan and Brianna; and their son, Tom Hutton of Atherton, California, his wife, Wende and their children Cameron and Rachel. A memorial service will be held at Epiphany Parish on Saturday, January 16 at 1pm, followed by a reception at The Seattle Yacht Club at 2:30pm. In lieu of flowers, please send any donations to the Pacific Science Center or a charity of your choice.

VAN MIERLO--Laurel, born April 26, 1925, passed away surrounded by her family in Albuquerque, NM on January 5, 2010. Laurel began her eclectic career as an actress on Broadway and in Television. As Laurel Shelby, she sang and performed through the 1940's and 50's. During the 60's, Laurel worked on Fashion Avenue. In 1978, Laurel moved to Vieques, PR, reinventing herself at age 53 and becoming one of the island's first realtors. Laurel is survived by her loving family; beloved husband Adam; daughter Pamela and son-in- law Alex Camacho, daughter Patricia van Mierlo and son- in-law Tom Shields; son Chris van Mierlo and daughter-in-law Diane, grandchildren Julian, Isabel, Charlotte, and Simon Camacho and Michael, Douglas, and Jill van Mierlo; brothers Dr. Jon Abrams and Jerry Abrams. She was predeceased by her daughter Abbe Rollins. Family and friends will deeply miss Laurel, a forthright woman who helped blaze our trail. We will continue the journey she so enjoyed with her in our hearts.

The region can be broken down along well-known lines -- income, race, politics, to name a few. And, it turns out, one or two questions about an area's Netflix movie rental history can draw boundaries just as sharp. A statistical analysis of last year's 50 most popular Netflix titles in more than 500 ZIP codes in New York City and the surrounding suburbs reveal which areas are alike -- and different -- in terms of cultural taste. For example, the top 50 titles in ZIP code 10024 on the Upper West Side were much like those in Chappaqua and Maplewood, N.J.

ADAMS--John, of Locust, NJ, age 87, born in Paget, Bermuda, the youngest of the four sons of Henry Coolidge Adams and Louise Scarritt Adams, died peacefully at home with his family on January 5. Jack served on the Naval Ship USS Idaho during World War II. He attended Columbia Business School and enjoyed a successful career in finance in a New York City utility company. A member of the Rumson Country Club and the Sea Bright Beach Club, Jack was an avid sailor and loved ocean racing which began in 1956 with the Newport-Bermuda Race. He also enjoyed many hours on golf courses and ski slopes. Jack in known by many for his wonderful, bright approach to life and great sense of humor. His enthusiasm and fine principles were evident in every endeavor. He is survived by Ellen Noonan Adams, wife of 63 years, daughters Mary Minturn Adams of New York, Ann Adams Royal. In lieu of flowers, the family requests donations be sent to All Saints' Memorial Chapel, P.O. Box 326, Navesink, NJ 07752. A memorial service will be held in the spring.

An article last Sunday about couples who buy homes together before getting married misstated the income limits of the federal first-time home buyer tax credit. For purchases after Nov. 6, 2009, the full credit is available to married couples filing joint returns with modified adjusted gross incomes of up to $225,000, not $150,000; and for individuals with incomes of up to $125,000, not $75,000. (The lower numbers were the limits for purchases before Nov. 6.) The article also misstated whether the tax credit can be divided between unmarried buyers. Indeed it can, if both buyers qualify for the credit.

You have to go back to the finale of the movie ''Slap Shot'' to find a scene as ludicrous as the one in Chekhov, Russia, on Saturday. But there it was, starring Jaromir Jagr and a cast of players and referees from the Kontinental Hockey League. A series of brawls in the first four minutes of a game between Vityaz Chekhov and Avangard Omsk resulted in the assessment of 671 penalty minutes against Jagr and 30 other players -- so many that the game had to be suspended because neither team had enough players to continue.

Beloved husband of Estelle and father of Mark and Andrea, Nancy and Andy, and grandfather of Jeffrey, Alyssa, Rebecca, Mollie, and Melissa. Devoted friend of the Levitz and Drogy families. Graduate of Townsend Harris High School and CCNY. Distinguished CPA. Veteran of WWII Army Air Corps. His life was dedicated to his family and helping others. He will always be remembered and greatly missed by all who knew him.

Displaying images of fetuses on her computer screen, Dr. Choi Anna described what happens to them during an abortion. For years, she said, she washed her hands in contrition after each one she performed. Her colleague Dr. Shim Sang-duk said that until it halted the practice in September, their Ion Women's Clinic in Seoul did 30 abortions a month, twice the number of babies delivered there. Nearly all were illegal.

HOBBS--John Howard, a pioneer in the investment management industry and a philanthropist avid in his support of education and civil rights, died January 3 at his home in Charlemont, MA at the age of 73. John co-founded Jennison Associates, one of Wall Street's first independent institutional investment management firms, in 1969 with Spiros "Sig" Segalas, Jennison's current president and chief investment officer, and five other Wall Street investment professionals. At the time, institutional investment portfolios were managed primarily by large bank investment departments, insurance companies, and investment counselors. John and his colleagues built Jennison with the belief that in-house fundamental research and specialized investment teams would generate superior long-term investment returns. Jennison, now a subsidiary of Prudential Financial, manages more than $90 billion in assets for major institutions, mutual funds, and private individuals. Many of its existing client relationships were established while John was chief executive officer. John was instrumental in Jennison's expansion beyond equities into the institutional fixed income market with the 1975 acquisition of Carter, Doyle & Co. He was named Jennison's president and chief executive officer in 1976 and became chairman in 1994. In 1996, he took on added responsibilities as president of institutional asset management for the global money management group of Prudential. In 2000, he took the helm of Prudential's entire equity asset management business, including the active quantitative management firm Quantitative Management Associates. He served as Jennison's vice chairman from late 2002 until he retired in 2003. "John was the definition of magnanimous," Mr. Segalas said. "His work ethic was second to none. His humor was infectious, his laughter ever present, and his eyes always had a twinkle. He will be deeply missed by his many friends at Jennison." Most recently, John was vice chairman and chairman of the audit committee of the Madison Asset Management Group, a global infrastructure investment specialist. Madison is led by former CEOs and senior managing directors of some of Wall Street's most prestigious firms, as well as former cabinet officials, including a U.S. Secretary of Transportation. John was born in Boston. His parents Howard and Anne (Williams) both worked at Simplex Wire & Cable in Cambridge. He lived in Somerville before the family moved to Newton Highlands, where he spent most of his youth. In 1954, he graduated from Newton High School, where he debated and played viola in the school orchestra. With his sisters, Eleanor and Margot, who played violin, he formed the Hobbs Trio, playing in the community. His leadership qualities made him president of the student body and many clubs. John attended Wesleyan University and earned an A.B. from Harvard College in 1960. In 1965, he received an M.B.A. with High Distinction from Harvard Business School. He served in the Air Force Reserve, and spent a year as a Harvard teaching assistant before joining Waddell & Reed, where he became vice president and manager of investment research. John, with his late wife Liz, had a lifelong commitment to making things better for others. He supported education, one of his greatest passions, through numerous educational institutions and philanthropic organizations, especially the Harvard Graduate School of Education. In the 1990s, as co-chairs of the Harvard Graduate School of Education capital campaign steering committee, John and Liz helped raise $111 million dollars, the largest sum ever raised by a school of education. They endowed the John H. and Elisabeth A. Hobbs Chair of Cognition and Education held by Prof. Howard Gardner. They also helped many students cover education costs through the Hobbs Fellowship. John continued his involvement as a member of the dean's advisory board. He also supported Harvard University and the Harvard Business School, serving on the executive committee of the Harvard University committee on university resources and as a member of the board of directors of the associates of the Harvard Business School. He was a trustee of Wesleyan University, a trustee of Milano the New School for Management and Urban Policy, a trustee and president of the board of the Hewitt School in New York, a trustee and chairman of the board of Proctor Academy in Andover, NH, and a trustee of the Academy at Charlemont in Charlemont, MA. His devotion to child education and development extended beyond his support of academia. He was chairman of the board of Common Cents, a non-profit organization that creates and manages service-learning programs for young people. Its best-known program, the Penny Harvest, is the largest child philanthropy program in the U.S. John was also a director and chairman of the board of the Foundation for Child Development and the William T. Grant Foundation. He also helped found the Professional Association for Investment Communications Resources, which seeks to raise communication standards in the investment management industry. John had an affinity for political affairs, as well. He and former U.S. Sen. Don Riegle were office mates at Harvard Business School. John supported Sen. Riegle's first Congressional campaign in 1966 and continued to support him over the years as a counselor and friend, including serving as financial chair in several campaigns. John supported and contributed to other well-known Democratic political leaders, as well. Reflecting on his friend, Sen. Riegle remembers "His encouragement, faith and active help were solid rock under my feet. John was a truly selfless man. Everything he did over the span of his life was directed at helping others. Liz, his wife, was just as giving. My wife Lori and I feel profoundly blessed to have been in their circle of friends." John, husband of the late Elisabeth Hobbs, is survived by his two daughters, Margaret M. Hobbs and Kate H. Hobbs, and his son George C Hobbs; his two sisters, Eleanor Richardson of Niantic, CT and Margaret Sudbury of Winchester, MA; and many nephews, nieces, cousins and friends who will miss him dearly. A memorial service will be held at the Harvard Club of New York, 35 West 44 St., New York, NY on Friday, January 15 at 11am, followed by a reception (noon to 1pm).Donations in his memory may be made to the Harvard Graduate School of Education Hobbs Fellowship, 13 Appian Way, Cambridge, MA 02138; Wesleyan University, University Relations, 318 High St, Middletown, CT, 06459; the Foundation for Child Development, 295 Madison Ave, NY, NY, 10017; and the Academy at Charlemont, 1359 Rt. 2 the Mohawk Trail, Charlemont, MA 01339.

Fethiye Cetin recalled the day her identity shattered. She was a young law student when her beloved maternal grandmother, Seher, took her aside and told her a secret she had hidden for 60 years: that Seher was born a Christian Armenian with the name Heranus and had been saved from a death march by a Turkish officer, who snatched her from her mother's arms in 1915 and raised her as Turkish and Muslim.

LEVINE--George, 1923-2009, 86, educator, activist, artist, songwriter, performer; under the stage name of "George Lorrie", he hosted the "Folklore with Lorrie" on WNJR and "George Lorrie's Grand Concert of Folk Music" on WNCN, WBAI and other stations in the 50 and early 60s. A father of "interconnect" who battled then monopoly AT&T, appearing before the New York Public Service Commission and others on behalf of the public and municipalities to hold down telephone rates. Died on December 29, 2009 after a long illness, borne with grace. Survived by sister Rosalie, companion Ruth, sons Seth and Jeremy, daughter-in-law Patricia and grandchildren Erica and Joshua. We will never forget and always love you!

GREEN groups were full of praise on Thursday for the Environmental Protection Agency after it proposed the strictest standards to date for smog. Although auto tailpipes have historically been a major source of smog, the auto industry said that it had largely dealt with that issue. Ground-level ozone reductions, the carmakers said, were more likely to come from stationary sources like power plants.

GOWANUS HOUSES, a complex of 14 red-brick buildings that sits not far from its namesake canal in Brooklyn, opened on a June day in 1949, flush with the optimism that wreathed new housing developments for low-income New Yorkers. Among the 1,100-plus original families was a young couple named Leslie and Victoria Baskett Flowers. He worked in a printing firm and she was a welder. The fifth of their seven children was born in 1958. The little girl was christened Renee, but by the time she was a student at Hunter College, everyone was calling her Juice, thanks to her inexplicable preference for orange juice over more popular items like soda.

The Clippers might have felt a little like Cinderella after their 102-91 home victory over the Lakers at Staples Center on Wednesday. Behind 25 points and 10 assists from Baron Davis, the Clippers overcame their far more glamorous and successful hometown rivals and housemates. It was their first victory over the Lakers since April 2007. Clippers center Chris Kaman chipped in with 21 points and 14 rebounds in the victory. Kaman, who leads the team with 20.4 points per game, is far from a household name. But this season he has been among the best centers in the N.B.A.'s Western Conference, if not the league.

BESSENYEY--Baroness Eva Barcza, born December 19, 1924 in Szentmartonkata, Hungary. Daughter of Eva (Koos) and Lajos Barcza, educated in Budapest and moved to Lausanne, Switzerland in 1943, where she met Francis Bessenyey. They thoroughly disliked each other at first, only to be drawn close upon the German invasion of Hungary. Eva and Francis were married in 1946, and thereafter emigrated to the United States, where they settled in a five story walkup in New York City - "A damn hot place." Eva worked for the French bank Societe Generale, and to Francis' dismay, earned more than he did. Eva and Francis had three daughters: Margit, Ilona and Kristina. Eva was the consummate mother, caregiver and peacemaker. She knitted, sewed, cooked, managed three kids' schedules for the next 20 years and, according to Francis' own words, "kept him in line." She supported Francis in his professional life, and ensured that he remained an integral part of the family. An avid reader and student of life, Eva knew more than many scholars on a myriad of subjects. Once the children were older, Eva worked for FACSEA, the French Cultural Service, from which she retired in 1990. She received the "Ordre des Palmes Academique" for her service to France. Her retirement took her and Francis to Alaska, Florida and Montana for visits with her children and grandchildren. Eva loved opera, Jeopardy, Antiques Roadshow and New York Times Crossword puzzles, which she completed in ink. An expert translator, and despite a health condition that ultimately left her blind, Eva put into English many important books related to Hungarian politics. She was active on the boards of several charitable Hungarian organizations. Since the 1950s, Eva and Francis regularly traveled to Hamilton, Montana to visit Francis' stepmother on her ranch the Bitter Root Stock Farm. Eventually they took over the ranch, moving there full time in 2009. Eva passed away on December 27th with her husband holding her hand and her family at her side.

ADAMS--William Healey, 63 years young, passed away on January 3, 2010, after a two and half year battle with ALS (Lou Gehrig's disease). In an email to his daughter on New Year's Day, he said he would "keep fighting." Surrounding his bedside were his wife of 38 years, Ellen (Dale), his two children, Brooke and Beau. Bill Adams was born in Charlotte, North Carolina on November 16, 1946, the son of Mary Frances (Healey) and Thaddeus Adams. He was predeceased by his parents and his two brothers, Thaddeus and Douglas. Bill Adams grew up in Charlotte, was a star athlete in high school and was recruited to play basketball at the University of North Carolina (Chapel Hill) by the legendary coach, Dean Smith. Upon achieving distinction as a freshman, Bill was excused from basketball by Dean Smith when the coach discovered that Bill had lost a kidney playing football in high school. Coach Smith remained a mentor and close friend throughout Bill's life. After graduating from UNC in 1969, Bill moved to New York where he joined the Bank of New York. In 1976 Bill Adams and Ellen moved to San Francisco, where he helped to open the corporate branch of the Chemical Bank. The Adams family, now including Brooke and Beau, moved back to New York in 1981. However, their experience of living in San Francisco was to draw them back in 1984. Prior to his current position as a managing director of Chilton Investment Company, he was the CFO of the Bank of San Francisco and managing director at Bankers Trust for its Pacific Rim private banking. Bill's athleticism was aptly demonstrated on the golf course. He loved the competition and the camaraderie inherent in golf. He was a member of the San Francisco Golf Club, the Cypress Point Club, the Burlingame Country Club and the US Seniors Golf Association. In addition, he enjoyed his friendships at the Pacific Union Club and in New York at the Brook and the Racquet & Tennis Club (where he was an accomplished squash player). While at UNC, Bill Adams was a member of Delta Kappa Epsilon fraternity and the Lodge. Despite being afflicted with ALS, Bill Adams established and was central to the William H. Adams Foundation for ALS Research, which actively supports ongoing research in the effort to find a cure for ALS. Since its formation in 2008, the Foundation has contributed over $1 million to fund cutting edge research under the sponsorship of Dr. Jeffrey Rothstein at the Packard Center at Johns Hopkins. One of Bill's most cherished moments was the August 31st, 2009 ALS fundraiser organized by the Adams Foundation and hosted by golf legend, Tom Watson. Bill Adams was devoted to his family, and their time together, both at home and traveling, was most important to him. He is survived by his wife Ellen, his two children, his daughter's husband, Zach Read, and two grandchildren, Isabelle and William ("Briggs") Read. There will be a memorial service at 3pm on Thursday, the 14th of January at St. Ignatius Church in San Francisco. In lieu of flowers, donations in Bill's memory can be made to the William H. Adams Foundation for ALS Research, Deutsche Bank Alex Brown, 101 California Street, 46th Floor, San Francisco, California 94111, attention: Lisa Walsh.

An article on Dec. 27 about the death of Edward M. Kennedy in August referred incorrectly to the assassination of his brother President John F. Kennedy, and a correction in this space last Sunday erroneously corrected the length of his tenure in the Senate. The president was assassinated in 1963, the year after Edward Kennedy was elected to the Senate -- not the same year. And as the article correctly reported, Senator Kennedy served 46 years -- not 47 as the correction said. (The correction also erred in stating that the length of tenure was incorrect in Mr. Kennedy's obituary, in two other articles on Aug. 27 and Aug. 28 and in an editorial on Aug. 28. All four correctly reported the tenure as 46 years.)

STILL haven't managed to open those blister-packed headphones you got for Christmas? Perhaps you're waiting for the cuts on your fingers to heal before giving it another try. You are not alone. The packaging of electronics and other small items has reached the point of outrage. A person practically needs the Jaws of Life to open anything. In a St. John's University English class the other day, 10 students tackled George Orwell's ''1984'' like generations of collegians before them. But while there was plenty of higher-order thinking, the class -- and the students -- were technically still in high school. The college class is one of 16 being taught at Jericho High School here on Long Island, half of them added in the past two years through new partnerships with St. John's in Queens, Molloy College in Rockville Centre and the Rochester Institute of Technology. The Jericho students simultaneously fulfill their high school graduation requirements and, for a reduced fee, earn college credit.

''While in Russia, I came to have a very high respect for the integrity and the honesty of the Soviet leaders,'' he says. ''I respected the honesty of their convictions, and they respected mine. I also came back with a firm conviction that these people were sincerely devoted to world peace.''

The Wall Street Journal has a fascinating article today by Yaroslav Trofimov about how the U.N. is working in rural Afghanistan to vaccinate kids against polio -- and carrying letters from Mullah Omar to protect them from local militants and fundamentalists. The laissez-passers from Mullah Omar are the only way for health workers to reach the more violent parts of rural Afghanistan in safety. It's obviously embarrassing to have to carry permission slips from the Taliban, but, hey, that's just the only way to work in those areas.I think that's a useful way to think about education in rural parts of Afghanistan as well. Some aid groups are already negotiating with the Taliban about putting schools in certain areas that the Taliban control. The biggest concern for the Taliban has been that boys and girls be separate and that the girls are taught by a woman. Their other big issue is that the school books can't have a photo of President Karzai. With those conditions they have, sometimes, been willing to allow girls' and boys' education. That's not going to work everywhere, and the Taliban will be more suspicious of schools than of vaccinations -- but I think it's worth trying in more areas. If NGO's can get some Taliban approval to work in some areas, that would be a step forward.

On Sunday, Croatians gave Ivo Josipovic a landslide victory in the country's presidential election despite an ad campaign by his main rival that sought to portray the avant-garde composer and law professor as a Dr. Evil-like figure scheming to return the nation to communism.

Spider-Man and Tobey Maguire are parting ways. Mr. Maguire was set to reprise his leading role in "Spider-Man 4" in May 2011 with Sam Raimi, who directed the first three installments, returning to the helm. But following disagreements about the creative direction of the film (Hollywood translation: the script wasn't so good and there were conflicting casting strategies), Mr. Raimi opted to move on, according to Deadline.com. Rather than move forward with a different director, Sony decided to push the button on a "Spider-Man" reboot that it has been simultaneously developing. In a press release Monday afternoon, Sony confirmed that the next "Spider-Man" movie will take Peter Parker back to high school. The new chapter, written by James Vanderbilt ("Zodiac"), will have a new cast and director and focus on "a teenager dealing with both contemporary human problems and amazing super-human crises," Sony said. The target release date is now summer 2012. Together, the first three "Spider-Man" movies sold over $1 billion in tickets at North American theaters, according to Box Office Mojo.

Millburn Police are asking for the public's assistance in an investigation by the Millburn Detective Bureau into the theft of an $18,000 sable coat from Saks Fifth Avenue at the Mall at Short Hills on Saturday (Jan. 9). An employee of Saks reported that, at about 2:15 p.m., she saw a woman remove the security tag on a coat in the fur rack. The employee took the coat from the woman and started to call for help when she saw the woman take another coat, described as a "bleached knitted sable coat," and run to the parking deck labeled Teal, Level 1. The suspect got into a black Maxima with two men inside, and they all fled, the woman reported. Anyone with information is asked to call detectives at 973-654-7017.The police reported a number of other shoplifting incidents at the Mall at Short Hills in the last week, but none as costly as the Saks theft. ~Lois DeSocio

If you happen to be in Paris this week, it's your last chance to see "Grandi Legni," an exhibition of work by the Italian architect and designer Andrea Branzi at the Azzedine Alaia Gallery. Organized by two well-known Milan galleries -- Design Gallery Milano and Nilufar -- the exhibition features large-scale, mixed-media works that are the latest in Branzi's continuing investigation of the anthropological, "animist roots" of design. Branzi, who was part of the radical architecture studio Archizoom in the 1960s and was a co-founder of the Domus Academy, feels that in its quest for formal perfection, contemporary design has hit a self-referential brick wall. In these seemingly primitive, totemic pieces, he employs old wood beams (the "big woods" of the exhibition's title), semiprecious stones, mosaic and a new printing technology from 3M to search for the soul of design between the ancient and the modern.

To some, the picture speaks 1,000 words and four of them are: the Packers were robbed. The image of Cardinals cornerback Michael Adams with his index finger hooked on Packers quarterback Aaron Rodgers's face mask was captured far and wide, sparking the question of whether it was a penalty and why it did not negate the fumble Adams caused. The question gets louder because the fumble Adams caused turned into the game-winning touchdown in overtime of the N.F.C. wild card playoff game when linebacker Karlos Dansby ran it into the end zone.

I don't put a great deal of stock in overly precise efforts to pair food and wine. I understand the desire to get things right - who wants wine and food to blot each other out? - but obsessive efforts, special methods, pairing wheels, etc., hold very little interest for me. I just want to have a good meal, with good wine, and I want to enjoy them both, together. I don't think selecting proper wines is a problem, once you get in the habit of drinking wine with your meals.

The actors James Roday (Shawn Spencer on the television series "Psych") and Michael Weston (Lucas Douglas on television's "House") will star as two friends who face the consequences of a weekend of debauchery in "Extinction," a new play by Gabe McKinley, a publicist for the production said on Monday. The production is scheduled to run at Off Broadway's Cherry Lane Theater from Feb. 13 to March 14. Directed by Wayne Kasserman, the cast will also include Amanda Detmer and Stefanie E. Frame, who appeared with the two men in a run of the play in Los Angeles last fall.

Simon Cowell, the music impresario and tough-talking "American Idol" judge you love to hate, will leave "American Idol," the Fox reality competition, after the current season, he said on Monday. Mr. Cowell made the announcement during a Fox presentation at the Television Critics Association press tour in California. Though there had been speculation about Mr. Cowell's status with the show for several weeks, he said that he had only formally reached an agreement with Fox "at half-past-10" this morning to bring another reality series, "The X Factor," to the network next year. Mr. Cowell said he would leave "American Idol" to focus on that show. Bill Carter is at the event and will have updates on Media Decoder.

"Avatar" has been lauded for its technological wizardry and the all-encompassing movie experience it offers. As for the writing: not so much. He'll face off against Scott Neustadter and Michael H. Weber for "(500) Days of Summer"; John Lucas and Scott More for the "The Hangover"; Mark Boal for "The Hurt Locker"; and Joel and Ethan Coen for "A Serious Man."

Even bogus boxing can be hazardous on a Broadway stage. Santino Fontana, who plays the young suitor Rodolpho in the current Broadway production of "A View From the Bridge," remains out of the show since sustaining a minor concussion from a boxing scene with Liev Schreiber's character during a performance New Year's weekend. Mr. Fontana left the show temporarily under doctor's orders, according to a statement on Thursday from a publicist for the show, and he was scheduled to still be off for Monday night's performance. It is not clear when he will return. The role of Rodolpho is being played by the understudy, Morgan Spector. Mr. Fontana sustained the concussion during a scene in which Rodolpho is drawn into sparring by Eddie Carbone (Mr. Schreiber), the jealous uncle of Rodolpho's love interest, Catherine (Scarlett Johansson). No one from the production was available to comment on Monday about Mr. Fontana's health or whether the boxing scene has been re-choreographed, the publicist said.

We have a winner: as expected, the Museum of Contemporary Art in Los Angeles said on Monday that it would name Jeffrey Deitch as its director. Mr. Deitch, the New York gallery owner, has also helped start an art advisory service for clients at Citibank, and founded his Deitch Projects in 1996. Mr. Deitch also managed Sotheby's 20th-century Art Gallery Program, and in 1997 Sotheby's bought 50 percent of Deitch Projects, a relationship that has since dissolved. Other contenders for the position were believed to include Tobias Meyer, the head of Sotheby's contemporary art department worldwide and Sotheby's principal auctioneer, and Samuel Keller, the art-fair impresario who ran Art Basel and Art Basel Miami Beach until he became director of the Beyeler Foundation in Riehen, Switzerland.

In the 1990s, Starbucks was opening one new store per day. Green mermaid logos popped up on retail facades everywhere, sometimes within feet of one another, making the sameness from store to store all the more noticeable. But it's not the '90s anymore, and when Starbucks stock began dropping in 2007, the Seattle-based company realized, among other things, that the cookie-cutter approach to store design had fallen out of fashion. Last year, Starbucks announced it would renovate its thousands of company-owned stores, in 52 countries, to be more sustainable and to look, well, less global and more local.

The hard-to-open packaging on Barbie dolls and other gifts underneath the Christmas tree has left many consumers ripping. Yes, these plastic fortresses deter shoplifters and help reduce the wastefulness of bulky cardboard boxes, manufacturers say, but at what cost?

There was a time when pasta dishes dressed with just cheese, cream or milk were popular, at least with me and my family, but today they seem stodgy and fat. In the new social media order, everyone will broadcast everything about themselves all the time, and generation gaps will be created at lightning speed. Major awards shows are no exception: both Adam Shankman, a producer of the Oscars, and Ricky Gervais, the host of the Golden Globes, have taken to Twitter. But over the weekend, they revealed very differing takes. While Mr. Shankman, also a judge on "So You Think You Can Dance," was busy promoting the Academy Award dance auditions, asking his followers what they thought the 10 best picture nominees would be, and, like everyone else, admitting an obsession with "Jersey Shore," Mr. Gervais was more reserved.

Our colleague Christopher Drew writes today about the deluge of video coming from remotely piloted aerial drones flying reconnaissance in Afghanistan. This flood of video data is just the tip of the iceberg. The Air Force, for instance, has 195 Predators and 28 Reapers, and plans to increase the number of cameras that drones carry. Soon, the larger Reaper drones could record in 65 different directions at once.

Theater people are said to live for applause, and London theatergoers, although slightly less enthusiastic than their New York counterparts, are usually happy to oblige at the drop of a curtain. So it was strange -- and oddly refreshing -- to experience the loud silence that greeted the end of the first act of "Our Class," which I saw over the weekend in one of its final performances at the National Theater, where it opened in September. I was reminded that sometimes the sound of no hands clapping is a greater tribute than the collective clamor of many.

In a press kit for Josephus Thimister's first haute couture collection in a decade, in Paris on Jan. 24, I came across an intriguing photograph taken for Vogue by Steven Meisel. A millennial portrait of youngish world-shakers, it included Thimister, Hedi Slimane, Veronique Branquinho, Roberto Menichetti, and Miguel Adrover. In a fairly short time, these designers were to move away from the frontline of fashion-Mr. Slimane to photography, Mr. Thimister to Charles Jourdan-while others in the portrait, notably Nicolas Ghesquiere and Hussein Chalayan, were to hold our attention and still others, like Olivier Theyskens, seemed to enter a stage of limbo, between jobs. A number of stars are not included in the portrait-no Alber Elbaz, who was then leaving Saint Laurent for Lanvin, no Phoebe Philo, who was at Chloé at the time, and no Christopher Bailey, who perhaps had not yet proven himself at Burberry. Maybe the only thing group portraits tell us is to beware of group portraits. This is a highly unstable business, as we've learned in the last few years.

Same-Sex Marriage Heads to Court | The first federal trial over the issue of same sex marriage begins on Monday in San Francisco. It will address whether the 2008 ballot vote to ban same-sex marriage in the state was unconstitutional. The trial is unusual on several fronts: It will include testimony from two gay couples at the center of the case, video coverage will be available at some point on YouTube and the two lawyers representing the gay couples were courtroom adversaries who argued opposite sides in the battle over the fate of the 2000 presidential election. [The San Francisco Chronicle, The New York Times]

McHUGH--Peter S.,of New York City died at home on January 5 after a protracted battle with prostate cancer. Born in 1929, Peter spent his youth in Los Angeles. As a young man he took up the family business, working as an actor both on stage and in early television. He often toured summer stock and appeared regularly opposite his father, Frank McHugh, in shows such as Ah, Wilderness. He served in the US Air Force in the Korean War. He studied at Palos Verdes College, UCLA, and earned his Ph.D. in Sociology at Northwestern University. His work as a professor led him from University of Delaware to Columbia University to Goldsmiths, University of London, and finally to York University, Toronto. A frequent contributor to scholarly journals, Peter also authored or co-authored a number of influential books in his field including: Defining The Situation: The Organization of Meaning in Social Interaction, and On The Beginning of Social Inquiry. Peter's love of discourse bestowed those around him with his remarkable curiosity, erudition, charm and well-honed sense of humor. His commitment to close friends and family will be deeply missed. Peter was a devoted husband to the late Patricia, a supportive father to Caitlin and Joshua, and a dear grandfather to Calder. He was a thoroughly dedicated son to his mother, the late Dorothy Spencer McHugh.

The Treasury's schedule of financing this week includes Monday's regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday. The rate on the six-month issue was 0.14 percent, and the rate on the four-week issue was 0.02 percent.

LAURA VEIRS ''July Flame'' (Raven Marching Band) ''Honey wax/melt it down/make your heart molten somehow,'' sings the Portland, Ore., singer-songwriter Laura Veirs in ''Summer Is the Champion,'' drawing out her vowels cleanly. The song begins with a finger-strummed nylon-string guitar, takes on horn-section harmony over wakeful rhythm and piano chords on every beat, and finally graduates to sumptuous pools of pedal-steel guitar, Neil Young in 1971 style.

BURKINA ELECTRIC ''Paspanga'' (Cantaloupe Music) The West African interior meets the jet stream, and the digital slipstream, on ''Paspanga,'' the full-length debut by Burkina Electric. A sleek, kinetic album, it documents a continuing project spanning several continents, with members based in Burkina Faso, Germany and New York. Whatever awkward dislocations that might suggest, they're nowhere to be found in the music, which imagines a global dance floor.

REISMAN--Stanley W.,of Boynton Beach, FL and New Rochelle, NY died January 6, 2010. Beloved husband of Estelle and father of Mark and Andrea, Nancy and Andy, and grandfather of Jeffrey, Alyssa, Rebecca, Mollie, and Melissa. Devoted friend of the Levitz and Drogy families. Graduate of Townsend Harris High School and CCNY. Distinguished CPA. Veteran of WWII Army Air Corps. His life was dedicated to his family and helping others. He will always be remembered and greatly missed by all who knew him.

LERNER--Henry Robert, 81, beloved husband, adored father, grandfather, friend and trusted advisor, died on January 8 after a 35 year battle with Parkinson's Disease. Henry was born in Belgium and emigrated to New York during WWII. Fifty years ago, Henry married Renee Orlan and together had three children, Stephen, Claire and Alan. Henry attended CCNY and George Washington Law School. He was an accomplished intellectual property lawyer, an avid fan of classical music and opera, and an enthusiastic tennis player. Devoted to the State of Israel, he led a young Zionist organization in the 1950s. He served in the US Army in the Korean War and on the Board of Education of Englewood Cliffs, NJ. He will be deeply missed. Henry is survived by Renee, his three children and six grandchildren, his brother Marcel Lerner and sister Irene Moshief. Services will be held at Gutterman and Musicant, 402 Park Street, Hackensack, NJ on Monday at 12:30pm. Shiva will be observed at the Lerner residence on Monday and Tuesday 6pm to 8:30pm. Suggested donations to the Parkinson's Disease Foundation (www.pdf.org).
BRANDT--Sheryl M.,passed away peacefully on January 8, 2010. Beloved mother of Wendy Hope Leiser and Barry James Brandt. Services private.

Total album sales, including CDs and digital albums, were down 12.7 percent from 2008 to 2009, even as digital track sales rose 8.3 percent in the same period. Universal Music Group was the top record company in 2009, with 30 percent of album sales and 33 percent of digital track sales. Universal owns Interscope, which represents Lady Gaga, the Black Eyed Peas and Eminem. Michael Jackson, above, whose ''Number Ones'' was originally released in 2003, was the top-selling artist in 2009, with 8.3 million units sold. Taylor Swift was second, with 4.6 million.
