Ravens (10-7) at Colts (14-2) Baltimore demolished the New England Patriots on the strength of a powerful running game and a frightening defense. But with Joe Flacco, right, limited by a quadriceps injury, they have virtually no passing game -- and that is going to make a second surprising victory difficult. The Ravens' offensive line may be able to push around the Colts' undersize-but-fast defense, but the Ravens' shortcoming all season has been their secondary, and that is a doomsday matchup against Indianapolis.

PAPES--Theodore Constantine, Jr.,81, died peacefully in his sleep on January 8, 2010. He will be forever known as a loving husband, father, grandfather, philanthropist, and executive. Mr. Papes was the founding President and CEO of Prodigy Services Company, which began as a joint venture of IBM, Sears, and CBS in 1988. He began his career as an IBM salesman in 1952, and ultimately became a Senior Vice-President and Group Executive, Director General of IBM Europe/Middle East/Africa, and President of Systems Product Development Division. Born in Gary, Indiana, "Ted" was the son of Theodore Constantine and Mary Di Paola Papes, immigrants from Greece and Italy, respectively. Ted served in the U.S. Navy as an aviation electronics technician after graduating from Horace Mann High School in Gary. He then enrolled in his alma mater, the University of Michigan, on the G.I. Bill where he graduated Phi Beta Kappa in 1952 with a BA in economics. He was an avid member of the Alpha Delta Phi fraternity and became Sports Editor for the "Michigan Daily". His memory and legacy will be kept alive by his adored wife of 54 years, Centes Morrill Papes, his children Matthew (Deborah) Papes, Thaddeus (Valita) Papes, Daniel (Christina) Papes and Karin (Cyril) Cabral, ten grandchildren, and many dear friends. Ted will be remembered as a compassionate leader, mentor, and coach. His greatest loves were his wife Centes, his family, the Michigan Wolverines, his Catholic faith, photography, the Adirondack mountains, barbershop and choral singing, and fishing and skiing with his wife and children. Visitation will be at Beecher Funeral Home, Pleasantville on Tuesday 2-4 and 7-9pm. Funeral service will be held at the Church of St John and St. Mary, Chappaqua on Wednesday at 11am. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that donations be made to San Miguel Academy of Newburgh, 241 Liberty Street, Newburgh, NY 12550, The Boys and Girls Club of Northern Westchester, 351 Main Street, Mount Kisco, NY 10549 and The Northern Westchester Hospital Center, 400 East Main Street, Mt. Kisco, NY 10549. Beecher Funeral Home, Inc., 418 Bedford Road, Pleasantville, NY 914-769-0001.

ADAMSONS--O. Karlis M.D. Ph.D.,died peacefully at home on January 8, 2010 at age 83. Born in Riga Latvia, his M.D. summa cum laude was from University of Goettingen, Germany; Ph.D. from Columbia University; and residency in obstetrics and gynecology from Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center in New York. He remained in academia at Columbia Presbyterian, Mount Sinai School of Medicine, Brown University and University of Puerto Rico where he was chairman for 24 years. He was devoted to his patients, research and residents, whose success he nurtured and took great pride in. His interests included chess which as a youth he played blindfolded versus multiple opponents. He is fondly remembered and survived by his wife and large loving family.

Cowboys (12-5) at Vikings (12-4) When Minnesota faded down the stretch of the regular season, the Vikings struggled to protect Brett Favre. The Arizona Cardinals sacked Favre three times and intercepted him twice, and now DeMarcus Ware and Anthony Spencer are on the way. The Eagles tried to triple-team Ware on Saturday night, leaving Spencer virtually untouched. The Vikings have a multidimensional offense, but if Dallas can get pressure without blitzing, Favre will struggle to find his rhythm. The Cowboys have allowed just 31 points in their last four games, and they overwhelm offenses when they can limit their penalties. That allows the Dallas running game to dominate the time of possession, as it did against the Eagles.

THE GILDED PALACE OF SIN ''You Break Our Hearts, We'll Tear Yours Out.'' (Central Control) The Gilded Palace of Sin, a three-man band from Manchester, England, pays some attention to words and melodies on its debut album, ''You Break Our Hearts, We'll Tear Yours Out.'' Its songs are grim, sometimes gallows-humored tales that work the gothic-metaphysical territory -- death, violence, faith, despair, wandering, transcendence -- of songwriters like Nick Cave, the band's most obvious model. There's ''Mean Old Jack,'' a bluesy stomp about a serial wife killer, and ''Wedding Rice,'' a list of someone's transgressions intoned over glacially alternating guitar chords: ''I saw you desecrating bones/destroying home after happy home.''
International CHURCHES ATTACKED

As White House and Congressional negotiators work toward an agreement on a final version of sweeping health care legislation, they seem likely to push the 10-year price tag closer to the $1.05 trillion cost of the House-passed bill while relying on new taxes proposed by the Senate, probably including a bigger increase in the Medicare payroll tax than currently proposed. As small teams of Congressional staff members work furiously to hash out the final differences between the two versions, Congressional leaders and White House officials are trying to navigate an increasingly difficult set of competing demands while also fulfilling President Obama's top goals: that the legislation not add to the deficit, that it reduce long-term health spending and that it cost around $900 billion.

KRELLENSTEIN--Chester A.,age 78. Son of the late Miriam and Hyman Krellenstein. Beloved brother of Shirley and Ely Krellenstein and Dr. Daniel Krellenstein. Services Wednesday, Wellwood Cemetery, Long Island, NY.

9 P.M. (13) SAM COOKE: CROSSING OVER Sam Cooke instilled the spirit of gospel into pop music and in 1957, with ''You Send Me,'' became the first black singer to reach No. 1 on both the R&B and pop charts. Cooke, above, had a string of soaring hits like ''Soothe Me,'' ''Wonderful World'' and ''Cupid''; was a mentor to Aretha Franklin; and earned the support of Dick Clark in his fight against racism. But his career was cut short in 1964, when, at 32, he was gunned down while in the company of a prostitute. This ''American Masters'' presentation chronicles his life and career, from his early childhood singing at his father's First Baptist Church in Chicago to his involvement in the civil rights movement, and asks what might have been. Muhammad Ali, James Brown, Smokey Robinson, Lou Rawls and the producer Jerry Wexler are interviewed; Danny Glover narrates. 8 P.M. (ABC) THE BACHELOR: ON THE WINGS OF LOVE The high-flying Jake Pavelka, who hit turbulence while searching for romance with Jillian Harris on ''The Bachelorette'' last season, continues his quest for a partner. This week the 15 remaining women will move into a villa in Malibu, Calif., and start the dating process. Six of them will take part in a sexy photo shoot for InStyle magazine; five will visit Six Flags Magic Mountain; three won't have dates at all. And one will be piloted by Mr. Pavelka to a getaway in Palm Springs, where the twosome will be serenaded by the band Chicago. Then a bombshell is dropped.

WURTZEL--Sam, 90, passed away on January 7, 2010. Survived by his wife of 68 years, Bernice, his sons Alan and Gary, daughters-in-law Susan and Aviva, six grandchildren, and 13 great-grandchildren. He was a gentle man who was adored by all who came to know him.

Total album sales, including CDs and digital albums, were down 12.7 percent from 2008 to 2009, even as digital track sales rose 8.3 percent in the same period. Universal Music Group was the top record company in 2009, with 30 percent of album sales and 33 percent of digital track sales. Universal owns Interscope, which represents Lady Gaga, the Black Eyed Peas and Eminem. Michael Jackson, above, whose ''Number Ones'' was originally released in 2003, was the top-selling artist in 2009, with 8.3 million units sold. Taylor Swift was second, with 4.6 million. SHELLY FREIERMAN

The mood at last week's Consumer Electronics Show in Las Vegas was decidedly more upbeat than at the previous year's show. At that exhibition, the chatter on the floor was less about innovation and breakthrough technologies than about how to weather the economic storm that would impede the kind of discretionary spending much of the electronics industry relies on. This year's show was a return to optimism. Tablet-size reading devices and three-dimensional television were two technologies often mentioned when exhibitors talked about future prosperity, but there were also developments in the comparatively mature industries of personal computing and cellphones.

VANINGEN--Herbert Terrell, Jr.,85, of Greenwich, CT died January 8, 2010 at home. Born in New York, NY on November 17, 1924, he was the son of the late Herbert Terrell VanIngen Sr. and Jessica Bishop VanIngen. Mr. VanIngen served in the U.S. Marine Corps and was a graduate of Yale University class of 1945W. He also was a member of the 1948 U.S. Olympic Hockey Team and was an All American Athlete in soccer and lacrosse. Mr. VanIngen spent his career in advertising, working for the New York Times and Curtis Publishing. He is survived by his wife Harriet Judson VanIngen, four sons; Judson VanIngen of Greenwich, Scribner VanIngen, Terrell VanIngen III, and Langdon VanIngen, all of Darien, CT. He was predeceased by sisters Ann Turner Black and Jane Turner. A memorial service will be held on Thursday, January 14, 2010 at 11am in Christ Church, 254 East Putnam Ave. Greenwich, CT. Memorial contributions may be made to the Alzheimer's Foundation of America, 322 Eighth Ave. 7th Floor, New York, NY 10001or to Greenwich Hospital Home Hospice, 5 Perryridge Road, Greenwich, CT 06830.

RICHTER--Frieda Einstoss Blatt, 97, died on January 9th, 2010. She was born in Augsburg, Germany and married Dr. Kurt B. Blatt in 1934. Together they fled Nazi Germany and built a new life in Haverstraw, NY. Frieda assisted her husband in managing a busy medical practice that spanned all of Rockland County. She cared for and encouraged their three children: Daniel of Los Angeles, Ruth Merkatz, of Rye, NY, and Dr. Philip Blatt of Wilmington, DE. She was active in numerous community organizations including the Haverstraw PTA, the Good Samaritan Hospital Women's Auxiliary, the Daughter's of Jacob Sisterhood, and Hadassah. She volunteered as a local air raid warden during World War II. Widowed in 1960, Frieda went to work outside the home as Administrative Assistant to the Dean of the Mt. Vernon School of Nursing. She married Max Richter in 1972, but following his untimely death in 1973 in Israel just days before the Yom Kippur War, Frieda relocated to Florida. She lived there for the past 35 years where she pursued education in the arts, traveled extensively, and was surrounded by countless, loving friends who mourn her loss. Frieda will be missed profoundly by her three children and their loving spouses Marti Blumenthal, Irwin Merkatz and Paula Breen. She will also be missed by six grandchildren Jessica and Chelsea, Kenneth, Neil, and Andrew, and Rebecca, and spouses Gregory, Sheri, Lynda, and Lisa all of whom loved, cherished and admired their Grandma for her kindness, strength, wisdom and sense of style. She was beloved by great-grandchildren Clarisa and Samuel, Jessie, and Lucienne and Sebastian who were lucky to know their Great-Grandma Frieda. She is also being mourned in Buenos Aires and Puerto Rico by descendants of her three brothers who fled Germany with Frieda's parents and settled in Argentina. Frieda lived the American dream. Immigrating to New York as a young bride without speaking English, separated from her family and knowing no one, she built a lasting legacy that will endure for generations. Services will be held on January 11, 2010, at 12 noon at Riverside Chapel, 21 Broad Street West, Mt. Vernon, NY. Tribute gifts to honor Frieda's memory as a lifelong learner may be made to: Elderhostel, 11 Avenue de Lafayette, Boston, MA 02111. Toll-Free 1-800-454-5768.

Dr. Herbert Spiegel treated pain, anxiety and addictions by putting people into a trance. Broadway actors sought his help to overcome stage fright, singers to quit smoking, politicians to overcome fear of flying. For years he had a regular table at Elaine's, as well as his own place on the national stage. A New York psychiatrist, Dr. Spiegel, who died on Dec. 15 at the age of 95, was far and away the country's most visible and persuasive advocate for therapeutic hypnosis, having established it as a mainstream medical technique.

As chips and sensors become smaller and more advanced, mobile phones are beginning to take over any number of new functions, quickly replacing single-purpose devices like GPS units and music players. With the latest advancements in image sensors, we may be about to see the obsolescence of two other devices: the pocket point-and-shoot camera and the video camera.

World sports, and not simply African soccer, have to face up to the reality that they can no longer presume they are immune from terrorism. On Sunday, even as the African Cup of Nations was set to kick off in Angola, there was confusion among the Togo players who survived the attack on their bus in the volatile province of Cabinda. Three were dead and eight people reported wounded -- including two in intensive care -- yet the team was considering playing on.

HARRIS--John Andrews IV, of Berwyn, PA and Northeast Harbor, ME died unexpectedly from a fall on December 29, 2009 at the age of 81. Jay was born in Philadelphia, PA on September 12, 1928 the eldest son of John A Harris III and Elizabeth Flagler Harris. He graduated from Princeton University and obtained a Masters Degree in Government Administration from the University of Pennsylvania in 1966. Jay devoted the greater part of his life to environmental philanthropy, bringing his energy and foresight to organizations working on solutions to environmental problems worldwide. He called his foundation "Changing Horizons" because of his belief that the path to a successful future to our planet was one in which our priorities must always be changing to meet new challenges. He is survived by his beloved wife, Lawrie, sons, Shepard and Andy Harris of San Francisco, California, six grandchildren, and numerous nieces and nephews. He was predeceased by his sister, Anne, and his brother, Henry.

ELBIRT--Laura (nee Wydra). Elbirt family regrets to announce the death of Laura Elbirt, a Holocaust Survivor, a supporter of Israel, and a generous contributor to Jewish charitable organizations. May she rest in peace.

OMARION ''Ollusion'' (Starworld/EMI) Last summer was a tough one for the R&B singer Omarion. In June he signed up to be a part of Lil Wayne's Young Money Records. By August he was out, allegedly by mutual consent. ''Girl You Know,'' a song he recorded with that crew, was done over, with Omarion's hook replaced with one by the tender R&B singer Lloyd. The new version, called ''BedRock,'' became a smash.

Jets (10-7) at Chargers (13-3) No team is hotter than San Diego, winner of 11 straight to end the regular season. Outside of the Colts, the Chargers have the most explosive offense in the playoffs. Philip Rivers, right, had 28 touchdowns passes and just 9 interceptions, and it is hard to imagine him misfiring the way Carson Palmer did in the wild-card game. The Jets would love to continue to play a ball-control type of game; they do not want Mark Sanchez in a shootout with Rivers. With Darrelle Revis probably matched against Vincent Jackson, the Jets will hope to hit Rivers, who was sacked only 25 times, before he can dump the ball off to Antonio Gates. JUDY BATTISTA

The television shows "True Blood," "Glee" and "Mad Men," and the films "I Love You, Man" and "Precious: Based on the Novel 'Push' By Sapphire," are among the nominees for the Gay & Lesbian Alliance Against Defamation's annual GLAAD Media Awards, the group announced. The winners of the awards, which are for "recognizing and honoring media for outstanding images" of the lesbian, gay, bisexual and transgender people, the alliance said in a news release, will be chosen from 116 nominees in 24 English-language categories and 36 nominees in eight Spanish-language categories. "Precious" and "I Love You, Man" were among the five movies nominated in the outstanding film - wide release category; "True Blood" and "Mad Men" were nominated for outstanding drama series, alongside "Brothers & Sisters," "Grey's Anatomy" and "Skins"; and "Glee" was nominated for outstanding comedy series, as were "Modern Family," "United States of Tara," "Beautiful People" and "Greek." The actress Cynthia Nixon will receive the group's Vito Russo Award at a ceremony in New York, and the cast of the Broadway revival of "Hair" will receive a special recognition for its "commitment to raising visibility for marriage equality," GLAAD said.

I'm quite amazed that Google is showing the guts to announce that it will no longer censor within China (google.cn) and is prepared to pull out of China altogether. Wow! Finally, a company shows some principles and backbone in this area, after Microsoft Bing censored Chinese-language content worldwide (they claim it was a bug) and Yahoo helped the Chinese government sent dissidents to prison.There are no perfect solutions for dealing with a repressive government, and I made my own share of compromises when I lived for five years in China. I'm a big believer in engagement as a whole, when foreign engagement amounts to a watchdog and boosts civil society. But instead so many foreign companies have acted as lapdogs and facilitated censorship and surveillance, while refusing to speak up for the values they claim to be committed to.

Let the long period of national mourning begin: the ninth season of "American Idol" began tonight, and it was two hours of dead-man-walking. With the future stability of the show in doubt, Tuesday's premiere episode, focusing on the Boston auditions, was a reminder of its strengths and weaknesses. Soak in Simon Cowell's evident distaste for Kara Dioguardi; ponder the physics of Victoria Beckham's head tilt; let the shock of a contestant saying Randy Jackson's his favorite judge sting anew. Soon, this will all be just a memory.

A potent earthquake centered just 10 miles from a city of close to 2 million people, most of whom are deeply impoverished, is a recipe for utter calamity, and initial reports out of Port-au-Prince, Haiti, and nearby communities indicate that is what has unfolded in that unlucky country. It appears that at least one hospital and a school -- two of the keystone structures in any community -- are among the buildings that collapsed, along with dozens of shanties built on steep slopes.

My review this week is of The Breslin, a restaurant on the ground floor of the Ace Hotel, on 29th Street of Broadway in Manhattan. The Breslin is the brainchild of Ken Friedman, the scary smart music-head restaurateur behind the Spotted Pig and the late John Dory, and the chef April Bloomfield. Ms. Bloomfield cooks as hearty cuisine at The Breslin as she has at her other restaurants: pig's feet and bellies, lots of fat and lots of flavor. This makes for nice dinners but difficult sleeping, even for those who consume moderately. (Check out the slide show above for a look at her food.)

While covering the development of digital, high-definition television since its inception, I've been approached by any number of startups that promised The Next Big Thing in displays: rear-projection sets that would cost a small fraction of current technology; a technique to dramatically increase screen contrast and remove all reflective room light that was so promising it was financed by one of the biggest television manufacturers in the world; SED technology demonstrated by Toshiba that put the picture quality of the best plasma TVs to shame. In short, flat panel displays so enticing that makers of other technologies would immediately throw in the towel.

"I hate seeing guys who have a good look going and then crack it open with a Manhattan Portage bag," says the accessories designer Basil Racuk. "It drives me crazy." We feel your pain, Basil. Though Jack Spade has made some progress in addressing this all-too common problem, the line's ubiquity (in our non-scientific survey, every second man on the F train was carrying one) has compromised its appeal. Two solutions to the man-purse dilemma: Racuk's eponymous collection of made-to-order satchels, and the Madly, a line of men's bags just introduced by Melanie Dizon and Jake Quellman.Racuk, who's based in Northern California, goes for a rustic-yet-refined look - think Berkeley professor crossed with Milanese aesthete - and works with customers on every aspect of a bag's design. "A good accessory is an exclamation point," he says. "You want to get it just right." His designs are distinguished by their trend-proof but not boring classicism - you can order his minimally structured briefcase in bright red if you like.

Hands held over an oudoor fire for warmth. It is certainly an effective photojournalistic device for conveying - wordlessly - the idea that unusually cold weather is burdening a place that is unaccustomed to it and unequipped for it: India, in this case, from which several hands-over-the-fire pictures have been transmitted in recent weeks. (Today's photo is Slide 10.) But is this a case of visual shorthand so effective it threatens to become cliché? A glance at the pictures below reveals subtle variety. Each picture tells a slightly different story. And that never gets tiresome.

Long a staple of ladies who lunch (in Geneva), the Swiss fashion house Akris is expanding its line to include handbags. Akris is no stranger to the material: it has been used to structure its coats, and there is even woven horsehair covering the walls of its London boutique. Pony up the hefty $3,990 at Saks Fifth Avenue, Bergdorf Goodman and Akris boutiques.

The debate over European economic performance has gone in two directions. One is the usual response of people when they get something very wrong: they start quibbling over minor details (which dataset was Manzi actually using? what about immigration?) to throw up dust clouds. The key thing to remember is that we had a flat assertion that social democracy leads to stagnant economies; that assertion is just wrong.

Encores! has found its Fanny -- and its Cesar and its Marius, too. Elena Shaddow, George Hearn and James Snyder will play those characters in New York City Center's coming Encores! production of "Fanny," the musical based on Marcel Pagnol's trilogy of "Marius," "Fanny" and "César," its press representatives said on Tuesday. Ms. Shaddow (whose Broadway credits include "The Woman in White" and "Fiddler on the Roof") will play Fanny, the French woman whose illegitimate pregnancy sets off a story of romance and reconciliation. Mr. Snyder (Broadway's "Cry-Baby") will play Fanny's lover, Marius, and Mr. Hearn (a Tony winner for "Sunset Boulevard" and "La Cage aux Folles") will play his father, Cesar. The cast also includes Rondi Reed (a Tony winner for "August: Osage County") as Honorine, Fred Applegate ("The Producers") as Panisse, David Patrick Kelly as the Admiral and Michael McCormick as Escartifique. "Fanny," which is directed by Marc Bruni, choreographed by Lorin Latarro and with music directed by Rob Berman, will run at City Center from Feb. 4 through 7.

Less than a month after a group calling itself the "Iranian Cyber Army" attacked Twitter, users of China's most popular search engine, Baidu, were redirected on Tuesday morning to a Web page displaying a message claiming that the same group had blocked access to that site as well.

Among the things the Vatican approves of: piety, penitence, "The Simpsons." Among the things it does not endorse: sinfulness and "Avatar." Both the Vatican newspaper and radio station have criticized that James Cameron film, calling it emotionally unengaging and saying that the film tries to replace divinity with nature, The Associated Press reported. The newspaper, L'Osservatore Romano, wrote that "Avatar" "gets bogged down by a spiritualism linked to the worship of nature," according to The A.P. Vatican Radio said the movie "cleverly winks at all those pseudo-doctrines that turn ecology into the religion of the millennium," adding: "Nature is no longer a creation to defend, but a divinity to worship." The newspaper wrote that for all of the "stupefying, enchanting technology" in the movie, it offers "few genuine emotions." But both news media outlets agreed, as the newspaper wrote, that the true accomplishment of "Avatar" was its "extraordinary visual impact." The film is to be released in Italy on Friday.

The Carlyle Group, following in the footsteps of one of its biggest rivals, announced that it was teaming up with the Beijing government to start a domestic Chinese private equity fund, Bloomberg News reported.

Personal Lives on the Stand | In the first day of the same-sex marriage trial in federal court in San Francisco, Theodore B. Olson asked his client, "What does it mean to be a lesbian?" Two gay couples testified about their lives and their reactions to the 2008 passage of Proposition 8, the state ballot initiative that changed the state's constitution so that gays and lesbians could not marry. Video coverage of the nonjury trial, which addresses the constitutionality of the gay-marriage ban, is not available on YouTube, as had been planned. Hours before the trial began, the United States Supreme halted, for a few days, the plan to show the court proceedings on YouTube until the justices could review the issue of cameras in the court room. [The New York Times]

GameStop, the video game retailer, said on Monday it had authorized a $300 million stock buyback plan and planned to spend $200 million on opening new stores and other types of expansion.

Sergio Marchionne, the chief executive of both Fiat and Chrysler, said that the American carmaker might be ready for an initial public offering as soon as next year, The Financial Times reported.

If you've always been interested in Persian history but a trip to Iran is not in the cards right now, a visit to Istanbul might be a good backup choice. Through Feb. 5, the museum at the city's Topkapi Palace -- former home of the Ottoman sultans -- is hosting "Ten Thousand Years of Iran's Civilization and Two Thousand Years of Joint Heritage," an exhibition featuring some 150 objects from the National Museum of Iran, as well as pieces from Turkish museums.
Shanda Games of China has agreed to buy Mochi Media, an American online game company backed by venture firms Accel Partners and Shasta Ventures, for $80 million in cash and stock.

The Dutch brewer Heineken has managed a delicate balancing act in clinching the auction for the beer business of Femsa of Mexico, Breakingviews says. Despite outbidding SABMiller, the deal is in line with prices paid for growing Latin American markets. Meanwhile, Heineken's all-share offer keeps debt under control while leaving its founding family in charge, the publication remarks.

A new book about the 2008 presidential campaign quotes the U.S. Senate majority leader, Democrat Harry Reid of Nevada, as saying that "the country was ready to embrace a black presidential candidate, especially one such as Obama - a 'light-skinned' African American 'with no Negro dialect, unless he wanted to have one.' An editorial on Sunday mischaracterized the safety record of ground meat produced by Beef Products Inc. The editorial said incorrectly that two 27,000-pound batches of processed beef had been recalled. The contamination of the meat was discovered by the company in its plant before the beef was shipped. No meat produced by Beef Products Inc. has been linked to any illnesses or outbreaks.

Because of an editing error, an obituary on Saturday about Catherine Biden, the mother of Vice President Joseph R. Biden, misstated Mr. Biden’s age during his first campaign for the United States Senate. He was 29, not 30. (By the time Mr. Biden was sworn in as a senator in January 1973, he had turned 30, the minimum age required for the office.).
Jordan Hill, the Knicks’ first pick in the draft, has yet to make much of an impact on the court.

The Advertising column on Monday, about a new campaign for Aflac, misidentified the agency behind the new advertising campaign. It is the Zimmerman Agency of Tallahassee, Fla., part of the Omnicom Group — not a Tallahassee office of Zimmerman Advertising, another Omnicom agency.

An article on Saturday about the first substantive hearing of a commission established by Congress to investigate the causes of the financial crisis referred incorrectly to a similar investigation in 1932 that sought to learn the causes of the Wall Street crash of 1929. That inquiry was a series of hearings conducted by the Senate Banking Committee; it was not established as a commission. (The investigation has become known as the Pecora hearings, after Ferdinand Pecora, the chief staff investigator.) The error has appeared in other articles written since Congress last year began considering creating a commission to investigate the recent crisis, including articles on March 12, May 6 and July 16 last year and an Op-Ed Page column on Oct. 18.
The defense has sparked a four-game winning streak by Dallas, but now the Cowboys have to face Adrian Peterson and Brett Favre in Minnesota.

An article in some editions on Saturday about an accident in which Howard Safir, the city’s former police commissioner, backed his car into a pregnant pedestrian in Manhattan included an erroneous address in some copies from the police for the scene of the accident. It took place in front of 1418 Third Avenue, not 1421 Third.
A billboard in Times Square featuring the president in a Weatherproof coat created controversy and will be taken down.

An article in some editions on Dec. 22 about criticism of Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg by the outgoing and incoming city comptrollers after the Bloomberg administration acknowledged having more than 2,500 unregistered bank accounts misstated the year in which the city received $181 million from unregistered accounts controlled by the office of Robert M. Morgenthau, then the Manhattan district attorney. It was 2009, not 2008.

An article in some editions on Friday about an expected mortgage default by the owners of Stuyvesant Town and Peter Cooper Village, sister apartment complexes in Manhattan, misspelled, in some copies, the given name of a longtime tenant at Peter Cooper who said apartment turnover had increased under the current landlords. She is Soni Fink, not Sonni.

An article in some editions on Friday about the F.B.I.’s seizure of a passport belonging to Adis Medunjanin, a Queens man who came under scrutiny during the investigation of what officials have said was a bomb plot by Al Qaeda, misspelled, in some copies, the surname of Mr. Medunjanin’s lawyer. He is Robert Gottlieb, not Gottleib. (Mr. Medunjanin was arrested on Friday on terrorism charges.).

Baseball Commissioner Bud Selig issued a statement saying that “the use of steroids and amphetamines amongst today’s players has greatly subsided and is virtually nonexistent”.

The City Room column in some editions on Dec. 31, about a State Senate proposal for referendums asking voters whether New York should be split into two states, misstated, in some copies, the year that the Constitution was ratified. It was 1788, not 1787.

An article on Friday about the New Jersey Senate’s defeat of a bill that would have allowed same-sex marriages misstated, in some editions, the length of time between 1915, the year that New Jersey voters rejected a referendum that would have allowed women the right to vote, and the year that the 19th Amendment was ratified, granting women the vote nationwide. The amendment was ratified five years later, in 1920, not three years later.

An article in some editions on Thursday about the indictment of a former Yonkers city councilwoman and two other people on federal corruption charges misidentified the position once held by Zehy Jereis, one of those indicted. He is the former chairman of the Yonkers Republican Committee and a former board member of the Westchester County Republican Party; he was not the “former leader” of the Westchester party.

An article on Saturday about the effects of early winter storms on already strained state and local budgets misstated, in some copies, the current number of state troopers in Iowa, where officials say they do not have enough patrol officers to handle all accidents. It is 379, not 37 (down from 455 about 10 years ago).

Enter the judges. The Sundance Film Festival, above, which begins on Jan. 21 in Utah, announced on Monday the members of the five juries awarding prizes. The awards will be presented on Jan. 30 by David Hyde Pierce. The United States dramatic competition will be evaluated by the author Russell Banks (“Cloudsplitter,” “The Sweet Hereafter”); Jason Kliot, producer of 20 films that have been screened at the festival, including “Welcome to the Dollhouse”; Karyn Kusama, director of “Aeon Flux” and “Jennifer’s Body,” the critically drubbed zombie cheerleader movie; the actress Parker Posey (“The House of Yes,” “Best in Show”); and Robert Yeoman, a cinematographer on films like “Bottle Rocket” and “Drugstore Cowboy.” Lined up for the United States documentary competition are the producer-director Greg Barker (“Sergio”); the producer-director Dayna Goldfine (“Ballets Russes”); Nancy Miller, a senior editor at Wired magazine; the filmmaker Morgan Spurlock (“Super Size Me”); and Ondi Timoner, the only filmmaker to win the Grand Jury prize at Sundance twice, for “Dig!” and “We Live in Public.”.

A flutist with the Chicago Symphony Orchestra who briefly took a temporary post with the Los Angeles Philharmonic, only to return to Chicago, apologized for his departure and denied a news report in which he appeared to be critical of the Philharmonic. The flutist, Mathieu Dufour, had been on leave from the Chicago orchestra when he joined the Philharmonic on a one-year trial basis, starting in September. But this month he told The Chicago Sun-Times that he had decided not to remain in Los Angeles, telling that newspaper that the Philharmonic has “no tradition there — no tradition of sound and no tradition of working together as a dedicated ensemble.” In an e-mail message to the Philharmonic’s musicians reported by the Culture Monster blog of The Los Angeles Times (latimesblogs.latimes.com/culturemonster), Mr. Dufour wrote that he had returned to Chicago to have shoulder surgery and apologized for “having left the season so abruptly.” He also wrote that he was “grossly misquoted” by The Chicago Sun-Times, and added, “I sincerely hope that none of you have read it, but if any of you have seen it, I beg you not to pay any attention to it.” Andrew Patner, who wrote the report for The Sun-Times, told Culture Monster that he stood behind his reporting.

Even bogus boxing can be hazardous on a Broadway stage. Santino Fontana, below, who plays the young suitor Rodolpho in the current Broadway production of “A View From the Bridge,” remains out of the show since sustaining a minor concussion from a boxing scene with Liev Schreiber’s character during a performance on New Year’s weekend. Mr. Fontana left the show temporarily under doctor’s orders, according to a statement on Thursday from a publicist for the show, and he was scheduled still to be off for Monday night’s performance. It is not clear when he will return. The role of Rodolpho is being played by the understudy, Morgan Spector. Mr. Fontana sustained the concussion during a scene in which Rodolpho is drawn into sparring by Eddie Carbone (Mr. Schreiber), the jealous uncle of Rodolpho’s love interest, Catherine (Scarlett Johansson). No one from the production was available to comment on Monday about Mr. Fontana’s health or whether the boxing scene has been rechoreographed, the publicist said.

KELLMAN--Joseph, 90. A Legend in Chicago Business and Chicago Philanthropy. Joe Kellman, a titan of the Chicago business and philanthropic communities, died peacefully on Thursday, January 7, 2010, at his home in Texas. He passed away on his 90th birthday surrounded by his family. Upon retirement in 2001, he and his wife LouAnne moved to Southern California, where they were residing at the time of his death. Joe Kellman was born on January 7, 1920, and grew in the North Lawndale community of Chicago. In the 9th grade, Joe had to drop out of school to work in his father's glass shop. After his father's death, he and his brother Morrie assumed ownership of the business. When they dissolved their partnership in 1950, Joe took over two small retail glass shops and grew them into The Globe Group, the nation's largest privately owned auto glass replacement company. In 1999, Joe sold the company to Belron International. Joe's achievements in business were rivaled only by his charitable endeavors. He vowed never to forget his early beginnings and pledged to serve youth and their families in North Lawndale. His interest in boxing led him to open the Archie Moore Gym in 1961 at 1512 South Pulaski as an after-school boxing club for boys. Shortly after opening the gym, Joe realized that sports alone could not change a young person's life. In the mid 1960s, Joe, with the help of long-time friend Buddy Hackett, transitioned the gym into the Better Boys Foundation (BBF). Today, BBF serves some 800 boys and girls each year through licensed child welfare services, innovative out-of-school time programs, and college scholarships. Its operations are housed in a 30,000 square foot, state-of-the-art facility financed by the Joseph Kellman Family Foundation. The new BBF Center opened in 2008 and represents Joe's 50-year commitment to North Lawndale. In 1988, Joe co-founded with Vernon Loucks, Jr., Chairman and CEO of Baxter International, and Fred Turner, Chairman and CEO of McDonalds, the Corporate/Community Schools of America, the country's first corporate-sponsored school. His intent was to prove that the common business practices could be applied to public schools to improve learning. The Joseph Kellman Corporate/Community School in North Lawndale is now one of Chicago's best performing. Along with his successful business career, philanthropic work, and advocacy efforts, Joe also bred racehorses and promoted every major boxing event in the city of Chicago over a 20-year period with friend and partner Ben Bentley. His premiere racehorse was Shecky Greene, an internationally renowned sprinter that won the Eclipse Award as 1973 Sprint Champion, the same year he ran in the Kentucky Derby and set the pace for Secretariat in his record run. Joe Kellman lived a long and fulfilling life that he shared fully with his family and friends. Joe was predeceased by his daughter Celia (Cissy). He is survived by his wife LouAnne; sons Jack and Richard Kellman; stepsons Bill and Bruce Suggs; grandchildren Robert Saxner, Cindy DeMaio, Allison Cantrell, Colette, Jake, Olivia, and Stephanie Kellman, and Suzannah and Kye Suggs; and great-grandchildren Jaclyn, Dylan, and Brooke DeMaio, and Owen and Maeve Saxner. Joe Kellman will be remembered always as a man of exceptional integrity who was committed to equity of opportunity for all people. A public visitation will be held Thursday, January 14, 2010, from 10am-1pm at the Better Boys Foundation, 1512 South Pulaski Road in Chicago. Valet parking will be provided. A private burial service has also been planned. In lieu of flowers, the family asks that contributions be made to the Better Boys Foundation, 1512 South Pulaski Road, Chicago, IL, 60623.

In the aftermath of Friday's chilling attack on Togo's national team that left three dead before the start of the African Cup of Nations, South African officials immediately stepped forward in an attempt to separate the events in Angola from concerns about security ahead of the start of the 2010 World Cup in June. ''It has no impact on our World Cup,'' Danny Jordaan, the leader of South Africa's organizing committee, told Reuters on Saturday. ''The world understands that sovereign countries are responsible for their own safety and security, and to say what happened in Angola impacts on the World Cup in South Africa is the same as suggesting that when a bomb goes off in Spain, it threatens London's ability to host the next Olympics.''

The White House said Monday that President Obama and his wife, Michelle, would attend the funeral Mass on Tuesday for the mother of Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. Catherine Biden died on Friday in Wilmington, Del. She was 92.

John Hoeven of North Dakota, a widely popular Republican, announced Monday that he would run for the Senate this year, a decision that increases his party's odds of capturing an open seat in the state. KAUFMAN--Robert Jay, of Brookline, MA died on January 8, 2010. Born August 30, 1951 to Felix and Eleanor Kaufman. Robert attended Boston University and received his Bachelor of Fine Arts from the San Francisco Art Institute. He was Associate Professor of Illustration at the Art Institute of Boston at Lesley College from 1994-2009 and Chair of the Illustration Department from 1996-2007. Prior to his tenure at The Art Institute of Boston, Robert taught at the University of North Carolina at Charlotte and at the School of Visual Arts in New York City. Robert believed in the significance of illustration as a vital political and educational force, a way for both children and adults to learn about their world. Robert received AIB's Faculty Award for Excellence in Teaching in 2007 and Lesley University's Impact Award in 2009. Robert's own work reflected his keen powers of observation, exploring the symbolism inherent in common objects and filling his insatiable appetite for places and their history. His illustrations, characterized by wry humor and an ironic perspective, appeared in The New York Times, The Atlantic, Time, Travel and Leisure, Playboy, Sports Illustrated, Games Magazine, The Wall Street Journal, Rolling Stone and many other publications. Robert illustrated two children's books: Count-A-Saurus by Nancy Blumenthal in 1989 and Nat, Man of 1000 Faces by Michael Chesworth, in 1991. In 2005, Robert wrote and illustrated Blockology: An Off Beat Guide to Lower Manhattan. Blockology provides unique insight to the character and architecture of 36 blocks below 14th Street in lower Manhattan. The New York Times called Blockology the ultimate love letter to the city. Its publication led to numerous presentations, interviews, and walking tours to share his knowledge and affection for the urban landscape and its rich layering of culture and history. Robert is survived by his wife of twenty years, Susan Scott, his daughter, Emili, his father, Felix of New York City, and his brother, Kenneth (Barbara) of Kenilworth, Illinois. He also leaves his mother-in-law, Shirley Scott, sisters-in-law, Linda Scott (Jim), Kathleen Dorran (Bill), brother-in-law, Brantley Scott and six nieces and nephews. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to: The Melanoma Research Alliance, 1101 New York Avenue NW, Suite 620, Washington, DC 20005. Website: www.melanomaresearch alliance.org.

Jamie Langenbrunner, the stoic Devils right wing from Minnesota's Iron Range with the powder-dry wit, was named Monday as the captain of the relatively young United States team for the Winter Olympics in Vancouver. Langenbrunner, 34, who is in his third season as the Devils' captain, is one of three players on the American team with Olympic experience. He played for the United States team that failed to earn a medal at the 1998 Winter Olympics in Nagano, Japan. He also played for the United States' World Cup team in 2004.

RHODES--Joan Black, passed away peacefully, and surrounded by family, in New York City on January 10, 2010. The cause of death was complications from pneumonia. Joan was born on July 31, 1926, and grew up in New York. She exhibited a remarkable intellect at an early age, and was graduated from Bryn Mawr College in 1947. She remained a strong supporter of the college throughout her life. Joan was the loving wife of John Bower Rhodes, who predeceased her, and a devoted parent. She traveled throughout the world, but was particularly attached to her homes and friends in Klosters Switzerland, Nantucket, and New York City. She was an active resident of these communities, and cared deeply about them. She is survived by her three children John Rhodes, Jr., Mark Rhodes, and Lydia Rhodes Petty, as well as eight grandchildren. A memorial service will be held this summer in Siasconset, Massachusetts. In lieu of flowers, contributions can be made to The Nantucket Cottage Hospital.

NOVAK--Joseph, S.J.,alumni chaplain and longtime member of the Fordham University family, died after a brief illness on Sunday, January 10, 2010, at Montefiore North Hospital in the Bronx. He was 82 years old. "Our hearts are heavy today, for we have lost an elder brother, a wise colleague and dear friend in Father Joe Novak," said Joseph M. McShane, S.J., president of Fordham. "His service to Fordham and to the church was both long and distinguished. Generations of Fordham students will remember Father Novak for his wit, gentleness and warmth, in and out of the classroom." Father Novak was born on March 14, 1927, and entered the Society of Jesus at St. Andrew-on-Hudson, Poughkeepsie, N.Y., on February 1, 1945. He was ordained to the priesthood on June 22, 1957. He was a graduate of Xavier High School, Woodstock College and the International Catechetical Center at Lumen Vitae, in Brussels. Before coming to Fordham in June 1962, where he served as an instructor both in the Department of Religion and Religious Education and at Fordham Preparatory School. Father Novak taught at Saint Peter's Preparatory and McQuaid Jesuit High School. During his career, Father Novak was the rector of the Jesuit community at Fordham and at Saint Peter's College in Jersey City, NJ. He served on the boards of Saint Peter's College, the University of Scranton, the College of the Holy Cross and LeMoyne College. He also served on the Board of Regents of Saint Peter's College. He was the author of Christian Vocation: Call of the King (Holt, Rinehart, Winston, 1964). Since September 2004, Father Novak served as Fordham's alumni chaplain, providing pastoral care to graduates and their families, developing and leading alumni retreats, and offering a series of continuing education programs to graduates. He was a gracious colleague, a mentor and a friend to the Development and University Relations staff. Father Novak is survived by his brother, Vincent Novak, S.J., founding dean of Fordham's Graduate School of Religion and Religious Education, and his sisters Lucy Novak and Antoinette Frees, and members of the Spellman Jesuit community. Father Novak's parents, Spiro and Pauline Novak, are deceased. The wake will be held on Tuesday, January 12 from 2 to 4pm, and on Wednesday, January 13 from 2 to 4pm and from 7 to 9pm at Loyola Hall on the Rose Hill Campus of Fordham University. The Mass of Christian Burial will be held on Thursday, January 14 at 11am at University Church on the Rose Hill campus of Fordham University. Father Novak will be interred in the Jesuit Cemetery, Auriesville, NY. Notes of condolence may be sent to his brother, Father Vincent Novak, at: Vincent Novak, S.J., Fordham University, Loyola Hall, Bronx, NY 10458.

Lindsey Vonn said in a conference call Monday that a recent article in an Austrian newspaper discussing the size advantage she has against her rivals helped motivate her last weekend, when she won three consecutive races. ''They used the word 'heavy,' and that irritated me,'' said Vonn, who is 5 feet 10 inches and 160 pounds. ''Heavy? That's ridiculous. I pride myself on my work ethic and on being as fit as anyone in the race. As a woman, I want to drop the subject, but I used it as motivation.''

Rod R. Blagojevich, the indicted, ousted former governor of Illinois, apologized Monday for saying in an interview that he was ''blacker than Barack Obama.'' In an article in the February issue of Esquire, that comment comes after Mr. Blagojevich portrays most politicians as phony, but says he is ''real.''

ANTONSEN--Constance Dean Armitage, a leader in the Conservative movement, died January 9, 2010, at 95. A professor of art history at Wofford College in Spartanburg, SC, for 29 years, she was also, for half that time, Wofford's fencing coach. For a somewhat longer period, she was active in Republican politics beginning in 1960 when she seconded the nomination of Barry Goldwater from the floor of the Republican National Convention. She was a delegate to six National Conventions and a member of the Platform Committee three times. She was President of the National Federation of Republican Women from 1972-75, a period when the NFRW grew to nearly 500,000 members. She was a member of the President's 23-man Advisory Council on European Affairs, 197273; Vice Chairman of the U.S. Commission on World Population, 197475; Chairman of the Third Decennial White House Conference on Aging, 198182; and U.S. Delegate to the (United Nations) World Seniors Conference in Vienna, 1982. Antonsen spoke 13 modern languages and was a past recipient of fellowships from the American Council of Learned Societies for studies in Mandarin and in Arabic. In the two years preceding Pearl Harbor, she used her fluency in German in undercover work for U.S. Naval Intelligence. She was the widow of Norman C. Armitage and of Randolph Antonsen. A son, R. Dean Armitage, predeceased her. She is survived by her daughter, Leslie Armitage Vallhonrat; four grandchildren, Christopher Vallhonrat, Gregory Vallhonrat, Heather Vallhonrat Garrett, and Seth Vallhonrat; and a great-granddaughter, Elizabeth Garrett. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Navy-Marine Corps Relief Society.

MARDEN--Michael, of New York City, age 75, died January 7, 2010. Husband of Leslie Macpherson, son of the late Nicholas B. and Kathryn Marden, he was born in New York City on September 27, 1934. He graduated from Briarcliff High School in 1951, Princeton University in 1955, and received his M.A. in American Studies from Columbia University in 1993. He served in the U.S. Army from 1955-1957. His career at CBS Television spanned from 1965 to 1989, working on the acquisition, scheduling and promotion of prime-time movies in New York, then becoming the Director of "Made for Television" movies in Los Angeles, and starting and supervising the CBS Late Movie in New York. In 1977 he became Director of Program Development, responsible for all aspects of developing comedy and dramatic series. After retiring, Mike continued with CBS News/New York Times conducting telephone interviews with members of Congress, delegates to various presidential conventions and the general public on timely subjects of local and national interest. He worked for the U.S. Census in New York and for Robert A. Becker Inc. where he recruited medical professionals for meetings and conferences on medical subjects. He also began working with Service Employees International Union ("SEIU") Communication Center in New York where he recruited union members to support political candidates and issues such as the presidential campaign of John Kerry in St. Louis, the New York State Budget campaign, union organizing in California, and the campaign for Senator Robert Menendez in New Jersey. In 2008 he led the SEIU team in Columbus, Ohio registering voters on behalf of Barack Obama. He went on to do similar work for then Senator Obama in Texas and Pennsylvania. He is survived by his wife Leslie, sons Scott, David, Christopher, Michael and daughter Sarah Guidotti (all by his first wife Suzanne Jacobs), grandson Ellis Guidotti, brother Brice and sister Mary Carroll. A memorial celebrating his life will be held in February. Donations in his memory may be made to Public Television, Thirteen, 450 West 33rd Street, New York, NY, 10001-2605.

The S.S. United States, which carried immigrants to America and vacationers to Europe faster than any other ocean liner, has not sailed into New York harbor in 40 years. But some fans of the giant ship are telling city officials that it should come home to Manhattan. Stripped of its interior appointments, streaked with rust, the United States has languished at a dock in Philadelphia for more than a decade. Several dreams of restoring it, as a passenger ship or a floating condominium, have been aborted.

KLEIBACKER--Charles John (19212010), renowned fashion designer, died Sunday, January 3, 2010, in Columbus, Ohio, at age 88. Brought up in his family's department store in Cullman, Alabama, Kleibacker graduated with a degree in journalism from the University of Notre Dame in 1943. He opened his own studio, Kleibacker, in New York City in 1960. His designs received critical acclaim from Vogue, Harper's Bazaar, Town and Country, and Women's Wear Daily and were featured by Bergdorf Goodman and Henri Bendel. Kleibacker's private clients included Mrs. Richard Nixon, Diahann Carroll, Mrs. Nelson Rockefeller, and Mrs. Irving Berlin. Since 2002, Kleibacker has been the Adjunct Curator of Design at the Columbus Museum of Art, where he created numerous significant exhibitions. He is survived by his sister, Ruth Richard and her children as well as many friends and admirers. Donations in his honor may be made to the Charles Kleibacker Endowed Fund for Excellence, Columbus Museum of Art, 480 East Broad Street, Columbus, Ohio, 43215.

A prominent Mexican businessman who tried to buy the airline Aeroméxico in 2007 died in a helicopter crash Sunday night along with his wife, son and daughter-in-law. Moisés Saba Masri, 46, was part of the second generation of the billionaire Saba family. The crash, which also killed the pilot, occurred in heavy fog on the outskirts of Mexico City.

ANDERSON--Dr. Melody M.,passed away on Sunday, January 10th. Melody was an accomplished psychotherapist who helped countless people during the course of her 20+ years in private practice. Melody held an MSW from Columbia University, a Ph.D. in Social Welfare from Yeshiva University and a Master of Arts in Psychology from the New School of Social Research. She was a National Woodrow Wilson Fellow and received numerous awards and honors for her work. Melody taught at Yeshiva University and lectured extensively. She was involved in formulating governmental social policy and was an advocate for the needs of women and the elderly. She co-founded the first licensed mental health facility in the U.S. focused on the psychological needs of midlife and older women. Melody loved traveling, antiques, music and the theater, among many other interests. Melody is survived by her husband Franz and leaves behind many beloved friends and family who will miss her dearly. Funeral Services will be at 11:30am on Wednesday, January 13th at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave., at 81st Street.

Neanderthals were different from you and me, the thinking goes, because they were cognitively inferior. For one thing, they appeared to be incapable of symbolic thinking, of using one thing to represent something else. Some humans in Africa, for example, adorned their bodies with stained seashells more than 100,000 years ago. To them, a shell wasn't just a shell, but a way to signify individuality. But evidence of similar behavior by Neanderthals has been discounted.

HEGARTY--Allen G.,of Bradenton, FL died January 8, 2010. Mr. Hegarty was born in Brooklyn, NY on June 29, 1915. He spent his winter vacations in Holmes Beach for 20 years and then moved from Jamesburg, NJ to become a full time resident in 1991. Mr. Hegarty, a registered engineer in six states, retired from Merck & Co., Inc. in 1980 after 38 years, having worked in various engineering positions, the last 12 years as Director of Engineering. He is survived by his wife, Marjorie W., stepchildren, Bonnie MacDonald of Bradenton, FL and North Haven, ME, Wendy Sands of Sarasota, FL and Hampton Beach, NH, Peter Currid of Bradenton, FL and two step-grandchildren, Hallie MacDonald and Jennifer Currid. There will be no viewing or services. Memorial donations may be made to a charity of your choice. Services by Griffith-Cline Funeral Home.

Composing is what I love to do most. It is what best combines my various skills and interests - imagination, reflection, organization and the desire to communicate my thoughts and emotions to anyone who will listen. I also love solitude: I do my creative work in an 18th-century barn on our farm near Boston, where I can pursue my ideas without the need to explain or translate until all is ripe and ready. So it may seem like a paradox that another large chunk of my life is spent in one of the world's most futuristic, collaborative and intensive centers of technological invention - the The Massachusetts Institute of Technology Media Lab. But the attractions and complexities of merging these worlds are central to how and why I work, and grow from seeds planted when I was very young.My mom is a Juilliard-trained pianist and a remarkable pedagogue and my dad is one of the pioneers of computer graphics, but it actually took me a while to start combining these fields. I grew up as a cellist, first playing solo Bach, then chamber music (I never particularly enjoyed playing in orchestras), and then, by high school, original composed or improvised music using a wired (or is that "weird"?) transformed rock cello that I created by placing large headphones around the cello for amplification, then sending the sound through tape recorder loops and analog transformation processes.

Tuesday night, upstairs at the bistro Ici, in Fort Greene, Brooklyn, a handful of hopefuls pushed snacks upon invitation-only guests and waited for the passing of judgment. One of them would take home the "I'm a Winner" trophy and, more important, win the consulting expertise of the Rooster Design Group. It was the culmination of the company's first "The Next Big Small Brand Contest for Culinary Genius." Rooster's founders, Fernando Music and Fran Gaitanaros, had canvassed the 140 local applicants and winnowed the field down to the final five. They got all kinds. "We had some real head-scratchers," Music mused. "Insects as nutritional supplements, positioned as a food that was borderline vegetarian. The insect ingredient would either be ground or mixed into the food product whole to make it more accessible and digestible. We also had a team with a perfectly nice product, good flavor profile, but one of the presenters was drunk ... that was pretty dark."

Another day, another iPhone app. While the deluge never seems to stop, there are a few recent apps that cover a somehow previously underaddressed need: travel guides.The new Wallpaper guide essentially brings a version of its existing guide books from page to screen, with 10 different cities at $3.99 a pop. For the most part the guides are smartly organized - there's a 24-hour guide (good for business travelers or if the city is just one stop of many), a section of essential info (which includes the somewhat inessential average price of a bottle of Champagne), an insiders' guide compiled by an actual resident and a panoramic photo of the city skyline with architectural highlights labeled and explained. The app also detects where you are in relation to every place in the guide and offers a link to Google maps for directions. Only the listings of restaurants, bars and nightclubs are lacking. They're all consolidated into one section called Urban Life, which does have appealing suggestions but also gives short shrift to cities with thousands of places to eat, drink and be merry. The Berlin app is currently available as a free download on the iTunes store for any on-the-fencers out there.

Overview | How are scientific and medical study results reported to the public? How can and should people interpret these reports with an eye to reliability and seek additional information to put the news into scientific context? In this lesson, students reflect on what they look for in science and health news. Then, using any day's Science Times and other resources, they evaluate news reports for validity and develop strategies for reading such reports and for developing research and experiment protocols.

I love to be pro-active and give advice on making that long winter break productive. I am learning, though, that many college freshmen view their first winter break as not only a break from finals and the demands of college, but a break from using their brains. They are not looking to make any plans. But after the initial joy of the homecoming subsides, and when the holidays are over, parents can encourage their college students to make good use of their time. Let's hear from Lily, our Ithaca freshman, about her first winter break:

As Joe Posnanski notes, nobody seems much inclined to do it. And you can understand why. McGwire's extended mea culpa comes years after it became clear that he took steroids, years after he stammered his way through a Congressional hearing, years after a public expression of contrition would have counted as brave and morally impressive. He's been beaten to the admission-and-apology punch by everyone from Alex Rodriguez to Jason Grimsley. And he still doesn't want to acknowledge, for understandable reasons, that the steroids made all his home runs possible, even though saying that they kept him healthy so that he could hit home runs is basically the same thing anyway.

Steve Martin has spun his wheel of talents again, and this time it has stopped at "author": Grand Central Publishing said in an e-mail message that it had acquired two new books from Mr. Martin, the actor, comedian, bluegrass musician, New Yorker contributor and coming Academy Awards show co-host -- one intended for young readers and one for the rest of us. The book for young readers is called "Late for School," and is based on a song that also appears on Mr. Martin's album "The Crow: New Songs for the 5-String Banjo"; it will include illustrations by C.F. Payne and a CD of the song (as well as a singalong version) and is to be released in September. The second book, called "Woman, One," is a novel that "examines the glamour and the subterfuge of the fine art world" in New York, the e-mail message said. (Yes, Mr. Martin is an art collector, too.) The book, Mr. Martin's first novel since "The Pleasure of My Company," is planned for a November release. Both books were acquired by Deb Futter, the editor-in-chief of Grand Central Publishing, an imprint of Hachette Book Group.

Art is long and life is brief, but sometimes art is brief, too. A wall painting by Richard Wright that won him the Turner Prize in December has been erased by workers at the Tate Britain museum -- as Mr. Wright intended, The Guardian reported. The painting, a gold-leaf fresco of an abstract design, was sanded and painted over by the museum's art handlers last week, after an exhibition on the Turner Prize, the prestigious British art award, was closed. Mr. Wright, 49, who lives in Glasgow, was named the prize winner over the heavily favored installation artist Roger Hiorns. In an Arts Beat post, Roberta Smith described Mr. Wright as "a cross between Sol LeWitt and Fabergé" who creates elaborate works that are meant to exist temporarily. The Guardian said Mr. Wright was not in attendance at this work's deletion.

The seemingly bottomless supply of songs that Johnny Cash recorded with the producer Rick Rubin before Cash's death in 2003 has yielded enough material for one more album. As you'd expect from the musician who called himself the Man in Black, this latest album, "American VI: Ain't No Grave," is a mix of the mournful and the morbid: in a news release, publicists for Cash said it would include covers of Sheryl Crow's "Redemption Day," Kris Kristofferson's "For the Good Times" and Tom Paxton's "Can Help But Wonder Where I'm Bound" as well as "Aloha Oe," and an original song called "I Corinthians: 15:55." Lost Highway Records, which is releasing the album on Feb. 26 (which would have been Cash's 78th birthday), called it the "final installment" in Cash's "American Recordings" series, whose first self-titled release was in 1994. (As with other departed artists, this may not necessarily be Mr. Cash's last posthumous release.) In a statement, Mr. Rubin said the songs on "American VI" were recorded in the months after Cash's wife, June Carter Cash, died. "Johnny said that recording was his main reason for being alive," Mr. Rubin added. "I think it was the only thing that kept him going."

After 9/11, the French newspaper Le Monde declared: We Are All Americans. And after yesterday's earthquake: Today, we are all Haitians. No country seems to have had worse luck with misrule, environmental mismanagement, natural disasters and poor governance than Haiti. And now the earthquake.Poverty always hugely magnifies natural disasters. I saw this first in the terrible 1991 cyclone in Bangladesh that killed more than 100,000 people. The poorest people lived in marginal areas, such as flood plains, and in flimsy huts that were immediately washed away. So they were killed. Those who were better off lived on firmer land in sturdier homes, and after the disaster they were able to afford clean water and medical care for their children. Frequently what kills people in these disasters isn't just nature but its interconnection with poverty, and in Haiti it's imperative to arrange not only the earthquake response -- digging people out of rubble -- but also a public health response by controlling disease and assuring access to clean water for survivors.

For a month, fans and potential customers of the New Orleans Jazz and Heritage Festival have been eyeing a big "artist TBA" on the schedule New Orleans Jazz and Heritage Festival. That TBA has now been announced by the festival: the surprise act for the first of Jazzfest's two weekends, on April 24, will be the reunited Simon and Garfunkel. It's not the first time that Paul Simon has played Jazzfest, but it will be Art Garfunkel's first time there, and this is to be Simon and Garfunkel's only American appearance in 2010. Simon and Garfunkel fans have been awaiting news of unions shows in the United States since Mr. Garfunkel joined Mr. Simon onstage at the Beacon Theater in New York last February. The festival, now in its 41st year, will also feature, among many others, Lionel Richie, My Morning Jacket, Dr. John, Darius Rucker and Drake in its first weekend (April 23 to 25), and Pearl Jam, Aretha Franklin, Van Morrison, B.B. King, the Neville Brothers and Widespread Panic in its second (April 29 to May 2).

If the phrases “David After Dentist,” “Lady Gaga Medley” and “Keyboard Cat” make you crack up immediately, or at least giggle, then the YouTube Wars Part I competition is the place to be tonight. Bring your knowledge of viral videos to the performance space Littlefield in Brooklyn, where contestants can go head to head in a bracket-style tournament. For each round, the two competitors will face off by playing their two favorite YouTube videos to wow the crowd. Whoever gets the best reaction moves on to the next round. Come armed with a playlist worthy of a belly laugh or at least a hearty guffaw. Organizers recommend choosing your start point wisely; video clips are limited to one minute. There will be prizes and drink specials, too.

It’s hard to sift through all 32 offerings of features and shorts from 13 countries that are part of the 19th annual Jewish Film Festival, which begins tonight. World War II dramas, the story of a Rothschild baroness in postwar New York, and a crime story co-directed by a Palestinian and an Israeli are all on the bill. Two of the stronger films, according to Stephen Holden, “depart from the beaten path of historical documentaries and feature films, many of which focus on the Holocaust.” One of them is Haim Tabakman’s fateful drama “Eyes Wide Open,” set in contemporary Jerusalem. The film observes the unforgiving response within an ultra-Orthodox enclave to a gay relationship involving one of its own. The other is Adam Elliot’s claymation feature, “Mary and Max,” which follows the pen-pal relationship of Mary Dinkle (the voice of Toni Collette), a lonely 8-year-old girl living outside Melbourne, Australia, and Max Horovitz (Philip Seymour Hoffman), an obese 44-year-old Jewish New Yorker with Asperger’s syndrome. Go to see those and discover other surprising cinematic gems. The films will be shown at the Walter Reade Theater and the Jewish Museum.

“Nowhere in New York right now is the fetish for pork fat and dairy flavor more on display,” Sam Sifton writes, than at the Breslin where “April Bloomfield, the chef and an owner, is exhausting gall bladders daily.” If the thought of shredded lamb, breaded and fried; or a soft-boiled Scotch egg, the orb caked in sausage meat, then breaded and fried; or deep-fried stuffed pig’s foot, “the size of a toddler’s leg,” makes your mouth water, then this is your spot. The vaguely British barroom, off the lobby of the Ace Hotel, attracts a “bedlam of gastrotourists and scenemakers.” But a visit should not be taken lightly: with an offering of “10 colors of fat,” “excess can become wretched, and fast.” Thankfully, at least for your body’s sake, the restaurant doesn’t take reservations.

After weeks of complaints from ticket holders, the producers of the Broadway musical “Spider-Man, Turn Off the Dark” announced on Tuesday that they would refund tickets through Ticketmaster for preview performances that had been scheduled to start on Feb. 25 but are now, as expected, canceled. The producers did not provide new dates for previews or an opening night, saying only that a revised schedule would be announced shortly and that they still planned to open the show in 2010. With music by U2’s Bono and the Edge and direction by Julie Taymor (“The Lion King”), “Spider-Man” has been marred by delays after an earlier group of producers was unable to raise the money to produce the show. The production is now expected to cost about $50 million, making it the most expensive in Broadway history.

Spider-Man and Tobey Maguire are parting ways. Mr. Maguire was set to reprise his leading role in “Spider-Man 4” in May 2011 with Sam Raimi, right, who directed the first three installments, returning to the helm. But after disagreements about the creative direction of the film Mr. Raimi opted to depart, according to Deadline.com. Rather than go forward with a different director, Sony decided on a “Spider-Man” reboot that it had been simultaneously developing. In a press release on Monday, Sony confirmed that the next “Spider-Man” movie would take Peter Parker back to high school. The new chapter, written by James Vanderbilt (“Zodiac”), will have a new cast and director, and focus on “a teenager dealing with both contemporary human problems and amazing superhuman crises,” Sony said. The target release date is now summer 2012. Together, the first three “Spider-Man” movies sold over $1 billion in tickets at North American theaters, according to Box Office Mojo.

Are N.F.L. coaches catching on to the latest research that says kicking on fourth down isn't always the smart call? Possibly. Fourth-down conversion attempts were more common in 2009 than in any other year of the decade. From 2000 through 2008, offenses attempted conversions on 12.4 percent of fourth downs. In 2009, the rate was 14.5 percent. Although only 2.1 percentage points higher in absolute terms, this represents a 17 percent increase in the frequency of attempts.

MY mother broiled a mean steak, but it was never better than when she was able to coax a tri-tip out of the butcher. She faced two challenges when buying this cut. First, there is only one per cow, so it is not all that common. Second, it goes by so many (often incorrect) names -- California cut, Newport steak, sirloin tip, sirloin butt, culotte, bottom sirloin, top sirloin and more -- that it's sometimes a bit of work just to make it clear what you want. I prefer the term tri-tip, which I believe to be not only correct but descriptive, because the steak is triangular and is the tip of the sirloin. This ultra-thick, nicely marbled, strongly flavored steak is perfect for roasting, broiling or a combination of stove-top and oven cooking. It's wonderfully suited to this practically instant version of romesco, the Catalan sauce more commonly used with fish. (If you can't find tri-tip, use any thick cut of sirloin, or even steaks from the not-too-flavorful fillet, which will be helped immeasurably by the romesco.)

The Cowboys and the Jets played on wild-card Saturday, yet drew Sunday games in the divisional round. That gives them seven days between games. The Cardinals and the Ravens played on Sunday, yet drew Saturday games in the divisional round. That gives them five days between games. The Cowboys are America's Team. The Jets hail from the league's biggest market. It may seem as if the N.F.L. is playing favorites, but it's not so: divisional-round schedules were determined on Jan. 4. That raises the question: If the N.F.L. is able to determine wild-card dates and start times after the final action in Week 17, why aren't the divisional-round dates and start times determined after the final action in the wild-card round? ANDY BENOIT

Shirley Rich, widely regarded as a star among New York casting directors, who for half a century scoured the country for little-known actors -- little-known actors with names like Judd Hirsch, Sean Penn and Tom Cruise -- to flesh out a spate of Broadway plays and Hollywood films, died on Dec. 28 in Greenwich, Conn. She was 87 and lived in Rye, N.Y. Ms. Rich, who was known in private life as Shirley Rich Krohn, died of natural causes, her son, Steven Krohn, said.

There is a surprisingly fine line between nightmarish and cute. Jeremy Wade toes and then smears it in ''There Is No End to More,'' a solo for Jared Gradinger that returned for a one-night engagement at Japan Society on Monday. Mr. Gradinger collaborated on the direction and choreography with Mr. Wade, an American artist living in Berlin whose acclaimed 2006 work, ''Glory,'' brought him to the attention of Japan Society's artistic director, Yoko Shioya. The resulting commission allowed Mr. Wade to spend time in Japan, where he followed his interest in manga comic books and the country's aesthetic of extreme cuteness.

RATTNER--Nathaniel, D.D.S.,91, died peacefully at his Forest Hills home on January 11 after a long struggle with cancer. He leaves behind his wife of 56 years, Miriam, his children Judith (Michael Di Bari) and Kenneth (Patricia) and grandchildren Rebecca, Sofia, Casey and Samantha. A World War II veteran, Nat was generous, gregarious and active until the end. A keen intellect, Nat was an avid philatelist, amateur historian, bridge expert and voracious reader. He will be greatly missed. A memorial service will be held at Schwartz Brothers in Forest Hills on January 13 at 3pm.

NORTH CAROLINA AT CLEMSON9 p.m., ESPN The Tar Heels are rebuilding after their national championship last season. They enter the game with a 12-4 record and a No. 12 ranking. The 24th-ranked Tigers, led by Trevor Booker, are 13-3. In basketball polls, it's good to be a university from North Carolina. For a month, fans of the New Orleans Jazz and Heritage Festival have been eyeing a big ''artist TBA'' on the schedule. That TBA has now been announced: the surprise act for the first of Jazzfest's two weekends, on April 24, will be the reunited duo of Simon and Garfunkel, above. It's not the first time that Paul Simon has played Jazzfest, but it will be Art Garfunkel's, and this is likely to be Simon and Garfunkel's only American appearance in 2010. Simon and Garfunkel fans have been awaiting news of shows in the United States since Mr. Garfunkel joined Mr. Simon onstage at the Beacon Theater in New York last February. The festival, in its 41st year, will also feature, among many others, Lionel Richie, My Morning Jacket, Dr. John, Darius Rucker and Drake in its first weekend (April 23 to 25), and Pearl Jam, Aretha Franklin, Van Morrison, B. B. King, the Neville Brothers and Widespread Panic in its second (April 29 to May 2).

It may sound like an echo of the David Bowie song that goes, ''We can be heroes -- just for one day.'' Seventh Avenue is being renamed ''Project Runway Avenue'' -- just for one day. The day is Wednesday, the day before the cable channel Lifetime will run the first episode from a new season of ''Project Runway,'' the designer competition that is changing coasts again. It is returning to New York after a run in Los Angeles. Its return is the reason for the street renaming.

If you've been eager to spend a truly unpleasant hour in a theater, ''Jerk'' at Performance Space 122 is ready to accommodate you. The piece, part of both the Under the Radar Festival and Coil 2010, comes with high expectations, but by its end you may add a few other ''uns'' to your assessment as well, like unrewarding and unenlightening. ''Jerk'' is a one-man puppet show of sorts from France that explores the real-life serial killings by Dean Corll and two young accomplices in Texas in the early 1970s. Jonathan Capdevielle, the performer, and Gisèle Vienne, the director, interpreting text by Dennis Cooper, probably think they're invading the audience's comfort zone in the way that bracing theater often does. Apparently they're not aware that a zillion other artworks about serial killers have already worked this territory to the point of numbness.
