10 P.M. (Cinemax) I LOVE YOU, MAN (2009) Paul Rudd plays Peter Klaven, a girl's guy (code for wuss) without a male friend. Jason Segel, above center left with Mr. Rudd, who teamed up with him in ''Forgetting Sarah Marshall,'' is Sydney Fife, a guy's guy so secure in his maleness that he wears Ugg boots and shorts to walk his teeny dog. The two meet cute at an open house and, voilà!, Peter has a best man to stand by his side at his wedding to Zooey (Rashida Jones) -- if the wedding ends up happening. Writing in The New York Times, Manohla Dargis called the film ''a fitfully funny comedy that owes much to Judd Apatow, the king of such sublimated man-on-man affairs,'' adding that the director, John Hamburg, ''doesn't do anything with the camera, but he sets a nice, easygoing tone for the actors.'' Andy Samberg plays Peter's masculine gay brother; J. K. Simmons and Jane Curtin are their parents; and Lou Ferrigno is himself. 10:30 A.M. (13) RELIGION & ETHICS NEWSWEEKLY Kim Lawton looks at the effect of the Haiti earthquake on religious people, and their efforts to send aid. Bob Abernethy talks with Jim Wallis, the author of ''Rediscovering Values: On Wall Street, Main Street and Your Street -- A Moral Compass for the New Economy,'' about the ethical implications of the lavish bonuses expected to be given to financial industry executives later this month.

Members of the Cleveland Orchestra were onstage on Thursday night for performances of Strauss's ''Don Juan,'' a violin concerto by Thomas Adès and Brahms's Second Symphony. It was their first night back with their music director, Franz Welser-Möst, since Jan. 6, when they had said that a strike could take place as early as this Monday. About 15 minutes before the concert's 8 p.m. start time, they left the stage, and a colleague announced that they would be passing through the aisles with leaflets, which is exactly what they did. (Above, the keyboardist Joela Jones.) The leaflets made the performers' case in a contract dispute with management, which wants them to take a salary cut this season, as staff members and executives have done. The musicians are calling for a freeze in pay at last year's levels. After the leaflets were distributed, the players made their way back to their chairs, tuned up and started ''Don Juan.''

The embattled president of Stevens Institute of Technology, Harold J. Raveché, will step down in July, the college said Friday. And under the terms of a settlement ending a lawsuit by the State of New Jersey that questioned his $1.1 million salary, the institute said it had accepted extensive governance changes that would stiffen oversight of its financial management. Dr. Raveché will be paid his salary, which exceeds those earned by the presidents of Harvard, Princeton and M.I.T., for a year after he leaves office July 1, Attorney General Anne Milgram said. And under the terms of his contract, Dr. Raveché will be compensated as a consultant through June 2014, she said.

Johnson & Johnson paid kickbacks to the nation's largest nursing home pharmacy to increase the number of elderly patients taking the antipsychotic Risperdal and several other medications, according to a complaint filed Friday by the office of the United States attorney in Boston. The payments violated the federal anti-kickback statute and led Omnicare, a pharmacy company specializing in dispensing drugs to nursing home residents, to submit false claims to Medicaid, the complaint charged.

Art Bartlett, a founder of Century 21, the real estate franchising giant whose brand name eventually appeared on ''For Sale'' signs on lawns throughout the country and even abroad, died on Dec. 31 at his home in Coronado, Calif. He was 76. The cause was complications of Alzheimer's disease, his daughter, Stacy Bartlett Renshaw, said. Mr. Bartlett and his business partner, Marshall Fisher, were groundbreakers in the residential real estate industry -- among the first to enable hundreds, and later thousands, of brokers operating from their own offices to compete with the regional and national chains that began emerging in the late 1960s.

Deep in thought over possible retirement last summer, Bode Miller was in a strikingly different place on Friday, back atop a World Cup podium after his first victory in nearly two years. It came in the super-combined event, a shortened downhill run and then a single slalom run that served as an hors d'oeuvre before Wengen's main course -- the classic Lauberhorn downhill on Saturday that is one of the most historic and picturesque events, and one that Miller won in 2007 and 2008.

Service Saturday, January 16, 11:30am at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81st St.

Senator Ben Nelson, below, Democrat of Nebraska, on Friday asked the Senate majority leader, Harry Reid of Nevada, to remove a special provision in the health care legislation that would have the federal government pay all the costs for a proposed expansion of Medicaid in Nebraska. The provision was added to the Senate version of the legislation to help secure Mr. Nelson's vote after he expressed concerns about the cost of the expansion. Under the Senate bill, the federal government would pick up the full cost of the expansion for three years, after which states would have to pay a small portion of the expense.

KIRSTEN--Marvin J.,died January 15 at the age of 88. Beloved husband of Anita (Tiplitz) for 66 years, father of James and Patricia Ehrmann (Steve), Bop to Elizabeth and Ben, and brother to Helen Levine. Veteran of WWII, photographer with Merrill's Marauders in Burma. Graduate of Wharton School at University of Pennsylvania. Manufacturer of men's clothing for many years. He will be missed by many for his warmth and concern for others. Service Sunday, January 17 at Riverside Chapel, Amsterdam Avenue and West 76th Street at 11:15am.

SABBAGH--Hassib. The Sabbagh family sadly announces the passing of Mr. Hassib J. Sabbagh on Tuesday, January 12, 2010 in Cleveland, Ohio at age 89. Born to a prominent Christian family in Palestine in 1920, Mr. Sabbagh graduated from the American University of Beirut in 1941. Upon graduation, he borrowed $1,000.00 from his uncle and co-founded Consolidated Contractors Company (CCC) with Said Khoury. CCC is today one of the largest construction companies in the Middle East. At the time of his death, Mr. Sabbagh was CCC's honorary chairman. Hassib Sabbagh was an extraordinary humanitarian and philanthropist. He was a major contributor to the American University of Beirut, Harvard University, Cleveland Clinic, Massachusetts General Hospital, Carter Center and The Council on Foreign Relations. He was a founder of Georgetown University's Center for Muslim and Christian Understanding. He was a trustee emeritus of the Cleveland Clinic Foundation. He also founded the Diana Tamari Sabbagh Foundation, a large charitable organization that supports educational and medical institutions across the world. He was decorated by the Vatican under Pope John Paul II. A mass and funeral services will be held in Beirut, Lebanon on Sunday, January 17, 2010. Condolences in Beirut will be received at Sabbagh and Khoury Building. Nicola Sursok Street, Ramlet Albaida on Monday and Tuesday 18 and 19 January. Condolences in New York City will be received at a future date which will be announced.

With uncounted thousands dead and many thousands more injured, the stricken city of Port-au-Prince is in a vast medical crisis. Patients with head, chest or abdominal injuries or whose limbs have been badly crushed need immediate surgery, but given the collapse of hospitals and medical centers, little is available.

The pharmaceutical industry's trade group will oppose health care legislation if the White House and Congress reduce a proposed 12-year exclusivity period for biologic drugs, according to an e-mail message that the head of the trade group, Billy Tauzin, sent to the group's board members on Friday. The board includes the chief executives of Pfizer, Merck, Bristol-Myers Squibb and other leading pharmaceutical companies.

NASH--Warner, M.D.,died peacefully in his home at age 88 on January 3rd, 2010. Born in Mainz, Germany, he came to the United States at age 17 and joined the US Army in 1942. He attended Washington University, in St. Louis and later graduated with an M.D. in 1953 from Columbia University's College of Physicians and Surgeons. It was there that he discovered the work he loved and met the person with whom he would share a life of immeasurable joy, Artemis Damaskinidou, his medical school classmate. Warner approached his work as an Obstetrician and Gynecologist at Lenox Hill and Doctors Hospitals with passion. He adored delivering babies as a solo practitioner for over 40 years. He always wore a warm smile and had a constant sparkle in his blue eyes. Warner is survived by his devoted wife of 56 years, Artemis, his loving daughters, Jackie and Laurie, sons-in-law, Peter and Mark, granddaughters; Phoebe, Anna and Julia and a grandson, Max. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions to www.fistulafoundation.org or to the charity of your choice are welcomed. For information call (609)731-0088.

Sand volleyball has secured its spot on the list of emerging sports for women after narrowly surviving a vote Friday by Division I institutions and athletic conferences at the N.C.A.A. convention to strip the sport of its status. The vote was 166, or 58 percent, in favor of removing sand volleyball from the list, and 118, or 42 percent, opposed. Opponents of sand volleyball needed a 62 1/2 percent vote to prevail. Backers of the popular outdoor version of volleyball successfully lobbied last year to add sand volleyball, commonly known as beach volleyball, to a list of emerging sports intended to expand athletic opportunities for women. But no sooner had the sport been added than opponents sought to override the decision.

As tension rose here in the battered Haitian capital, relief workers scrambled on Friday to deliver desperately needed food, water and medical care, recover survivors still trapped in the rubble and collect thousands of decaying bodies from the streets. An immense relief operation was under way, with cargo planes and military helicopters buzzing over the crowded Toussaint Louverture International Airport. But three days after the earthquake struck, with many cries for help going silent, not nearly enough search and rescue teams or emergency supplies could make it here. The United Nations said it had fed 8,000 people, while two million to three million people remained in dire need.

Prosecutors arrested two former aides of a leading member of Japan's governing party on Friday, adding to a growing campaign finance scandal that has dogged the new government. Prosecutors also requested an arrest warrant for a third former aide of the official, Ichiro Ozawa, the secretary general of the Democratic Party, as they investigate about $4 million in improperly reported money used to buy land in Tokyo.

Dennis Stock, a photographer whose intimate and evocative portraits captured the essence of jazz performance and helped shape James Dean's moody public persona, died Monday in Sarasota, Fla. He was 81. The cause was colon cancer, said the Magnum Photos cooperative, of which Mr. Stock had been a member and mainstay for six decades. Mr. Stock and his wife, the author Susan Richards, divided their time between Sarasota and Bearsville, N.Y.

If you weren't sort of half paying attention to the Jets-Chargers game as you finished off a nice Spanish red, you may have noticed that some of the red-carpet smiles were more forced than usual this year at the Golden Globe awards. Getting out of a limo while you haul a couple of pounds of damp couture silk behind you isn't exactly a blast. Heidi Klum, poured into a soupy Cavalli, actually seemed annoyed by the number of steps she had to negotiate - and she had Seal, her manly husband.

At the On the Runway blog, Cathy Horyn takes a look at Golden Globe fashions: "Getting out of a limo while you haul a couple of pounds of damp couture silk behind you isn't exactly a blast," she writes. "It would have been nice to see someone look playful, friendly and sexy - an I-don't-care-kind-of-girl. Instead the soggy n' safe red carpet of the Globes served up one-shoulder gowns (Amy Poehler in red Jay Godfrey, Marion Cotillard in black Dior, Drew Barrymore in something beige and stuffy), lots of forceful bosom (Mariah Carey, a convincing battleship in black) and far too many renditions of 'Mad Men' hair. Can't we give it a rest?"

"I hope she wins for our movie," Nora Ephron told the Bagger at some awards show or other in the last few weeks, on the subject of Meryl Streep competing with herself in the best actress -- comedy category at the Globes. Ms. Ephron got her wish, when Ms. Streep won for "Julie & Julia."

On Saturday night, at parties given by Paramount and Lionsgate here in Los Angeles, the Bagger encountered those fabled creatures, those unicorns of the awards season, the members of the Hollywood Foreign Press Association. For the most part, they lived up to their fanboy reputation, snapping photos with stars and acting giddy. The Paramount party, at the Chateau Marmont, attracted an even rarer breed -- older Academy members, who don't usually brave the paparazzi. Don Rickles was there.

MONDAY'S PUZZLE - Some solvers get frustrated when there are too many clues about sports or opera or 19th century French poetry or whatever their particular blind spot happens to be. Today's crossword is much simpler for television watchers. TV used to be the closest we had to a broadly shared cultural experience. Say the secret word and win $100. These days, you may not even have any friends who watch the tube. Times have changed.

Steven Spielberg is turning his eye to Ground Zero. The Oscar-winning director will be the executive producer of a documentary with the Science Channel about the reconstruction of the former World Trade Center site in lower Manhattan, Variety reported last week. "Rebuilding Ground Zero" will be broadcast in six parts in 2011. Filmed in 3D and high definition, the series will examine the different groups working to build the project, from the Port Authority of New York & New Jersey to the engineers, politicians and constructions crews. The series will also make use of time-lapse photography and other methods to chronicle the construction of One World Trade Center. The idea was initially conceived of by the architect Danny Foster and the director Jonathan Hock.
A look at some of the company’s past productions.

The awards season is off to a good start for Kathryn Bigelow. Her action-packed film, "The Hurt Locker," about a bomb disposal unit in Baghdad, took home prizes for best picture and best director at the Critics' Choice Awards on Friday, The Associated Press reported. "It's wonderful to have this honor," Ms. Bigelow said at the ceremony, "but the recognition should also go to the men and women who are in the field to this day." James Cameron's "Avatar" and Quentin Tarantino's "Inglourious Basterds" won the most awards, with Mr. Tarantino's cast taking the prize for best ensemble and Christoph Walz winning for best supporting actor. Mr. Tarantino also won for best original screenplay. "Avatar" was named best action movie and also won for cinematography, editing, art direction, sound and visual effects. Jeff Bridges' turn as a hard-drinking country singer in "Crazy Heart" earned him the best actor award while Meryl Streep and Sandra Bullock tied for the best actress honor for their respective work in "Julie & Julia" and "The Blind Side" and Mo'Nique won the best supporting actress prize for her portrayal of an abusive mother in "Precious." The winners are chosen by members of the Broadcast Film Critics Association.

The University of Pennsylvania is now home to the papers of the Jewish American author and rabbi Chaim Potok, the university announced Friday. Potok, the author of "The Chosen," "My Name is Asher Lev" and other works about the struggle between religious and secular Jewish life, died in 2002 at age 73. An alumnus of the university, he bequeathed his papers to Penn, where he also taught. The collection includes writings, correspondence, lectures, sermons, article clippings and fan mail, including a letter from the Nobel Laureate and Holocaust survivor Elie Wiesel. The collection will be housed in the university's rare book and manuscript library.

Audiences can now prepare for boarding: "Come Fly Away" has its crew. The new Broadway musical conceived, choreographed and directed by Twyla Tharp and based on the music of Frank Sinatra, has announced its cast. The show, about four couples who fall in and out of love at a nightclub, stars Matthew Dibble, Holley Farmer, Laura Mead, Charlie Neshyba-Hodges, Rika Okamoto, Karine Plantadit, Keith Roberts and John Selya, all of whom appeared in last fall's production of the show, then called, "Come Fly With Me," at Atlanta's Alliance Theater and several of whom appeared in Ms. Tharp's 2002 Broadway hit "Movin' Out" (that one was based on the music of Billy Joel). The show, which has a cast of 15 dancers and an on-stage 19-piece big band, is to begin previews on March 1 and open on March 25 at the Marquis Theater..

Update | 3:35 p.m. The architect Frank Gehry has withdrawn from a project to design a Museum of Tolerance in Jerusalem, according to a report in Israel's Haaretz newspaper last week. The building, which is being built by the Simon Wiesenthal Center, which opened the first Museum of Tolerance in Los Angles in 1993, has drawn criticism because it is being constructed on a site that was once part of a Muslim cemetery. However, other architects involved in the project say that Mr. Gehry's resignation was not related to protests over the site, but to financial issues. According to the architecture firm, Kolker, Kolker, Epstein Architects, part of the initial planning team, Mr. Gehry resigned after rejecting a request by the center to reduce the scope of the plan, the cost of which has been estimated at $250 million. Plans for the project were first announced at a groundbreaking ceremony in 2004 which included the former prime minister Benjamin Netanyahu, Mr. Gehry and Arnold Schwarzenegger in Jerusalem.

An article on Dec. 27 about the play “Silver Stars” misstated the project on which Culture Ireland and the Irish Theater Institute collaborated for the Dublin Theater Festival, where the play had a run in September. They produced a showcase with the Dublin Theater Festival, they did not produce the entire festival.
An article last Sunday about George Clooney misstated the profession of the character he played in “Michael Clayton.” He was a lawyer and former prosecutor; he was not a former police officer.

An article last Sunday about the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences’ lack of recognition of Doris Day referred incorrectly to the academy’s recognition of Orson Welles. He did in fact win an Oscar in a specific category, for best screenplay (“Citizen Kane”) in 1941. It is not the case that, like Charlie Chaplin, he “inexplicably never won the prize in competition.” (Welles also received an honorary Oscar in 1970.).

The “Living In” column on Dec. 27, about Chickahominy, Conn., misspelled the name of a local stone mason who emigrated from Sardinia in the 1902s and was responsible for building various structures in town. He was Sebastiano Bazzoni, not Bozzoni.

The “On the Market” page last Sunday included an erroneous name on the contributors’ line. It was Elsa Brenner who provided a listing for a 1910 colonial in Upper Grand View in Rockland County. It was not Marcelle S. Fischler.

A rendering with the “Postings” column last Sunday about Hunters Point South, a midpriced housing development slated to be built on the Queens waterfront, carried an incomplete credit. The rendering was by Arup/Thomas Balsley Associates/Weiss/Manfredi — not just Weiss/Manfredi.

The “In the Region” article in Westchester and Connecticut copies last Sunday, about plans and timetables for new affordable housing in Westchester in light of a recent court mandate, misidentified the nonprofit group that is marketing Minerva Place, a 14-unit affordable development in White Plains. It is Community Housing Innovations — not the Housing Action Council, another builder of affordable housing in the area.

These pancakes are so feathery, creamy and tangy that you may find yourself unable to let them cool off before devouring them.

This recipe appeared in The Times in an article by Joanna Pruess. The recipe came from Bridge Creek Restaurant in Berkeley, Calif. A few tips: Don’t cook the pancakes all the way through. You want the center to be a pocket of cream. The pancakes are so fragile that it may take a few tries to flip them. I used the thinnest, most flexible spatula I own, wedged it halfway under the pancake, letting the other half hang, then turned my wrist and gently laid it down on the other side. I recommend this over more aggressive flipping, which will tear the pancakes.

The 36 Hours column on Jan. 3 about Tucson, Ariz., misstated the cross street of the location of one cafe and misstated part of the name of a menu item at another cafe. The Epic Cafe is on the corner of University Boulevard, not University Avenue, and the sampler of three dishes chosen by the chef at Cafe Poca Cosa is called El Plato Poca Cosa, not La Plato Poca Cosa.

To the Editor: The article “36 Hours Tucson, Ariz.” (Jan. 3) gave lots of excellent suggestions about my city. I was surprised, though, that the author recommended flying to Phoenix and driving “scenic I-10” to Tucson. This is one of the most unattractive and crowded roads in Arizona, and it can be closed for hours by traffic accidents (once you leave Phoenix, there’s no alternate route). Anyone who wants to come to Tucson for just 36 hours — and spend four (or many more) hours on I-10 — should instead take a flight to our convenient, uncrowded airport.

To the Editor: Regarding the Practical Traveler column “10 Ways to Cut Your Travel Costs This Year” (Jan. 10), as I read this article, I thought to myself: We are still in a recession. People are spending carefully; discretionary funds are all but extinct. So, why would I go through all this trouble (10 steps) to find a cheap fare. The airlines and hotels want my money. They’ve made a fortune over the past 10 years during the boom; now they have to adjust and offer me deep discounts if they want my money. I will not be running myself ragged trying to get the best deal. Period.

McGILL--Helen Ludwig, born July 3rd 1911, WPA artist, sculptor, painter, teacher, dancer, ceramicist and community activist, died of natural causes on November 28th 2009, four months after celebrating her 98th birthday. She joins her beloved husband, philosopher VJ McGill (born 18971977) in the peaceful hereafter, after a conscious goodbye full of music and laughter, reminiscing with her dear granddaughter and friends and family from her city of San Francisco. Helen is survived by her daughter, Maisie Conrad; son-in-law, Richard Conrad; granddaughter Vera Conrad; grandson Ethan Conrad; great granddaughter Olivia Conrad; niece Donna Stuart by marriage to the late David Stuart; brother Raymond Ludwig and his wife Jean; descendants from Connecticut through the Ludwig, Zahner, Gottier, and Neumann families. A memorial service will be held on Saturday, January 23rd 2010, at 3pm in the chapel of the First Unitarian Church, located at 1187 Franklin Street, San Francisco, CA 94109. In lieu of flowers, donations in Helen's memory may be made to KQED, at kqed.org.

DIBB--June Anne (Bridges), M.D.,of Ho-Ho-Kus, NJ died Wednesday, January 13, 2010 at age 79. Born in Cold Spring on Hudson, NY on June 1, 1930 she lived in Ho-Ho-Kus for 42 years. Dr. Dibb was a graduate of Vassar College and the University of Pennsylvania Medical School. She served her psychiatric residency at Columbia-Presbyterian Hospital and NYS Psychiatric Institute, NY, NY. Other professional appointments include Assistant Clinical Professor for Albert Einstein College of Medicine, Bronx, NY from 1968 to June of 1977 and attending Psychiatrist for Bergen Regional Health, Paramus from 1974 till the present. Dr. Dibb also maintained private psychiatric practices, first in New York, and later in Ho-Ho-Kus, spanning nearly 50 years. Surviving is her dear husband Kenneth Lawler Bridges, of Ho-Ho-Kus, NJ, and her devoted daughters Brooke Eaton Bridges (Frank) of New York City and Paige Lawler Bridges of Washington, DC. Also surviving are her two beloved grandchildren, Saxon Eaton Frank and Bowie Bridges Frank and her brother, Jack Dibb of Pasadena, CA. She was predeceased by her sister Helen Gleszer of St. Petersburg, FL. The family will receive friends on Saturday, January 23, 2010 from 14pm at the Vander Plaat Funeral Home, vpfh.com, 257 Godwin Ave., Wyckoff, NJ. Private cremation will be held. In lieu of flowers, donations to the James A. McFaul Environmental Center, 150 Crescent Ave., Wyckoff, NJ 07481 (payable to the County of Bergen) would be appreciated.

EISENBERG--Ethel Piermont, passed away January 9, 2010 with her children by her side. Born May 5, 1919 to Kate and Gustav in New York City. Pre-deceased by her beloved Saul. Survived by daughters Susan Fisch, Marcy Eisenberg, Kate Robinson, son-in-law Andrew Robinson, granddaughter Sarah Robinson, and brother Donald Piermont, Sr. All will miss her perfect pitch, wonderful wit and endless love. She also leaves devoted caretakers, Anne Keane and Kay Munnelly, as well as scores of friends and family. Donations to benefit Alzheimer's research and care to Eisenberg Family Charitable Trust, c/o Jacqueline Elias, JP Morgan Private Bank, 345 Park Avenue, 4th Floor, New York, NY 10154.

SAN MIGUEL DEL MONTE, ARGENTINA, APRIL 18, 2009 I came to Argentina with a one-way ticket on Jan. 6, 2009, with no plan of what to do next or when to return. I met Mauro (pictured) in El Calafate, Argentina, and spent the next eight months taking weekend road trips with a South American Vespa club. This was taken in San Miguel del Monte, a small Argentinian town 140 kilometers outside the city of Buenos Aires. I would never have had the sheer pleasure of meeting this village, off the pages of the Rough Guide, had it not been for Mauro and his passion for Vespas. LEAH CONCANNON

WERNER--Harold D.,89, of Morris Township, NJ, died at home on December 20, 2009. He was a dearly loved husband, father, grandfather, great-grandfather, and uncle. He was the chief psychiatric social worker at the Morris County Guidance Center, founder of the local chapter of Big Brothers, and Executive Director of the League for Family Service in Bloomfield, NJ. He co-founded and was president of Psychiatric Outpatient Centers of America (POCA), and taught at Fairleigh Dickinson and Kean Universities. Werner challenged Freud's theory of the unconscious in his three books on cognitive therapy. He is survived by his wife of 65 years, Hilda, his son Ken, his daughter April, his nieces, and their families. He will be sorely missed.

BROWN--Marguerite Dressner, of Cambridge, MA, January 13. Beloved wife of Benjamin H. Brown, mother of Elspeth W. Macdonald and Mark Woodcock of New York, and Timothy B. Brown of Cambridge. Also survived by a brother, Elliott Dressner, of Houston, Texas, six grandchildren and three great-grandsons.

Theater Of all the soigné, quip-dispensing and unquenchably self-dramatizing characters created by Noël Coward, few came closer to self-portraiture than Garry Essendine, the beleaguered actor-protagonist in ''PRESENT LAUGHTER,'' the 1939 comedy that opens in revival this Thursday at the American Airlines Theater. ''Garry Essendine is me,'' Coward said, atypically disregarding grammar for the sake of emphasis. As Coward's biographer Philip Hoare pointed out, it wasn't so much Essendine's surface sophistication or narcissism as his appetite for control amid chaos that made him so revealingly like his creator. And actors throughout the years have had a high old time portraying Essendine's exquisite agony as his carefully ordered world threatens to crash down upon him: Coward himself, of course, but also Clifton Webb (in the play's belated Broadway debut in 1946), George C. Scott (1982) and Frank Langella (in 1996). Now Victor Garber takes up Essendine's cigarette holder and silk dressing gown in a Roundabout Theater Company production directed by Nicholas Martin. Though an assured Broadway veteran, Mr. Garber is probably best known as the not- quite-trustworthy authority figure from the television spy drama ''Alias.'' Expect him and Mr. Martin, who delivered a bracingly unconventional ''Hedda Gabler'' (starring Kate Burton) in 2001, to find some ambiguous shadows within Essendine's urbanity. 227 West 42nd Street, Manhattan, (212) 719-1300, roundaboutheatre.org; $66.50 to $116.50.

To the Sports Editor: Re ''McGwire Admits Steroid Use in 1990s, His Years of Magic,'' Jan. 12: Mark McGwire claims that steroids did not improve his ability to hit the ball. He missed the point. Steroids enabled him to hit it farther, for home runs. Bottom line: McGwire remains a liar. Gary Wesley

HAAS--Barbara Hersch, passed away peacefully on January 12, 2010. Beloved by her companion and best friend, Howard Eisenstein, her family and many friends. Barbara was a lady of style and grace and shared her love for life with all who had the privilege of knowing her. Barbara's warmth, goodness, compassion and concern for others were her hallmarks. YVES PINARD, the head chef at Le Grand Louvre restaurant beneath I. M. Pei's pyramid in Paris, has used the Louvre's paintings as inspiration for many of his dishes. In ''Food in the Louvre'' (Flammarion, $19.95), all those paintings are collected with commentary and recipes by Mr. Pinard, and a forward by Paul Bocuse, the Michelin star-studded chef. Mr. Pinard's recipes combine seemingly incompatible ingredients like skate wing, oysters and saffron that somehow end up alluring.

''A day felt like a year. You're buried alive. You can't scream. You wonder if anyone will ever come.'' Ronald Jedna, who was rescued from the rubble of his apartment building after the earthquake in Haiti.

Fashion is showing the sobering effects of the recession in a very positive way. The inexpensive and lightweight puffy down coats that have been around for decades have taken sophisticated new shapes, often in licorice black and in fabrics that resemble ciré (top row). During the holiday season, these shiny-surface coats were a favorite of European visitors -- and one tiny dog. Others prefer a matte finish (bottom row). There are cocoons, capes, pillow collars, baby dolls and even a jacket with a bustle back. Young people have completely embraced down, while their mothers, accustomed to winter furs, continue with pelts.

Haitians have been migrating to the United States since even before their nation became independent in 1804, but the bulk came in waves driven by political repression and economic uncertainty, through the 1980s and 1990s. In 2008, nearly 800,000 Americans identified Haitian as their ancestry, and 522,000 said they were born in Haiti. There are 250,000 Haitian-Americans in the New York area. More than 75,000 live in Brooklyn, primarily in Flatbush and Flatlands but also in Canarsie, and nearly 40,000 in Queens, mainly around Cambria Heights; there are also concentrated pockets in Rockland, Suffolk, Essex and Fairfield Counties. They are more likely than other immigrants from the Caribbean to be naturalized United States citizens. Thousands of Haitians, mobilized by ethnic radio stations and other media, protested in 1997 against the police officers who brutalized Abner Louima, a 30-year-old Haitian immigrant, in Brooklyn. A decade later, Mathieu Eugene became the first Haitian-born member of the New York City Council.

LETTANG--John. Died suddenly on January 14, 2010 in New York City. He was known as a friend to the wildlife of Central Park, the birdwatchers of Pale Male and Lola, and loved the arts through his timeless photography. Most of all he loved his family, fellow bird watchers, and park friends. Known previously as the gentle doorman at 470 Park Avenue he will be dearly missed by all. We invite all who knew my father for a remembrance on Sunday, January 17 at 2pm in Central Park on the Bridge over the Pond near Central Park South.

Donations may be made to the Center for Hope Hospice, Scotch Plains, NJ or to any no-kill animal shelter.

THOMPSON--Robert L.,Professor Emeritus of psychology at Hunter College and the Graduate Center of the City University of New York, and leader of the Red Onion Jazz Band, died peacefully January 13, 2010 at St. Luke's Hospital after suffering a collapse. Born December 6, 1926 in New York City, he received his doctorate in experimental psychology from Columbia University in 1959. He taught at Columbia, then at Hunter College, establishing its doctoral program in biopsychology and chairing it for many years. "Bob" Thompson led the Red Onion Jazz Band, a traditional New Orleans-style jazz band, for over fifty years. He played drums with what Allegro called "some of the greatest jazz performers of the 20th century." Dr. Thompson was a founding member of the Society for Neuroscience, an active member of the New York Academy of Sciences, and co-editor of the Academy volume The Self Across Psychology. He leaves behind his partner of 30 years, Virginia Held, her children and grandchildren, and his stepdaughter Elyn MacInnis and her family. We will miss him terribly. Donations may be made to the Martha's Vineyard Trustees of Reservations or the American Association for the Advancement of Science. A memorial service will be held at a later date.

STRAUSS--Helen May, psychologist, 94, passed away peacefully on January 10, 2010. Wife of the late Frederick Strauss, daughter of the late Otto and Eugenie May, sister of the late Ernest May. BA Barnard, MA/Ph.D. Columbia, Post-Doc NYU; Navy WAVE in WWII; founding faculty IPPNJ; faculty Rutgers GSAPP. Generously shared her professional skills with non-profit organizations and was the 1997 NJ Psychologist of the Year. Adored by her five children (Robert, Arthur, Carol, Walter, Donald), their spouses, eleven grandchildren, two great- grandchildren, countless beloved friends and relatives who span the globe. Memorial Service January 23, 2pm, Unitarian-Universalist Congregation, Montclair, NJ. Donations to Youth Consultation Service, Hackensack, NJ or Children's Defense Fund.

SCHENKEL--Stephen, 75, Emmy nominated television writer, producer and network executive died peacefully. Mr. Schenkel earned his reputation as a creative force and innovator by producing "All My Children," "Another World," and "Edge of Night." Co-Creator/Creative Consultant on "Ryan's Hope" and "ABC After School Specials." A Columbia University grad, Mr. Schenkel served as an executive at NBC, CBS, ABC and Benton & Bowles. He developed and produced a full spectrum of entertainment (variety, mini-series, game) programs and Discovery Channel documentaries. Stephen married his beloved Penny Bergman in 1990 after meeting her on the set of "All My Children." For both, it was a marriage made in soap opera heaven. Survivors include the families of Ellen and Cantor Tyrone Bauer, Bergman and Gottlieb in-laws. Donations: Parkinson's Disease Foundation or Trustees of Columbia Univ. c/o Dr. Leonard Stern/Chronic Kidney Disease Program.

WITH all due respect to Elvis, Graceland Brooklyn has some of the grooviest groomers in Williamsburg. The sleekly renovated motorcycle garage-turned-salon is outfitted with four vintage barber chairs (one from 1901), three tattoo stations, a piano, a turntable and an extensive record collection. GLOVER--William Charles, age 76, of New York City and Nevis, West Indies, on January 12, after a brief battle with brain cancer. William Glover was the Director of The Granger Collection, a leading historical picture library, which he founded with his wife Erika in 1964. He was also a keen photographer, naturalist, and horticulturist with a particular interest in cacti, succulents, and palms. He was born in Wyoming in 1933, read history at Balliol College, Oxford, and after a short stint in the US Army, settled in the 1950s in New York City, where he worked first at Dover Publications and then at Culver Pictures. He is survived by Erika, his wife of 47 years; daughters Johanna Wasylik of Alberta, Canada, and Lorna Abungu of Nairobi, Kenya; sons-in-law Rick Wasylik and George Abungu; and grandchildren Charlotte, Nicholas, and Alexander Wasylik, and Ajuma Abungu. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to The George Marshall Institute (www.marshall.org) or The American Indian College Fund (www.collegefund.org).

EGGERS--George Dewey, Jr. 83, of Princeton, NJ and Key West, FL on December 21, 2009. Educated Poly Prep, Princeton University. A natural leader who served his country with distinction as a Brigadier General, USA. His dedication to Princeton as an administrator and volunteer was generous and unwavering. Survived by his wife Margaret (Mickey), sons George III, and Robert, eight grandchildren and five great-grandchildren. Memorial service Princeton University Chapel, 11:00am Saturday, July 3, 2010. Interment service Arlington National Cemetery, 1:00pm Tuesday, July 6, 2010. Donations may be made to Princeton University for the George D. Eggers, Jr. '47 Book Fund, P.O. Box 5357, Princeton, NJ 08543-5357.

MARTIN--Malcolm Bruce, age 83, died in New York City on December 25. Born and educated in Sidney, Australia, he immigrated to London and joined Revlon International in marketing and began a 35 year career in London, New York and around the world until retirement in 1991. A man of superb taste, a devotee of gentlemans' sports (golf and tennis), a true renaissance man, his life was surrounded by classical music, opera, theatre and the written word. He enjoyed a wide circle of close friends who now mourn their loss as they remember him and prepare to celebrate his life at a funeral at St. Bartholomew's Church Wednesday afternoon January 20 at 4:30pm. In lieu of flowers, gifts can be made to The Friends of Great Music at St. Bartholomew's Church 325 Park Ave, New York, NY 10022.
BAUM--Joan. Lovingly missed and always remembered. The Jurick and Lust Families

LOHMAN--J. Frederic. Known to friends and family as Fritz, was born in Fort Wayne, IN in 1922. He graduated from Kenyon College in Gambier, OH and received his design training at Brown University and the Rhode Island School of Design. After college he went to California where he worked as a set designer for Paramount Pictures and, with the advent of television, with the Dumont Corporation in the same capacity. He then came to New York as assistant decorating department manager of James McCreary & Sons, and later became an associate director of The Bertha Schaefer Art Gallery. In 1951, he established his own interior design firm, J. Frederic Lohman, Ltd., at 451 East 58 Street. Throughout a hugely successful career Fritz lent his design talents to both residential and corporate interiors. Notable on his long list of achievements was Wedgewood House, The Forum (high-rise NYC apartment buildings), the lobbies of The Criterion and The Bergen Mall theaters, the model houses for Reston, VA (Model Community of the Future) near Washington, DC, and the administrative center for Global Foods. Apart from his virtually innumerable residential and corporate environments in New York City and across America, his residential interiors are to be found in London, Vienna, Montreal, Geneva, Jamaica and Lagos, Nigeria. He created settings for UniRoyal, Dupont, and the American Cyanamid Company, and designed several of "The Ten Best Dressed Rooms" at The National Design Center. His American Standard bathrooms and many other promotional settings were regularly seen in national magazines. His atelier catered to a prestigious clientele which included Barbara Walters and the late French couturier, Jacques Fath, among others. Some years before he retired from design, closing his offices in 1984, he and his life partner, Charles Leslie, who he met in 1968, had established a small real estate holding company to acquire and restore neglected SoHo industrial buildings and to convert them for artists' housing. This was in 1969, the same year they mounted their first exhibition of homoerotic art in their SoHo loft. The better part of the next ten years embroiled them in battles with the city to change the zoning in SoHo--The Planning Commission was initially opposed--and to obtain landmark status for The SoHo Cast Iron Historic District from the Landmarks Preservation Commission. Along with others, Fritz was crucially instrumental in achieving both goals. In the 1970s, the couple became involved in the theater, producing several off and off-off-Broadway shows which included "Naked Highway" by Matt Creeger, a spoof based on old movies such as "The Petrified Forest" and "Duel in the Sun", which had a good run at the 7th Ave Playhouse; "Men, Women & Why It Won't Work" by Miriam Fond; and, most notably, "Purification", the only blank verse drama by Tennessee Williams, which had never before been produced. Williams, who was in the audience, praised the production. Although he continued to do work for old friends and clients long after he officially retired, his last major undertaking before that time was the restorative design and complete redecoration of the grand ballroom, the gold room, the hunt room, and the study of the 110-room Vanderbilt mansion, Idle Hour, as Oakdale, Long Island. The mansion belongs to Dowling College and is used for public, administrative and ceremonial functions. Inveterate travelers, Fritz and Charles covered the globe more than once and spent great blocks of time in Asia, Africa and--particularly--in Europe and Morocco. Continuously active in their support of gay causes and organizations (SAGE, The Center, Lambda Legal Defense, etc.) they founded The Leslie/Lohman Gay Art Foundation in 1990 to encourage the creation of and to protect art that is perceived to be gay and therefore endangered by societal prejudice. Fritz took great joy in their large extended family and the three little goddaughters they are putting through school, and the big goddaughter who has her MFA and is pursuing a successful career as an artist. His life was also enriched by their three homes--their New York loft, their country house on the Eastern Shore of Maryland, and a beautiful, ancient Arab house in the medina of Marrakech in Morocco. Apart from Mr. Leslie, family survivors include five nephews, two nieces and their families. In lieu of other remembrances, it is asked that expressions of sympathy be sent to the Leslie/Lohman Gay Art Foundation (LLGAF) referencing the Fritz Lohman Museum Fund. As the co-founder of LLGAF, Fritz's name will now grace a new fund dedicated to the next significant growth phase--the establishment of The Leslie/Lohman Museum of Gay & Lesbian Art. Checks (payable to LLGAF) may be sent to: LLGAF, 26 Wooster Street, NY, NY 10013, Attn: Fritz Lohman Museum Fund.

GOLDSTEIN--Herbert, 93, of Teaneck, NJ on January 13, 2010. Born in Hamilton, Ontario, Canada, he resided in Teaneck since 1979. A veteran of WWII, Dr. Goldstein received his undergraduate and master's degrees from San Francisco State College, earning his Ed. D. in mental retardation at the University of Illinois, Urbana in 1957. He continued at the University of Illinois and rose to the rank of Associate professor while also serving as a special consultant to the Illinois Department of Public Instruction. In 1962, Dr. Goldstein was a Fulbright Scholar and Lecturer at the University of Oslo, Norway, and in 1971, was a Fulbright Scholar in Australia. From 1962 to 1967, he was Professor and Chair of the Department of Special Education at the Ferkhauf Graduate School of Yeshiva University in NYC. In 1968 he became Director of the Curriculum Research & Development Center in mental retardation at Yeshiva and New York Universities. He held a range of leadership positions in professional organizations and retired from NYU in 1980 as professor emeritus. Widely published, Dr. Goldstein is highly regarded as a respected authority and pioneer in his field. He is survived by his beloved wife, Marjorie, sons Jay (Carol) of Winnipeg, Manitoba, Canada, Jed of Denver, CO, grandsons Josh (Maureen) and Eli, and great-granddaughters, Hannah and Abby. He also leaves Mark and Dorothy Tunick, Judith Granoff, Linda Lehman Keefe, deeply valued nieces and nephews, much loved cousins, and many good friends. A memorial service in celebration of his life will be held on Friday, January 29, at 1pm promptly at the Glenpointe Marriott. In lieu of flowers, contributions in his memory may be made to: The Herbert Goldstein Scholarship Fund through the William Paterson University Foundation, 300 Pompton Road, Wayne, NJ 07470 or to Hackensack Hospice Inpatient Unit, 336 Prospect Avenue, Hackensack, NJ 07601.

SABBAGH--Hassib. The Sabbagh family sadly announces the passing of Mr. Hassib J. Sabbagh on Tuesday, January 12, 2010 in Cleveland, Ohio at age 89. Born to a prominent Christian family in Palestine in 1920, Mr. Sabbagh graduated from the American University of Beirut in 1941. Upon graduation, he borrowed $1,000.00 from his uncle and co-founded Consolidated Contractors Company (CCC) with Said Khoury. CCC is today one of the largest construction companies in the Middle East. At the time of his death, Mr. Sabbagh was CCC's honorary chairman. Hassib Sabbagh was an extraordinary humanitarian and philanthropist. He was a major contributor to the American University of Beirut, Harvard University, Cleveland Clinic, Massachusetts General Hospital, Carter Center and The Council on Foreign Relations. He was a founder of Georgetown University's Center for Muslim and Christian Understanding. He was a trustee emeritus of the Cleveland Clinic Foundation. He also founded the Diana Tamari Sabbagh Foundation, a large charitable organization that supports educational and medical institutions across the world. He was decorated by the Vatican under Pope John Paul II. A mass and funeral services will be held in Beirut, Lebanon on Sunday, January 17, 2010. Condolences in Beirut will be received at Sabbagh and Khoury Building. Nicola Sursok Street, Ramlet Albaida on Monday and Tuesday 18 and 19 January. Condolences in New York City will be received at a future date which will be announced.

Once glamorous, air travel has turned into a slog of security rules, long waits and cramped limbs. This is partly because so many more people fly today. In 1940, passenger planes in the United States carried only 3 million people, compared with 17 million in 1950 and about 650 million in 2008, according to FareCompare.com. Keep in mind, too, that in the early 1980s, shortly after deregulation, many of the cheaper domestic roundtrip tickets sold for $250 to $300, and the same is true today, said Rick Seaney, C.E.O. of FareCompare.com. So, adjusted for inflation, the cost of air travel has actually fallen.

SPIELMAN--Rose. January 13, 2010, 106 years young. Predeceased by her beloved husband Benjamin and sons Stanley, Marvin and William. Dearly loved by her daughters-in-law, grandchildren and great-grandchildren. A long life well lived. She will be missed by all.

BROMAN--Marguerite Morgan ("Peggy"), died December 23rd, 2009, in Framingham, Massachusetts. She was born in Revere, MA in 1915, the oldest of the six children of James Morgan and Eileen Glavin Morgan. She graduated from Emerson College in Boston, MA in 1937; and, like her father, she entered the retail business. In her twenties, she started the sportswear department at Arnold Constable (the department store, formerly at 38th St. and Fifth Avenue), which at that time catered to the "carriage trade", but wanted to appeal to a more youthful market; she became the sportswear buyer for the Manhattan store and its suburban branches. As her younger sister, Nancy, said, "She carried the five of us on her shoulders"; all five of her siblings worked for the retail store early in their careers. In 1945 Peggy married Carl A. Broman, in Norfolk, VA. They were later divorced. Throughout her life, Peggy continued to work, while raising her two daughters. She was in the real estate business in Greenwich, CT; and she ultimately managed a retail business in Westport, CT, until her retirement in 1985. But Peggy's greatest achievement was as a pioneer in recognizing and addressing the needs of mentally challenged children and adults. She was an advocate long before that term came into vogue; she mainstreamed her child, both academically and in the workplace, long before it became a matter of course. Her tenacity and strong will set an example for other young parents faced with raising a special-needs youngster. Peggy was a fighter--to the end. She leaves two daughters, Nancy A. Broman, and Constance McCashin; her son-in-law, Sam Weisman; her two grandchildren, Daniel M. Weisman, and Marguerite K. Weisman; her two sisters, Nancy M. Boyle, and Winifred M. Taylor; and numerous nieces and nephews. Contributions in Peggy's memory may be made to The Carmelite Sisters for the Aged and Infirm, St. Patrick's Manor, 863 Central St., Framingham, MA 01701; or to The Abbey of Regina Laudis, 273 Flanders Road, Bethlehem, CT 06751.

WEISS--Clare Megan, curator of public art for New York City Parks Department, died January 11th age 43 of breast cancer. She is survived by her fiance and long time companion William Hampton-Sosa, her loving parents Maggie Boepple and Jonathan Weiss, her devoted stepfather Willard Boepple, her cherished brother Paul Weiss, his wife Nell, their children Clay and Ian of Washington, DC and grandparents Marjorie and Ian Forbes of England. Clare, a graduate of Rutgers and Christies, worked for ABC News for many years and at iVillage, MiaVita, Bruno Marina Gallery and the Brooklyn Museum. A memorial celebration will be held at 2pm Saturday February 13th at the Picnic House in Prospect Park Brooklyn.

He is also survived by sisters Nanette Schwing and Carolyn Wilkinson. Dan was a lifetime baseball and softball player, and devoted New York Yankees fan. He worked as a magazine executive for over 40 years and published an industry newsletter. Please visit his memorial website at: www.memorialwebsites. legacy.com/dancapell.

The Indianapolis Colts probably will not hold up Saturday night's game as a monument to avoiding rust during a playoff bye week, considering that Ed Reed improbably intercepted Peyton Manning twice on the same third-quarter drive. But after nearly a month at the center of the debate about whether teams should rest their starters in meaningless games -- and whether their own history of shaky playoff performances suggested they made the wrong choice -- the Colts provided the answer: this time, it worked for them. The Colts beat the Baltimore Ravens, 20-3, in a somnolent American Football Conference divisional round game, the first time in four tries in the Manning era they have won a playoff game after having a first-round bye. As the conference's top seed, they will host the winner of the Chargers-Jets game next Sunday in the A.F.C. Championship game for the right to go to the Super Bowl.
KAPLAN--Herbert E. Longtime accountant and dear friend to the Levin family. Herb's keen mind, playful wit and gentle heart never wavered, and neither will our memory of him.

WAILL--Robert S.,Economist and Securities Analyst, 79. Died peacefully on January 14, 2010 with his family at his side after battling a long illness. WEISS--Doris (nee Strongin), 87, died peacefully in her sleep January 11, 2010 at home in Miami. Her many friends in Florida, New York, and Sac (you know who you are) treasured her generosity, humor and love, and will miss her profoundly.

CINES--Andrea, June 10, 1938 - January 14, 2010. Passed peacefully and quickly. Devoted mother to Seth and Andrew Matlins; smitten and unconditional lover of her grandchildren, EllaRose and Otis Matlins of Los Angeles, and Hannah Matlins of Bangor, ME. Friend and counsel to her daughters in-law, Eva Karelsen of Los Angeles and Paula Matlins of Bangor. Hers was a life defined by a strong belief in the role of community, whether it be 60 years of allegiance and connection to her classmates at The Little Red Schoolhouse; the neighborhood streets she'd walk in central Jersey, a coterie of other needlepoint aficionados, or her enduring identity as a life-long New Yorker. Daughter of Fannette Aul and Arnold Cines, Andrea brought to life what she had and what she'd been given. She leaves us quickly, too soon, but as always, as a real dame.
DAVIDSON--Stephanie. Seven years and the love is still so strong. Paul, Spencer & Zach

FOR over three decades the photographer Bruce Weber has defined American glamour with his imagery. Mr. Weber has also been a prolific producer of books, including ''All-American,'' an annual almanac of esoterica he encounters in his travels. But when he sat down last year to plan the next edition, the world appeared to have shifted on its axis, with many around him struggling to find their feet. ''I wanted to put together a series of stories as eclectic and inspiring as you might hear at a late-night party,'' Mr. Weber said, ''because the morning after, you feel a reason to continue, even if you don't know all the answers.'' Fittingly, the latest volume in the series, ''All-American IX: A Near-Perfect World'' (Little Bear Press, $140), is a casserole of conceits, from poetry and photojournalism to profiles of the choreographer Carmen de Lavallade and the doomed beatnik pretty-boy artist Bill Morrow. As ever, nature is never far in Mr. Weber's search for the sublime: a paean to Big Sur features the strapping landscapes and characters that have made the place as synonymous with muscular naturalism as Mr. Weber himself. HORACIO SILVA

MARDEN--Michael, of New York City, age 75, died January 7, 2010. Husband of Leslie Macpherson, son of the late Nicholas B. and Kathryn Marden, he was born in New York City on September 27, 1934. He graduated from Briarcliff High School in 1951, Princeton University in 1955, and received his M.A. in American Studies from Columbia University in 1993. He served in the U.S. Army from 1955-1957. His career at CBS Television spanned from 1965 to 1989, working on the acquisition, scheduling and promotion of prime-time movies in New York, then becoming the Director of "Made for Television" movies in Los Angeles, and starting and supervising the CBS Late Movie in New York. In 1977 he became Director of Program Development, responsible for all aspects of developing comedy and dramatic series. After retiring, Mike continued with CBS News/New York Times conducting telephone interviews with members of Congress, delegates to various presidential conventions and the general public on timely subjects of local and national interest. He worked for the U.S. Census in New York and for Robert A. Becker Inc. where he recruited medical professionals for meetings and conferences on medical subjects. He also began working with Service Employees International Union ("SEIU") Communication Center in New York where he recruited union members to support political candidates and issues such as the presidential campaign of John Kerry in St. Louis, the New York State Budget campaign, union organizing in California, and the campaign for Senator Robert Menendez in New Jersey. In 2008 he led the SEIU team in Columbus, Ohio registering voters on behalf of Barack Obama. He went on to do similar work for then Senator Obama in Texas and Pennsylvania. He is survived by his wife Leslie, sons Scott, David, Christopher, Michael and daughter Sarah Guidotti (all by his first wife Suzanne Jacobs), grandson Ellis Guidotti, brother Brice and sister Mary Carroll. A memorial celebrating his life will be held in February. Donations in his memory may be made to Public Television, Thirteen, 450 West 33rd Street, New York, NY, 10001-2605.

KENNEDY--Thomas Robert Evans, BBA, BEd, MEd, LLB, JD. His sudden death on November 5, 2009 at his home in Fredericton, New Brunswick in his 60th year. He was the son of the late Waldo and Madeline (Kennedy) Evans. He is survived by his three sisters Sheila, Mavis and Donna. He studied at UNB and received a Bachelor of Business Administration, a Bachelor of Education, a Master's in Education, along with a law degree. He received his Jurish doctorate from University of Detroit. He was a pilot and an electrician. Tom was an outdoor enthusiast who enjoyed sailing and flying. He will be sorely missed for his humor, wisdom, tolerance, strength of character and equanimity. His ashes will be scattered at sea in the old sow of Grand Manan Island, Canada.
TANENBAUM--Linda. Linda was a special friend; We will miss her spirit, humor and unique sense of style; but most of all her friendship. Marian & Ed Saltzman Family

FERO--Kelly Peter, of Austin, TX (February 17, 1952 January 4, 2010) developed winning strategies for policy leaders and political candidates for three decades in the U.S. and abroad. A former journalist, he was a recognized expert on communicating complex challenges to gain popular support for vital public programs. He helped oversee the Texas Performance Review for State Comptroller John Sharp, and co-authored Vice President Al Gore's National Performance Review report. Fero served as policy adviser and strategist for the government of Mexico and its U.S. ambassador and helped organize that nation's first open presidential primary. Born in Michigan and raised in Argentina, Fero graduated from UNAM, the national university in Mexico City. He authored The Zani Murders and was a gifted musician and songwriter. Kelly is survived by his wife, Mary Elizabeth Duhe Fero; daughters Caitlin Newlands and Kate Smith Riggleman; grandchildren Isaiah Carroll, Maya and Kira Anthony, and Skyla Riggleman; father Barnard Fero; and brothers Patrick, Michael and Timothy. His mother, Evelyn, preceded him in death. Kelly's generous spirit, humor and fight for a more just world endure and challenge us to live for a better tomorrow.

INSPIRED by 17th-century ''nature morte'' painting, Emily Miranda's jewelry usually runs toward the macabre, incorporating barnacles, snails, gilded alligator feet, rabbit paws, rhinestones, rattlesnake heads and scraps of fur. ''I'm drawn to decadence, and things that are somehow both gruesome and gorgeous,'' said Ms. Miranda, who lives in New York. But for this delicate brass necklace ($800), she channeled paper cutouts by Matisse. Not one to limit herself to a single medium, Ms. Miranda also makes Dutch still-life-inspired cakes that she painstakingly decorates with handmade sugar-paste sculptures. Her sweetest achievement? A complicated confection she made for the designer Ted Muehling covered in sugar snakes and bugs. Emilymirandastudio.com. SANDRA BALLENTINE

News of Mr. Manzoni's appointment had been floating around since last September.

The evening before he was sworn into office, Barack Obama stepped out of Blair House, the government residence where he was staying across from the White House, and climbed into an armored limousine for the ride to a bipartisan dinner. Joining him in the back seat were John Brennan, his new counterterrorism adviser, and two foreign-policy advisers, Denis McDonough and Mark Lippert. The three men with the president-elect were out of breath, having rushed more than a mile from transition headquarters on foot after failing to find a taxi in Washington's preinaugural madness. As the motorcade moved out, they updated Obama on gathering evidence of a major terrorist plot to attack his inauguration. After a weekend of round-the-clock analysis, the nation's intelligence agencies were concerned that the threat was real, the men told him. A group of Somali extremists was reported to be coming across the border from Canada to detonate explosives as the new president took the oath of office. With more than a million onlookers viewing the ceremony from the National Mall and hundreds of millions more watching on television around the world, what could be a more devastating target? ''All the data points suggested there was a real threat evolving quickly that had an overseas component,'' Juan Carlos Zarate, President George W. Bush's deputy national security adviser for combating terrorism, told me last fall. As the inauguration approached, signs of a plot ''seemed to be growing in credibility and relevance.'' Another senior Bush official involved in those tense events a year ago said that protecting the new president was not enough. Even a failed attack would send a debilitating message to the world. ''If something happens on the podium and there's chaos,'' this official told me, ''that's the first time you see the new president, and you really don't want that.''

Even as Democrats nail down the final details of their health care bill, Republicans are devising ways to convert it into political capital. Their greatest hope is to defeat the bill outright, rebuffing President Obama on his signature domestic issue and weakening the Democrats heading into the midterm elections. Republicans now think they can persuade some conservative and moderate Democrats in the House to vote against the final bill, which initially passed the House by just five votes.

HIRSCH--Samuel, life-long labor and civil rights activist and U.S. Army veteran, died on December 2, 2009 at the age of 86. Sam was co-founder of the Greater New York Labor-Religion Coalition with the late Rev. Robert Kennedy at a time of plant closings and eroding workers' rights. He was instrumental in the passage of lead paint regulations, worked tirelessly for heath care reform, and was very active in the civil rights struggles in the 1960s and in the movement to end apartheid in South Africa. Earlier he was active in the painters' and the culinary workers' unions, and a target of McCarthyism. In the 1970s, while on the staff of the Amalgamated Clothing and Textile Workers Union, Sam played an important role in helping southern textile workers secure their first contract with textile giant, J.P. Stevens, and then became an organizer with Corporate Campaign, Inc. from 1981 until his death. A memorial will be held on Tuesday, February 9 at the Tamiment Library, NYU, 70 Washington Square South, 10th Floor, Manhattan, with a reception at 6pm, followed by a tribute at 7pm. RSVP appreciated: info@corporatecampaign.org or (718) 852-2808.

As a 5-foot-4, dark-haired Jewish girl in her early 20s, I was never a minority in New York City until I moved to Park Slope, where I seem to be one of the few childless residents. While it might be enjoyable for outsiders to read books like ''Prospect Park West,'' which details the mommy culture run amok, it is a whole other sensation to be stuck with your latte next to a mother suckling her infant. Though I have grown adept at dodging double strollers and turning a blind eye to the toddlers who frequent my favorite cafes, I refuse to share my bar space -- the last refuge for single Slopers -- with infants.

LONG a staple of ladies who lunch (in Geneva), the Swiss fashion house Akris is making room in its line for handbags. The Ai Bag coincides with the acquisition of Comtesse, an 80-year-old German firm specializing in the manufacture of woven horsehair. Akris is no stranger to the material: it has been used to structure its men's coats, and there is even woven horsehair covering the walls of its London boutique. Pony up the $3,990 price tag at Saks Fifth Avenue, Bergdorf Goodman and Akris boutiques. ANNE CHRISTENSEN

THE NEWSPresident Obama called for a new tax to be levied for at least a decade on about 50 of the largest financial institutions, ''to recover every single dime the American people are owed'' for the bailout of Wall Street. BEHIND THE NEWS The announcement, a day after a special commission publicly grilled top bankers over the causes of the financial meltdown, tapped into simmering popular anger at Wall Street's return to soaring profits and bonuses. After Mr. Obama chided the banks in some of his harshest terms to date, a top industry lobbyist called the whole thing ''strictly political.''

Television While the news on Broadway this season has been the dominance of screen actors, the New York stage has done what it can to redress the balance: Matthew Morrison (''South Pacific'') and Lea Michele (''Spring Awakening'') star in ''Glee,'' Jesse Tyler Ferguson (''The 25th Annual Putnam County Spelling Bee'') stars in ''Modern Family.'' This week the balance tips a little further with the premiere of ''THE DEEP END'' (ABC, 8 p.m. Thursday), a new lawyers-in-lust drama whose cast includes the Tony Award winner (for ''Dirty Rotten Scoundrels'') Norbert Leo Butz. His character, a Southern-fried member of a high-powered Los Angeles firm, is named Rowdy; his job is to recruit and teach the young, attractive lawyers around whom the story lines revolve. Billy Zane stars as a dictatorial partner; Matt Long plays an idealistic first-year associate, an older version of the character he played five years ago in ''Jack and Bobby.''

LEONARD SLATKIN is a big jazz fan. But he was unprepared for what unfolded when, after performing as guest conductor of the New York Philharmonic at Lincoln Center one spring night in 1995, he decided to catch the pianist Michel Camilo's show at the Blue Note in Greenwich Village. ''I really hadn't heard piano playing that ferociously virtuosic in a club like that,'' Mr. Slatkin said in a recent interview. ''At the same time, the sensitivity he brought to the ballads was just extraordinary.''

Service Saturday, January 16, 11:30am at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81st St.

Classical At a point in his career by which many opera singers have settled into respectable retirement, the celebrated Spanish tenor Plácido Domingo continues to seek new challenges. Mr. Domingo first performed in Verdi's ''Simon Boccanegra'' at the Metropolitan Opera in 1995, playing Gabriele Adorno, a tenor role. But in 2007 Mr. Domingo announced that he intended to take on the title part, one of Verdi's greatest baritone roles. On Monday, three days before he turns 69, Mr. Domingo will fulfill that ambition during the Met's latest revival of Giancarlo del Monaco's 1995 production.

Art Some 75 exhibitors will gather for the 56th WINTER ANTIQUES SHOW, starting Friday at the Park Avenue Armory. The show includes antiquities through the 1960s, ranging from ancient Roman glass to midcentury Modern. One third of the exhibitors specialize in Americana; the others in English, European and Asian fine and decorative arts. A committee of 160 experts from the United States and Europe vets every object for authenticity, date and condition. Proceeds benefit the East Side House Settlement, a community resource center in the South Bronx that focuses on education and technology. Through Jan. 31, at 67th Street and Park Avenue, (718) 292-7392.

BOWE--James J.,58, of Westchester County, New York, passed away at home on January 10, 2010, after an extended illness. Son of Mary and Bill Bowe, Jim was born in the Bronx on October 31, 1951. Jim was predeceased by his daughter, Brooke, in 2007. He is survived by his wife, Mary, brothers, Bill and Michael, daughter, Laura and grandchildren, Chloe, Abigail and Grace. Services will be held at St. Theresa's Church, 1394 Pleasantville Rd., Briarcliff Manor, NY on Monday, January 25, at 11am. In lieu of flowers, please make contributions to the Brooke Bowe Memorial Trust Fund, c/o Michael Bowe at 82 Park Drive, Mt. Kisco, NY 10549.

HOREN--Roxy, a personal manager for Hollywood and Broadway actors, died December 31, according to her life partner of 40 years, the actress Susanne Wasson. Ms. Horen began her career with Jose Quintero at the Circle in the Square Theatre in the early 1950s and later managed the careers of Christopher Lloyd of "One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest" and Judith Moore of "Sunday in the Park with George." Ms. Horen resided in New York City and Bucks County. In addition to Ms. Wasson, Ms. Horen is survived by her sister, Iris Dragan, and nieces Alice Dragan and Roxanne Thom.

FRUGAL TRAVELER A subway to the ski slopes? Not exactly, but one ski resort in upstate New York is just a Metro-North train commute away. This week, Matt Gross takes his snowboard to Grand Central Terminal, above.

KLEINFIELD--Jeanne K. Welcher Ph.D.,of Glen Cove, LI, on January 13, 2010, age 87. Professor Emerita of CW Post College L.I.U. and St. John's University. Brilliant Teacher, Scholar and Author. Beloved wife of the late Herbert L. Dear sister of the late Richard Welcher (Alice). Also, survived by nieces, nephew and cousins. Special friend of Dr. George E. Bush Jr. Interment private. A Memorial Mass will be held at a later date. Services entrusted to Dodge-Thomas Funeral Home, Glen Cove.

IF clothes make the man, what to make of a doorman in a $500 uniform that may or may not include top hat, tails, white gloves, golden epaulets, an equestrian jacket, embroidered building logos, and pants with a tuxedo stripe that is not necessarily black? A century ago, most New York doormen were similarly attired, as throwbacks to liveried servants. These days, the regalia of the city's thousands of doormen (women are still a rarity) varies wildly. The hipster trend downtown is uniformless; at the Empire State Building, the uniforms are dyed the precise shade of gray as the marble in the elevators.

It's hard to keep up with the latest punch line in late-night world. Conan, Jay, Jimmy. Who's on first? On NBC it has been ''The Jay Leno Show,'' 10 p.m. (followed by something called the news); ''The Tonight Show With Conan O'Brien,'' 11:35; and ''Late Night With Jimmy Fallon,'' 12:35. Not so long ago -- just last year in fact -- there was no comedic host jumping in before the news. The magic hour was 11:35, and Mr. Leno was the man to kick it all off (going against David Letterman on CBS, of course, but generally beating him in the ratings). But NBC had promised the ''Tonight'' gig to Mr. O'Brien, giving Mr. Leno five years to ease out of the slot first held by Steve Allen, Jack Paar and then, for three decades, Johnny Carson. Despite getting a new show, Mr. Leno has not been much of a draw in the dreaded prime time, and he has cast longing looks back at the later hour. And NBC is prepared to give it to him. Not. So. Fast. Mr. O'Brien says he won't return to a post-midnight gig, thank you very much. Needless to say, the monologues all around last week were less funny ha-ha and more funny vicious. Stay tuned. Whenever.

At its height, NBC was the very model of what a television network should be. With iconic programming, enviable ratings and spectacular business success, the peacock network delivered plenty of laughs along the way with ''The Cosby Show,'' ''Seinfeld'' and ''Friends.'' Nobody is laughing anymore.

Tomorrow, Jan. 19, marks the official publication of Barbara Herrnstein Smith's "Natural Reflections: Human Cognition at the Nexus of Science and Religion." The title would seem to identify the book as an addition to the ever-growing body of studies that explore the relationships and tensions between religion and science, usually with the intent either of declaring one epistemologically or morally superior to the other, or of insisting (somewhat piously) that the two are compatible if we avoid extreme claims and counterclaims, or of triumphantly announcing that science is a form of faith, or of purporting to demonstrate that religion can be explained in naturalist terms as an expression of the instinct to survive and propagate.
Tyco International will acquire Broadview Security for $1.9 billion in a deal that brings together two big North American names in residential and commercial security, the two companies said Monday.

In 2007 the independent film “Once,” featuring the Irish musician Glen Hansard and the Czech pianist and songwriter Marketa Irglova, charmed audiences at the Sundance Film Festival. The pair, known as the Swell Season, went on to win an Academy Award for their duet from the film, “Falling Slowly.” The festival returns again this weekend, and another movie and soundtrack will surely emerge as the surprise hit, but before then go see the duo at Radio City Music Hall, where they will be performing songs from their follow-up album, “Strict Joy,” on Tuesday night.

Continue traveling through the city’s past with a visit to “Downtown Pix: Mining the Fales Archives, 1961-1991.” The exhibition reminds us what the arts scene in the East Village, SoHo and TriBeCa was like at the height of the AIDS epidemic, writes Martha Schwendener, “before gentrification and before the downtown ethos and aesthetic were packaged into family viewing spectacles like ‘Rent’ or those by Blue Man Group.” The show at the Grey Art Gallery includes more than 300 photographs and offers a glimpse of the “downtown of experimental art, music, film, theater and dance — often mashed up and delivered simultaneously.”

“Just Kids,” writes Janet Maslin, captures a moment when Patti Smith and Robert Mapplethorpe “were young, inseparable, perfectly bohemian and completely unknown.” The “tenderly evocative memoir” by Ms. Smith, the punk-rock queen, chronicles her early relationship with the photographer. Ms. Smith came across Mr. Mapplethorpe in a back bedroom of a Brooklyn apartment. He “resembled a hippie shepherd,” while she “had been contemptuously described as looking like ‘Dracula’s daughter,’ ” Ms. Maslin writes. They would go on to “become roommates, soul mates, friends, lovers and muses.” On Tuesday night, starting at 7 p.m., Ms. Smith will read about those bygone days at the Barnes & Noble at Union Square.
Chris Hayes, left, of The Nation and Tim Carney of The Washington Examiner assess the embattled Martha Coakley.

David Carr's media column this week looks at the state of affairs with late-night television. He argues that the ratings drama surrounding "The Tonight Show" has nothing to do with Conan O'Brien or Jay Leno, but is instead a demonstration of the changing tide of consumer habits from television time slots to the Web.

MILAN -- The idea of rebels is always a powerful one in men's fashion, and it's been making the rounds here this season. Bottega Veneta's Tomas Maier brought flair and sophistication to his parade of Teddy Boys with tapered trousers, bright blazers, chunky creeper shoes and slick duck's tail hair. Roberto Cavalli's renegades sported woven leather pants, destroyed jeans and metal mesh tops; at John Varvatos, rockers layered knit coats under and over double-breasted suits and long cardigan jackets. And at Emporio Armani, the nonconformist vibe came via snowboarding and acid-hued paraphernalia; not to mention, of course, the group of 30 models who closed the show wearing nothing but skimpy flesh-toned underwear and the Reebok EA7 sneakers developed by Emporio Armani and Reebok. Who worked out the nonconformist look best? You tell us.

Maybe it's just me, but I could have sworn that some of the ladies who showed up at the Golden Globes on Sunday had put on a little weight. It's almost criminal to name names, because the very actresses whose body-mass indexes have been the subject of endless tabloid speculation are the very ones now sporting sexier curves. You could definitely see the difference if you concentrated solely on the upper arms. Instead of a Barbie-doll circumference, there was suddenly, amazingly, a womanly roundness to their frames. More Marilyn than Twiggy, that's for sure.

The rain at Sunday's Golden Globes may have wreaked havoc on the hair-dos, but it did not wilt ratings. About 17 million people watched NBC's live telecast of the ceremony, according to Nielsen data, a fat 14 percent increase from the year before, when about 15 million watched. In the crucial advertising category of people age 18 to 49, the Globes perked up 10 percent -- exactly what the network had predicted -- going into the night.

FLORENCE, Italy -- Here in at the fall/winter 2010 men's collections at Pitti Uomo it was hard to miss the continuing influence of vintage Americana on the sportswear being shown. However, there's a new technical edge infusing these traditional tweeds with elements of the worlds of mountaineering and climbing.A line simply called M based in Tokyo offered the perfect emblem of this rugged rough-and-ready sportswear, showing a photo of a shaggy model in a down vest embellished with Fair Isle-style detailing in the shadow of a snowy peak along with the slogan "Challenge Mount Fuji ... because it's there." It offered the same graphic pattern in a heavy woolen short, an odd choice for a winter "pant" but one that consistently cropped up at the show. The trek-worthy gear also featured hooded plaid parkas with built-in backpacks.

MILAN -- The buzzword for the men's shows here so far has been "heritage" - which is to say that designers are going back to their roots in order to entice still-weary customers with items that reflect the value of their houses rather than flash-in-the-pan status symbols. Dolce & Gabbana led the way with one of its strongest presentations in seasons, using Giuseppe Tornatore's new film, "Baarìa," as the starting point for a Sicilian-inspired collection highlighting Italian tailoring and distressed work wear. The Sunday-best suits looked especially sharp when contrasted with worn-out tank tops, frayed jeans and long johns tucked into worker boots. Domenico Dolce and Stefano Gabbana are celebrating their 20th anniversary this year, and their attention is clearly in the right place.

Who says literature can't be hot? The Fine Books Company of Rochester, Mich., is selling "The Complete Science Fiction Asbestos Collection," a set of fireproofed, autographed first editions of Ray Bradbury's "Fahrenheit 451" and Stephen King's "Firestarter." The books are bound in a silvery, asbestos material, and going for the minor sum of $31,810. For those with money to burn, apparently.

Maria Kirilenko did not jump for joy or toss her racket skyward after winning her match with Maria Sharapova on the first day at the Australian Open. She even tried to quiet her more boisterous supporters as she walked to the net to shake hands with her taller, more celebrated opponent. Kirilenko looked as though she was already focusing on her next match, and this victory was not at all a surprise to her.

A software engineer who was the first person in Britain to be prosecuted for illegal file-sharing has been found not guilty of conspiracy to defraud, BBC News reported. The engineer, Alan Ellis, ran the now-defunct file-sharing Web site OiNK.cd from an apartment in Middlesbrough, in northern England, from 2004 to 2007 until it was shut down in a police raid. Though the site did not require users to pay and instead asked for voluntary donations, prosecutors said that Mr. Ellis had $300,000 in a Paypal account and received $18,000 a month in donations. Mr. Ellis, 26, said in court that he had not intended to defraud the copyright holders of the songs downloaded through OiNK.cd, and that he had set up the Web site "to further my skills. To better my skills for employability." The site, which did not host any songs itself, facilitated the illegal downloading of more than 21 million music files.
