Let's see Microsoft try to use these blurbs in their next Xbox campaign: the Sony PlayStation video game console has been criticized by President Hugo Chávez of Venezuela, not because he finds Assassin's Creed II oddly unengaging or is growing impatient for the release of Final Fantasy XIII, but because he believes that it is "poison" and will lead children down a capitalist "road to hell," Agence France-Presse reported. On his weekly radio and television show, Mr. Chávez said, "Those games they call 'PlayStation' are poison. Some games teach you to kill." He added that violent video games are sold by capitalist countries so they can "later sell weapons," and they "promote the need for cigarettes, drugs and alcohol so they can sell them," according to Agence France-Presse. In October, Venezuela passed a law making it illegal to sell violent video games, an offense punishable by up to five years in prison. Mr. Chávez has previously criticized Nintendo for promoting "selfishness, individualism and violence," and that was before the company released New Super Mario Bros. Wii, which is, like, totally impossible.

Apropos of a point I made in today's column: there were two major tax changes in Reagan's first term, which began in January 1981. ERTA, aka the Reagan tax cut, was signed in August 1981; TEFRA, which raised taxes, was signed in September 1982.

Matthew McCarthy, the owner of the Film/Art Gallery, began collecting film posters as a boy, but his private obsession turned public only a few years ago. And he has Audrey Hepburn to thank. As the story goes, he was visiting his linen-backer to restore some old Hepburn movie posters when the linen-backer asked if McCarthy knew Sean Hepburn Ferrer, the actress's son. "He thought Sean might be interested in buying some of the posters," says McCarthy. And indeed, Ferrer bought a bunch of them. "That was my first big sale." The introduction turned into a job for McCarthy as an archivist for the Hepburn foundation, and it prompted him to start his Web-based gallery, offering up some of his 3,000 vintage movie posters for sale. Hollywood and design insiders have quickly caught onto McCarthy's astonishing collection of rare and foreign posters, many of them far more avant-garde than the standard-issue Hollywood versions. (Check out the Czech edition of "Cool Hand Luke.") Besides continually adding to his collection, McCarthy (whose partner, Tyler Cassity, owns Hollywood Forever cemetery, where he hosts extremely popular movie nights in the summer) is planning a bricks-and-mortar gallery space to hold screenings and poster exhibitions based on particular stars, directors and genres.

Rebecca Stead, author of "When You Reach Me," a mystery and a novel of friendship set in New York City, won the John Newbery Medal for the most outstanding contribution to children's literature on Monday. Ms. Stead was widely considered a favorite among librarians and bloggers who write about books for young people. The novel, which takes place in 1979 and chronicles an intimate neighborhood on the Upper West Side, tells the story of Miranda, a sixth-grader who must unravel clues about why her best friend, Sal, stopped talking to her. "When You Reach Me" has spent eight weeks on the New York Times Best Seller List for children's chapter books. The award was conferred by the Association for Library Service to Children, a division of the American Library Association, at the library association's midwinter conference in Boston. The association also awarded the Randolph Caldecott Medal for the most distinguished American picture book for children to "The Lion & The Mouse" by Jerry Pinkney. Mr. Pinkney's book is a nearly wordless adaptation of Aesop's fable about how the king of the animal kingdom is helped by one of its smallest creatures. For the first time this year, the Young Adult Library Services Association, also a division of the library association, awarded a prize for a nonfiction work to "Charles and Emma: The Darwins' Leap of Faith" by Deborah Heiligman.

(The Jets recovered.)2) Rex Ryan's decision to go for it on fourth-and-one at the San Diego 29 with 1:09 remaining. (Thomas Jones converted the first down, sealing the game.)Excerpt:

It was the brightest flash of brilliant Orange. In a 1974 World Cup group match between the Netherlands and Sweden, Johan Cruyff picked the ball up on the edge of the box under pressure from a defender, feigned to cross, then pulled the ball back between his legs, leaving the Swedish fullback flailing like a drunken sea captain. And just like that, the Cruyff Turn was born.Since then, there have been other moves that have become synonymous with an individual player. At the World Cup in South Africa this year, we can hope to see some of the players performing their signature moves in action.

MELBOURNE, Australia -- A rising star of women's tennis, Yanina Wickmayer of Belgium, fought the elements and a determined challenger, Alexandra Dulgheru of Romania, to win a three-set battle before a capacity crowd of about 6,000 spectators on the Margaret Court Arena. After a lengthy rain delay, Wickmayer prevailed, 1-6, 7-5, 10-8, to reach the second round. Had she lost, it would have represented a major setback, even though she was not seeded here because of an unresolved dispute over her availability for drug testing. The match was interrupted several times by a summer rain that stalled many of the tournment's opening-day matches and eventually drove the two women off the court and into the locker room in midafternoon after more than three hours of play. Wickmayer is ranked 16th in the world and had defeated Dulgheru three times last year while climbing the ladder of women's tennis in the shadow of her Begian compatriots, Justine Henin and Kim Clijsters. But Dulgheru, a 20-year-old from Bucharest, fought tenanciously before yielding.

Up or down? It’s hard to know where to look for Plácido Domingo this week at the Met. When he is not in the pit conducting Verdi’s opera “Stiffelio,” he is onstage singing. He’ll be easy to spot tonight when he performs Verdi’s “Simon Boccanegra.” “As a young man, Mr. Domingo was a baritone,” writes Anthony Tommasini. “He built his top range through hard work, note by note, to become a tenor, a project that turned out extremely well. He has sung some 124 roles so far. Now, for the first time at the Metropolitan Opera, he performs his newest role, for baritone, the title role of Verdi’s 'Simon Boccanegra.’ For this back-to-the-future adventure, Mr. Domingo will have the support of James Levine in the pit, and a cast including the tenor Marcello Giordani and the soprano Adrianne Pieczonka. Though the plot of 'Simon Boccanegra’ is nearly impenetrable, in its revised version, which is offered here, the opera is rich with first-class Verdi music.”

There are many places around the city paying tribute to Martin Luther King Jr. today. One of the highlights is sure to be at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, where the borough’s president, Marty Markowitz, and Medgar Evers College of the City University of New York will host a public celebration in his honor. The festivities begin at 10:30 a.m. with the actor Danny Glover appearing as the keynote speaker and the New Life Tabernacle Mass Choir and the Human Orchestra providing musical performances. Stick around after the event at the opera house for a free screening of the documentary “Soundtrack for a Revolution,” which Mr. Glover produced. The movie explores the history of the civil rights movement through freedom songs and includes performances by John Legend, Joss Stone, Wyclef Jean, the Roots, Richie Havens and others. It begins at 1 p.m.

To go with the 1,126 penalty minutes he has accumulated, Georges Laraque has scored 53 goals in his 12-year N.H.L. career. But none were bigger than the one he scored Thursday, the night the Montreal Canadiens opened a fund-raising drive dedicated to earthquake recovery in Haiti. ''It was a magic moment,'' said Laraque, whose goal was his first in 21 months, as well as his first as a Canadien. ''I dedicate this goal to all the Haitians, to my family members and to all of those who lost loved ones or who are looking for them.''

EELS ''End Times'' (E Works/Vagrant) Mark Oliver Everett, the songwriter behind Eels, regularly casts himself as a man who's solitary, miserable and getting worse, quietly or noisily. It's a role that suits his bleary voice and his direct, unadorned lyrics. Mr. Everett stays mostly subdued on the Eels' eighth studio album, ''End Times,'' which he has bluntly described as a ''divorce album.'' In the title song, he sings, ''The world is ending/And what do I care/She's gone/End times are here.''

LINDSTROM & CHRISTABELLE ''Real Life Is No Cool'' (Smalltown Supersound/Feedelity) The first sound on ''Real Life Is No Cool,'' an early front-runner for the year's best Norwegian electro-disco album, is a disembodied voice: urgent, female, digitally garbled, backward-looped. It sputters alone for a while before a synthetic bass line fades into the mix, followed by a beat. ''What should we do?'' the voice asks breathily then, one minute into ''Looking for What,'' the album's opening track. ''Should we start? Should we stop? Should we stop looking? Looking for what?''

OTTE--Robert Laine, June 18, 1923 - January 16, 2010. Bob was born in New York City. He served as gunnery officer on LST 707 in the South Pacific for three and a half years during WWII. He graduated from the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill and New York University Law School. He and his brother, Bill, were co-secretaries of the National Chemical Credit Association in New York City for many years. He is survived by his wife, Nancy Fairfield Otte of Mequon, WI, his daughter and son in law, Mary and Kim Harper of Melbourne, Australia, his brother, Bill Otte of New York City and his sister, Eileen Ford of Oldwick, New Jersey. In retirement Bob lived in Flinders, Victoria, Australia and Mequon, WI. Schmidt & Bartelt Funeral and Cremation Service, Mequon 262-241-8085, schmidtandbartelt.com

8 P.M. (USA) TOM BROKAW PRESENTS: AMERICAN CHARACTER ALONG HIGHWAY 50 Mr. Brokaw, above, takes off down a road often called the backbone of America to document the changing political, economic and cultural face of the nation. The 12-state, 3,000-mile journey begins on the Eastern Shore of Maryland and ends in California, passing Civil War battlefields, the Ohio and Mississippi Rivers, the Great Plains and the Great Basin, Wild West towns, the Continental Divide and a part of Nevada where signs proclaim Highway 50 to be the loneliest stretch in America. This hourlong documentary will be followed by ''Dispatches From the Road,'' updates highlighting the people and places Mr. Brokaw visited on his trip. 1 P.M. (MSG Plus) THE GAME 365: USA HOCKEY ... THE NECKS ''Silverwater'' (ReR) ''Silverwater,'' like most albums by the Necks, is like land passing below you from an airplane window. It's so big and slow that it resists description.

The Nets are 3-36 heading into Monday's game against the Los Angeles Clippers. Their winning percentage, .077, suggests they will win just six games this season and set an N.B.A. futility record, a mark now held by the 1972-73 Philadelphia 76ers, who went 9-73. The good news for the Nets is that this is not an accurate representation of what is expected to happen. Although the Nets have won just three games, a better way to predict their future performance is to use the team's offensive and defensive efficiency ratings. It is important to adjust the team's raw ratings based on their opponent strength and game location. This allows us to create power rankings that illustrate what efficiency ratings we would expect to see if each team played every other team once at home and on the road.

The Rangers' scorers finally awoke at Madison Square Garden on Sunday night in a 6-2 victory, though it took a game against the Montreal Canadiens, who have the second-worst regulation record in the East, to rouse them from their offensive slumber. The Rangers won after rallying from a 2-0 first-period deficit with three goals in the second, when they outshot the Canadiens, 15-2.

Five weeks after surgery on his right knee, Ivica Kostelic felt healthy enough to rip down two selective slalom runs and end up the winner here Sunday. But climbing the podium after knee surgery is a Kostelic family tradition. Ivica has done it for years, and his younger sister, Janica, did it too before leaving the sport in 2006 with more gold medals (four) than any women's Olympic Alpine skier in history.

POMERANTZ--Murray. It is with deepest sorrow that we acknowledge the passing of Murray Pomerantz, peacefully, on Sunday, January 17, 2010. Murray, a beloved husband of 53 years, devoted father, adored grandpa, and cherished son and brother, shared his endless love of life with everyone. Namesake of "Murray's Bagels" in Greenwich Village and Chelsea, he will forever be within our hearts. Murray was born in Manhattan and raised in Brooklyn. He lived in Staten Island, New Jersey and then back again in Brooklyn. He was tirelessly dedicated to his family, and his greatest joy and pride were his children and grandchildren. Murray was a truly extraordinary man who was deeply loved and respected, and will be missed not only by his family, but by all who knew him. Funeral services will be held Tuesday, January 19, 2010 at 10am, at the Parkside Memorial Chapels, 2576 Flatbush Avenue, Brooklyn, NY 11234. With eternal love, Roslyn, Ellen, Matthew and Adam

WEINTRAUB--Bernard "Bernie" Martin, beloved husband, father and friend to so many passed away on January 16, 2010 at 1:54pm in Los Angeles, California. His wife of 52 years Ellie, children Danny, Lizzie, daughter-in-law Vinnet and nephew Irv were by his side. Bernie passed peacefully and did not suffer. Bernie lived a life full of adventure, accomplishment, laughter, love and friendship. One of those rare people who everyone loved, Bernie always had a smile on his face, a song in his heart, a positive and uplifting spirit and an encouraging word for his family, friends and clients. Bernie severed his country proudly during the Korean War and was one of the founding partner's of the boutique literary agency Robinson Weintraub and of the Paradigm literary and talent agency. His clients worked on numerous iconic television shows including I Love Lucy, The Jackie Gleason Show, All in the Family, M.A.S.H., Maude, Sanford & Son, The Cosby Show, Different Strokes and Roseanne, to name just a few. Bernie had many charitable interests, giving generously to groups that promoted Jewish causes, the State of Israel, civil rights, the environment and the humane treatment of animals. He helped found Laniado Hospital in Israel and was on the Board of Governors of Cedars-Sinai Hospital in Los Angeles. His funeral will take place on Monday, January 18, 2010 at 2pm PST at Mount Sinai Mortuary 5950 Forrest Lawn Drive, Los Angeles, CA. In lieu of flowers, please make contributions in Bernie's honor to American Israel Cultural Center (www.aicf.org; 212.557.1600) Jewish National Fund (www.jnf.org; 888.JNF.0099) American Diabetes Association (www.diabetes.org; 1.800.diabetes).

KNOPFELMACHER--Margaret (nee Harris), on January 17, 2010. Beloved wife of Joseph. Survived by her brother Howard, nieces Margaret and Carolyn and grandniece Alyssa. Questions may be referred to Gramercy Park Memorial Chapel.

Maria Sharapova sat in her chair with her eyes closed, trying to take deep, reassuring breaths. The last time she stepped in Rod Laver Arena, she left as the 2008 women's Australian Open champion. She had just dropped the first set, 7-6, in her opening match to her friend and fellow Russian Maria Kirilenko. Sharapova knew she was in trouble, too. She had sprayed the ball for 29 unforced errors and, after leading in the tie breaker, 4-2, Kirilenko employed a languid, patience pace to capture five straight points and the set.

For decades, the microfinance industry has really been about microcredit -- making tiny loans to shoestring entrepreneurs in poor countries. Taking deposits and creating savings accounts for the poor has gotten short shrift. The reasons were straightforward: money for loans often came from international donors, and collecting small deposits seemed to be an inefficient headache for the microfinance bankers.

JACOLOW--Marie, 70, of Spring Lake, NJ, and Boynton Beach, FL, passed away peacefully on January 17, 2010. President Obama came to Massachusetts on Sunday in hopes of rescuing the flailing candidacy of Martha Coakley, the Democratic candidate in an election on Tuesday that will determine whether the party preserves a 60-vote majority in the Senate needed to keep alive health care legislation and the rest of the president's agenda. ''Understand what's at stake here, Massachusetts,'' Mr. Obama said, imploring those who supported him to take heed of the magnitude of the race to fill the seat of the late Senator Edward M. Kennedy. ''It's whether we're going forwards or backwards.''

BEATINI--Doris (nee Scacchetti), 85, died Friday, January 15, 2010 from bladder cancer and a subsequent stroke. She was born on December 7, 1924 in Jersey City, NJ; grew up in Union City, NJ and last resided in Montvale, NJ. Doris was the daughter of Laurence and Edna (nee Henckel) Scacchetti and sister of Laurence. She attended Emerson High School in Union City, NJ and the Scudder School in New York City, working for most of her life as a customer service manager for various companies. Doris is survived by her husband Michael, her sons Michael, Thomas, Mark, and daughter Nanda. Paul, her youngest son, predeceased her on 9/11 in the WTC Tower 2 collapse. She also has four grandchildren: Mark and Danielle (children of Mark and Diane) and Julia and Daria (children of Paul and Susan) and a cat named Mario. We will remember her for her love, kindness, wit, and intelligence. All of her family, immediate and extended, was her pleasure. Funeral Service 10am Tuesday at the Robert Spearing Funeral Home, Inc., 155 Kinderkamack Road, Park Ridge, NJ. Interment in George Washington Memorial Park, Paramus, NJ. Visitation 2-4pm and 7-9pm on Monday.

ANGELILLI--Francis "Frank" J.,Professor of Business and Finance at NYU for 44 years and beloved patriarch of a family of 18, died peacefully at home on January 15th at the age of 90. Professor Angell was adored by hundreds of students during his 44-year tenure at NYU's Stern School of Business. His outstanding service was recognized with many awards and accolades, including being voted the honor of "Great Professor". He will be greatly missed by his children, Marietta Schiff, and Peter Angelilli, their spouses, Larry Schiff and Arlene Angelilli, and his sister Theresa Leuschner. He was the proud and doting grandfather of Dr. Bradley Schiff, Jennifer Roff Ph.D., James Schiff Esq, Lauren Angelilli Esq, Jeff Preston, Elizabeth Levine, Ronald Levine, Dr. Allison Angelilli, Evan Boulukos, Jonathan Angelilli, and Kristen Angelilli. He was the adored great-grandfather of Josephine and Annabel Schiff and Ella Jean Levine. Married for 63 years to the elegant and beloved Josephine Danza Angelilli whom he lost on March 3, 2004. Longtime resident and beloved community member of Atlantic Beach Long Island. Funeral services are currently being made at Fairchild Sons Inc (516)627-2000.

With the Massachusetts special election for United States Senate increasingly unpredictable, Democrats in Washington are contemplating a fall-back plan to advance far-reaching health care legislation, even if a Republican victory on Tuesday deprives Senate Democrats of the crucial 60th vote they need to overcome filibusters. For the moment, at least, the preferred Plan B would be to try to persuade House Democrats to approve the health care bill that the Senate adopted on Christmas Eve, obviating the need for an additional Senate vote and sending the measure directly to President Obama for his signature, administration officials and Congressional aides said on Sunday.

The Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., whom we honor today, talked about the disparity between promise and reality in America. This work -- a conté crayon drawing with garlands of American flags -- is meant to explore those themes, too. It juxtaposes a black woman's face with the flag to conjure the complex relationship between African-Americans and patriotism. The tension grows out of the contradiction of living in a country that did not afford my ancestors basic human rights -- while at the same time being fully aware and proud of the contributions those very ancestors made to our history and culture.

HEFFNER--Linda Reiss, at the age of 60. Died peacefully on January 16, 2010 with her family by her side after a long and courageous battle. Devoted wife of Edward Heffner; beloved mother of Amy Lokhin (Mark), Sanford and Lisa Heffner and cherished grandmother of Alice. Sister to Roberta Miller (Joshua) and Marvin Reiss (Susan). In addition to her devotion to her family, Linda was an astute business woman with a daring drive and keen sense of purpose and loyalty. She upheld these characteristics not only in the work place but also in every aspect of her life. She single handedly manage her family real estate company and helped make it become the successful venture that it is today. Linda was a friend to all who knew her, and a woman with true style and dignity. Funeral services Monday 12 noon at Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 91 and Amsterdam Ave.

OBEY--Helen M.,on January 16, 2010. Beloved wife of the late Rev. Robert F. Obey. Loving mother of Erica and Karl. Proud grandmother or Erik, Kevin and Luke. Visiting Monday and Tuesday 2-4 and 7-9pm at Clavin Funeral Home, 7722 4th Ave., Brooklyn. Memorial service Thursday 11am at St. Peter's Church, 619 Lexington Ave. (54th St.), NYC. In lieu of flowers, please honor her devotion to the Lutheran community by donating to Lutheran Medical Center, 150 55th St., Brooklyn, NY 11220.

FLATAU--Fred N.,MD, 78 on January 8, of Naples FL from cancer. Formerly of New York City, Queens, Roslyn, and Rye Brook. Born Berlin 1931; Holocaust survivor. Graduated CCNY, MD from University of Heidelberg. Internist Flushing, NY. Past President Queens County Medical Society, Flushing Hospital Med Staff Society and 1st District Branch, New York State Medical Society. Leaves devoted wife Nancy Green of 47 years, daughter Karen -David Druckman, grandchildren Julia, Mathew and son Warren. Predeceased by parents Anny and Ernst, brothers Jerry and Steve. Devotee of medical, political and social justice causes. Humor, optimism, generosity and compassion were his hallmarks. In retirement was a volunteer physician and docent at Holocaust Museum of Southwest Florida where donations may be made in his memory to The Dr. Fred Flatau Fund www.hmswfl.org.

Nearly everyone agrees that there is something sick about the American health care system, especially when it comes to the seemingly out-of-control rise in costs. While Democrats and Republicans continue to fight over the remedy, there is one man who can claim to have rendered a specific diagnosis and -- more than 40 years later -- he wants lawmakers and President Obama to know that there probably is no cure.

THOMPSON--Robert L.,Professor Emeritus of psychology at Hunter College and the Graduate Center of the City University of New York, and leader of the Red Onion Jazz Band, died peacefully January 13, 2010 at St. Luke's Hospital after suffering a collapse. Born December 6, 1926 in New York City, he received his doctorate in experimental psychology from Columbia University in 1959. He taught at Columbia, then at Hunter College, establishing its doctoral program in biopsychology and chairing it for many years. "Bob" Thompson led the Red Onion Jazz Band, a traditional New Orleans-style jazz band, for over fifty years. He played drums with what Allegro called "some of the greatest jazz performers of the 20th century." Dr. Thompson was a founding member of the Society for Neuroscience, an active member of the New York Academy of Sciences, and co-editor of the Academy volume The Self Across Psychology. He leaves behind his partner of 30 years, Virginia Held, her children and grandchildren, and his stepdaughter Elyn MacInnis and her family. We will miss him terribly. Donations may be made to the Martha's Vineyard Trustees of Reservations or the American Association for the Advancement of Science. A memorial service will be held at a later date.

''Avatar'' surpassed most of last year's films by well over $100 million, and based on last weekend, is closing in on $500 million at the domestic box office. ''Twilight Saga: New Moon,'' which, like ''Avatar'' and ''The Blind Side,'' is still in theaters, may eventually earn more than ''Up.'' Fox, bracketing the top 10 with ''Avatar'' and ''Ice Age: Dawn of the Dinosaurs,'' had several films that earned more than $175 million last year, including ''Night at the Museum: Battle of the Smithsonian'' (above) and ''Alvin and the Chipmunks: The Squeakquel,'' also still in theaters. SHELLY FREIERMAN

The American military presence in Haiti underscored the rising complaints that the Haitian government had all but disappeared in the week since the earthquake struck.

Remember spending hours strolling through the old Tower Records store in the East Village, scanning the aisles for the latest Lemon Heads album or a potential love interest? Those days are long gone — as, thankfully, is our penchant for ’90s alternative rock — but for a few weeks you can revisit the feeling at the store’s old location on Broadway and East 4th Street, where the nonprofit group No Longer Empty has opened a multimedia art installation called “Never Can Say Goodbye.” The exhibition, by Ted Riederer, recreates the store with record bins, album covers, music posters and a performance stage as well as works by Meredyth Sparks, Siebren Versteeg, Ryan Brennan and other artists, which touch on the history of the store, the changes in the music industry brought on by the Internet and how technology has transformed the art form. The installation, which is free and will feature live performances, runs through Feb. 13.

It doesn’t have an orchestra pit, a stage or proper lighting, but that didn’t deter the Gotham Chamber Opera’s artistic director Neal Goren from staging Haydn’s comedy “Il Mondo Della Luna” at the Hayden Planetarium’s dome at the American Museum of Natural History. “Doing this opera at the planetarium is a perfect way to marry arts and science,” said Mr. Goren in a recent article. The opera, about a strict father tricked by his daughters into believing that he has been transported to the moon, uses digital video projections provided by NASA, lasers and other spacey technologies to fuse music and stargazing. It runs through Jan. 28.

“Was New York City a better place when there were sad old men sitting at the bar in the lobby of the Gramercy alongside stooped former artist’s models, with smoke curling up toward the ceiling on exhalations of gin breath and despair?” asks Sam Sifton. “Probably not. But the era is worth recalling as you sit at Maialino, drinking prosecco or coffee and looking south toward Gramercy Park as cabs inch past.” The latest venture from the restaurateur Danny Meyer is a Roman-style trattoria at the Gramercy Park Hotel, whose name is Italian for little pig. Pork is of course on the menu, but so is stracciatella, the Roman chicken soup with thick strands of egg; cold antipasti; and entrees including “a moist and flavorful plate of swordfish with mushrooms and fennel fronds, and another of crisp deviled chicken with black pepper and pickled chilies.” Enjoy them at a table or at the bar, “long, wide and walnut, maybe the most cordial surface the designer, David Rockwell, has ever put into a restaurant.” Or try the restaurant’s pièce de résistance, maialino al forno. “The skin, blasted to crisp in a hot oven, is dusted in rosemary, cracked fennel, salt and pepper: an apparently unambitious preparation that tastes just great.”

12,000 contestants, 13 golden tickets: The Chicago auditions made for a ponderously dull night on "American Idol." The two days of torture probably had Shania hopping the next plane back to La Tour-de-Peilz in Switzerland.

Liberal advocacy groups are insisting that Democrats must press forward with efforts to overhaul the nation's health care system despite the election results in Massachusetts on Tuesday night, while conservative groups are arguing that Scott Brown's victory is proof that the Democrats' health care bill is flawed and should be scuttled.

Senate Republicans moved quickly on Tuesday night to cast the election results in Massachusetts as a referendum on the Democrats' health care legislation and to urge the Democrats to abandon the bill.

Responding to the Republican victory in Massachusetts, Senator Jim Webb, Democrat of Virginia, is calling on Senate leaders to suspend any votes on the Democrats' health care legislation until the winner in the special Senate election, Scott Brown, is sworn into office.

Scott Brown, a little-known Republican state legislator, will be the next junior senator from Massachusetts, and the message for Democrats is: "it won't much matter"? Well, at least in terms of health care reform, writes Paul Waldman at the American Prospect, who sees two paths ahead:

Kennedy in the overwhelmingly Democratic state of Massachusetts.

If three is a trend, then peanuts are hot! Look! They're on the menu at brand-new Flatiron restaurant Rye House, boiled, right next to sweetbreads done Buffalo-style. Look! The following is the third in a series of reports from the Ethiopian village of Koraro, an important testing ground for the Millennium Village Project, an experiment in global development strategy spearheaded by economist Jeffrey Sachs. The reports, written by Jeff Marlow, a graduate student at the California Institute of Technology, consider which parts of the project are working and which ones aren't, and what can be learned from it to help billions of people escape extreme poverty.

Ethics in business is generally black and white. Don't lie. Do the right thing. Treat people fairly. If you have a good moral compass, it usually does not require much thought to run an ethical business. Or to be an ethical person. There are, however, occasions that make you stop and think. Here is one of them:

The strike is over. Musicians and management of the Cleveland Orchestra on Tuesday approved terms of a settlement over a wage dispute that had prompted a strike Monday. Salaries remain frozen this season and the next. They will go up by 3 percent in the first half of the 2011-12 season and by another 2 percent in the second half. The musicians have agreed to donate up to 10 rehearsals and concerts over the life of the contract. They will pay higher premiums for health insurance starting in July 2011. The agreement was announced by the musicians' committee chairman, Jeffrey Rathbun, and the orchestra's executive director, Gary Hanson.

Meanwhile, Miuccia Prada proved that sometimes to move forward you need to look back to the '70s -- by way of your own witty ugly-chic aesthetic, that is.

Overview | What are the effects of the earthquake in Haiti? What issues, problems and questions has the disaster caused and raised? How are students responding personally, and how can they help? In this lesson, students either participate in a personal response activity or engage in an in-depth teach-in project, researching topics related to the earthquake and presenting their findings to the community. They then develop proposals for a community service plan and choose one or more to implement.

After her upset of Lindsay Davenport, Mauresmo came out as an openly gay woman at her news conference after the match. Her athleticism and long flowing strokes, especially her one-handed backhand, took the tennis world by storm. Her future looked limitless.

The consensus on the left is a resounding no. According to Jonathan Chait, Matt Yglesias, E.J. Dionne, and many others, Obama's political difficulties are explained by a lousy economy, rather than a public backlash against liberalism. Like Ronald Reagan, who suffered a similar first-term swoon, the president is a prisoner of circumstance: His program is suddenly unpopular not because it's too liberal and ambitious, but because the unemployment rate is around 10 percent and holding. In this climate, any agenda would be unpopular, and Obama would having exactly the same problems if he'd governed as a cautious incrementalist rather than a would-be Lyndon Johnson.

The all-terrain vehicle accident that knocked the snowboarder Danny Davis out of his likely place on the United States Olympics team occurred at 3:30 a.m. Sunday. LONDON -- British book reviewers have gone all fluttery of late over "Must You Go?," Lady Antonia Fraser's perfumed love poem of a memoir about her late husband, Harold Pinter. This portrait of marriage, which begins, "I first saw Harold across a crowded room," is said to reveal the softer sentiments of a man known for stark dramas of human inhumanity. But you needn't buy Ms. Fraser's book to uncover a streak of gentleness in Pinter's makeup; that side of him is touchingly in evidence in the new production of "The Caretaker" that opened on Monday night at Trafalgar Studios, with Jonathan Pryce as the fetid old tramp Davies.

MILAN -- Yesterday's shows here continued to echo the emphasis that designers have placed on projecting authenticity. Gucci's Frida Giannini went back to the house's classic signatures, with '70s-inflected suits and turtlenecks, updated loafers with a bumped sole and wool sweaters trimmed in suede. The idea was to make sure there was something special for every kind of guy - though the decadent otter blazer or Mongolian lamb evening jackets are definitely for the wild at heart.

I love food, but I never actually wept over a meal until dessert at a former beer warehouse in Copenhagen last summer. I was at Madeleines Madteater - a kind of interactive dinner performance staged every few months in the neighborhood of Islands Brygge - eating nougat semifreddo while tightly wrapped together with a group of Danes in a stretchy white shroud, behind which waitstaff crept, caressing my back and pressing ghostlike faces through the fabric. There were lyrical strings and a dramatic chiaroscuro and a dancer undulating on the serving dais, and it was all gemütlichkeit, and ritual, and the sadness of endings, and - yes, I know this makes no sense. You had to be there. That is the point. It's art you experience with all five senses, the most satisfying performance in town. Madteater is precisely as its name translates: food theater.Unsurprisingly, Madeleines is named for Proust. The project, which started in 2006, is a collaboration between the chef Mette Sia Martinussen and the film production designer Nikolaj Danielsen, along with a board of directors that includes an anthropologist, a psychotherapist, a couple of artists and a neurology professor conducting research into the senses. But this is no gimmick; it's still very much about the food. Martinussen has long occupied a prime spot in the Modern Scandinavian cooking scene. She co-owned the experimental restaurant Ester & Soja with Claus Meyer, the chef of Copenhagen's beloved Noma. And in 2001 she and Danielsen opened a conceptual dining room called 1.th ("First Floor to the Right"), following it the next year with the experimental traveling restaurant MetteSias Sommerbus.

Neither snow, nor sleet, nor bone-chilling cold can keep the members of New York's assorted recreational bicycle clubs from the swift -- or, often, leisurely -- completion of their appointed rides around and out of the city. The New York Cycle Club, the Five Borough Bicycle Club and Fast and Fab, a lesbian, gay, bisexual and transgender bike club, are some of those that lead outings and other events year round. And while none of these was around at the turn of the last century, each traces its lineage back to the ubiquitous clubs that dominated the earliest years of cycling.

The strike at the Cleveland Orchestra appears to be over. The players and management said on Tuesday morning that a tentative agreement had been reached after a marathon bargaining session that began at noon on Monday and ended shortly before 6:30 a.m. Tuesday. The agreement requires ratification by the musicians and the orchestra's board, and that is expected today, giving the orchestra enough time to move forward with a scheduled trip to Miami for a series of concerts and educational events. It is due to leave on Thursday. No details were released, but the issues centered on pay: the players offered a freeze on salary this year and management asked for a 5 percent cut, to be restored next year, and a 2.5 percent raise the following year.

Californians Still Feel Things Are Worse | California's famous optimism is endangered. For the third consecutive year, a majority of Californians feel worse off financially than they did a year ago, according to a Field Poll. Until last year, Californians went more than 40 years without letting more than one year pass during which they felt that their finances were worse than the previous year. "This is a new era; California is usually bigger and better," said Mark DiCamillo, the Field Poll director. "It's not just affecting a certain population but is affecting a broad base of people." [The San Francisco Chronicle]

The Paris restaurant that helped cultivate the careers of names like Robuchon and Ripert has a new owner. Jamin (32, rue de Longchamp, 16th Arrondissement; 33-1-45-53-00-07; www.restaurant-jamin.com; Metro: Trocadéro and Boissière), which had its heyday in the 1980s, is now being run by Alain Pras, who bought the restaurant space -- as well as the name -- last year, and reopened it in October.

A proposed sale of Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer, the most powerful and lucrative studio during the golden age of film, drew only meager offers last week, and now, Michael Cieply and Brooks Barnes of The New York Times write, Hollywood must confront a troubling question: are movie studios becoming a financial footnote?

One night in 2007, employees at Skype Technologies decided to send a message to their corporate parent, eBay. They picked up the desk of Henry Gomez, an eBay senior executive and Skype's president, and moved it to a far corner of the company's London office, according to a former eBay manager.

Forget about the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index or the Dow Jones industrial average. The latest gauge of Wall Street performance -- at least on Madison Avenue -- is the K.B.S.& P. Client Stock Index, The New York Times's Stuart Elliott writes.

Cadbury will most likely squeeze more out of Kraft without an auction - an impressive feat, the publication remarked before the two companies' announcement Tuesday.

Fans of Lady Gaga were sufficiently baffled by the lyrics to her song “Bad Romance”; now they’re trying to understand how she was able to make a Friday appearance on “The Oprah Winfrey Show” while canceling or postponing several concert dates. On Thursday evening Lady Gaga canceled a show she was to perform at Purdue University in West Lafayette, Ind., writing on her Twitter account that she “was feeling dizzy and having trouble breathing” before the show and that she was later given a diagnosis of exhaustion and dehydration by paramedics. On Friday she taped an appearance on Ms. Winfrey’s show, where she discussed her upbringing, her personal life and her fans (and told the host, “There’s Gandhi, and there’s Oprah”) and also performed her song “Monster.” But that was the only performance that Lady Gaga would give for the weekend. The Star-Ledger of Newark reported that she canceled a show scheduled for Saturday at the Borgata Hotel Casino and Spa in Atlantic City. The concert promoter Live Nation said on livenation.com that a Lady Gaga show scheduled for Sunday in Wallingford, Conn., was canceled, and the Mohegan Sun casino in Uncasville, Conn., said one planned for Monday was postponed. Lady Gaga is scheduled to begin a four-night stand at Radio City Music Hall in New York on Wednesday.

In a video message posted on YouTube, the musician Wyclef Jean, below, defended himself against reports that he benefited personally from his Haitian relief charity, saying, “Not only I denounce all of that, I’m disgusted by that.” Last week the Web site thesmokinggun.com posted a report that said that the Yéle Haiti Foundation, the charity that Mr. Jean has promoted since the Haitian earthquake, “has a lackluster history of accounting for its finances.” The Smoking Gun, citing Internal Revenue Service records, said that the foundation had paid Mr. Jean and a business partner for rent, production services and Mr. Jean’s appearance at a benefit concert, and filed taxes for the first time in August, despite having incorporated 12 years ago. A weary-looking Mr. Jean, who was born in Haiti and recently returned from a visit there, said in the video that he had “always been committed to the people” of that country. He is scheduled to be a host of “Hope for Haiti,” a benefit telethon that will be on many networks on Friday. In a news conference on Monday, Mr. Jean reiterated his defense of the foundation. “Have we made mistakes before?” he said. “Yes. Did I ever use Yéle money for personal benefits? Absolutely not.” He added that the foundation’s books were “open and transparent,” and were given “a clean bill of health by an external auditor every year since we started.”.

The White House and Democratic Congressional leaders, scrambling for a backup plan to rescue their health care legislation if Republicans win the special election in Massachusetts on Tuesday, have begun laying the groundwork to ask House Democrats to approve the Senate version of the bill and send it directly to President Obama for his signature. A victory by the Republican, Scott Brown, in Massachusetts would deny Democrats the 60th vote they need in the Senate to surmount Republican filibusters and advance the health legislation.

A push by celebrities, athletes and the first lady encouraging text-message donations for earthquake relief in Haiti has contributed to a fund-raising bonanza for the American Red Cross, which a little over a year ago turned to Congress for a bailout. As of late Sunday, the organization had collected pledges of $103 million, about $22 million of which came through the text-messaging program. The National Football League's promotion of text-message donations during its weekend playoff games produced stunning results, with money ''coming in at the rate of $500,000 an hour,'' said Roger Lowe, a Red Cross spokesman.

MULLEN--Robert Welch, of New York City died suddenly on January 16 at age 78. Many who loved him knew him as "King." These include his beloved wife of more than 56 years Lucy (Reiss), his loving children Charlotte Sullivan (Ben), Robert Mullen, Jr. (Kathy) and Mary Lou Hall, and his adoring and adored grandchildren Elizabeth, Caroline, Catha, Charlotte, Madeleine, Henry, Christopher, Charles, Peter and Catherine and his many relatives and friends. Born to Helen and Arthur Mullen on January 4, 1932 in Jersey City, NJ, he was predeceased by his sisters Betty Joan Cosgrove, Mary Lou, George and Arthur Mullen. Bob attended the U.S. Naval Academy and graduated Seton Hall University and New York Law School. He was a veteran of the Korean War and clerked for the former Governor Thomas E. Dewey's law firm. Bob went on to enjoy an illustrious career of over 50 years specializing in admiralty law. A member of the Metropolitan Club, the New England Society, an Honorary Usher at St. Patrick's Cathedral and a retired trustee of Marymount School in New York City, Bob spent over forty summers in Bermuda, where he was a member of the Mid-Ocean and Coral Beach Clubs. Family to receive at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave., Wednesday and Thursday, 5-7pm. Mass of the Resurrection Friday, 3pm at St. Vincent Ferrer Church, 66th St. and Lexington Ave. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the American Heart Association.

The Jets' 17-14 win over San Diego on CBS on Sunday generated a 23.1 preliminary overnight Nielsen rating, up 8 percent from the A.F.C. divisional playoff game between San Diego and Pittsburgh a year ago. In the New York market, the game's rating hit its peak at the end, from 7:45 to 8 p.m., when it registered a 35.3. Minnesota's rout of Dallas on Fox was the higher-rated Sunday game with a 23.9, up 14 percent from the Eagles-Giants N.F.C. divisional playoff game last year.

He had eight grandchildren Petyon, Justin, Zack, Daniel, Ethan, Arielle, Yonatan and David who was born two months ago. He loved his wife and family very much, and his wife and family loved him.

From his home in the quiet village of Rorbas, outside Zurich, Rudolf M. Elmer is chipping away at the centuries-old traditions of Swiss banking secrecy. Mr. Elmer, who ran the Caribbean operations of the Swiss bank Julius Baer for eight years until he was dismissed in 2002, moved to Mauritius in the Indian Ocean and began parceling out to global tax authorities what he said were the secrets of his former employer.

MONTFORT--Jay David, March 2, 1959 January 12, 2010. On January 12, Jay David Montfort, a loving and generous son, husband and father, loyal friend and dedicated business leader, passed away at the age of 50. According to his beloved wife Jacqueline, "He was intelligent, witty, loving, and generous. His interests were wide reaching and diverse yet he dedicated himself 100 percent to everything he did and was bound by duty and by always doing what was right." Jay's passions included flying, scuba diving, modern art and sculptures, collecting fine wines, and world history. It was his family however, that was his greatest love, and it was said of Jay that he "loved anything that was beautiful, but he loved his family more." Jay was born on March 2, 1959 in Newburgh, New York. He attended Vassar's Wimpfheimer School, Haldane Central School, and in the ninth grade, began studying at the Hotchkiss School, where he met several lifelong friends. Jay completed the combined Bachelor of Arts in Studio Art and Bachelor of Science in Engineering and Computer Science at Bucknell University. He excelled in studio classes in painting, drawing, and sculpture as well as art appreciation. In 1982, Jay followed his roots in the Hudson Valley and joined his father John in the company his grandfather started 75 years before, Montfort Brothers, Inc. in Fishkill, New York. A meticulous and methodical man, his work ethic was incomparable. He started out as a machine operator in one of the factories and was named President in 2000. At the time of his passing, he owned the business and two other manufacturing and masonry distribution companies: Federal Block Corporation and New Milford Block and Supply Corporation. The company employs over 100 people and is a leading supplier in the tri-state area. Jay was a successful residential land developer, as well. In 1998, Jay fell madly in love with Jacqueline Barlow. Although their time together was too short, they were blessed with two children, Alexander John and Elizabeth Dubois. The family resides in Fishkill, NY. Jay was a wonderful host, not only to his friends, but to good causes as well. He was passionate about giving to others and supported over 30 charities. Jay was on the Council Committee of Storm King Art Center, and a member of The Holland Society of New York and The Cato Institute, Washington, DC. Jay will live forever in the heart of his beloved Jackie and their children, Alexander, eight and Elizabeth, seven. He is lovingly remembered by his stepchildren, Joseph and Darren Barlow, Darren's wife Marilyn, and their children Leah and Jack. His mother, Elizabeth Frost Montfort and sister, Judy Montfort predeceased Jay. He is survived by his father, John Montfort, his stepmother Beverly Montfort and his brother, Jim Montfort. For those who wish to make a donation in Jay's memory, in lieu of flowers, the family would deeply appreciate contributions to enable Dr. Mark Frattini to continue his groundbreaking research in the cure for leukemia at Memorial Sloan Kettering. Donations can be sent to the following address: Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center, 1275 York Avenue, Box 432/Frattini, New York, NY 10065. Jay was an ardent supporter of the Harbor House on Mount Desert Island, Maine. This special place is the heart of the island community and serves to enrich lives by providing services for those in need along with civic, social, youth, and health and fitness programs. Gifts can be made in memory of Jay Montfort, Harbor House Community Center, 329 Main Street, Southwest Harbor, Maine 04679. Calling hours to be held at the Auchmoody Funeral Home in Fishkill, New York on Wednesday, January 20th, from 2-4pm and 7-9pm. A celebration of Jay's life will be held at the Frances Lehman Loeb Arts Center at Vassar College in Poughkeepsie, NY on Saturday, January 23rd at 11am with a reception following at the Vassar Alumni House. Mount Desert Island, Maine will be Jay's final resting place. A memorial service on his beloved island will be held in the summer at Invermeade, the family home in Southwest Harbor, Maine.

McLAUGHLIN--Bethann, 46, passed away peacefully on January 15, 2010 at her home in Chestnut Hill, PA after a long and courageous battle with cancer. Bethann was born to George J. III and Clara Buff on March 29, 1963. She was a 1981 graduate of Haddonfield Memorial High School and attended Greenmount College in Vermont, receiving her BA degree in 1985. Bethann has lived in Chestnut Hill since her marriage to William McLaughlin in 1993. They enjoyed 16 years of marriage and welcomed twins, Schuyler and William into their lives on March 29, 2003, sharing a birthday with their mother. As a junior in high school, she founded "BG's on the Beach" in Stone Harbor, NJ, a boutique jewelry store. Upon graduation, she continued her love of retail and worked her way up to become Assistant Manager at Saks Fifth Avenue in their Center City, Philadelphia store. Together with her mother, the late Clara Buff, she co-founded other retail ventures including "Cotton Comfort", "Linens for Less" and "Initial Gallery", all of which had locations in Haddonfield and Stone Harbor, NJ. Bethann's life would seem too short to many, but those who knew her and were touched by her understood that her love of life and impact on others far exceeds the quantity of time in which she lived. Her sense of humor, compassion and generosity brought much joy to family and friends. True to her attributes of compassion and generosity, she was active in the American Cancer Society and a supporter of the National Institute of Health. She was a loving and devoted mother and the last six years since the birth of her children were years of great pride, joy and happiness. Cancer had unfortunately made several appearances in her life. In dealing with this challenge, Bethann's positive attitude, strength and courage was an inspiration to all who knew and loved her. Her love for life and family extended her time beyond what all who knew her thought possible. Bethann is survived by her husband, William and their two children, Schuyler and William, her father, George J. Buff, III, brother, George IV (Izabela) and nephew, George V. Friends and family are invited to visit with her family on Friday, 9:30 to 11:00am at the Haddonfield United Methodist Church, 29 Warwick Rd., Haddonfield, NJ, where a Celebration of Life Service will follow at 11:00am. Interment Locustwood Memorial Park, Cherry Hill, NJ. Her family requests in lieu of flowers, donations be sent to Friends of Wissahickon, 8708 Germantown Ave., Philadelphia, PA 19118-2717. www.fow.org. Services by the Foster-Warne Funeral Home. Collingswood, NJ. To email condolences please visit www.fosterwarnefuneralhome.com.

It was championship point of a grueling struggle last August in Washington, and neither Andy Roddick nor Juan Martín del Potro would give up. As their shots sprayed the court, Roddick, in his first tournament since pushing Roger Federer to 16-14 in the fifth set at Wimbledon, angled a forehand close to the line. Del Potro saw the ball hit wide; the linesman called it out. Del Potro smiled, preparing to whip off his headband and move to the net for a congratulatory handshake from Roddick.

ENGLE--Joe R.,87, New York City, died January 17, 2010. Born January 26, 1922 in Coshocton, OH, he was the son of the late Perry L. and Georgia R. Engle. Mr. Engle was a graduate of the Ohio State University where he currently sat on the Ohio State Foundation Board and the Harvard Business School. He also served as the engineering officer aboard an LST in WWII. He was a manufacturer's representative for his entire business career and a cofounder of the Loctite Corporation in Hartford, CT. Mr. Engle was a lifelong Presbyterian and one of his great interests was theological education. He was endowed three chairs in homiletics at Princeton Theological Seminary and also a chair in homiletics at Union Theological Seminary in New York on whose board he had served for nine years. At Princeton's Seminary he also endowed the Joe R. Engle Institute of Preaching whereby each summer 50 young preachers are brought back to campus and provided with an intense refresher course to improve their preaching skills. It is now in its seventh year. Mr. Engle also had a lifelong interest in scholarships for needy students for Coshocton County, Ohio with a preference for first generation college students to attend the Ohio State University. Survivors include his wife, Elizabeth, a stepson, Dr. Graham Barr, both of New York City; a sister, Mary E. Ehrich, and a nephew, Dr. William Ehrich, both of Bloomington, IN. Memorial service with Reverend John Walton officiating, Saturday, January 30th at 4pm at the First Presbyterian Church, 12 West 12th St. (at 5th Ave., and 12th St.) In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the charity of one's choice or to the Engle Institute of Preaching at Princeton Theological Seminary.

10 P.M. (13); 11 P.M. (49) COPYRIGHT CRIMINALS Long before the era of the video mash-up, hip-hop musicians were perfecting the art of audio montage through ''sampling,'' the reuse of previously recorded music in otherwise original compositions. Once lawyers and record companies got involved, the borrowed melody became a copyright infringement, with artistic expression facing off against the law. In this ''Independent Lens'' presentation Benjamin Franzen and Kembrew McLeod interview those who view sampling as pillaging and those who argue that the practice isn't new or unique to music. The interviewees include the hip-hop pioneers De La Soul, above, and Public Enemy; the funk innovator George Clinton; Jeff Chang, the author of ''Can't Stop Won't Stop''; and the drummer Clyde Stubblefield, who worked with James Brown and is one of the world's most sampled musicians. 8 P.M. (Fox) AMERICAN IDOLSimon Cowell, Randy Jackson and Kara DioGuardi sort the wheat from the chaff in the latest round of auditions in Chicago.

Only about half of all Americans with depression receive treatment of any kind, a new study reports. And just one in five are getting care -- talk therapy, medication or both -- that conforms to guidelines from the American Psychiatric Association. The findings, which appear in the January issue of Archives of General Psychiatry, were based on nationally representative surveys of 15,762 adults from February 2001 to November 2003.

Ukraine carried out the first round of its presidential balloting on Sunday far more competently and fairly than in its election five years ago, election monitors said Monday. The monitors said the first round was not marred by the kind of government meddling and outright fraud that occurred in 2004. The top finishers, Viktor F. Yanukovich, the opposition leader, and Prime Minister Yulia V. Tymoshenko, will move to a runoff next month.

When watching a Hollywood movie that has robed itself in the themes and paraphernalia of science, a scientist expects to feel anything from annoyance to infuriation at facts misconstrued or processes misrepresented. What a scientist does not expect is to enter into a state of ecstatic wonderment, to have the urge to leap up and shout: ''Yes! That's exactly what it's like!'' So it is time for all the biologists who have not yet done so to shut their laptops and run from their laboratories directly to the movie theaters, put on 3-D glasses and watch the film ''Avatar.'' In fact, anyone who loves a biologist or may want to be one, or better yet, anyone who hates a biologist -- and certainly everyone who has ever sneered at a tree-hugger -- should do the same. Because the director James Cameron's otherworldly tale of romance and battle, aliens and armadas, has somehow managed to do what no other film has done. It has recreated what is the heart of biology: the naked, heart-stopping wonder of really seeing the living world.

JELLINEK--George, age 90, of Hastings-on-Hudson, NY, died peacefully on January 16, 2010. Born in Budapest, Hungary, Mr. Jellinek began studying violin at age five, but his greatest love was opera. A lifelong student of that art, he attended performances throughout Europe and later the United States. He was Musical Director of Station WQXR from 1968 to 1984 and a frequent guest on the Texaco Metropolitan Opera Quiz. His popular syndicated radio program, The Vocal Scene, was heard by listeners coast to coast for 36 years. Mr. Jellinek was also a frequent contributor to Opera News, Stereo Review, and other musical publications, and authored several books in the field. He is survived by his beloved wife Hedy, his daughter Nancy Berezin, granddaughter Amy Ford, and great-granddaughter Ava Ford. Private funeral services will be held this week, with a larger memorial service to follow at a later date.

“Barbara” wears a fur coat, a Marilyn wig and a blank stare. “Deborah” leans against the rear window of a car, casually smoking and “Beth” just sets things on fire in a parking lot. Inspired by Alfred Hitchcock, David Lynch, Douglas Sirk and other masters of sexy darkness, the photographer Alex Prager specializes in cinematic images of women. Her latest portraits can be seen at Yancey Richardson Gallery, which is presenting “Week-End,” now through Feb. 20. The exhibition of new work by Ms. Prager is the third installment in her trilogy of staged female portraits set in the artist’s native city, Los Angeles. Ms. Prager examines female types with wigs, makeup, retro costumes and intriguing narratives lurking just outside the frame that make you want to look.

How much will the forthcoming Chevrolet Volt actually cost? Is it the low $30,000s? Or is it around $40,000? Call it the war of the asterisk. The growing confusion over the pricing of battery E.V.'s and plug-in hybrids has to do with a $7,500 federal tax credit for purchasers of cars with battery packs of 16 kilowatt-hours or more. With high prices made unavoidable by expensive batteries, carmakers are sorely tempted to simply lower the price by the amount of the credit, then add an asterisk and fine print reading, "Price includes a $7,500 federal tax credit."

Bulgarians have something to celebrate today, as the country's entry into the Oscar pool for foreign-language film, "The World Is Big and Salvation Lurks Around the Corner," has advanced to another round. Eight other films made the shortlist, and as usual, there were some high-profile omissions. Those that made it include selections from Israel ("Ajami"), Kazakhstan ("Kelin"), the Netherlands ("Winter in Wartime") and Peru ("The Milk of Sorrow"). The two most-well known films on these shores are Michael Haneke's "The White Ribbon," the German entry, and "A Prophet," ("Un prophète") by Jacques Audiard from France. Both received rapturous reviews and the bulk of attention from other awards and critics groups.

Wednesday's sweater weather notwithstanding, blizzards and ice may yet lie ahead, but take heart: the dead of winter is behind us. Statistically speaking, at least. Jan. 19 has the lowest average temperatures of the year in New York City -- a low of 26 degrees and a high of 37, according to AccuWeather.com. The average high and low for Jan. 20 both leap upward by three-tenths of a degree.

There are excerpts in "Shocking True Story" (Pantheon), a new history of the infamous and influential celebrity-scandal rag Confidential, that should strike you as straight out of a James Ellroy novel: the built-up glitz and the hard-boiled sleaze, to start, as well as something about the language - full of implication and insinuation, and as tart and pulpy as a blood orange. The author, Henry E. Scott, writes in the book's acknowledgments that he was reading Ellroy's "L.A. Confidential" when he became inspired to write about the magazine - which for five years in the 1950s incited paranoia in Hollywood's bedrooms and boardrooms with tightly sourced, stylized accounts of celebrity indiscretion. At the New York-based magazine's height - which is to say just before its downfall at the hands of Tinseltown attorneys - it enjoyed a circulation of 9 million. Its pages laid the groundwork for the National Inquirer, E! and US Weekly; indeed, where once went Confidential, now goes TMZ.Not unlike an Ellroy novel, "Shocking True Story" sometimes delights in the macabre, particularly in the long passages it lifts from Confidential's pages. One article, from the magazine's November 1954 issue, could almost describe a Jacques-Louis David painting from 150 years earlier: "Police found her nude body in the bathroom of her San Francisco apartment. There was a grim touch of neatness, even comfort, in the way she had met death. After filling the tub with water, she had arranged a stack of pillows around the edge and drowned herself." The woman's name was Dr. Jean S. Tatlock, and she was a communist. She killed herself in 1944, some six months after an overnight rendezvous with her former boyfriend, Dr. Robert Oppenheimer. This wasn't news by late 1954, but it did endear Confidential's charismatic, power-peddling owner, Robert Harrison, to J. Edgar Hoover's F.B.I. and the forces of McCarthyism, who at a public hearing earlier that year stripped Oppenheimer of his Atomic Energy Commission security clearance.

When was the last time you looked at a piece of paper? Eight and a half by 11, unmarked, unblemished copy paper. That was the first task for the 20 students (and one architecture and design curator) at the Museum of Modern Art's Bauhaus Lab last week. The workshop was one of a series that are being held in conjunction with the exhibition "Bauhaus 1919-1933: Workshops for Modernity," which closes on Jan. 25. "Shout out your first thoughts," said Ati Gropius Johansen, the daughter of the pioneering Modernist architect and Bauhaus founding director Walter Gropius, who was teaching the Three-Dimensional Workshop. Five people immediately said, "White."The students were arrayed around a flower-shaped table in the atrium of the museum's education wing. Johansen had placed one sheet of paper in the center. "What else?" she asked. "It has four sides." "It has 90-degree angles." "It is flat." This last response interested Johansen. She reclined gently on the table. "How is it lying? If this were a person, what would you find yourself doing to it?" Another student blurted out, "It is like a baby." After 10 more minutes of discussion, Johansen sent the students off with the instruction to create the biggest change in the paper with the least action: one fold, one roll, one rip.

In November, a study appeared in The New England Journal of Medicine that should give pause to many athletic dopers and those who love them. The study examined the effects of Darbepoetin Alfa, one of a class of drugs commonly known as Epo that is used to stimulate the body's production of red blood cells. In the experiment, more than 4,000 patients with diabetes, kidney disease and anemia were given either Epo or a placebo. The researchers were testing the impact of the drug when it was used as approved, at moderate doses in sick people. What they found, to their surprise, was that slightly more of the patients taking Epo suffered heart attacks than those in the placebo group, that nearly twice as many suffered a stroke and that the Epo group's self-reported quality of life, their subjective sense of fatigue and illness, was barely better than with placebo.

The architect Bernard Tschumi has donated 43 drawings by his father, the Swiss architect Jean Tschumi, to the Museum of Modern Art, the younger Mr. Tschumi is to announce on Wednesday. Jean Tschumi, who died in 1962 at 57, helped influence modern architecture and design in the mid-20th century and became an influential figure in architectural education and practice. The works on paper range from Mr. Tschumi’s early work while a student in Paris to his last project, the Nestlé headquarters in Vevey, Switzerland. With this gift MoMA becomes the only institution outside of Europe to house a collection of drawings by Mr. Tschumi; the majority of his drawings are in the Archives of Modern Construction at the Lausanne Polytechnique, whose architecture school Mr. Tschumi founded in 1942, and in Basel in the collection of the pharmaceutical giant Novartis, formerly Sandoz, for which Mr. Tschumi built headquarters and laboratories in Switzerland and France. (Mr. Tschumi’s desk for the company director, above.) His notable works include the headquarters building of the World Heath Organization in Geneva. “I think he was very ambitious and at the same time a little ironical about the pitfalls of fame,” Bernard Tschumi said in a telephone interview from Paris on Tuesday. “I think he would have been extremely pleased, but with a twinkle in his eye.”.

“There are some secrets which do not permit themselves to be told,” Edgar Allan Poe wrote in his 1845 short story “The Man of the Crowd.” And since 1949 one such secret has attended Poe’s final resting place in Baltimore at the Westminster Hall and Burying Ground, where a black-clad figure has shown up annually early on the morning of Jan. 19, the author’s birthday, to raise a Cognac toast to his grave and deposit three red roses, along with the remnants of the Cognac bottle. But the visitor — whose identity, or identities, has never been revealed, despite some claims to the contrary over the years — failed to show up this year for the first time, ending a strange crepuscular tradition and disappointing a crowd of more than 30 people who forfeited a good night’s sleep to witness the visitation. “I was very annoyed,” Jeff Jerome, curator of the Edgar Allan Poe House, told The Baltimore Sun. “I’ve been doing this since 1977, and there was no indication he wasn’t going to show up.” Some conjectured that the Poe Toaster, as the visitor has come to be known, might have just had the flu or car trouble. But Mr. Jerome spoke with a Poe-ian air of finality. Last year was the bicentennial of Poe’s birthday, he said. “And if it was going to end,” he said, “that would be the perfect time to end it.”.

Jay-Z, Muse and Gorillaz will headline the 11th annual Coachella Valley Music and Arts Festival when that sprawling rock event gets under way on April 16 in Indio, Calif., planners announced on Tuesday. They are hoping to maintain the momentum from last year, when the festival drew its second-highest crowds, despite the economic downturn. The big news from the show is that it will serve as a stop on what seems to be shaping up as a sizable reunion tour for the long-lamented lo-fi band Pavement, which broke up a decade ago. Along with bands of the moment like Vampire Weekend, Dirty Projectors, Girls and Grizzly Bear, this year’s lineup includes some venerable names like Gil Scott-Heron, Grace Jones, Devo and Sly and the Family Stone, along with a few oddball entries like the filmmaker John Waters (maybe he’ll do his rendition of “Mama, I’m a Big Girl Now” from “Hairspray”?) and D J Lance Rock, of the hipster children’s show “Yo Gabba Gabba” fame.

The Future Generation Art Prize, a new $100,000 award for artists younger than 35, created by the Ukrainian billionaire and art collector Victor Pinchuk, has announced the members of the prize’s jury, and many of the names are well traveled on the international art circuit. They include Daniel Birnbaum, the director of the Städelschule Art Academy in Frankfurt and the director of the 2009 Venice Biennale; Robert Storr, the dean of the Yale University School of Art and the director of the Venice Biennale two years before that; Okwui Enwezor, the director of Documenta XI in 2002 and a highly sought-after curator and writer; and Ai Weiwei, probably China’s most famous living artist. The Victor Pinchuk Foundation, a nonprofit organization founded in 2006, also announced that it had begun to accept entries from artists, who can submit applications online at futuregenerationartprize.org through April 18. The prize will be awarded every two years, along with a more populist noncash side award, the People’s Choice Prize, to be determined by a public online vote, à la “American Idol.”.

The shortlist for the Brit Awards, Britain’s equivalent of the Grammys, seems at least one name too short to many fans. Susan Boyle, above, who rocketed to fame last April after her appearance on “Britain’s Got Talent” and whose first record just finished a six-week run at the top of the Billboard album chart, selling more than three million copies, was nowhere to be seen among the nominees, who include Lady GaGa, Lily Allen, Taylor Swift, Jay-Z, Bruce Springsteen and the newcomer Pixie Lott. The winners will be announced on Feb. 16 at a ceremony in London.

Weather, time and general wear and tear take their toll on every kind of material, and the street is as a good a place to notice this as anywhere else. The sole of a businessman's shoe in Lower Manhattan shows scuffs and the start of a hole. A close look at the sidewalk around Gramercy Park reveals the same thing is happening to bluestone as it is tread upon by millions of feet, decade after decade. Earlier pictures in the series are at nytimes.com/lens.

The musicians of the Cleveland Orchestra and their management settled a strike on Tuesday that lasted little longer than a quick scherzo but made clear the tensions raised by difficult economic times across the orchestra world. The orchestra struck on Monday, and negotiators met at noon that day at a mediator's office a few miles outside the city. They reached a tentative agreement shortly after dawn on Tuesday, and it was ratified later in the day.

The all-terrain-vehicle accident that knocked the snowboarder Danny Davis out of his likely place on the United States Olympic team occurred around 3:30 a.m. Sunday. According to a report from the Summit County, Utah, sheriff's department, Davis was on a four-wheel vehicle that slammed into a closed gate at the end of a driveway. The report said that Davis was thrown from the vehicle and later found unconscious by friends, with injuries to his legs. Other news media reports said that Davis was not alone, but it was not clear who was driving.

There were no outbursts from Serena Williams here -- at least on the court. She swiftly and, for the most part stoically, took apart her overmatched opponent, Urszula Radwanska, in straight sets on Tuesday. But afterward, Williams, the women's defending Australian Open champion, pointedly questioned the fine imposed on her for threatening to shove a ball down a line judge's throat last summer at the United States Open. Williams, making her first Grand Slam appearance since the profanity-laced outburst at Flushing Meadows, said she believed the $92,000 fine was too severe and suggested that it would have been less if she had not been a woman.

For several years, the slogan of the United States ski team has been, ''Best in the World.'' At the 2006 Turin Olympics, this motivational motto was perceived by the international community to be more of a battle cry and, rightly or wrongly, a haughty one. After the Austrians Benjamin Raich and Hermann Maier finished first and third in the 2006 Olympic men's giant slalom, Maier mocked the American slogan. ''Who is the best in the world?'' Maier bellowed with a laugh at the postrace news conference. At the time, the Austrian Alpine team had won nine Olympic medals and the Americans had won one.

Neither snow, nor sleet, nor bone-chilling cold can keep the members of New York's assorted recreational bicycle clubs from the swift -- or, often, leisurely -- completion of their appointed rides around and out of the city. The New York Cycle Club, the Five Borough Bicycle Club and Fast and Fab, a lesbian, gay, bisexual and transgender bike club, are some of those that lead outings and other events year round. And while none of these was around at the turn of the last century, each traces its lineage back to the ubiquitous clubs that dominated cycling's early years. In the 1880s and 1890s, growing middle-class participation in cycling led to the formation of hundreds of clubs across the United States. The first to form was the Boston Bicycle Club, created on Feb. 11, 1878. The following February a club was formed in Buffalo. The first New York City club came in 1880, also in February (something about the cold seemed to drive riders to associate in those days, perhaps for the warmth of the pack).

Erich Segal, a Yale classics professor turned popular writer whose first novel, ''Love Story,'' became a staggering commercial success if not quite a critical one when it appeared in 1970, died on Sunday at his home in London. He was 72. The cause was a heart attack, his daughter Francesca said on Tuesday. Mr. Segal had been ill with Parkinson's disease for 25 years.

9 P.M. (13) THE AUDITION How do you get to the Met? Audition, audition, audition. Susan Froemke covers the week leading up to the finals of the Metropolitan Opera's 2007 National Council Auditions, where thousands of aspiring singers annually compete for a cash prize, the chance to perform onstage at the Met and a jumpstart to a major operatic career. At the heart of the film, presented by ''Great Performances at the Met,'' are three tenors: Alek Shrader, 25, whose movie-star looks may not be enough to help him hit nine high C's in Donizetti's ''Pour Mon Ame,'' the aria that made Pavarotti famous; Ryan Smith, 30, who dreams of stardom despite little formal training (Mr. Smith died of cancer in 2008); and Michael Fabiano, 22, who wrestles with some inner demons -- and who currently can be seen at the Met in Verdi's ''Stiffelio.'' Above, the 11 finalists. 8 P.M. (Fox) AMERICAN IDOL Auditions continue in Orlando, Fla.

MASSAD--Alex H.,on January 16, 2010, at the age of 86, died in his sleep at his home in Austin, Texas. Alex was born July 10, 1923 in Drumright, Oklahoma, the son of Lebanese immigrants. He graduated in 1943 from the University of Oklahoma and served in the Navy as an Ensign in WWII. He married Delores Jean Razook of Wichita, Kansas on January 29, 1950. From 1946 to 1986, Alex worked for Magnolia Petroleum Company and its successor Mobil Corporation in numerous locations, including its headquarters in New York City. For many years, and at the time of his retirement, he was Executive Vice President of Mobil Corporation and President of its Worldwide Exploration and Production Division, based in New York. He was a member of Mobil's board of directors from 1977 to 1986, as well as a director of Ingersoll Rand Corporation from 1982 to 1996 and Bangor Punta Corporation for several years. Alex is survived by his wife Dee; his son Steve Massad of Houston, Texas and his daughters Caroline, Sally and Maggi; his daughter Alexis Massad Gleitman and her husband Jim Gleitman of Austin and their children Jimmy, Robert and Rachel; his son Tim Massad and his wife Charlotte Hart of New York City (and temporarily Washington, DC) and their children Emil and Jayne. Family and friends are invited to attend a memorial service and celebration of Alex's life at 11:00am, Saturday, January 30, 2010 at Good Shepherd Episcopal Church, 3201 Windsor Road, Austin, Texas, followed by a reception immediately after the service. In lieu of flowers, donations may be sent in memory of Alex to Seton Hospital, 3501 Mills Ave., Austin, Texas 78731 or to Good Shepherd Episcopal Church, 3201 Windsor Road, Austin, Texas 78763. Services by Weed-Corley-Fish Funeral Home South Congress, 2620 S. Congress, Austin, TX 512/442-1446. You may view memorials at www.wcfish.com.

McLAUGHLIN--Bethann, 46, passed away peacefully on January 15, 2010 at her home in Chestnut Hill, PA after a long and courageous battle with cancer. Bethann was born to George J. III and Clara Buff on March 29, 1963. She was a 1981 graduate of Haddonfield Memorial High School and attended Green Mountain College in Vermont, receiving her BA degree in 1985. Bethann has lived in Chestnut Hill since her marriage to William McLaughlin in 1993. They enjoyed 16 years of marriage and welcomed twins, Schuyler and William into their lives on March 29, 2003, sharing a birthday with their mother. As a junior in high school, she founded "BG's on the Beach" in Stone Harbor, NJ, a boutique jewelry store. Upon graduation, she continued her love of retail and worked her way up to become Assistant Manager at Saks Fifth Avenue in their Center City, Philadelphia store. Together with her mother, the late Clara Buff, she co-founded other retail ventures including "Cotton Comfort", "Linens for Less" and "Initial Gallery", all of which had locations in Haddonfield and Stone Harbor, NJ. Bethann's life would seem too short to many, but those who knew her and were touched by her understood that her love of life and impact on others far exceeds the quantity of time in which she lived. Her sense of humor, compassion and generosity brought much joy to family and friends. True to her attributes of compassion and generosity, she was active in the American Cancer Society and a supporter of the National Institute of Health. She was a loving and devoted mother and the last six years since the birth of her children were years of great pride, joy and happiness. Cancer had unfortunately made several appearances in her life. In dealing with this challenge, Bethann's positive attitude, strength and courage was an inspiration to all who knew and loved her. Her love for life and family extended her time beyond what all who knew her thought possible. Bethann is survived by her husband, William and their two children, Schuyler and William, her father, George J. Buff, III, brother, George IV (Izabela) and nephew, George V. Friends and family are invited to visit with her family on Friday, 9:30 to 11:00am at the Haddonfield United Methodist Church, 29 Warwick Rd., Haddonfield, NJ, where a Celebration of Life Service will follow at 11:00am. Interment Locustwood Memorial Park, Cherry Hill, NJ. Her family requests in lieu of flowers, donations be sent to Friends of Wissahickon, 8708 Germantown Ave., Philadelphia, PA 19118-2717. www.fow.org. Services by the Foster-Warne Funeral Home. Collingswood, NJ. To email condolences please visit www.fosterwarnefuneralhome.com.
