Gather round people, today we are going to discuss the highly opaque but hugely important topic of "O.T.C. derivatives," or securities that derive their value from other securities and are traded between institutions "over-the-counter," rather than on an exchange where they can be more closely regulated and monitored. Examples of such derivatives are an option to buy a stock in the future at a fixed price set today and credit-default swaps, a form of insurance against the future default of a bond.

Last week, after years of public curiosity about what was hidden behind Mark McGwire's testimony to Congress in 2005, McGwire admitted he indeed had a secret. He conceded that his career was marked by intermittent steroid use, even during 1998, the year he broke Roger Maris' single-season home run record. His historic run was unreal . . . literally.My brother was and is a supporter of the unreal - a huge fan of science fiction's Godzilla. Thanks to him, when I was growing up I would catch an occasional episode of the TV show where Godzilla would take on Rodan (or some other nemesis) and they would end up in these knock-down, drag-out fights, reaping collateral damage all along the way. Once Godzilla went on his rampage, our eyes fixed on the TV, waiting to see which landmark would end up a pile of rubble. We loved it. And when the May 1998 release date of a remake of "Godzilla" approached, even with the baseball season in high gear I anticipated seeing it in a Philadelphia theater as soon as I could find some down time in between games.

Andaz Wall Street, Hyatt's first New York boutique hotel, opened this week (with a Midtown location to follow this spring), and if I'm reading the tea leaves about what this means for many of the nearly 50 hotels that will open in New York this year, one theme emerges: recession luxe. The Andaz property, part of an entirely new brand for Hyatt, is a far cry from last year's extremes of old-school opulence and flophouse chic. In June, the unabashedly luxurious Pierre Hotel reopened, flaunting a $100 million renovation and posting room rates of the "if you have to ask ..." variety. Then the Crosby Hotel opened, with each of the 86 rooms awash in bespoke fabric and art, and priced to match. Conversely, the aggressively gritty Ace and Jane Hotels, the latter featuring communal bathrooms, promised hipster cred on the cheap.

I took a brief leave of the catwalks to take in the annual SIHH luxury watch preview in Geneva. The packed hallways and buzzing booths were a welcome contrast to the quiet post-crisis scene a year ago. As usual there were the requisite one-upmanships between brands. Some innovations were astounding, others simply showy. There was an equally strong emphasis on heritage and brand DNA, with many companies focusing on line extensions, as they're called, or simply slight updates of existing styles. Some industry leaders took a break from bloat and put their watches on strict, chronograph-free diets, "Biggest Loser" style. Piaget's new Altiplano was recently named the world record holder for the watch with the thinnest automatic movement, as well as the thinnest automatic case. Rival Vacheron Constantin's new Patrimony Traditionale 1968 was named the world's thinnest manual winding watch. Finally, Baume & Mercier clocked in with its new Classima Executive, measuring only 4.4 millimeters thick, with a lean price of $1,490 for the quartz-movement watch. These three made strong, sleek statements that can hold their own against more "complicated" competitors. Cartier introduced the Montre Calibre, featuring a chunkier case and the first in-house-designed and in-house-produced automatic movement. A. Lange & Sohne's Zeitwerk Phantom was inspired by a dinner in the dark held in Berlin during the introduction of the original Zeitwerk. A UV-transparent coating allows the absorption of light by the numerals hidden beneath the face to glow in the dark. Audemars Piguet took cues from the car-racing world for its Royal Oak Offshore Grand Prix. The auto-inspired detailing and graphics, plus a dark forged carbon case and bright red anodized aluminum face, made for a racetrack-worthy watch. In one of the most innovative watches of the show, Montblanc introduced the Metamorphosis, a Transformer-style watch that has to be seen to be believed (and explained). This two-faced watch, the result of a collaboration between expert watchmakers, features two dials that separate to reveal two more hidden dials with chronograph functions. From the chic and seemingly simple to the innovative and complicated, this year's SIHH confirmed that the vitality of the watch business depends on tradition as much as innovation.

A new modeling study published in this week's issue of Science projects a rise of about 30 percent in potential hurricane damage in the western Atlantic toward the end of the century as emissions of greenhouse gases rise. Although the overall number of storms in the region are expected to drop, the number of strong ones -- those reaching Category 4 or 5 in the hurricane index -- are expected to double from the number produced now, the study says. The projections are based on a midrange scenario for a rise in the heat-trapping emissions linked to global warming.

If there were only a song in "Rent" that noted the passage of time in excruciatingly precise detail, this might be the moment to cite it. On Thursday, press representatives for that musical said that its national tour will play its final performance on Feb. 7, making it the first time since it opened that "Rent" will not be performed on a Broadway or national stage. "Rent," Jonathan Larson's rock-opera gloss on "La Bohème," had its Off Broadway and Broadway openings in 1996 (after a workshop production in 1994), and went on to play 5,123 performances at the Nederlander Theater before closing in 2008. The national tour has played 373 performances in 39 cities, traveling 54,000 miles in the process. The final tour performances of "Rent" will take place Feb. 3 through 7 at the Community Center Theater in Sacramento, and will feature Adam Pascal, Anthony Rapp and Gwen Stewart, from the musical's original cast.

From Simon Johnson at Economix:

After a highly contentious departure from the airwaves, a beloved personality has revealed the project in which he'll make his long-awaited return to television. No, not Conan O'Brien - David Hasselhoff. A&E said that it had ordered a new "real-life docu-series" (or as it is also known, a "reality show") that will star Mr. Hasselhoff (or as he is also known, "the Hoff") that will follow him as he raises two teenage daughters and attempts to help them find their places in the entertainment industry. Mr. Hasselhoff, the former "Knight Rider" and "Baywatch" star, said earlier this month that he was quitting his position as a judge of the NBC competition program "America's Got Talent," saying only that he was leaving to pursue his own series. The A&E show, which does not yet have a title, will take viewers on a shadowy flight with Mr. Hasselhoff and his daughters, Taylor-Ann, 19, a communications major at the University of Arizona, and Hayley, 17, a fashion model, who both aspire to be professional singers. Ten episodes have been ordered and are scheduled to be shown later this year.

BART officials hope to break ground on the 3.2-mile extension this summer. Critics have called the extension a "ski lift to the airport" for the elite. "I think this is a problem of process," said James Fang, the president of BART's board. "We are confident we can beat back this last obstacle to the project." [The Oakland Tribune]

The Fitness column last Thursday, about nutritional supplements for exercisers, overstated Dr. Teri M. McCambridge’s role at the American Academy of Pediatrics. She is the chairwoman of its council on sports medicine and fitness, not the chairwoman of the entire academy. The article also referred incorrectly to nitric oxide; although caffeine is often added to supplements that contain it, it is not a caffeine-based stimulant. And a picture caption with the article misidentified the exerciser who begins his morning workout by taking N.O.-Xplode. As the article correctly reported, he is Michael Deutsch — not Alex Feintuch, who is shown in the picture.

An article on Saturday about a reunion of the passengers and crew aboard the US Airways jet that crash-landed onto the Hudson River a year ago misstated the location of the crash and the event that occurred 90 seconds into the flight. The crash was at 40 degrees 46 minutes 10.19 seconds north latitude, and 74 degrees 16.69 seconds west longitude — not south latitude. It was the intake of geese by the plane’s engines that took place at the 90-second mark, not the crash itself.

In their latest filing with the Los Angeles Superior Court, lawyers for Roman Polanski on Tuesday said officials with the district attorney’s office had “intentionally misled the Swiss” government with a false record of Mr. Polanski’s long-running sex case as a way to secure his extradition from that country. The claim is included in a brief for a planned Friday hearing on whether Mr. Polanski, who in 1978 fled the United States before sentencing on a conviction of having sex with a minor, should now be entitled to sentencing in absentia. “Politics seems to be interfering with the just administration of the law,” wrote Mr. Polanski’s lawyers, Chad S. Hummel and Bart Dalton, in response to a district attorney’s brief arguing that Mr. Polanski should have to appear before sentencing. This month the Los Angeles County district attorney, Steve Cooley, formed a committee to explore a run for California attorney general. Tuesday’s filing did not specifically mention that possible run for state office, but it said the district attorney’s insistence that Mr. Polanski return to the United States was a “nakedly political” approach to the case. Los Angeles prosecutors have long argued that Mr. Polanski’s fugitive status deprived him of any right to challenge his treatment in California.

If the next “Spider-Man” movie features an adorable nonlinear plot device, a musical number set to an underappreciated Hall & Oates song or a terrible final line that exhausts all your good will toward the film, now you know why. On Wednesday, Sony Pictures Entertainment announced that it had signed Marc Webb, above, the director of the hit romantic comedy “(500) Days of Summer,” to direct a fourth installment in its “Spider-Man” franchise, The Hollywood Reporter said. Last week news emerged that Sam Raimi, the director of the first three hit films about Spider-Man, and his star, Tobey Maguire, who plays the Marvel Comics hero and his alter ego, Peter Parker, were leaving the franchise over creative differences. Sony had said that it wanted to return the film series to the teenage roots of the Peter Parker character. In announcing that it had hired Mr. Webb, the studio said in a statement that it wanted a director “who could capture the awe of being in Peter’s shoes so the audience could experience his sense of discovery while giving real heart to the emotion, anxiety and recklessness of that age.” The new “Spider-Man” film is being planned for a 2012 release, but no stars or screenwriters have been announced.

Scott Brown lives by what he calls ''Army values,'' instilled 30 years ago when he joined the Massachusetts National Guard. ''The most regimented person I know,'' his oldest daughter calls the Republican politician, who abhors disorder while sometimes inviting it with audacious pursuits -- whether jumping into frigid lakes at 5 a.m. (for triathlon training) or into a seemingly quixotic Senate race. ''I treated this campaign like a sprint triathlon,'' Mr. Brown said in an interview Wednesday. ''You have to be good in everything, 18, 19 hours a day. We were just out there cranking.''

Don't send shoes, send money. Don't send baby formula, send money. Don't send old coats, send money. Nonprofit groups rarely look a gift horse in the mouth, and the relief effort in Haiti is desperate for resources. But the experience of wasteful giving in the past, coupled with the ease of speaking out via blogs, Facebook and Twitter, have led to an unprecedented effort to teach Americans what not to give.

After an unidentified man's laptop set off alarms at Munich's international airport Wednesday indicating the possible presence of explosives, the traveler simply picked up the computer, walked into the crowded departure terminal and disappeared, touching off the fourth airport security scare in a month. The incident caused flight cancellations and delays for thousands of travelers as the better part of one of the airport's two terminals shut down and passengers were forced to evacuate. The man had still not been identified as of late Wednesday.

HASSIBI--Mahin, 72, died at Sloan Kettering Memorial Hospital yesterday surrounded by loving friends and family after a one year struggle with cancer. In her work and her life, Mahin was a powerful force of love, a fierce advocate for children's mental health and a creative and visionary thinker. Mahin Hassibi was Professor of clinical psychiatry New York Medical College, Associate Professor of Clinical Psychiatry, New York University, Asst. Chief of Child Psychiatry Metropolitan Hospital, Medical Director of Choices Mental Health Center and contributing editor to On the Issues Magazine. Dr. Hassibi was the co-author with Stella Chess and Harry Breuer of "Disordered Thinking and Communication in Children" 1980 as well as co-author of "Principles and Practice of Child Psychiatry" with Stella Chess in 1978 along with numerous journal articles. Her groundbreaking pieces in On The Issues included "Sexual Apartheid in Iran", Why Change the world when you can have a Prozac Moment" and Breaking the Male Patina in Biology". Wise, courageous and compassionate, she is survived by friends and family and in the hearts and minds of all those whose lives she touched. Donations may be made in her honor to Doctors without Borders. A Memorial Service will be announced.

The Philippine election commission cleared the way Wednesday for Joseph Estrada, a former president, to run for the office a second time. The commission dismissed a pair of cases that would have disqualified Mr. Estrada, left, for the vote in May, although some analysts say they believe the decision contravenes the Constitution, which prohibits a president from seeking a second term. Mr. Estrada, 72, has long contended that the constitutional ban does not apply to him because he completed less than half of his six-year term.

Acting on intelligence failures exposed by the attempted bombing of a Detroit-bound airliner on Dec. 25, Prime Minister Gordon Brown announced a major tightening of British aviation security measures on Wednesday, including the creation of a new no-flight list of terrorist suspects similar to one maintained by the United States. Mr. Brown announced an immediate suspension of the twice-a-week flights between London and Sana, the capital of Yemen, by Yemen's national airline, Yemenia, while efforts are made to improve airport security in Yemen. A new focus on Yemen as a base for plots by Al Qaeda has been one of many consequences of the failed Dec. 25 attack. American authorities have accused a 23-year-old Nigerian, Umar Farouk Abdulmutallab, and say he was prepared for the plot by Qaeda operatives in Yemen.

Odlyzko investigated why the Internet connection from his home in Minneapolis to his office just over two miles away was so sluggish, he found the answer: the data was taking a round trip to Denver. His team of researchers issues reports about the growth of Internet traffic, and he uses the team's tools to watch his own connections, too.

The president-elect of Honduras agreed on Wednesday to grant safe passage to the Dominican Republic for Manuel Zelaya, the ousted president. The accord, signed Wednesday by President-elect Porfirio Lobo of Honduras and President Leonel Fernández of the Dominican Republic, would allow Mr. Zelaya to travel and speak publicly. Mr. Zelaya, who was overthrown in a coup last June, called the proposal ''a good gesture'' and said he would study it, the Honduran media reported.

YOU'RE not supposed to talk on a mobile phone while you're at the gym, but many people do anyway -- and check e-mail, listen to music and surf the Web, all while glued to an exercise machine. And so, to keep the smart phone from toppling off an elliptical trainer (''No really, Mr. Genius Bar, I swear I never dropped it.''), a phone-holding armband may be a wise investment. These armbands, which sometimes come with plastic windows that give the wearer access to the controls, are alternatives to pockets or the sloping face of a treadmill.

Wednesday's sweater weather notwithstanding, blizzards and ice may yet lie ahead. But take heart: The dead of winter is behind us. Statistically speaking, at least. Jan. 19 has the lowest average temperatures of the year in New York City -- a low of 26 degrees and a high of 37, according to AccuWeather.com. The average high and low for Jan. 20 both leap upward by three-tenths of a degree.

Harold Faber, a retired reporter and editor at The New York Times whose work for the paper ranged from war reporting in Korea, sustaining a grave injury while doing so, to covering the regions north of New York City, died Jan. 7 at his home in Salisbury, Conn. He was 90. His wife, Doris, confirmed the death.

An article on Dec. 30 about the possibility that Umar Farouk Abdulmutallab, accused of trying to blow up a Northwest flight to Detroit, might have been influenced by Islamic militancy at schools in Britain, where he once attended the University College London, misstated the number of Muslim students compared with the number of other students in higher education there. Nearly 100,000 of the approximately 2.4 million students are Muslims, not ''nearly 100,000 of 500,000.''

Scott Brown's decisive Senate victory in Massachusetts imperiled the fate of the Democratic health care overhaul as House Democrats indicated they would not quickly approve a Senate-passed health care measure and send it to President Obama. After a meeting of House Democratic leaders Tuesday night even as Mr. Brown's victory was being declared, top lawmakers said they were weighing their options. But the prospect of passing the health care overhaul by pushing the Senate plan through the House appeared to significantly diminish.

BEIJING China announced Thursday that its gross domestic product in fourth quarter 2009 grew by 10.7 percent year-on-year, up from a revised growth rate of 9.1 percent in the third quarter. China's economy is surging forward even as many other nations, including the United States, are still trying to punch through the global recession. Over the whole year, the Chinese economy grew by 8.7 percent, surpassing the 8 percent growth-rate benchmark that Chinese leaders assert is necessary to maintain social stability. If China keeps up that growth rate, it will likely replace Japan as the world's second-largest economy by the end of this year.

There was no reason for Kenny Lofton to retire after the 2007 season. He was 40 years old, but he was still good. He had played a full season and hit .290 with a .367 on-base percentage for Texas and Cleveland, helping the Indians come within a game of the World Series. Lofton was not great on defense, but he was a useful and productive player, and he knew it. He had just made $6 million, part of the $60 million or so he had earned in his long career. When the suitable offers did not come his way as a free agent, he simply stopped playing.

MARTIN--Alastair Bradley. The Trustees and staff of The Metropolitan Museum of Art mourn the passing of Alastair Bradley Martin, an art collector of great distinction who was a treasured benefactor and honorary trustee of the Museum. Over more than 50 years, he donated and loaned important works of medieval art that are on display in the main building and The Cloisters, and contributed as well to the areas of ancient Near Eastern art, Islamic art, and European sculpture and decorative arts, thereby enhancing the Museum's encyclopedic collections. Through participation in several advisory committees, he always shared his time and wisdom generously. We extend condolences to his entire family. James R. Houghton, Chairman Thomas P. Campbell, Director Emily K. Rafferty, President

More than a few eyebrows will likely be raised on Thursday when the Italian architect Renzo Piano unveils his design for the expansion of the Isabella Stewart Gardner Museum here. The cultural watchdogs of Boston don't take well to change. And the museum, whose collections haven't moved since 1924, is one of the most beloved art institutions in this city. Its eclectic array of artworks from the Middle Ages to the early-20th century, displayed in a dazzling faux-Venetian palazzo, stands alongside those in the Frick Collection in Manhattan and the Getty Villa in Malibu, Calif., as a rare -- and intimate -- expression of a single collector's vision.

McLEAN--Joan K.,died January 18, 2010. Born Brooklyn, NY, October 19, 1930. Admired sister of James and Richard, much-loved aunt of fourteen. Mass: Church of the Immaculate Conception, West Hampton Beach, NY. January 26, 10:30am. Burial: Holy Cross Cemetery, Brooklyn, NY.

VADALA--Catherine. The Officers, Board of Governors and members of Metropolis Country Club mourn the passing of our esteemed honorary life member Catherine Vadala, wife of our late former Green Superintendent Bruno Vadala and extend our heartfelt condolences to her family, including her daughter Lucille Grasso and son-in-law Anthony Grasso, our current Green Superintendent. Neda Birbrower, President Ronald M. Stuart, Secretary

KAPLAN--Frank. Fenway Golf Club expresses profound sorrow at the passing of its esteemed member Frank Kaplan, husband of Barbara Schreckinger Kaplan. We extend our sincere condolences to his entire family. Jeffrey Citron, President

FRIEDLANDER--Florence (nee Corvino), 82, of Tarrytown, NY passed away on January 18, 2010. Born February 14, 1927 in The Bronx, she was one of eight children. Florence fell in love with education, became a Community Superintendent of District 29 and never stopped teaching. She was predeceased by her beloved husband Gordon D. Friedlander. She is survived by her brother Richard (Mary) Corvino, sister Elizabeth (Milton) Jordan of Mount Vernon, NY along with many beautiful nieces, nephews, grandnieces and grandnephews. Visitation will be at the funeral home, Friday, January 22 from 3pm to 5pm and 7pm to 9pm. Mass of Christian Burial will be celebrated 10am Saturday, January 23 at the Church of Our Lady of Mount Carmel, Elmsford, NY. Interment Gate of Heaven Cemetery, Hawthorne, NY. In lieu of flowers please send donations in Florence's name to The American Breast Cancer Foundation, Inc., 1220 B East Joppa Road, Suite 332, Baltimore, MD 21286. 1-877-539-2543, Email: contctABCF@abcf.org, Dwyer & Vanderbilt Funeral Home, 90 North Broadway, Tarrytown, NY, 10591, 914-631-0621.

(Fox) BONES The lab tightens security when Brennan (Emily Deschanel, right) and her team are ordered to work on a highly classified government case, leading Booth (David Boreanaz) and his boss (Diedrich Bader) to bend some rules to get at the reason for the investigation. Meanwhile Cam (Tamara Taylor) worries that her adopted daughter, Michelle (Tiffany Hines), is keeping a secret. 7 A.M. GRAY--Edward W. T. III, of Manhattan and Remsenburg, NY, died on January 17, 2010. Founder, President and CEO of Analytic Asset Management; Founder and Board Chair of the Countess Moira Charitable Foundation; previously, founder, President, and CEO of Gray, Seifert and Co., and Senior Vice President of Bessemer Trust Company. Graduate of Princeton University, the Stonier Graduate School of Banking, and Blair Academy. Member of Princeton Reach Out '56. Past President of the Rotary Club of New York and Chair of its Foundation. Trustee of the Lichtenstein Foundation. Director, United Nations Association of New York. Member of the Episcopal Diocese of Long Island Investment Advisory Committee; previously Warden and Vestryman of St. Mark's Episcopal Church, Westhampton Beach, and Director, Westhampton Yacht Squadron and Westhampton Beach Family Counseling Services. Member of the Union League Club (Library Committee). Previously Vice President and Trustee of the Newark Episcopal Diocesan Investment Fund and in Montclair, NJ, Senior Warden of St. Luke's Church and member of the Boards of Directors of the Mental Health Resource Center and the Salvation Army Montclair area. Coast Guard officer and veteran. Skied on every continent, traveled extensively throughout fifty states and the world and was also an avid golfer, sailor, tennis and bridge player, and singer. In recent years, authored four plays. Loving husband, father, grandfather, and brother, Mr. Gray is survived by his wife, Michele LeMoal-Gray; sons Taylor and Peter and daughter Carolyn and their spouses, Kathy, Donna, and Marc; grandchildren Brendan, Matthew, Stephen, Jessica, and Emily; sister Alice and nieces, nephews, cousins and friends. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Foundation of New York City Rotary Club or Family Counseling Service of Westhampton Beach, NY. Funeral arrangements will be announced. Memorial service planned for April 2010 in New York City.

Senator-elect Scott Brown, Republican of Massachusetts, said in his victory speech that he was eager to get to Washington and start his new job. But Mr. Brown, who owes his victory to independent voters, will find himself at the center of a partisan typhoon over the fate of the major health care legislation. At his victory speech, the crowd chanted ''Forty-one! Forty-one! Forty-one!'' -- a reference to Mr. Brown's role as the 41st Republican senator, which will deny Democrats the 60 votes they need to overcome Republican filibusters and advance legislation, including the health care bill.

South Korea would launch a pre-emptive conventional strike against the North if there were clear indications of an impending nuclear attack, the South Korean defense minister said Wednesday in Seoul. The comments by the minister, Kim Tae-young, reconfirmed the South Korean military's stance on the possibility of a nuclear strike by the North, Defense Ministry officials said. The tough talk came as a government research group in Seoul said that North Korea's leader, Kim Jong-il, who reportedly had a stroke in 2008, might die in two or three years and that any ensuing instability could lead to a limited war on the divided peninsula.

The Federal Bureau of Investigation improperly obtained calling records for more than 3,500 telephone accounts from 2003 to 2006 without following any legal procedures, according to a newly disclosed report by the Justice Department's inspector general. Instead, according to the 289-page report, F.B.I. agents informally requested the records from employees of three unidentified telephone companies who were stationed inside a bureau communications office.

MULLEN--Robert Welch, of New York City died suddenly on January 16 at age 78. Many who loved him knew him as "King." These include his beloved wife of more than 56 years Lucy (Reiss), his loving children Charlotte Sullivan (Ben), Robert Mullen, Jr. (Kathy) and Mary Lou Hall, and his adoring and adored grandchildren Elizabeth, Caroline, Catha, Charlotte, Madeleine, Henry, Christopher, Charles, Peter and Catherine and his many relatives and friends. Born to Helen and Arthur Mullen on January 4, 1932 in Jersey City, NJ, he was predeceased by his sisters Betty Joan Cosgrove, Mary Lou, George and Arthur Mullen. Bob attended the U.S. Naval Academy and graduated Seton Hall University and New York Law School. He was a veteran of the Korean War and clerked for the former Governor Thomas E. Dewey's law firm. Bob went on to enjoy an illustrious career of over 50 years specializing in admiralty law. A member of the Metropolitan Club, the New England Society, an Honorary Usher at St. Patrick's Cathedral and a retired trustee of Marymount School in New York City, Bob spent over forty summers in Bermuda, where he was a member of the Mid-Ocean and Coral Beach Clubs. Family to receive at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave., Wednesday and Thursday, 5-7pm. Mass of the Resurrection Friday, 3pm at St. Vincent Ferrer Church, 66th St. and Lexington Ave. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the American Heart Association.
KAPLAN--Frank 93, of Rye, NY and Palm Beach, FL. Services January 21, Ballard-Durand, White Plains, NY 11:00am, (914)949-0566.

The N.F.L. players union fired back at team owners Wednesday, one day after the Giants co-owner John Mara said he was frustrated by the pace of labor negotiations and was resigned to a 2010 season without a salary cap, starting in March. ''It's very discouraging,'' said Nolan Harrison, a former player and a member of the union's retired players steering committee. ''If I'm working on a deal with somebody and we have a timetable and a month and a half before the completion of a deal, and the other side comes out and says, 'I give up, I don't think we're going to get a deal done,' No. 1, it sends a bad message. No. 2, it really smells of not bargaining fairly.

In a rare moment away from the courthouse, Raj Rajaratnam, the Galleon Group‘s founder and accused mastermind of a multimillion-dollar insider trading ring, was caught on camera by Bloomberg News leaving Tao restaurant in Manhattan on Friday.

President Obama’s plan to rein in big banks and their ability to make risky bets may seem to hark back to the days when commercial banking and investment banking were separated by the Depression-era Glass-Steagall Act. But the so-called Volcker Rule, as Mr. Obama’s proposal is known, does not go as far as Glass-Steagall in that it would allow commercial banks to retain some investment banking activities, like underwriting securities and trading on behalf of clients.

There’s no doubt that the closer you stand to the president, the better he can hear you. So the lineup as President Obama announced his plan on Thursday hints that he is not listening quite as much to Treasury Secretary Timothy F, Geithner anymore, The Washington Post writes.

The tougher approach to financial regulation that President Obama outlined on Thursday reflected a changed political climate, the rebound in big banks’ fortunes after their taxpayer bailout and a shift in power within the administration away from those who had been seen as most sympathetic to Wall Street.

The choreographer Mark Morris is well acquainted with dance forms from other cultures. Tonight you can start to catch up with him by paying a visit to India by way of the Dance on Camera Festival. The annual festival, with films from around the world through Feb. 2, opens tonight at the Mark Morris Dance Center in Brooklyn. On the bill is the premiere of "Nrityagram: For the Love of Dance," a documentary by Nan Melville about a gurukul, or dance village, near Bangalore where students live and dance in close proximity with their master guru. Before the documentary will be a screening of "Bahudha," part of a series of duets using the Kathak style of Indian classical dance. The colorful short shows two dancers performing before projected images of themselves. Stick around after the film when Mr. Morris and Ms. Melville will participate in a Q. and A.

Conan O'Brien closed out his career at the "Tonight" show -- and NBC -- with a last monologue centering on his tumultuous last week on the show and a last commentary that expressed his gratitude for the opportunities NBC gave him and for the staff and friends and fans who supported him.

On taking the bench, he announced that he had already given lawyers a tentative ruling, but was willing to hear a few last words before finalizing it.

Will they return to flashy spending or invest it more conservatively? Paul Sullivan examines this question in his Wealth Matters column in The New York Times and finds a number of people are leaning toward caution.

McCain-Feingold, that Quixotic attempt to turn money and politics into oil and water, was lanced by the Supreme Court on Thursday in a 5-4 decision based on the idea, espoused by Justice Anthony Kennedy, that "If the First Amendment has any force, it prohibits Congress from fining or jailing citizens, or associations of citizens, for simply engaging in political speech." To some extent, most of us would agree on the "citizens" point -- it's that "associations" bit that's the fly in the ointment for many.

Shortly after her loss in Massachusetts, Martha M. Coakley has delivered her own post-mortem on how her campaign to succeed the late Edward M. Kennedy in the Senate went awry.
Former President George H.W. Bush officially endorsed Senator Kay Bailey Hutchison, Republican of Texas, in her gubernatorial primary against sitting Gov. Rick Perry.

The high points of the day were Rick Owens and Comme des Garcons. Many times an Owens' show feels like a journey of self-realization: the American who brought his dark, singular aesthetic to Paris and seemingly discovered it there. His latest collection flowed like a skillful narrative. The opening looks were tailored, monochromatic and spare, with cropped pants and a shoulder line that looked as straight and strong as an industrial beam.

Grant Desme hit 31 home runs and stole 40 bases in Class A last season, and as an encore, he was named most valuable player of the Arizona Fall League. The Oakland Athletics had plans to invite Desme, a 23-year-old outfielder, to spring training next month.

The House Judiciary Committee has devoted two hearings to the subject of football head injuries. The Senate will soon consider a bill to raise awareness of the seriousness of sports concussions. As the issue climbs the political ladder, it's fair to wonder if President Obama will chime in on the subject.
It's officially a trend, and a great one at that. Point-and-shoot cameras are gaining built-in GPS capabilities that are very useful to peripatetic photographers who want to geo-tag their images.
Outside Port-au-Prince, major obstacles still stand in the way of getting food, water and shelter to those affected by the earthquake.

Sony unwrapped two new Cyber-shot cameras that pack cool features like built-in GPS, automatic high dynamic range (HDR) image capture, and a new wireless file transfer technology. They also can record full HD 1080p video in the AVCHD format, a first for Sony.

The words "poetry" and "best seller" don't appear often in the same sentence. But if you want to get a handle on what verse Americans are reading right now, here's the place to go - the Poetry Foundation's contemporary poetry best-seller list.Scanning the most recent Poetry Foundation list, for the week ending Jan. 3, 2010, one thing is pretty clear: it's Mary Oliver's world, we only live in it. Ms. Oliver, who writes earnest poems about nature, has no fewer than five books in the Top 10. (She's been knocked out of the No. 1 position this time, however, by Wendell Berry's book "Leavings.")

A few days after Morgan Stanley reported its first loss in its 74-year history, the bank announced late Friday afternoon that its chief executive, James P. Gorman, would receive $8.11 million in deferred stock as part of his bonus for 2009, The New York Times's Graham Bowley reports.

With the news that Sundance and the nearby, concurrent festival Slamdance will share content with online and non-traditional platforms like YouTube and Microsoft's Xbox 360, Variety examines whether these short-term deals could hurt filmmakers looking for distribution. With every angle needed to make a profit, "the availability of a movie for rent before a film is sold could dissuade some dealmakers from offering a more lucrative deal, considering one of their distribution platforms has already been eliminated from the mix," Marc Graser writes.

Around 3 in the morning on Thursday, Trisha Alam awoke to a shocking but joyous sight. Her father, Nurul Alam, a Bangladeshi fruit vendor who worked on the Upper East Side and whose plight The New York Times chronicled last month, had returned to their home in Parkchester in the Bronx after around three months' detention at the Hudson County Correctional Center in Kearney, N.J.

Frozen pizzas and chili bowls? Not at Cortina d'Ampezzo, a fashionable ski resort in the Dolomites of northern Italy, which is prized for its fine dining as much as its fresh snow. Evan Rail skis his way from mountain hut to mountain hut, sampling the region's Tryrolean goulash, house-made spaghetti and steaming polenta.

For the second time in less than 80 years, the nation's commercial banks are being told to stick to their knitting. Their knitting is taking deposits, handling checking accounts, lending money and managing the nation's payment system. Twice now, they have ventured beyond these standard activities, gotten into trouble and almost brought down the financial system.

Expectations weren't exactly high going into the 2010 New York Cycle World International Motorcycle Show. After a year of plummeting American sales, manufacturers were not in a position to showcase flashy new products or fancy exhibits. Most of the presentations at the media preview on Friday focused on products that had been revealed elsewhere. It was a distinct change from the 2009 show, when the industry had a previous-year sales boost to crow about and there were new models and concept bikes on display.
Sixteen states and the District of Columbia had double-digit unemployment rates in December, according to a new government report, with Michigan's jobless percentage still in the top spot.
In the latest poll from the Kaiser Family Foundation, Americans are evenly divided over the "health reform proposals being discussed in Congress," a finding echoed in other recent national polls.

Time and again, it comes down to this: individual faces seem to convey the impact of mass trauma far more resonantly than broader views of destruction and devastation. Several such faces already stand out in the coverage of the earthquake in Haiti. And today, Ruth Fremson added to that poignant gallery with her portrait of Jean Marseille (Slide 4), waiting at the University Hospital of Haiti to be transferred to a hospital ship because his injuries are so significant. Mr. Marseille's gaze at the camera - his gravity unimpeached by the strip of tape across his forhead with the word, "Ship" - cannot be ignored and will not soon be forgotten.

SCOTTSDALE, Ariz. - As I walked past row after row of vehicles during the collector car auctions here this week, I was struck by a display that drew a large crowd. Some people were walking away with tears in their eyes.

Museums in Los Angeles aren't the only ones receiving gifts from Eli Broad. Mr. Broad, the billionaire philanthropist and Michigan State alumnus, and his wife Edythe Broad, have donated an additional $2 million to the construction of an art museum that bears their names on the Michigan State campus in East Lansing. The gift, announced by university officials earlier this week, brings the total gift from the couple to $28 million: $7 million earmarked for acquisitions, exhibitions and operations and $21 million for construction of the Eli and Edythe Broad Art Museum, designed by Zaha Hadid, the Pritzker-award winning architect.

Brooklyn Heights Montessori School will close the Little Room, a well-known preschool for children with special needs, in August after failing to secure a new sponsor for the program during a yearlong search.

The hosts of several progressive talk shows hastened to remind fans on Friday that although the brand-name network Air America had abruptly folded, their shows were still on the air.

Field-goal kicking wasn't so great during the regular season -- kickers converted just 81.3 percent, way off from last year's 84.5 percent, the highest in N.F.L. history. But it has been a disaster in the postseason, where kickers have made just 57.8 percent of their attempts, including Shayne Graham and Nate Kaeding, who are a combined 0-5 against the Jets.

Bievenue à Paris! After the first day of men's-wear shows, critics have already dropped that favored "heritage" buzzword. As Scorecard can tell you, concept reigns here in the City of Light, so better make sure your theme explores dualistic tension and depth. (Bonus points awarded for making references to Austrian symbolism, modernist lit, and/or the postmodern, preferably all at once.)

The Bay Area blog has been reporting daily from the federal courthouse in San Francisco on the case of Perry v. Schwarzenegger. That case is challenging the constitutionality of Proposition 8, the ban on same-sex marriage approved by voters in 2008. Among the lawyers on the plaintiff's team are Theodore B. Olson, David Boies, Theodore J. Boutrous Jr., Christopher Dean Dusseault, Christine Van Aken, Danny Chu, Matthew D. McGill and Therese Stewart. The legal team for the defense includes Brian Raum, Charles J. Cooper, David Thompson, Andrew Pugno, James Campbell, Jordan Lorence, Nicole Moss, Howard C. Nielson Jr. and Peter A. Patterson.

Jacques Audiard's ''Un Prophète'' (''A Prophet''), which won the Grand Jury Prize at last year's Cannes Film Festival, received 13 nominations on Friday for the César award, the French version of the Oscars, including ones for best film, best director and best actor for Tahar Rahim.

The new movie "Extraordinary Measures,'' opening around the country this weekend, focuses on a father's quest to find a treatment for Pompe disease, a rare and often fatal disorder that disables the heart and muscles. While the movie takes some liberties on the real life events and people it depicts, it's based on the true story of entrepreneur John Crowley, as chronicled in the book "The Cure'' by Wall Street Journal reporter Geeta Anand.

Loretta Lynn has been added to the 2010 lineup of the Lilith Fair, the music tour of female performers. Ms. Lynn, Cat Power, Kate Nash, Norah Jones and Lissie were among the artists announced by the festival producers this week. The festival also added San Diego, Phoenix and Austin to the tour. Attorneys for Michael Jackson's estate have filed papers opposing an effort by Joe Jackson, the singer's father, to receive a monthly allowance, The Associated Press reported. Attorneys for the estate administrators, John Branca and John McClain, filed papers to deny Mr. Jackson's request for more than $15,000 a month from his son's estate. The attorneys noted that the singer did not name his father as a beneficiary in his will and trust and that Joe Jackson failed to show that his son supported him while he was alive. When he filed for the monthly stipend in November, Mr. Jackson said he needed his son's financial help to survive.

A client of the Swiss banking giant UBS has won an appeal to prevent her account information from being handed over to authorities in Washington as part of a tax evasion investigation, Reuters reported.

"A Proper Burial" (03:40)Against what seemed almost insurmountable odds posed by the wreckage in Haiti - "As Haitians Flee, the Dead Go Uncounted," Damien Cave reported - the Auguste family was determined to give Clotaire a fitting burial. Damien and Rob Harris followed as the family's quest took them high up into the hills. That a simple burial could be a triumph is a testament to the level of catastrophe for the Haitian people. But the camera's unobstrusive presence also helps document a small victory for a single family that is also - one might argue - a victory for humanity. (K.B.)

São Paulo fashion week is still coming into its own, but it certainly gives good show. From a slew of supermodels to unmarked after-parties, the cool quotient held its own against the more traditional fashion capitals. This season's model check saw Lara Stone walking for Forum Tufi Duek, Brazil's prodigal son Jesus Luz doing an awkward catwalk turn for Ellus, Alessandra Ambrosio filling in for Gisele at Colcci, Isabeli Fontana opening for Alexandre Herchcovitch and Chanel Iman at Rosa Cha.

ELYRIA, Ohio - Conceding his health care overhaul had run into "a little bit of a buzz saw,'' President Obama vowed on Friday to keep fighting for legislation that will "hold the insurance industry accountable" and "to bring more stability and security to folks who are in our health care system.''

Monologue | Thursday night on "The Jay Leno Show" on NBC: Well, in political news, the big upset. A Republican was elected to the U.S. Senate in Massachusetts, filling a seat once held by Ted Kennedy. So, this could tip the delicate balance of power in the U.S. Senate from the completely incompetent back to the morally corrupt.

Anyone who has shopped for a mortgage knows how confusing the process can be -- loans come with different sets of fees, interest rates and closing costs, all of which must be untangled before you can figure out who's offering the best deal. But comparison shopping may get a little easier.

Monologue | Thursday night on "The Late Show With David Letterman" on CBS: Anybody here from Massachusetts? You got a new senator, congratulations. Do you know anything about this guy? His name is Scott Brown. Isn't that the guy Elvis played in "Clambake?"

Monologue | Thursday night on "The Tonight Show With Conan O'Brien" on NBC: NBC and I have finally reached a separation agreement. I'd like to apologize to the guests that were scheduled for next week. President Barack Obama, the pope, the queen of England, and our good friend, Elvis Presley, was stopping by.

Monologue | Thursday night on "Late Night With Jimmy Fallon" on NBC: Well, today officially marks the beginning of President Obama's second year in office. He has three years left, but NBC offered him $45 million to leave altogether. So, we'll see what happens.

Monologue | Thursday night on "Jimmy Kimmel Live" on ABC: The Supreme Court today ruled in a five votes to four decision that corporations can now spend as much as they want on political campaigns. In other words, if Exxon or Dow wants to support a candidate, they can give him or her as much money as they want. I can't see that having any negative repercussions, can you?

The chairman of Goldman Sachs's quantitative hedge fund group, whose funds run off of complex computer trading algorithms, plans to step down at the end of the month, Bloomberg News reported Friday, citing unnamed sources.

The revamped Sundance Film Festival - slogan: "Reborn. Rebellion. Rebirth. Rebel. Renewed. Rebooted" -- got under way on Thursday night, and some changes were already evident. At the opening news conference, Robert Redford, the founder and guiding light, dissed a regular attendee: "Paris Hilton doesn't have anything to do with anything," he said, as Roger Ebert reported.

Representative Barney Frank said Friday that the House Financial Services Committee, which he leads, would push to replace Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, seized by regulators almost 17 months ago, with a different model for mortgage financing.

Tom Taylor has a problem. He is the inspiration for Tommy Taylor, a world-renowned boy-wizard character concocted by his father, an author. The pressure of being linked to such a beloved icon is crushing. There's also an added complication: Tommy's fictional world is seeping into the real one. And that's just the beginning of "The Unwritten," a new series written by Mike Carey and illustrated by Peter Gross, whose first collected edition lands at No. 8 on our softcover list this week.

This is an auspicious beginning: hours before the opening film at the Sundance Film Festival, the first deal has already been made. Variety reports that "Waiting for Superman," a documentary about the crisis in public education, was picked up by Paramount for its (much-streamlined) boutique Paramount Vantage division. The film comes from Davis Guggenheim and Lesley Chilcott, the director-producer team behind "An Inconvenient Truth," which made an Oscar-winning moneymaker out of another unsexy topic -- the environment.
Judging from some draft evaluations prepared by the Environmental Protection Agency and General Electric, the plan for dredging the Hudson River for PCBs faces some likely adjustments.

The Paris shows were off to a good start with Louis Vuitton, where the men's studio director, Paul Helbers, got things going with a Vienna-inspired parade of somber flecked coats and jackets, convertible boots with zippers and beautiful bags with abstract hand-painting by the artist Christian Schoeller. Helbers said that he had looked at artists like Egon Schiele and Gustav Klimt for inspiration; he also commissioned a soundtrack featuring a Kafka reading, and even changed the show-space configuration: instead of a normal runway, models walked in a mazelike setup to allow for greater proximity to the audience. It was a smart move. From the leather anoraks and blazers to the new clog-inspired short boots and the contrasting fabric insets on jackets and coats, this was a collection that needed to be seen up close.
The fall 2010 collection from Dries Van Noten.

The Seven Stars Resort in Turks and Caicos is offering 40 percent off as part of a winter special. With the discount, rooms start at $390 a night through March 31. A three-night minimum stay is required.

Now let's see. How many versions of "Frankenstein" will this make? Danny Boyle, the director of the Oscar-winning "Slumdog Millionaire" is to direct a stage adaptation of "Frankenstein," based on the novel by Mary Shelley, The Guardian reports. Nicholas Hytner, the director of the National Theater in London, said that the British director will make his debut at the theater later this year. Mr. Hytner said that Mr. Boyle, who began his career at London's Royal Court and the Royal Shakespeare Company, was returning to his first love after film "distracted" him for a while. (Mr. Boyle also directed "Trainspotting.") "Danny first talked about this eight years ago and it has taken him eight years," Mr. Hytner said of Mr. Boyle's decision to direct the playwright Nick Dear's new adaptation of "Frankenstein." It will be a "large-scale and theatrically and visually ambitious stage production," Mr. Hytner said

SCOTTSDALE, Ariz. -- The Russo & Steele classic car auction was interrupted Thursday night by strong winds accompanying a wild storm that damaged cars and ripped away huge sections of the event's tents and deposited them in the traffic lanes of the adjacent 101 freeway.

Oprah Winfrey is the latest subject for Kitty Kelley, known for her often unflattering, dishy and best-selling celebrity biographies. Crown Publishers announced this week that Ms. Kelley's 544-page, unauthorized "Oprah: A Biography," will be released on April 13, The Associated Press reported. The first printing will be at least 500,000 copies. Ms. Kelley has written books about Frank Sinatra, Nancy Reagan and the Bush family. She conducted 850 interviews for the book and spent the last three years combing through Ms. Winfrey's life, Ms. Kelley said, according to the A.P. She was, Ms. Kelley said, "full of admiration for her accomplishments and fascinated by her complexity."

In an inexplicable fashion, Kim Clijsters crashed out of the Australian Open against the Russian Nadia Petrova, winning just one game on the way to a loss ESPN.com's Ravi Ubha called a "savage beating".

Watch out, "Mamma Mia!" The Spice Girls are cooking up a musical with an original story based on their hit songs, Reuters reports. The working title is "Viva Forever," after the 1998 British No. 1 single by the five-member British band. The "Viva Forever" creators are the band's former manager Simon Fuller and Judy Craymer, who produced the worldwide hit musical "Mamma Mia!" which featured the songs of the Swedish band Abba, and later became a movie starring Meryl Streep. "Mamma Mia!" has made $2 billion in the past decade. The Spice Girls show could debut on the London stage in two or three years, Mr. Fuller and Ms. Craymer said. The Spice Girls - Melanie Chisholm (Sporty Spice or Mel C), Victoria Beckham (Posh Spice), Geri Halliwell (Ginger Spice); Emma Bunton (Baby Spice) and Melanie Brown (Scary Spice) became a cultural phenomenon after releasing their first single "Wannabe" in 1996. The group split up in 2000 but reunited for a tour in 2007.

"Creation," which concerns Charles Darwin's 20-year-long Hamlet moment over writing "Origin of Species," is not what you commonly call a sexy story - even if 5-year-old viewers (both of them) will still say eeeewww: a barnacle is graphically dissected, a fox eats a rabbit (thus furthering the cause of movie foxes not named Megan; see "Antichrist") and, in Darwin's workshop, acid-washed birds are boiled down to their bones. For adults, however, the most disturbing event in this British production will be a rather Victorian sex scene between Darwin and his wife, Emma. Why? Because they're played by the real-life couple Paul Bettany and Jennifer Connelly.Sure, we understand: the director, Jon Amiel, wanted to avail himself of the instant intimacy of a married twosome. But who wants to see that? Who wanted to see Alec Baldwin and Kim Basinger getting it on in "The Getaway"? Who wanted to cross the minefield that was Tom Cruise and Nicole Kidman in "Eyes Wide Shut"? Who wanted to see Ed Harris and Amy Madigan (as the painter Jackson Pollock and heiress Peggy Guggenheim) coupling like wildebeests in "Pollock"? O.K., that was pretty funny. But married people in bed? You might as well watch a Don Johnson-Melanie Griffith festival.

Various news reports that Tim Geithner is privately opposed to the new Obama bank plan -- which isn't that much of a surprise, but he should not be talking about it (if he is). What we do have is this PBS interview, in which he certainly isn't doing much to back the concept. The correct answer to "In essence are you saying that big banks need to be broken up" is "Yes"; add some qualifiers if necessary -- "we're not talking about a sudden disruption, but about new rules of the game, but the eventual goal is smaller banks that aren't engaged in inappropriate activities" or something like that.

"Fantastic Mr. Fox," Wes Anderson's adaptation of the Roald Dahl children's book, has garnered Mr. Anderson some of the most effusive praise of his already-lauded career, and made him a contender in the awards game. Parents Object To Internet Tower | Parents expressed anger at a school meeting Wednesday about a proposal to put a 37-foot Internet antenna tower disguised as an evergreen tree near Walnut Heights Elementary School's playground. If approved, the school district would receive $15,000 a year from Clearwire, which sells a WiMax broadband service. The antenna spreads radio waves wider than Wi-Fi radio waves, something that concerns some parents. "I don't want my kids used as an experiment," said John Johnson. [The Contra Costa Times]

He’ll focus on techniques like mediation, guided imagery, movement, dance and nutrition, as well as experiments with drawing and dialogue. The Modern, Fatty Crab, Babbo, ilili and the Waverly Inn are among those on a long list of restaurants that will donate up to 10 percent of sales to charities. Bring a big appetite, proceeds will be distributed to Action Against Hunger, Doctors Without Borders and Partners in Health.

Beyoncé and Madonna are among the more than 100 big names in music, film and television scheduled to take part in “Hope for Haiti Now: A Global Benefit for Earthquake Relief,” a two-hour telethon on Friday night to be broadcast around the world on television and online. The show, which in the United States will begin at 8 p.m. Eastern time on all the major networks and on cable channels, is to feature musical performances from multiple locations: Bruce Springsteen, Sting, Shakira and Wyclef Jean will play in New York, while in London Bono and the Edge of U2 will collaborate with Jay-Z and Rihanna, with Coldplay also slated to perform. The program in Los Angeles is to include performances by Stevie Wonder, Taylor Swift and Justin Timberlake and a collaboration among Keith Urban, Kid Rock and Sheryl Crow. Songs from the telethon will be for sale on iTunes for 99 cents beginning Saturday, will all proceeds going to a number of relief organizations.

Urban design projects that incorporate the arts will be awarded grants of up to $250,000 each from the National Endowment for the Arts, the chairman, Rocco Landesman, announced to the United States Conference of Mayors in Washington on Thursday. The Endowment expects to distribute up to 15 new grants starting at $25,000 to help finance emerging arts districts and design projects that enhance public spaces, like parks, libraries, memorials and pedestrian bridges. “We want to make sure that citizens engage with the arts by having communities transform themselves through public spaces that have cultural activities," Mr. Landesman said in a speech. Interested cities need to submit their statement of interest by March 15. The guidelines and application materials are now available on the Endowment’s Web site, arts.gov.

The acclaimed London production of “The Pitmen Painters,” about a group of British miners who become artists, will transfer to the Broadway house of the Manhattan Theater Club in September, the theater company announced. The producer Bob Boyett had been aiming to mount the production on Broadway this spring but opted instead for an arrangement with the nonprofit Manhattan Theater Club to move the show to its 650-seat Samuel J. Friedman Theater. Mr. Boyett said the company had been courting him “in a big way” to do the show and that he had been unable to line up another Broadway house for a commercial run in time. Written by Lee Hall, who wrote the screenplay for the film “Billy Elliot” and the book and lyrics for the musical version now on Broadway, “The Pitmen Painters” had well-reviewed runs at Live Theater Newcastle and the National Theater in London, and it won the Evening Standard Award for best play in 2008. The original London cast, above, will perform in the Broadway production.
The principal foursome from the Chicago production of the musical “Million Dollar Quartet” will reprise their roles when it transfers to Broadway, the show’s producers said on Thursday.

A Brooklyn architecture firm has won the annual competition to transform the courtyard of the P.S. 1 Contemporary Art Center in Long Island City, Queens, this summer. The firm, Solid Objectives — Idenburg Liu, came up with an interconnected system of poles and bungee cords that is constantly altered by human action and environmental factors like rain and wind. (Above, a computer rendering of a street view.) “On discovery of its elasticity, visitors engage with the structure, to envision games, test its limits or just watch it gently dance,” the architects’ proposal said. The competition, the 11th Young Architects Program, is run jointly by P.S. 1 and the Museum of Modern Art. The winning firm’s principals, Florian Idenburg and Jing Liu, said they opened their office just two years ago and were grateful for the competition’s vote of confidence. “This is the perfect form for a young firm to test new ideas,” Ms. Liu said on Thursday. “It’s temporary and it’s an open pavilion, so there’s not much prescribed program except for natural elements like shade and cooling.”.

The producers of “Alfred Hitchcock’s The 39 Steps” announced that their stage comedy, adapted from the 1935 film, would reopen off Broadway at New World Stages on March 25. The play, in which all the characters of “The 39 Steps” are juggled by four rapidly moving actors, has already been in three theaters over the course of its New York run. It originated at the American Airlines Theater in 2008, then moved to the Cort Theater and the Helen Hayes Theater, where it played for the last time on Jan. 10.

Amy Winehouse, below, pleaded guilty to assaulting a theater manager at a Christmas pantomime show in central England, Reuters reported. She was given a two-year conditional discharge and ordered to pay about $140 in costs and about $160 in compensation to the manager, Richard Pound.

On Wednesday the Web started to percolate with word that the artist Banksy had hit the Sundance Film Festival. Yes, the graffiti art that popped up in Park City, Utah, over the last couple of days was his handiwork. But this time the art was just a sideshow to a film directed by Banksy, “Exit Through the Gift Shop,” a surprise addition to the festival lineup, which kicked off on Thursday. “Exit Through the Gift Shop,” scheduled to have its premiere on Sunday night, is about an eccentric French shopkeeper and amateur filmmaker who was so obsessed with Banksy that he wanted to make a documentary about him. But the British-born Banksy turned the tables and made a film about the effort to film him.

President Obama wants to cut down to size those too-big-to-fail banks. But his vow on Thursday to rewrite the rules of Wall Street left many questions unanswered, including the big one: Would this really prevent another financial crisis? The president's proposals to place new limits on the size and activities of big banks rattled the stock market, but banking executives were perplexed as to how his plan would work. Indeed, many insisted the proposals, if adopted, would do little to change their businesses.

LOHMAN--J. Frederic. Known to friends and family as Fritz, was born in Fort Wayne, IN in 1922. He graduated from Kenyon College in Gambier, OH and received his design training at Brown University and the Rhode Island School of Design. After college he went to California where he worked as a set designer for Paramount Pictures and, with the advent of television, with the Dumont Corporation in the same capacity. He then came to New York as assistant decorating department manager of James McCreary & Sons, and later became an associate director of The Bertha Schaefer Art Gallery. In 1951, he established his own interior design firm, J. Frederic Lohman, Ltd., at 451 East 58 Street. Throughout a hugely successful career Fritz lent his design talents to both residential and corporate interiors. Notable on his long list of achievements was Wedgewood House, The Forum (high-rise NYC apartment buildings), the lobbies of The Criterion and The Bergen Mall theaters, the model houses for Reston, VA (Model Community of the Future) near Washington, DC, and the administrative center for Global Foods. Apart from his virtually innumerable residential and corporate environments in New York City and across America, his residential interiors are to be found in London, Vienna, Montreal, Geneva, Jamaica and Lagos, Nigeria. He created settings for UniRoyal, Dupont, and the American Cyanamid Company, and designed several of "The Ten Best Dressed Rooms" at The National Design Center. His American Standard bathrooms and many other promotional settings were regularly seen in national magazines. His atelier catered to a prestigious clientele which included Barbara Walters and the late French couturier, Jacques Fath, among others. Some years before he retired from design, closing his offices in 1984, he and his life partner, Charles Leslie, who he met in 1968, had established a small real estate holding company to acquire and restore neglected SoHo industrial buildings and to convert them for artists' housing. This was in 1969, the same year they mounted their first exhibition of homoerotic art in their SoHo loft. The better part of the next ten years embroiled them in battles with the city to change the zoning in SoHo--The Planning Commission was initially opposed--and to obtain landmark status for The SoHo Cast Iron Historic District from the Landmarks Preservation Commission. Along with others, Fritz was crucially instrumental in achieving both goals. In the 1970s, the couple became involved in the theater, producing several off and off-off-Broadway shows which included "Naked Highway" by Matt Creeger, a spoof based on old movies such as "The Petrified Forest" and "Duel in the Sun", which had a good run at the 7th Ave Playhouse; "Men, Women & Why It Won't Work" by Miriam Fond; and, most notably, "Purification", the only blank verse drama by Tennessee Williams, which had never before been produced. Williams, who was in the audience, praised the production. Although he continued to do work for old friends and clients long after he officially retired, his last major undertaking before that time was the restorative design and complete redecoration of the grand ballroom, the gold room, the hunt room, and the study of the 110-room Vanderbilt mansion, Idle Hour, as Oakdale, Long Island. The mansion belongs to Dowling College and is used for public, administrative and ceremonial functions. Inveterate travelers, Fritz and Charles covered the globe more than once and spent great blocks of time in Asia, Africa and--particularly--in Europe and Morocco. Continuously active in their support of gay causes and organizations (SAGE, The Center, Lambda Legal Defense, etc.) they founded The Leslie/Lohman Gay Art Foundation in 1990 to encourage the creation of and to protect art that is perceived to be gay and therefore endangered by societal prejudice. Fritz took great joy in their large extended family and the three little goddaughters they are putting through school, and the big goddaughter who has her MFA and is pursuing a successful career as an artist. His life was also enriched by their three homes--their New York loft, their country house on the Eastern Shore of Maryland, and a beautiful, ancient Arab house in the medina of Marrakech in Morocco. Apart from Mr. Leslie, family survivors include five nephews, two nieces and their families. In lieu of other remembrances, it is asked that expressions of sympathy be sent to the Leslie/Lohman Gay Art Foundation (LLGAF) referencing the Fritz Lohman Museum Fund. As the co-founder of LLGAF, Fritz's name will now grace a new fund dedicated to the next significant growth phase--the establishment of The Leslie/Lohman Museum of Gay & Lesbian Art. Checks (payable to LLGAF) may be sent to: LLGAF, 26 Wooster Street, NY, NY 10013, Attn: Fritz Lohman Museum Fund.

The results of the Senate election Tuesday in Massachusetts have been widely interpreted as a sudden indictment of Democratic health care legislation. Yet a spate of recent national polls signal that little has changed over the last six months: Americans have remained divided over the proposals without significant shifts. Over all, most of the latest polls show more Americans oppose the health care changes being debated in Washington, but the most recent survey finds an even split.

STEIN--Ruth. World renowned psychoanalyst Ruth Stein died on January 17, 2010 of a massive stroke at age 62. Her family, friends, colleagues, patients and students in New York and Israel mourn her untimely death. Ruth's brilliance and creative contribution to the field were accompanied by an extraordinarily warm and loving presence. We will miss her.

Oksana Domnina and Maxim Shabalin of Russia are the reigning world ice dancing champions and favorites for the gold medal at next month's Winter Olympics. But their original dance, performed to an aboriginal theme, is generating anger in the middle of the Australian summer, with the aboriginal elder Sol Bellear calling the dance ''very offensive.'' ''We see it as stealing aboriginal culture, and it is yet another example of the aboriginal people of Australia being exploited,'' Bellear, of the New South Wales state Aboriginal Land Council, told Reuters on Thursday.

WERLE--Frederick, 86, of Purchase, NY and Lanesborough, MA died on January 18th. Mr. Werle grew up on the Upper East Side, graduated from Stuyvesant High School and at age 16 matriculated at NYU. After enlisting and serving in the 3084th Engineering Division of the U.S. Army in WWII, he returned home to manage the family property, The Amherst Hotel on Lexington Avenue, and complete his engineering degree. He enjoyed a long career in real estate starting at Helmsley-Spear and eventually, through his own firm, Oak Hill Realty. Mr. Werle was an aviator, sportsman and avid traveler. He is survived by his wife of 50 years, June, his son and daughter, Brett and Dawn, his son-in-law Tom and two grandchildren, Courtney and Kyle. Not too long ago, Meryl Davis and Charlie White were the up-and-coming ice dancing team who performed in the shadows of the veterans Tanith Belbin and Ben Agosto. But at the United States nationals in Spokane, Wash., they officially took center stage. Davis and White edged Belbin and Agosto -- the 2006 Olympic silver medalists -- by just 0.4 of a point to win the compulsory dance. They scored 45.42 points, an American record.

SHEFFIELD--Carolyn Blair, aged 99, died on January 13th at her Manhattan apartment. She was the great-granddaughter of Ezra Cornell, founder of the University in 1865. Her devoted and beloved husband, Frederick Sheffield, died in 1971. Known for her generous nature, she surrounded herself with loving friends and enjoyed conversations with everyone she met. A 1928 graduate of The Brearley School, she was a member of the Cosmopolitan Club. She is survived by her three children, James Rockwell Sheffield, Margaret Blair Sheffield, and Ann Cornell Sheffield, and four grandchildren, Jamie Sheffield, Sarah Sheffield, Mandy Roth, and Jon Roth, and two great-grandchildren. A Memorial Service will be held on Thursday, February 4th at 3pm at St. James Episcopal Church, Madison Avenue and 71st Street. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to The Brearley School, 610 East 83rd Street, New York City, NY, 10028.

HIMMELMAN--Helen, died peacefully in her sleep on January 20 at the age of 93 at The Osborn Retirement Home in Rye, New York. She was the beloved wife of the late Sol Himmelman, mother of Harold (Bonnie), grandmother of Ken, Liza, and Jeff, and great-grandmother of Sam, Lily, Kylie, Lukas, and Eve. She and her late husband were among the first group of residents of The Osborn, which treated them both with great, loving care. She was a highly skilled woman who served for many years as President of Northeast News Co. She was a volunteer for ten years at the Memorial Sloan-Kettering Hospital in New York City. She could count cards better than the best gamblers. In lieu of flowers, the family would appreciate any gifts of remembrance be sent to a charity of one's choosing in her memory.

She was a hug of a mom, a kind-hearted and gentle teacher, and a loyal friend with music in her heart, a roast in the oven, brownies in the freezer, a sweater on the knitting needles, and an ever-listening ear on the phone. The deeply adored wife of Stanley Preiser, she leaves her three devoted children, Yael Simckes, David Smiley and Sage Smiley, her stepdaughter Irene Aronoff, her loving sons- and daughter-in-law Dani Simckes, Marcus Melander and Lauren Kogod and her grandchildren, Keshet and Avia, Leah and Elliot, Isak, and Jacob. Andy Roddick fired an ace on the first point of his Australian Open match Friday against Feliciano López. It was an omen -- but it took the seventh-ranked Roddick four sets and more than three hours to make it a reality, winning his third-round match, 6-7 (4), 6-4, 6-4, 7-6 (3). What gave López's fans hope were his fluid strokes and bombshell serve (he hit a dozen aces in the first set alone). He broke Roddick's serve in the fifth game of that first set, fired three aces to avoid losing his own serve, and squeezed out a victory in the tie breaker.

The grand opening of Red Bull Arena will bring a storied Brazilian club, Santos, to Harrison, N.J., for an exhibition match on March 20. The Red Bulls will open the league portion of their schedule at their new stadium against Chicago on March 27. Santos has won 17 São Paulo state championships, including in 2006 and 2007. Perhaps its most famous player and export was Pelé. Red Bull Arena is across the Passaic River from the heavily Brazilian and Portuguese Ironbound section of Newark. redbull JACK BELL

ADAMS--Lorraine Ann Gladus, 77, died peacefully Monday, January 18, 2010 at her home in Mount Olive, New Jersey, after a long and brave fight with spinal cord disease. She was a true beauty with an unusual gift for empathy. Her family, friends and patients will always miss her vibrant intelligence and spirited sense of humor. Lorraine was born in William Penn, Pennsylvania to Ann (Novitsky) and Stanley Gladus on October 9, 1932. She was a 1950 graduate of Coaldale High School in Coaldale, Pennsylvania and received her B.A. degree in Spanish at Pennsylvania State University in 1954. She married Theodore Valentine Adams Jr. in 1956 and became a parent with the birth of her daughter, also named Lorraine, and her son Taylor. An extraordinary mother, she was devoted to their upbringing and education, sharing with them her love of theater, books and words. She spent most of her adult life in Summit, New Jersey, where her insightfulness and sensitivity led her to graduate school for training as a psychotherapist. Despite paralysis of her left arm in 1987, she was able to earn her master's degree in clinical social work at Rutgers University in 1989. She worked as a therapist at the former NEDAC Counseling Center in Verona, New Jersey (now COPE Center in Verona and Montclair, New Jersey) between 1990 and 2003. Her compassion for her patients and her enthusiasm for her work illuminated her life and theirs. She is survived by her husband, also of Mount Olive; her daughter, her son, her daughter-in-law Meredith Breitbarth and her beloved granddaughter Zoe Adams, all of Manhattan. Services are at 10:15am Saturday, January 23, 2010, at the David J. Stianche Funeral Home, 123 Center St., Jim Thorpe, Pennsylviania, 18229 (570)325-8322 or dgrs2@ptd.net, http://www.stianchefh.com followed by memorial mass at 11am at St. Katharine Drexel Catholic Church, (the former St. Michael's), 124 E. Abbott St., Lansford, Pennsylvania, 18232, (570)645-2282 with burial afterwards in Sky-View Memorial Park, 108 Lafayette Ave., Tamaqua, Pennsylvania 18252. Visit Friday, 6-8pm in the funeral home; and again Saturday, 9:30am until the time of services.

When Lady Gaga finished her thumping, strobing, razzle-dazzle song-and-dance numbers at Radio City Music Hall on Wednesday night, she held her pose and kept the stage lights on, delighting her many camera-wielding fans. Her Monster Ball tour always provided something worth a snapshot: a sci-fi tableau, perhaps, or a skimpy, glittery costume. The more her image gets around, the better Lady Gaga does. ''Take my picture!'' she urged the audience, in her first of four sold-out shows at Radio City. ''I want to be a star.'' She is. A combination of well-planned outlandishness, media exposure and catchy, stuttering choruses -- ''pa-pa-pa-pa-paparazzi,'' ''p-p-p-poker face'' -- has made Lady Gaga a multimillion-selling, Grammy-nominated star in less than a year and a half since the 2008 release of her debut album, ''The Fame'' (Streamline/Konlive/Cherrytree/Interscope). Stefani Joanne Angelina Germanotta, a k a Lady Gaga, sings, writes, dresses and apparently exists to toy with celebrity as performance art, seeing how freaky (in a fascinating way) she can be as she reaches a mass audience.

SOYBEL--Thomas, a lawyer and author of children's verse, died on January 16th, in Boston, MA. He was 52 years old. Born at Lenox Hill Hospital and raised on West End Avenue, Mr. Soybel believed that only Zabar's sold real coffee and only the Hudson was an important river. He graduated from the Rudolf Steiner School in 1975 and earned his B.A. at Williams College and his J.D. at Boston University. After serving as an Assistant District Attorney in Manhattan, he worked at Proskauer, Rose, Goetz, and Mendelbaum, and as an attorney for Dartmouth College in Hanover, NH. His illness required that he retire in 1994. His children's book, The Diner on the Wall, illustrated by Pam DeVito, was published by Windswept House the following year, and he continued to write whimsical poetry for his friends and family. He is survived by his wife, Virginia Earll Soybel, and their daughter, Anna, both of Boston, his parents, Renate and Arthur Soybel, and his sister, Carol Ann (Soybel) Bartges, of New York City, and his nieces and nephew. J. S. Waterman & Sons & Waring Wellesley 781-235-4110 www.jswaterman.com

If Manager Billy Davies takes his club to the Premier League, Forest fans will do more than make him the sheriff of Nottingham by proclamation -- he will be the new earl of England's East Midlands. ''The great thing is that I've got experience getting a Championship club into the E.P.L. before it was ready,'' Davies, a 45-year-old Scotsman, said in a telephone interview from Nottingham, referring to his previous job at nearby Derby County. ''And I've said the same thing to the Forest people. We're a good young side that is making strides and has potential. But it is too early for this team and the infrastructure. I have been in this position before and then found myself out of a job. I don't want déjà vu!''

Justine Henin and Carlos Rodriguez have been together since she was 14. She was a wunderkind then, and he was her coach. Both have a bit of age on them now, but all you had to do was watch Henin search the grandstand for him after each hard-fought point to see not much has changed. They do not merely exchange glances; they mind-meld. Each had plenty to think about Friday when Henin's comeback and Australian Open was almost ended after Alisa Kleybanova, the No. 27 seed, dropped her in the first set, 6-3. But Rodriguez knew his player would not quit -- and she did not, battling back to a 3-6, 6-4, 6-2 victory.

In hindsight, it should probably come as little surprise to Democrats that voters in Massachusetts, a state with universal access to health insurance, would not feel all that motivated to rescue President Obama's efforts to provide similar benefits nationwide. Massachusetts has the lowest proportion of uninsured residents of any state in the nation -- just 5.2 percent, according to the Kaiser Family Foundation -- thanks to the state's 2006 universal health care law, which the winner in Tuesday's special election, Scott Brown, supported as a Republican state senator and which was signed by Gov. Mitt Romney, also a Republican.
