Former Senator John Edwards admitted on Thursday that he fathered a daughter with a campaign videographer with whom he had an extramarital affair during his presidential campaign. ''I am Quinn's father,'' Mr. Edwards said bluntly in a statement released to the news media, confirming what his wife, Elizabeth, his children, close friends, former staff members and the general public already knew or suspected.

The United States will provide a dozen unarmed aerial spy drones to Pakistan for the first time as part of an effort to encourage Pakistan's cooperation in fighting Islamic militants on the Afghanistan border, American defense officials said Thursday. But Pakistani military leaders, rebuffing American pressure, said they planned no new offensives for at least six months. The Shadow drones, which are smaller than armed Predator drones, will be a significant upgrade in the Pakistanis' reconnaissance and surveillance ability and will supply video to help cue strikes from the ground or the air.

Robert F. McDonnell, the newly sworn-in governor of Virginia, will deliver the Republican response to President Obama's first State of the Union address Wednesday. Mr. McDonnell was a Republican star in 2009, as the party bounced back to capture the governors' mansions in both Virginia and New Jersey after disastrous elections in 2006 and 2008. He was sworn in on Saturday.

"If you are in the market for a 14,000-pound, 6-foot-tall urn carved from a block of pink Tennessee marble and encircled by a neo-Classical frieze of Indians hunting buffalo and engaging in intertribal warfare, hurry over to the 56th-annual Winter Antiques Show," writes Ken Johnson, "before someone else snaps it up." The object is on view at Gerald Peters, one of 75 art and antiques dealers gathered to "dazzling effect" under the "capacious roof" of the drill hall at the Park Avenue Armory on view daily through Jan. 31. Go to marvel at items like a complete Egyptian sarcophagus, Tiffany lamps, Cubist flappers, and others displayed in booths that are constructed to resemble tony antique shops and even a room in an 18th-century Bostonian home. The show covers a "practically encyclopedic range of art, decorative objects, furniture, tribal arts and crafts," with "dealers in ancient art, medieval suits of armor, Art Nouveau, American folk art and Modernist design." The cutoff for the newest material is 1969. The oldest objects date back thousands of years.

The cartoonist Garry Trudeau will help us try to get a handle on the ongoing wars in Afghanistan and Iraq tonight at the 92nd Street Y. The "Doonesbury" creator will be part of a round-table discussion with David Stanford, who with Mr. Trudeau, publishes Trudeau's Sandbox, a blog by Iraq soldiers and veterans, as well as the photographer David Levinthal. The discussion, which will be moderated by Time magazine editor and writer Roger Rosenblatt, will examine the conflicts as they are seen through cartoons, blogs, photography and traditional journalism.

The Bay Area has long been known as a center for documentary filmmaking. In her latest column, Chloe Veltman says that while the success of locally produced documentaries can be attributed to education, funding and community, it ultimately comes down to storytelling.

My Sunday column is about the Salwen family of Atlanta, and how they sold their house and used half the money to fund poverty-fighting projects in Ghana. To me, the most striking thing about their story and book was how the project empowered not only the Ghanaians but also the Salwens. And I see that all the time: Somebody reluctantly takes on some good cause, thinking that it's the right thing to do even if they're way too busy, and then the cause turns out not to be a sacrifice but the best thing they've done.

In today's New York Times, Walt Bogdanich reports on the devastating consequences of medical mistakes related to radiation treatment. He tells the story of several patients who believed they were undergoing lifesaving treatment but instead were hit with lethal doses of radiation. He writes:
Radiation accidents like those that injured Scott Jerome-Parks and Alexandra Jn-Charles don't have to be made public under New York state law, leaving many unaware of treatment risks.

In his 10th N.F.L. season, at an age when most running backs have started, or finished, a sharp decline, Thomas Jones posted career numbers with the Jets. This follows his usual unusual pattern. Drafted seventh over all by Arizona in 2000, Jones has played for four teams and reached the Super Bowl with Chicago in the 2006 season. Yet he was voted to his first Pro Bowl last season and he gained a career-high 1,402 rushing yards this season. But there is more to the 31-year-old Jones. He is the Jets' unquestioned leader and pregame speaker. He runs a music production company, Outta Pocket Entertainment. And he enjoys watching old television sitcoms.

I'm reading and thoroughly enjoying Andre Agassi's autobiography, "Open." At the moment I'm only 67 pages into it, but I'm really struck most by one thing: Although I read a couple of reviews of this book, my recollection of the reviews was that the big deal with this Agassi story was that he admits to taking drugs during his tennis career. For me, that's a thoroughly uninteresting point compared to the extraordinary story of how his father worked him as a child and gave him no choice in life as to what he would do. He would be world champion, No. 1, tennis player. No choice, any disagreement about that and you're punished, kid. And coupled with this treatment by the father - which even more miraculously actually succeeded - Andre talks about how much he hated tennis as a child, and in the first chapter of the book while fighting through his last United States Open, his hate for the game then too!

SMITH--Ruth Proskauer, a reproductive-rights and choice-in-dying advocate who helped found NARAL, died January 22 at the age of 102. She died peacefully at home surrounded by family, exactly the sort of death for which she had advocated for decades. She was a field worker and executive secretary of the Planned Parenthood League of Massachusetts (1946-1953). She was a cofounder of NARAL in 1969. She helped draft the Cook-Leichter Act of 1970, establishing abortion as a woman's legal choice in NY State. A board member and officer of the Euthanasia Society of America and the Society for the Right to Die, and a major supporter of Compassion & Choices, she was a lifelong advocate for terminally ill patients' right to choose a "good death." She organized a long-running seminar on the Supreme Court at Quest, a group that offers classes taught for and by retired professionals. The daughter of Joseph M. and Alice Naumburg Proskauer, she was born in Deal, New Jersey, on August 14, 1907. She is survived by two children, Anthony R. Smith and Gael S. Arnold, six grandchildren, and seven great-grandchildren. There will be no funeral. Family and friends will be notified of a celebration of her life and legacy. In lieu of flowers, please support Compassion & Choices or NARAL Pro-Choice NY.

A collision with a large bird forced a United Airlines plane to return to Dulles International Airport in northern Virginia, the Federal Aviation Administration said. The plane, a Boeing 757-200 bound for San Francisco, sucked the bird into its right engine shortly after takeoff around 4:30 p.m., an F.A.A. spokeswoman said. She said that the pilot had quickly returned the plane to the airport and that it landed safely.

SCHWARTZ--Ethel Wiesenthal, of Boynton Beach, Florida and previously of Kew Gardens Hills, New York on January 22, 2010. Beloved wife of the late Melvin, loving mother of Helene and Howard, Barry and Marian and the late Gale. Devoted grandmother of Fred and Vivian, Seth and Mina, Richard and Rena and Ingrid and Paul. Proud Great-Grandmother of Matthew and Sarah, Benjamin and Sabina, Jesse and Gillian and Alana and Benjamin. A former president of the Sisterhood of the Jewish Center of Kew Gardens Hills, President of the North Shore Long Island Branch of Women's League for Conservative Judaism, National Vice President of Women's League and Chairman of its National Social Action Committee. She was also a Scholarship Patron and long time supporter of the Jewish Theological Seminary and a recipient of its Binah Award. Her family celebrates her rich and meaningful life and mourn her passing. Services will be held at Schwartz Brothers-Jeffer Memorial Chapels, 114-03 Queens Blvd. (at 76th Rd.), Forest Hills, NY 11375 at 10:00am on Sunday, January 24.

The two biggest secular coalitions were hit hardest by this month's decision to bar about 500 candidates from parliamentary elections in March, a top election official said Thursday, as efforts to resolve what has become a political crisis intensified. Critics have warned that the disqualifications, made on the grounds that the candidates promoted the Baath Party of former President Saddam Hussein, could damage the credibility of the March 7 vote, which is crucial to American plans to withdraw.

MELNICK--Barbara A.,nee Ruda. We mourn the passing of our beloved wife, mother, mother-in-law, grandmother and stepmother, Barbara. SHERRILL--H. Virgil. The Boards of Overseers and Managers and the staff of Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center note with sorrow the death of H. Virgil Sherrill, who served with great distinction as a member of MSKCC's Boards from 1969 until his retirement in 2008. His contributions to this institution were far-reaching and long-lasting. From 1978 until 2000, Mr. Sherrill was Chairman of Memorial Hospital's Board of Managers and Vice Chairman of MSKCC's Boards of Overseers and Managers. He served on several finance and planning committees, where his expertise in investment banking and his leadership skills played a part in helping the institution achieve its position as a preeminent cancer center. At the time of his death, he was Honorary Chairman of the Hospital's Board of Managers and a Member Emeritus of MSKCC's Board of Overseers. A steadfast supporter of biomedical research and the promise it holds for improving cancer care, Mr. Sherrill also served on the Sloan-Kettering Institute's Board of Managers from 1978 until 2005. Patients with cancer and their families, and members of the cancer research and MSKCC communities will be forever grateful for his generous philanthropic support, his guidance, and his wisdom. We extend our sincere condolences to his wife, Betty; his son, Stephen (a member of MSKCC's Boards); his daughter, Ann Sherrill Pyne; and his grandchildren. James D. Robinson III Honorary Chairman Douglas A. Warner III Chairman Richard I. Beattie Vice Chairman Louis V. Gerstner, Jr. Vice Chairman Harold Varmus, MD President Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center

New York is a city of blocks, each with its own history, customs and characters. Yet from these small stages spring large talents. Anyone who doubts that need look no further than a stretch of Edgecombe Avenue perched on a bluff near 155th Street. It was part of Sugar Hill, the neighborhood of choice for elegant black musicians, dapper actors, successful professionals -- and those who aspired to be like them.

(Showtime) TWILIGHT (2008) Kristen Stewart (right, with Robert Pattinson) is Bella Swan, the new girl in a small Washington town who falls, body and soul, for Edward Cullen (Mr. Pattinson), a vampire with all sorts of superhuman powers -- but who somehow manages to keep his fangs in his mouth. Catherine Hardwicke directed this unorthodox romance, based on the novel by Stephenie Meyer and a script by Melissa Rosenberg. Peter Facinelli assumes a ghostly pallor as Carlisle, Edward's doctor father and the head of a picture-pretty, well-behaved clan (played by Ashley Greene, Nikki Reed, Jackson Rathbone and Kellan Lutz) that, but for occasional hunting sprees, likes to think of itself as, uh, vegetarian. Manohla Dargis, writing in The New York Times, called the film ''a deeply sincere, outright goofy vampire romance for the hot-not-to-trot abstinence set.'' 10:30 A.M. LURIE--Walter A.,on January 16, 2010, at 97. Much loved father of Ruth Lurie Kozodoy and the late Michael Rubinow Lurie; husband of the late Olga Rubinow Lurie; grandfather of Sarah K. Penso, Peter Kozodoy (and Moria Paz), and Elizabeth Kozodoy; great-grandfather of Avraham and Eli. A social psychologist and an insightful, generous-spirited man, Dr. Lurie was Director of Program Analysis, National Jewish Community Relations Advisory Council, 1946-80; Director, Large City Budgeting Conference (Council of Jewish Federations), 1956-68; President, Conference of Jewish Communal Service. Memorial gathering Sunday, 2pm, Zion Memorial Chapel, 785 E. Boston Post Rd., Mamaroneck. Donations may be sent to UJA/Federation of New York or the Mamaroneck Public Library.

Robben W. Fleming, who as president of the University of Michigan in the late 1960s and '70s steered it through a turbulent era of student protests, using his labor negotiator's skills to help defuse crises before they could turn violent, died Jan. 11 in Ann Arbor, Mich. He was 93. His son, James, confirmed the death. His father's health had been failing for some time, he said.

When Dr. Thomas L. Petty started his research into severe chronic lung disease in the mid-1960s, oxygen therapy was generally administered in hospitals and typically for only a short time. Lung disease experts believed that providing oxygen to pulmonary patients for extended periods would cause a buildup of carbon dioxide in their bloodstreams, making them sicker. But through clinical experiments, Dr. Petty, a pulmonologist, helped demonstrate that providing supplemental oxygen outside the hospital to patients with severe disease improved their energy levels and extended their lives.

The McDonald's Corporation said Friday that its fourth-quarter earnings and revenue topped analysts' estimates as global sales rose at its established stores. Sales at stores open at least 13 months grew 2.3 percent, rising in every region in both the quarter and in December, helped by a mix of discounted prices and new products, longer operating hours and remodeled restaurants. Net income in the fourth quarter climbed 23 percent, to $1.22 billion, or $1.11 a share, from $985.3 million, or 87 cents a share, a year earlier, the company said. Sales rose 7.3 percent, to $5.97 billion. Excluding one-time items, the company earned $1.03 a share. The results topped the $1.02 a share in income and $5.94 billion in sales that analysts had expected. Shares of McDonald's, which is based in Oak Brook, Ill., rose 19 cents, to $63.39.

SHERRILL--H. Virgil. The Trustees, Women's Board, staff and alumni of The Boys' Club of New York express their deepest sympathy to his wife, Betty Sherrill and the family of our dear friend, H. Virgil Sherrill, who passed away on January 20, 2010. Elected to the Board of Trustees in 1966. Virgil was a Board member of 44 years. He served on many BCNY Committees, including the Jefferson Park Clubhouse Committee, the Pitt Street Fundraising Committee, Ways and Means Committee, Nominating Committee and the Sports Dinner Committee. His passionate dedication and support of our boys were extraordinary. We will miss him greatly. The Boys' Club of New York

An article on Jan. 10 about the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences’ lack of recognition for Doris Day referred incorrectly to the Academy’s recognition of Orson Welles, and a correction in this space last Sunday, based on the article, also referred incorrectly to the Academy’s recognition of Charlie Chaplin. Welles did in fact win an Oscar for a specific category, for best screenplay for “Citizen Kane” (1941), and Chaplin won in a specific category, for best original dramatic score in “Limelight.” (The score written with Raymond Rasch and Larry Russell.) It is not the case that Welles and Chaplin “inexplicably never won the prize in competition.” (Welles received an honorary Oscar in 1971, and Chaplin received honorary Oscars in 1929 and 1972.).

The minarets, as pointed out, resemble missiles, and I would argue that the message conveyed isn’t that Sharia law is the next step, but that Switzerland will become a war zone. IF you were to choose one article of clothing to represent Laura Linney, it would have to be the little black dress. Simple, elegant, appropriate for any occasion. Add a white pilgrim's bonnet and a long apron, and Ms. Linney is transformed into the nobly suffering Elizabeth Proctor in Arthur Miller's ''Crucible.'' Dress it up with pearls, a slash of red lipstick and Manolos, and she is a high-strung Upper East Side wife in the 2007 film ''The Nanny Diaries.'' Include a scarf, a camera bag and a crutch, and she becomes Sarah Goodwin, the recuperating war photographer in Donald Margulies's new play ''Time Stands Still,'' opening on Broadway Thursday at the Manhattan Theater Club's Samuel J. Friedman Theater. Even Ms. Linney's pale scrubbed face, with nearly invisible blond eyebrows and eyelashes, invites one to draw in expressions, as if she has paint-by-numbers features. That shape-shifting quality, along with a puritan's work ethic, enables her to inhabit varied roles with the steadfastness of a rent-control tenant and has frequently brought rapturous reviews. Ben Brantley in The New York Times has called her ''an actress of peerless emotional transparency, capable of conveying a multitude of conflicting feelings through minimal means.''

THERE are many interesting auto logo stories, including Cadillac's recent discarding of its heraldic ducks for a new version of its shield and crest. And BMW recently cleared up the history of its logo, saying that it's based on the Bavarian flag, not a spinning propeller. But perhaps the most intriguing story is that of the Ford logo designed by the heavyweight champion of logo designers, Paul Rand, who did those of I.B.M., ABC, Westinghouse, U.P.S. -- and Enron. In 1966, Rand was hired by Henry Ford II to rethink and modernize the familiar scripted oval Ford logo.

THOMAS DOZOL, a photographer whose work has appeared in French Vogue and Interview, spent three years shooting people in their bathrooms -- stripped down and soaking wet, their skin flushed from long, hot showers. The intention was to remove the artifice of portraiture and lay bare the humanity of his subjects, who include Gwyneth Paltrow, the photographer Wolfgang Tillmans and the model Jamie Bochert (left). ''I wanted to grasp something fragile and raw,'' Mr. Dozol said. ''I wanted them in their most relaxed state.'' Which is not to say there weren't moments of extreme awkwardness. ''It definitely tested my level of comfort with nudity,'' he said. ''Even with people I knew, it was like, 'Hello!' ''

BERRY--William Augustus: September 29, 1933, Jacksonville, TX - January 3, 2010, Columbia, MO. Artist, author, illustrator, Professor Berry's work was shown in 500 exhibits, awarded over 120 prizes. Innovative drawing, luminous color and unusual compositions earned invitations to artists' colonies: Altos de Chavon, Dominican Republic; Montalvo Center for Arts; MacDowell Colony; Lacoste School of Arts, France; Camargo Foundation, France; Rockefeller Foundation, Italy. Collections include: Boston Museum of Fine Arts, Addison Gallery; Stedman Gallery, Rutgers; Muscarelle Museum of Art; Glenn Lowry, Craig Lucas, Helen Hayes and Wanda Landowska. His book Drawing the Human Form (1977, 1994), cited as "excellent" by Ernst Gombrich, remains a classic text. In the 1960s, Berry's illustrations appeared in: Newsweek, Esquire, The New Leader, The Reporter, Harper's, John Hopkins, Holiday, Mid-East, Opera News, The NY Times, Sports Illustrated, TV Guide; and books: Kennedy Without Tears, Tom Wicker; Still Quiet on the Western Front, Gene Smith; On Firm Ice, Carter Wilson; and A Journey to the Arctic, Knud Rasmussen. He was the first Art Director of Texas Monthly and designer/consultant for art books, WS Benson Co. Trained at UT Austin (BFA), and USC (MFA) he taught at UT, Boston University, and University of Missouri-Columbia, where he was Director of Graduate Studies, Department Chair, and Curators' Professor of Art. Mr. Berry, son of William Lafayette Berry and Esther Cory, leaves his wife, Janet; sister, Dixie; nieces: Gay Lynn Sneed; Jaye Lynn Boyack; Faye Lynn Quast; and many friends and students who revered and loved him. Checks may be made to UMC Dept. of Art, memo FBO Rollins Scholarship/Memory Wm Berry. Send to: Univ. of Missouri, A126 Fine Arts Bldg. Columbia, MO 65211.

Sometimes, love is not all you need. In fact, it can be downright dangerous. Love abounds in the family depicted in Darci Picoult's new play, ''Lil's 90th''; but the Eldridges are in big, big trouble anyway. The problem is Charlie, the family patriarch: affectionate, generous, proud and, alas, increasingly addled. His wife, Lil, his daughter, Stephanie, and his grandson, Tommy, should be busy spreading the safety net. But they are blinded by their love and too caught up in their own concerns to be watching out for him. Their kindly indulgence and inattention abet his mischief until it is too late to undo the damage.

NOT too long ago, a magazine in Manhattan invited me, by e-mail, to interview for a job. After meeting with me, the managing editor and the director of human resources asked me to take home the standard editing test and return it ASAP. I dutifully obliged. And then I waited. One day. Two days. A week. A month. Two months. Three ... well, you get the picture.

SHEFFIELD--Carolyn Blair, aged 99, died on January 13th at her Manhattan apartment. She was the great-granddaughter of Ezra Cornell, founder of the University in 1865. Her devoted and beloved husband, Frederick Sheffield, died in 1971. Known for her generous nature, she surrounded herself with loving friends and enjoyed conversations with everyone she met. A 1928 graduate of The Brearley School, she was a member of the Cosmopolitan Club. She is survived by her three children, James Rockwell Sheffield, Margaret Blair Sheffield, and Ann Cornell Sheffield, and four grandchildren, Jamie Sheffield, Sarah Sheffield, Mandy Roth, and Jon Roth, and two great-grandchildren. A Memorial Service will be held on Thursday, February 4th at 3pm at St. James Episcopal Church, Madison Avenue and 71st Street. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to The Brearley School, 610 East 83rd Street, New York City, NY, 10028.

He looked like some sort of fur trapper, this bearded man walking through the snowy woods here in upstate New York. But then, Frank Serpico has always been known for his disguises. Anyone who has seen the celebrated 1973 film ''Serpico'' knows that he often dressed up -- bum, butcher, rabbi -- to catch criminals. His off-duty look was never vintage cop either, with the bushy beard and the beads.

SMITH--Ruth Proskauer. NARAL Pro-Choice New York mourns the loss of Ruth Proskauer Smith, a founding hero of the reproductive rights movement. Her remarkable history on behalf of reproductive freedom spans back to the 1940's, when she began speaking out to gain women access to birth control. She co-founded NARAL in 1969 with the goal of litigating state abortion prohibitions, a life mission that led us to the steps of the United States Supreme Court and Roe v. Wade. Her commitment, leadership and courage will be deeply missed. We send our heartfelt condolences to her family and all those who were touched by her legacy.

With vacationers still wary about spending money in 2010, tour operators are offering travel packages that scale back on amenities like guides, while rebranding them as more flexible and independent-minded. Trafalgar, a tour company based in London, is offering a CostSaver program for Europe (trafalgar.com/costsaver) that gives travelers more free time to explore on their own. While drivers and local guides are still part of the deal, the 36 tours include some sightseeing without any escorts. Daily rates start at $86 a person for eight-day City Breaks in Paris, London, Amsterdam and Rome.

COOPER--Jean Thompson, 79, of Southold, NY, died suddenly in St. Thomas, USVI, on January 18, 2010. She was a dedicated Cornell University alumna, a nationally recognized tapestry rug hooking artist and teacher, the owner and director of the Long Island Rug School, and a fearless fundraiser for Eastern Long Island Hospital. She is survived by Peter, her husband of 56 years, and her daughters Beth Kubinec (John) of Lancaster, PA and Susan Hodge Withers (Timothy) of East Greenwich, RI as well as her sisters Lois Anderson of Southold, NY and Judith Collins (David) of Lake Tahoe, NV, and numerous grandchildren.

GAMBINI--William, 92, died on January 3, 2010 in San Diego, CA after a long productive lifetime as an artist. Born in the Brownsville section of Brooklyn, Bill served with the U.S. Army Corps of Engineers and participated in the invasion at Normandy. Bill graduated C.C.N.Y., studied at the Brooklyn Museum Fine Arts School, Esmeralda Fine Arts School in Mexico City, and the Art Students League (where he subsequently taught). He was part of the New York school of abstract expressionism in the late 40s and 50s, involved in the Tenth Street Co-Op Gallery with deKooning, Kline, Rothko, Pollock, and others. In addition to one-man exhibitions, he had major group exhibitions at the Whitney Annual, Museum of Modern Art, Guggenheim Museum, Brooklyn Museum and Houston Museum. Bill is survived by his wife of 52 years, Peggy, his two children, Elizabeth and Vittorio, and four grandchildren: Tiffany, Tony, Dominick and Justin. A retrospective of Bill's work will be held on March 27th at the Borrelli Design building in San Diego. Tom, Diahn & Courtney McGrath

George Brown, 50, the owner of Arthur's barber shop on the Oval in this picturesque New England town, said he ''breathed a sigh of relief'' when Scott Brown was elected to the Senate last week in neighboring Massachusetts. To Mr. Brown, who is not related to the new senator, the election meant the welcome death of the Democratic health care legislation in Washington.

To the editor: Great new, enticing picks in ''The 31 Places to Go in 2010'' (Jan. 10) to whet the appetite for unusual travel. However, as a many-time traveler to Antarctica since the early 1980s, the statements suggesting that tourist travel has been only recent belie the facts. While 2010 may be a good year to go, ships complying with new standards at a later date will continue to make this continent the ultimate destination for those who have a love of unsurpassed natural beauty. Joan Larsen Park Forest, Ill.

In the two weeks since the earthquake struck Haiti, the devastation has been chronicled not just by journalists and news photographers, but also by novelists, bloggers and visual artists. The Op-Ed editors asked four painters, two in Haiti, two in the Haitian diaspora, to create works that reflect on the disaster and its aftermath.

To the Sports Editor: Re ''Admission Doesn't Guarantee Entry,'' Jan. 17: I was depressed by the opinion of Bruce Jenkins of The San Francisco Chronicle that ''cheating is a way of life in baseball.'' I grew up believing that sports were to be played hard but played fairly, and that although cheating existed, it was not acceptable in a contest where the object was to pit your best skills against your opponent's and take the outcome honorably.

KJOLBYE-BIDDLE--Birthe, archaeologist, aged 68 at Sobell House, Oxford, January 16, 2010, surrounded by her family, after a courageous two-year fight against ovarian cancer. Beloved wife and collaborator of Martin Biddle, mother of Signe and Solvej, grandmother of Andrea-Anna, James, Constance, and Melody. Funeral service in Winchester Cathedral on Thursday, January 28th at 1pm. Family flowers only, but donations, if wished, to Sobell House Hospice Charity (The Ward) or to Ovarian Cancer Action c/o Richard Steel and Partners, Alderman House, 12-14 City Road, Winchester, Hampshire, England SO23 8SG.

To the Sports Editor: Re ''For Edwards, Jets Epitomize Commitment to Winning,'' Jan. 19: Braylon Edwards said he was suffocated by the losing culture surrounding his former team, the Cleveland Browns. We Browns fans know, however, that it was Edwards who was holding the pillow over our faces.

YELLEN--John J.,Jr. September 25, 2009, in New York City. Loving husband of Paula Yellen; father of Cat Rebennack and Amy Yellen-Shaw; father-in-law of Malcolm Rebennack and Carl Shaw; grandfather of Sarah and Emma Shaw. Favorite human of Lizzy.

Bullet by bullet, workers removed the detritus of Cambodia's past. They pulled 300 land mines and 30,000 rounds of ammunition from the red dirt and then laid down a thick layer of asphalt. Today, what would pass for a very ordinary road in wealthier parts of the world is precious pavement for a country motoring toward prosperity and trying to leave its bloody past behind.

WEINREB--Steven, M.D.,died January 16, 2010 of Multiple Sclerosis at age 59. He was a medical doctor, college professor and linguist. We miss his intellect and loving care.

Behind the end zones at the University of South Carolina, red tip hedges grow against the stands at Williams-Brice Stadium, perilously close to the field of play. Whenever a Gamecocks receiver pulls up short of the hedges while pursuing a pass, Coach Steve Spurrier evokes the name of Sidney Rice, the one player who never did. ''I tell our guys, 'Sidney would go into those hedges to catch it, and you guys give up 3 yards from the out of bounds,' '' Spurrier said in a telephone interview last week.

The Sky Watch chart in some editions last Sunday mislabeled a line across the center of the map. It is the ecliptic, showing the apparent path of the sun -- not the celestial equator.

ErSELCUK--Dr. Muzaffer Mehmet, a retired professor of economics at Purdue University and airline executive, died peacefully at home in his Manhattan townhouse on January 17, 2010. He was 93. During his tenure as professor of Economics and Industrial Development at Purdue in Lafayette, Indiana he became involved in the aviation industry and was instrumental in the formation of Lake Central Airline, the first employee owned airline. Through a series of airline mergers, Lake Central later became a part of US Airways. While at Purdue, Dr. ErSelcuk was awarded a Fulbright Scholarship, which took him to Burma where he founded the school of business for the University of Mandalay. In 1969, after teaching nearly thirty years at Purdue, he joins Trans World Airlines as Director of Marketing and Development, setting up the airline's first General Sales Agencies around the world, and innovative concept at that time. While at TWA, he served two terms as Chairman of the Finance Panel for the Military Airlift Command. After retiring from TWA in 1982, he continued to serve as advisor to foreign governments, oil companies, and airlines. In 1986, Dr. ErSelcuk set up and funded the Yemen Education Fund, which he provided over 60 scholarships to Middle Eastern students for study in the United States, primarily at Purdue University. Dr. ErSelcuk was born in Istanbul, Turkey. After earning an A.B. at Robert College of Istanbul, in 1938, he received his M.A and Ph.D. degrees at Indiana University, graduating in 1945. He is survived by his wife, Gail Lois ErSelcuk, of Lafayette, Indiana; five children: Safika ErSelcuk of Los Angeles, California; Omer ErSelcuk of St. Croix, USVI; Ayse ErSelcuk of San Francisco, California; Emine ErSelcuk of San Francisco, California; Leyla ErSelcuk of Los Angeles, California; and two grandchildren: Jackson Sweeney of Los Angeles, California; Sophia ErSelcuk of St. Croix, USVI. A memorial service will be held at the Frank E. Campbell chapel, 1076 Madison Avenue, New York, NY on Friday, January 29, 2010 at 4:00pm (212-288-3500). In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Haiti Relief Fund at www.redcross.org.
Shareholders Suggest Minimum Sale Prices

PETER PHILIPS, Chanel's global creative director for makeup, has a way of turning out oddly elegant nail polishes that cause feeding frenzies when released. His latest? Particulière, a mauve-y mushroom color that made its debut on Chanel's spring runway and instantly sold out on its Web site late last month. (It has just been restocked.) Much of its appeal stems from its wearability. Unlike Jade, Chanel's pistachio-colored earlier offering, Particulière strikes that perfect balance of being a little punk while remaining relatively subtle. ''It stands out without being a screaming color,'' Mr. Philips said. ''And it gives your fingertips a touch of class.'' For a similar look, for about a third of the price, try Chinchilly by Essie.

Single women of a certain age, rest easy: after being dropped by Carnival Cruise Lines, the Second International Cougar Cruise has found a new host. The event, touring the Mexican Riviera May 16 to 23, is sponsored by the Singles Travel Company (singlestravelcompany.com) and the Society of Single Professionals, which have reserved 98 spots on Royal Caribbean's Mariner of the Seas, above. Earlier this month, a Carnival spokeswoman told USA Today that the line was dropping the Cougar Cruise, after hosting the first one in December, though no reason was given.

SICHEL--Walter, of So. Orange, NJ. Beloved husband of Nancy, devoted father of Susan Berger and John Sichel, adored grandfather. Funeral at "Bernheim-Apter-Kreitzman", 68 Old Short Hills Rd., Livingston, NJ on Monday at 1pm. Please call 1-800-938-6372 for additional information.

If luck is the battlefield's final arbiter -- the wild card that can trump fitness, training, teamwork, equipment, character and skill -- then Lance Cpl. Ryan T. Mathison experienced its purest and most welcome form. On a Marine foot patrol here through the predawn chill of Friday morning, he stepped on a pressure-plate rigged to roughly 25 pounds of explosives. The device, enough to destroy a pickup truck or tear apart several men, was buried beneath him in the dusty soil.

Although Notre Dame's Luke Harangody was picked as the preseason Big East player of the year, Villanova's Scottie Reynolds is certainly making a case during the regular season. After leading the Wildcats to the Final Four last year, Reynolds contemplated leaving for the N.B.A. before deciding to return for his senior season. With No. 1 Villanova now 18-1, and 7-0 in the Big East, after Saturday's 81-71 win against St. John's at Madison Square Garden -- and Reynolds averaging 18.7 points a game -- there seems to be no reason for him to regret the decision.

Film Ronald Bronstein wrote and directed the 2007 critics' darling ''Frownland,'' which Manohla Dargis of The New York Times called ''an up-close, painfully intimate portrait of a hapless, manipulative schlub, a Loser with a capital L.'' In ''DADDY LONGLEGS,'' directed by the 20-something New York indie filmmakers and Cannes darlings Benny and Josh Safdie, Mr. Bronstein stars as a hapless, manipulative, divorced father named Lenny, who is both loving and (literally) criminally irresponsible when it comes to his two young sons. The boys are played by Sage and Frey Ranaldo, sons of the Sonic Youth guitarist Lee Ranaldo, who appears as the boys' stepfather. Thursday at 7 p.m., Rose Cinemas, Brooklyn Academy of Music 30 Lafayette Avenue, at Ashland Place, Fort Greene, bam.org; $15. Also available with the Sundance Selects video-on-demand service.

FREED--Daniel. The last of a small group of great men who became trustees of the Vera Institute of Justice in its first decade and served actively for as long as they lived. Through his deep knowledge of the criminal justice system and reform efforts and his gentle but probing questions, Dan contributed to the board's deliberations, our staff's work--and justice. He was a wonderful human being, and we will miss him enormously. John F. Savarese, Chair Michael Jacobson, President

The snowboarders Shaun White and Kelly Clark finished the United States Olympic qualifying season Saturday by winning for the fourth time in five events, emphatically sending them to the Winter Games in Vancouver as the halfpipe riders to beat. The United States men's squad will also include the first-time Olympians Louie Vito and Scott Lago. The defending women's gold medalist Hannah Teter and the silver medalist Gretchen Bleiler will return to the Games.

Hasib Sabbagh, a founder of the Consolidated Contractors Company International, one of the largest construction companies in the Middle East, died on Jan. 12 in Cleveland. He was 90. His death was announced by the company.

ROBERT WRIGHT For students of high-profile philandering, 2009 was the gift that keeps on giving. And you can expect 2010 to bring its own cornucopia of revealed wrongdoing. After all, Tiger Woods, Mark Sanford and David Letterman weren't just victims of their libidos; they were victims of the new transparency -- the way digital technology, with each passing year, records more and more of our behavior for all the world to see, should it decide to look.

SCAMURRA--Anthony P.,passed away peacefully on January 17 at the age of 78 in New Hampshire. Beloved son of the late Anthony and Sara Scamurra. Anthony is survived by his sister, Marie (the late Dr. Russo) and brother Donald (Rose) and many nieces and nephews. Anthony was born in Buffalo, NY and early on relocated to New York City where he was an accomplished Interior Decorator, Hair Stylist and Singer. In his earlier years, he performed at various New York nightclubs, such as Leslie's and Don't Tell Mama. For many years Anthony worked as the Administrative Assistant to Stephen M. Pollan, P.C. Anthony will be greatly missed, but not forgotten. Funeral service by Phaneuf Funeral Home in New Hampshire.

HARRY REID WAS HOARSE and hacking, drawn and more stooped than usual on a Sunday morning 12 days before Christmas. It was not yet noon, and Reid was in his second-floor corner office in an empty United States Capitol. He had arrived to bad news. Joseph Lieberman, the independent Connecticut senator, had announced on CBS's ''Face the Nation'' that he would not support the Senate health care plan, which meant that Reid did not have the 60 votes he needed. Lieberman's announcement, which torpedoed a compromise that Reid helped to midwife, caught the Senate majority leader by surprise. Reid had spoken with Lieberman two days earlier, and one of Lieberman's top aides participated in the Saturday-afternoon conference call that Reid orchestrates for Democratic senators who will be appearing on the Sunday talk shows. ''He double-crossed me,'' Reid said stiffly, associates later recounted. ''Let's not do what he wants. Let the bill just go down.'' Rahm Emanuel, the president's chief of staff, arrived at Reid's office not long afterward -- casually dressed, a cup of coffee in one hand -- and after a brisk meeting, a decision was reached: Reid would abandon his compromise, which was intended to appease proponents of a government-run insurance plan. The concession would not sit well with a lot of Democrats, not to mention the powerful constituency of union voters in Nevada, where Reid is up for re-election in November. But there was little discussion. Reid and Emanuel are exemplars of the just-get-it-done style of legislating. As it turned dark outside, Reid began pulling senators aside in the lobby just off the Senate floor, speaking in a strained whisper as he presented the case in characteristically pragmatic terms. ''I'm with you; I'm for you,'' he told Tom Harkin of Iowa, one of the Senate's traditional New Deal Democrats, who was pained that the public option was dying.

EDSALL--Anne Marie, beloved daughter of John and Margaret Edsall died in her sleep on January 16, 2010 in Coconut Grove, Florida. Born on February 11, 1962 Anne is survived by her siblings Mary Agnes, Margaret Mary, John Francis and Thomas More, her son Christian and her nieces Nicole, Matilda, Alba, and Aida and her nephew John. She is also survived by her brothers- and sister-in-law, Michael Parides, Robert Bunselmeyer, and Grisel Edsall and uncles, aunts, and numerous cousins in Washington, DC, Stamford, CT, England, and France. She attended St. Joseph's School, was a graduate of Marymount School, attended the School of Visual Arts in New York City, and studied culinary arts. Anne was a free spirit, a voracious reader, a gourmet cook, and a delightful raconteur who always saw the quirky side of things and the special characteristics of friends and acquaintances. Her stories are unforgettable. She traveled widely with her family and in later years enjoyed adventurous forays across Mexico, the Caribbean, and Central America. The family is very grateful to Don Kohner, her companion of many years, for the love and care he lavished on Anne, and we thank his family for their support and warm hospitality. Anne's Mass of the Resurrection was held at St. Hugh's Church in Coconut Grove on January 18th. Donations in her name may be made to the library at St. Joseph's School at 420 East 87th Street, NYC 10128.

LINDSAY--John K. (Jack) 85, passed away on January 30, 2009 in New York City. In his youth he was the highest seller of "Liberty" magazines in Wisconsin. After graduating from the University of Wisconsin-Madison, where he majored in Economics and International Relations, Jack moved to New York City where he dedicated his professional life to the pharmaceutical industry. He was president of Richardson-Merrill from 1965-1970. Jack especially enjoyed being president of their international division earlier in his career and until his retirement. Work took him to Puerto Rico, the Philippines, Brazil and Naples, Italy. In retirement, Jack and his sister Jeanne Bartz traveled from Alaska to Australia, Ireland to Russia and South America to the Mediterranean countries. Jack appreciated making New York City his home because of its international atmosphere and multitude of things to do. His family gathered to honor him at a Mass. Thank you, Jack, for showing us how to live life with dignity, devotion, intelligence, dedication, a worldly view, adventure and a penchant for fun.

ANGELL--Frank. With profound sorrow, I offer my deepest sympathy to the family of Frank Angell whose recent passing has taken America's foremost educator. During our 43 year friendship Frank was my next door neighbor in the Village, my insurance professor at NYU, my partner in laughter, my moral compass and my lifelong teacher. His unbending loyalty to me, even in the face of pressure from school administrators, was nothing less than courageous. I share this loss with the thousands of students who came to love his Runyonesque character. A seat in Frank's Insurance class was, by far, the most sought after in NYU history. The secret was that Frank never taught Insurance. He taught communication, empathy and style, but most of all, he taught that education was fun. I was one of the fortunate ones to get to know him just a little better. Rest in peace, Frank, you earned it. Donny Carter

If that I.E.D. had worked like it was supposed to? Bye-bye, sweetheart. STAFF SGT. CHRISTOPHER J. DREHER, a bomb disposal expert in Afghanistan, to Lance Cpl. Ryan T. Mathison, who had stepped on a mine that failed to fully detonate. [4]

SILVER--Arthur, on January 17. Beloved husband of 59 years of Renee passed away following surgical complications. He is deeply mourned by his children Marc and his wife Mimi, and by his three adoring grandchildren, Samantha, Bryan and Jonathan. Raised near Yankee Stadium, he attended the High School of Music and Art. After serving as an officer in the U.S. Army in the Pacific during WWII, he completed an architectural degree at Carnegie Institute of Technology. He began his career working with Frank Lloyd Wright trained architects before establishing his own practice in New York City. A church, numerous temples, schools, community centers, and industrial buildings were among the many structures he designed. He later taught graphic design at the C.W. Post campus of Long Island University, eventually serving as Chairman of the Fine Arts Department before retiring in l989. His love of the arts, generosity of spirit, patience with young people and uncompromising standards made him an inspiration to all who knew him. He enriched our lives forever. A memorial service to celebrate his loving and creative life will be held at the Unitarian Universalist Congregation at Shelter Rock in Manhasset, NY on February 14th at 1pm.

GRAY--Edward W. T. III, of Manhattan and Remsenburg, NY, died on January 17, 2010. Founder, President and CEO of Analytic Asset Management; Founder and Board Chair of the Countess Moira Charitable Foundation; previously, founder, President, and CEO of Gray, Seifert and Co., and Senior Vice President of Bessemer Trust Company. Graduate of Princeton University, the Stonier Graduate School of Banking, and Blair Academy. Member of Princeton Reach Out '56. Past President of the Rotary Club of New York and Chair of its Foundation. Trustee of the Lichtenstein Foundation. Director, United Nations Association of New York. Member of the Episcopal Diocese of Long Island Investment Advisory Committee; previously Warden and Vestryman of St. Mark's Episcopal Church, Westhampton Beach, and Director, Westhampton Yacht Squadron and Westhampton Beach Family Counseling Services. Member of the Union League Club (Library Committee). Previously Vice President and Trustee of the Newark Episcopal Diocesan Investment Fund and in Montclair, NJ, Senior Warden of St. Luke's Church and member of the Boards of Directors of the Mental Health Resource Center and the Salvation Army Montclair area. Coast Guard officer and veteran. Skied on every continent, traveled extensively throughout fifty states and the world and was also an avid golfer, sailor, tennis and bridge player, and singer. In recent years, authored four plays. Loving husband, father, grandfather, and brother, Mr. Gray is survived by his wife, Michele LeMoal-Gray; sons Taylor and Peter and daughter Carolyn and their spouses, Kathy, Donna, and Marc; grandchildren Brendan, Matthew, Stephen, Jessica, and Emily; sister Alice and nieces, nephews, cousins and friends. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Foundation of New York City Rotary Club or Family Counseling Service of Westhampton Beach, NY. Funeral arrangements will be announced. Memorial service planned for April 2010 in New York City.

A dash of whimsy for the post-holiday blues, knitted animal-face hats, have made their way from the skating rink and the ski slope to the city streets. They were a hot item at pop-up boutiques at Bryant Park, Union Square and Columbus Circle at Christmastime. Now that the boutiques have folded their tents, the hats are offered by pushcart vendors (above, at Fifth Avenue and 58th Street) for about $30. A similar hat was popular in the mid-1950s at the Rockefeller Center skating rink (photos 1 and 2), though made of cut and sewn jersey with the faces on the back. Also seen around town: the crested look (bottom row).

Laura Chapman Hruska, a founder and the editor in chief of Soho Press, an independent book publisher that specializes in literary fiction and exotic crime stories, died on Jan. 9 at her home in Manhattan. She was 74. The cause was cancer, said her husband, Alan Hruska.

MINTON--Robert (Bob) Schenk Jr.,formerly of Nashville, Tennessee and Sandown, New Hampshire, passed away unexpectedly on January 20. He was the eldest son of the late Catherine Payne Minton and the late Robert Schenk Minton. Robert was a graduate of Father Ryan High School, Nashville, and the University of Tennessee, Knoxville. He had been an international banker throughout his career but was now living in retirement in Clonbur, Ireland, with his longtime companion, Stacy Brooks. He is survived by his son, Rob Minton III and Rob's wife Marcia, his daughters Katherine and Sarah Minton and their mother Therese Minton, his brothers George and John Minton and their families, his cousin Lynn Gothard and his uncle George Payne Sr. His remains will be reposing at his residence, Golden Bay, Clonbur, Co. Galway, Ireland, from 12 noon to 6pm on Sunday, January 24. A funeral Mass will be held on Monday, January 25, at St. Mary of the Rosary Church, Cong, County Mayo, Ireland, with burial afterwards in Lisloughrey Cemetery. Family flowers only, and donations instead to the Irish charity, Croi.

IN this episode, the Haggler again asks whether the Internet is a net plus or net minus for consumers. It's certainly excellent for consuming, which is to say that e-commerce has been a spectacular boon for people who like to shop but hate to bathe and leave the house. But what has the Internet done to the playing field on which consumers and sellers regularly mix it up? If the field has tilted, which side has benefited?

WALDMAN--Rose, formerly of Manhattan, passed away on December 26, 2009 in Auburn, Maine at age 99. Born in Poland, she immigrated with her family to New York in 1921 and made New York her home until she moved to Maine in 2008. A 1935 graduate of Hunter College, Rose had a long professional career in advertising finance, including positions at Biow Co. and Benton & Bowles. At Ted Bates Co. in the 1960s and 1970s her innovative ideas facilitated conversion of accounting and financial systems to the first generation computer systems. She retired in 1980 as a Vice President of Ted Bates & Co. Rose loved to travel and she enjoyed New York's theatre, ballet and opera. She was a volunteer for the New York City Opera. She will be greatly missed by her nephew Burt Glass; nieces Laurie Winsor, Sheila Meyer and Bernice Leve; grandnieces Lisa, Dianne, Lynn, and Pamela; grandnephew Steven; great-grandnieces Madeleine, Anna, and Sophia and great-grandnephew Jordan. Memorial gifts may be made to Androscoggin Home Care Hospice House, P.O. Box 819, Lewiston, Maine 04243.

Los Angeles Points of Interest A friend and I will be going to Los Angeles in June for the Los Angeles ''Ring'' cycle. Although the operas and lectures will take up much of our time, we would like to make the best use of our days to see as much as possible of what the city and its surroundings offer. How would you suggest we organize our free time? -- Eileen Romano, Washington D.C.

Pop There's no winning with a festival named SOUNDS LIKE BROOKLYN; inclusion is as perilous a task as exclusion. Next weekend the Brooklyn Academy of Music, presenting a Brooklyn-centric music festival for the fourth year running (and second time under this name), will do a little of both. Friday night features diametrically opposed rock bands. Les Savy Fav is spastic and precise at once, with flecks of its hard-core roots tenaciously clinging to its appealing melodies. It's joined by Vivian Girls, whose wistfully melodic no-fi dream-pop will probably be the haziest sound ever featured in the Academy's Howard Gilman Opera House.

Quick, which is the hottest team in the N.B.A.? It is not the Lakers or the Celtics or the Cavaliers or any of the usual suspects. It is the Charlotte Bobcats, a franchise that has never come close to a winning record in six years of existence.

CHRONIC--Betty M.,84, of Boulder, Colorado, died January 21, 2010. Memorial service will be held on Thursday, January 28th, 2010 at First Presbyterian Church of Boulder at 3pm.

Art The artists in ''TWILIGHT VISIONS: SURREALISM, PHOTOGRAPHY AND PARIS,'' the biggest of four shows opening Friday at the INTERNATIONAL CENTER OF PHOTOGRAPHY, put the City of Light on a dimmer switch. Photographs by Brassaï, André Kertész, Man Ray and others embrace modernism selectively, turning lively streets and cafes into haunted alleys and phantasmagorias. In addition to some 150 photographs, the show includes films, books and Surrealist ephemera. Friday through May 9, 1133 Avenue of the Americas, at 43rd Street, (212) 857-0000, icp.org.

'Thanks For Nothing, Lucca!' An Iowa State fan's sign referring to the junior guard Lucca Staiger, who was the Cyclones' third-leading scorer but left the team last Tuesday to play professionally in Germany. Iowa State took on No. 3 Kansas with eight scholarship players on its roster.

KOVACS--Giselle. Beloved wife of Arpad, mother of Peter and grandmother to Marissa, Justine and Felicia. Her smile and Hungarian accent will live forever in the hearts of her family and clients of Giselle Electrolysis.

KORNBLUEH--Fred, DDS, of Huntington, NY passed away November 23, 2009 at 89. Beloved husband of Eleanor (Stiglitz), devoted father of Jean (Mark), Nancy (Max) and Paul. Predeceased by both daughter Nora and (Oskar). Loving grandfather, great-grandfather, uncle and friend. A graduate of NYU, Columbia Dental School and a US Naval Officer. A kind, joyful, generous man and a painless dentist. He will be missed by everyone whose lives he touched.

I DRESSED as if preparing for a first date. I picked out a blue cotton sweater with an appliqué bird perched on the right shoulder. Pearl earrings, lip gloss, a touch of mascara. Jeans to balance out the makeup and the appliqué bird. I wanted to look as if I'd tried, but not too hard. In the Hungarian Pastry Shop, waiting for him, I stirred milk into my coffee and balanced my spoon on the saucer. I picked up a book and then put it down, gazing across the street at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine. When he walked in, the sun was just beginning to set.

Television The week starts out with love in a British village and ends with death on a South American beach. The love comes in ''EMMA,'' a four-hour adaptation of the Jane Austen novel being served up as a PBS ''Masterpiece Classic.'' The first two hours are being shown on Sunday (check local listings), with Parts 2 and 3, an hour each, on the two subsequent Sundays. Romola Garai stars as Emma Woodhouse, the would-be matchmaker. Jonny Lee Miller is her friend Mr. Knightley. And for those who think it would take a wizard to make Austen interesting, Michael Gambon -- Albus Dumbledore from the Harry Potter movies -- plays Emma's father.

Classical The composer PIERRE BOULEZ is conductor emeritus of the CHICAGO SYMPHONY ORCHESTRA. In the right repertory the Chicago musicians play splendidly for Mr. Boulez, a musician they clearly revere. His program on Saturday at Carnegie Hall, the first of two, has the right repertory. ''Le Tombeau de Couperin,'' Ravel's Impressionistic homage to French baroque music, will precede a performance of a recent flute concerto by the highly individual and dazzling French composer Marc-André Dalbavie, whose spiky modern music is steeped in a French sensibility for sound and color. Mathieu Dufour is the soloist. The main work is Bartok's bleakly gripping one-act opera with two singing characters, ''Bluebeard's Castle.'' There are two impressive soloists: the bass-baritone Falk Struckmann as Bluebeard and the mezzo-soprano Michelle DeYoung as Judith, Bluebeard's latest, and unwitting, wife. Saturday at 3 p.m., (212) 247-7800, carnegiehall.org; $44 to $133.
CONAN O'BRIEN: THE FAREWELL I am Conan O'Brien, and I am just three days away from the biggest drinking binge in history.

LINDBERG--Carl M.,December 21, 2009 of Radnor, PA and Bridgton, ME. Age 71. Devoted husband of Julie, loving father of Carl E. and Kristen (Sam Healey) and granddaughter Sydney. Son of the late Dorothea and Carl O. Lindberg of New York City. Carl was a financial advisor and founding partner of Brandywine Global Asset Management in Philadelphia, also Americana antiques dealer. Friends are invited to celebration of his life on Monday, January 25, 2010, 11am at St. David's Episcopal Church, 763 South Valley Forge Rd., Devon, PA and to luncheon following. Contributions in his memory are suggested to the Rufus Porter Museum, P.O. Box 544, Bridgton, ME 04009, of which he was a founder.

WEINTRAUB--Bernard "Bernie" Martin, beloved husband, father and friend to so many passed away on January 16, 2010 at 1:54pm in Los Angeles, California. His wife of 52 years Ellie, children Danny, Lizzie, daughter-in-law Vinnet and nephew Irv were by his side. Bernie passed peacefully and did not suffer. Bernie lived a life full of adventure, accomplishment, laughter, love and friendship. One of those rare people who everyone loved, Bernie always had a smile on his face, a song in his heart, a positive and uplifting spirit and an encouraging word for his family, friends and clients. Bernie severed his country proudly during the Korean War and was one of the founding partner's of the boutique literary agency Robinson Weintraub and of the Paradigm literary and talent agency. His clients worked on numerous iconic television shows including I Love Lucy, The Jackie Gleason Show, All in the Family, M.A.S.H., Maude, Sanford & Son, The Cosby Show, Different Strokes and Roseanne, to name just a few. Bernie had many charitable interests, giving generously to groups that promoted Jewish causes, the State of Israel, civil rights, the environment and the humane treatment of animals. He helped found Laniado Hospital in Israel and was on the Board of Governors of Cedars-Sinai Hospital in Los Angeles. His funeral will take place on Monday, January 18, 2010 at 2pm PST at Mount Sinai Mortuary 5950 Forrest Lawn Drive, Los Angeles, CA. In lieu of flowers, please make contributions in Bernie's honor to American Israel Cultural Center (www.aicf.org; 212.557.1600) Jewish National Fund (www.jnf.org; 888.JNF.0099) American Diabetes Association (www.diabetes.org; 1.800.diabetes).

In 1966, William Labov, the father of sociolinguistics, discovered that many people with New York accents -- the stock Noo Yawk kind -- didn't like the way they talked. It was kind of sad. Labov found widespread ''linguistic self-hatred,'' he reported. People from New York and New Jersey described their own speech as ''distorted,'' ''sloppy'' and ''horrible.'' No wonder those great old accents came to be regarded as a class giveaway, to be thrown over in the name of assimilation, refinement and the acquisition of Newscaster English. But that was the '60s, back before the never-ending you-tawkin-t'me aria was enshrined in movies like ''Mean Streets,'' ''Saturday Night Fever,'' ''Working Girl'' and, of course, ''Taxi Driver.'' Before long, people were consciously cultivating the once-despised dialect. Now an extra-hammy version of the accent -- which thrives in the New York City area, including northern New Jersey -- is a point of fighting pride, most recently among the brawling bozos on MTV's captivating and incendiary reality show ''Jersey Shore.''

The title, in its deadpan, felt postmodern, or perhaps stamped by Warhol: ''Love Story.'' But irony did not rule the novel and film that made a deity of Erich Segal in 1970. Mr. Segal, who died last week, drew cackles back then -- Roger Ebert called the book's prose ''sort of a cross between a parody of Hemingway and the instructions on a soup can.'' But at a moment of generational strife, the story had balm-like powers. There was something for everyone -- a rich rebel son (Ryan O'Neal), a feminist working-class heroine (Ali MacGraw), a heartless capitalist who is redeemed (Ray Milland). ''Love Story'' worked, John Wayne is quoted as saying, not because ''the girl'' had a foul mouth but because ''the American public wanted to see a little romantic story.'' For one brief moment, America fell in love.

THE NEWSScott Brown, a little-known Republican state senator, won a special election to fill the United States Senate seat from Massachusetts vacated by the death of Edward M. Kennedy. BEHIND THE NEWSMartha Coakley, the Democratic state attorney general, began as a heavy favorite but proved to be a weak campaigner, while Mr. Brown tapped into popular frustration with unemployment, Wall Street bailouts and the health care debate. His victory cost the Democrats the 60th Senate vote they need to break Republican filibusters meant to stall President Obama's nominations and legislative initiatives.

WHILE the film ''Amelia'' may have flopped, Amelia Earhart's fashion sensibilities have taken off. Aviator caps, the slick leather toppers worn by old-timey high-fliers, have been turning up on the runway and around town. For the Hermès fall collection, Jean Paul Gaultier accompanied each look with a cap and a pair of goggles (center left); and even at $840 a pop, the leather ones sold out. Similarly, Alexander Wang, in his spring collection, sent out a brimmed lambskin cap attached with a zipper to a removable cape (bottom left). Granted, the look may have been more George Clooney in ''Leatherheads'' than Amy Johnson in the skies, but it had the same sleek effect.

Carroll Driscoll is survived by her children, Robert, Richard, James, and Glenn, by her seven grandchildren, Alexandra, Julia, Isabella, Scott, Ryan, Robert, and Caytlin, and by her sisters, Donna, Helen, and Cynthia. To the list of big-name hotels expected to open in Manhattan this year -- including the Trump SoHo and the Mondrian -- comes another: the James New York, part of a mini-chain of boutique hotels (jameshotels.com) that includes the James Chicago.

CAPSOUTO--Albert, died on January 19th in New York City at age 53. He is survived by his two older brothers, Jacques and Samuel. Albert was a pioneer/co-founder with his brothers of Capsouto Freres Restaurant. He was deeply involved with the downtown community; a member of CB1 for over 19 years. Albert graduated from Stuyvesant HS and Yale University. He was gift to his family from the day he was born.

(13, 49) EMMA Romola Garai, above, stars in this ''Masterpiece Classic'' presentation of Jane Austen's novel about the rich, beautiful and clueless Emma Woodhouse, whose matchmaking attempts go disastrously awry, and whose own love life doesn't fare much better. Jonny Lee Miller plays her tenderhearted friend, Mr. Knightley, who can't quite hide his affection for her despite his occasional scolding. Michael Gambon is her gloom-and-doom father. Writing in The New York Times, Alessandra Stanley said, ''This 'Emma' doesn't toy with the delicate comedy at the heart of the novel, and it lyrically renders Austen's respect for stately homes and well-tended English landscapes. But it casts an unusual touch of darkness on the outer edges of the story.'' 10 A.M. SMITH--Ruth Proskauer, a reproductive-rights and choice-in-dying advocate who helped found NARAL, died January 22 at the age of 102. She died peacefully at home surrounded by family, exactly the sort of death for which she had advocated for decades. She was a field worker and executive secretary of the Planned Parenthood League of Massachusetts (1946-1953). She was a cofounder of NARAL in 1969. She helped draft the Cook-Leichter Act of 1970, establishing abortion as a woman's legal choice in NY State. A board member and officer of the Euthanasia Society of America and the Society for the Right to Die, and a major supporter of Compassion & Choices, she was a lifelong advocate for terminally ill patients' right to choose a "good death." She organized a long-running seminar on the Supreme Court at Quest, a group that offers classes taught for and by retired professionals. The daughter of Joseph M. and Alice Naumburg Proskauer, she was born in Deal, New Jersey, on August 14, 1907. She is survived by two children, Anthony R. Smith and Gael S. Arnold, six grandchildren, and seven great-grandchildren. There will be no funeral. Family and friends will be notified of a celebration of her life and legacy. In lieu of flowers, please support Compassion & Choices or NARAL Pro-Choice NY.
VIDEO On the Street: Critters A dash of whimsy for the post-holiday blues, knitted animal-face hats have migrated from the skating rink and the ski slope to the city streets.

ASK Melvin Van Peebles about his legacy, and you get a snort, a grimace, a wave of the hand, a game-show error buzz and a finely punctuated ''come on.'' ''I didn't even know I had a legacy,'' he said between rehearsals for his latest project, a musical-theater adaptation of his 1971 film ''Sweet Sweetback's Baadasssss Song.'' ''I do what I want to do.''

In his 10th N.F.L. season, at an age when most running backs have started, or finished, a sharp decline, Thomas Jones posted career numbers with the Jets. This follows his usual unusual pattern. Drafted seventh over all by Arizona in 2000, Jones has played for four teams and reached the Super Bowl with Chicago in the 2006 season. Yet he was voted to his first Pro Bowl last season and he gained a career-high 1,402 rushing yards this season.

A group led by Chuck Greenberg and Nolan Ryan said late Saturday that it had reached a deal to purchase the Texas Rangers from the Hicks Sports Group, potentially ending a nearly yearlong struggle for the team. Greenberg, a lawyer from Pittsburgh, and Ryan, the team's current president, must still win approval of 75 percent of the Major League Baseball owners as well as several banks that hold debt in the Hicks Sports Group. The Greenberg-Ryan group must also finish raising the money needed.

WEBER--Michael S.,December 5, 2009, age 64. Son of the late Dorothy (Silverberg) and David, brother of Robert, La Farlede, France. Michael had been a Senior Editor at Bedford/ St. Martin's Press until his untimely stroke in 2008. He will be greatly missed and will always be remembered for his sense of humor and his passions.
''We're about to get into a big fight with the banks.'' President Obama, calling for new limits on the size of big banks and their ability to make risky bets.

DESPITE the occasional foray into biblical interpretation or drunken anti-Semitic outburst, Mel Gibson has always been about fighting injustice, and his latest film, ''Edge of Darkness,'' which opens on Friday, is no exception. In it he plays a detective who goes on a revenge-fueled hunt for whoever killed his daughter. It is a plot that bears a resemblance to the story line of ''Mad Max,'' his first significant film, 31 years ago, in which he played a police officer who goes after the motorcycle gang that killed his wife and son. For Mr. Gibson it has been a circular trip back to where he started, with plenty of wrongs righted and bad guys laid low along the way. NEIL GENZLINGER

CONSTRUCTION delays are part and parcel of any new development, so it should come as no surprise that if you're signing a lease in a brand-new rental building, a firm move-in date can be elusive. Developers sometimes lease apartments before they have received final permits from the city. So if a building is still under construction, potential renters should ask whether the unit they hope to move into has a certificate of occupancy. If it doesn't, they should be prepared for delays.

Hong Kong doesn't have much in the way of professional sports, but it takes its horse racing very seriously. The racing season runs from September through July (it's too hot in the summer), so this is just about midseason. The next major meet, at the suburban Sha Tin track, above right, is the first leg of Hong Kong's Triple Crown on Jan. 31. For a more mellow experience, there are generally two meets a week, with weekend day races at Sha Tin, and Wednesday night races at the smaller Happy Valley circuit, in the middle of the city.

FLOCK--Howard R.,passed away, having suffered a heart attack, in New York City on October 3, 2009, at the age of 87. Howard graduated from Mercersburg School in Pennsylvania and earned a B.A. at Yale University. During World War II, he served as an officer in the U.S. Navy and fought bravely, on a destroyer escort ship, in the Battle of Okinawa. He received an M.A. in Fine Arts at Harvard University, and his Ph.D. from Cornell University, where his ideas on art and perception inspired his mentor Professor James J. Gibson in Experimental Psychology. For many years, Howard Flock was a Professor at York University in Toronto, where he helped to build a new and influential Psychology Department. He was the author of many articles in his field, pioneering research in visual perception. An avid student of Italian Renaissance painting and sculpture, he contributed funds and support to the City of Florence, Italy, for the restoration of its flood-damaged artworks and manuscripts. At the time of his death, he resided in his beloved New York City, where he had been a great supporter of the Metropolitan Opera, among other art institutions. Howard is survived by his sister-in-law, Maxine Magaziner Flock, and his nieces, Brenda Flock and Dana Goode and her family. He was laid to rest in the Flock family plot in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania.

WHAT will the coming Chevrolet Volt actually cost? Is it the low $30,000s? Or is it around $40,000? The growing confusion over the pricing of battery E.V.'s and plug-in hybrids has to do with a $7,500 federal tax credit for purchasers of cars with battery packs of 16 kilowatt hours or more. Fisker and Tesla cite prices that include the tax credit. That's a way to get the price down to $39,900 for Fisker's Project Nina car and $49,900 on Tesla's Model S. Khobi Brooklyn, a Tesla representative, said the company used this approach because it ''does bring the price down and makes the cars sound a bit better.''

STAMBERG--Melvin. Born Jersey City, 1918. Died January 22 at home in Huntington, NY. Beloved husband of Lois, father of Jill Jarnow and Peter. Grandfather of Jesse Jarnow. Teacher, manufacturer, developer. Past president of The Seaview Association of Fire Island. Dedicated to justice and respect for the environment.

ALL the earth -- or at least those living in a frenzied parallel universe known as Jets fandom -- might view the 6-foot-1, 235-pound retired New York City fireman as a talisman for regaining lost Super Bowl glory, a raging, one-man booster club for a once-storied football franchise on the verge of toppling doubt. But Edwin M. Anzalone, known by Gang Green followers far and wide as Fireman Ed, might be overcompensating for a secret he keeps hidden behind his weekly bouts of Sunday bluster: He views himself as a bit of a bad luck charm.

LEVITAN--Sidney, died at home on January 11, a week after celebrating his 99th birthday. He lived his first 96 years in Brooklyn before moving to be near his son, Daniel and daughter-in-law Esther in Northern Virginia. He taught French for several decades at Lafayette High and Erasmus Hall High where he was also chairman of Foreign Languages. After retiring, he and his wife, Ruth, pursued their passion for folk dance and for travel. He led dances at his four grandchildren's B'nei Mitzvah as well as at his granddaughter Marilin's wedding. Despite the heartbreaking loss of his son, Anson 13 years ago, and the death four years ago of his wife of 56 years, Sidney had great optimism and zest for life. He stayed on top of the news and was delighted at Barack Obama's victory. He was a source of love, support, inspiration and encouragement to Daniel, Esther and their son, Adam and to Anson's children, Marilin, Raquel and Sarah and their mother, Ruth Kaplan. He enjoyed many visits from his grandchildren, his grandson-in-law, Luis Vargas and his great grandson, Aaron Vargas. He is also survived by his sister, Sylvia, nephews Daniel, Richard and Robert Levitan and Alan Cotzin and niece Norma Passo. His brother Milton died three years ago. Gifts in his memory can be made to the Anson Levitan Intern Fund. Checks payable to LASSD may be sent to Michele Meldon, Legal Aid Society of San Diego, 1475 6th Avenue, 4th Floor, San Diego, CA 92101.

Just how President Obama‘s proposed banking restrictions would affect the large banks’ bottom lines remains somewhat unclear at this point. If broadly defined, banks could be forced to divest major portions of their business, while if narrowly defined, the banks could largely continue business as usual.

If you've ever received an unsolicited college application that looked like a brightly colored credit card solicitation - the kind that may have promised waived application fees and expedited processing - you might be interested in an article of mine just published on The Times's Web site.

Since last summer, the Marines have expanded their presence along the Helmand River, and as more troops flow into the country the momentum is pushing them farther into territory long out of Afghan government control. They now operate a web of outposts and patrol bases that dot the farmland and the steppe of Helmand Province, and they patrol regularly around and between them. Their sustained presence in many districts, along with the decrease in vegetation that followed fall harvests and the onset of cold Afghan weather, has left Taliban fighters with less ability to hide in a gunfight. Winter has brought a decrease in small-arms attacks.

TUESDAY'S PUZZLE - No, today's theme is not NEW TIERS over PAR, although that runs down the center of the puzzle. Paula Gamache has something much nicer going on. Her theme consists of five entries, each containing two words that can follow the word KEEP. I know because I can KEEP COUNT and KEEP TRACK. I also know how to KEEP QUIET, but I won't just yet.

It's hard to top Justine Henin's return to tennis after a 20-month hiatus, but the resurgence of Nadia Petrova is another compelling storyline in this year's Australian Open. The two are now playing in the quarterfinals, having survived a section of the draw that included Elena Dementieva, Kim Clijsters, and Svetlana Kuznetsova.

Bill Gates dropped by The New York Times on Monday to discuss his full-time job as head of the Gates Foundation, the world's largest philanthropy, especially its work in global health and development.

John Papola and Russ Roberts have finally released their much-anticipated (by me, anyway) music video of a rap battle between those two economic gangstas, John Maynard Keynes and Friedrich Hayek. Considering Professor Roberts blogs at a site called "Cafe Hayek," you can sorta guess where his sympathies lie. But it's a fun video no matter where you fall in this epic rivalry.

With his poll numbers in retreat and his agenda under fire, President Obama said in a television interview today that he would not sacrifice his ambitious goals simply to win a second term in the White House.

The Obama administration has asked the Senate Armed Services Committee to delay hearings on the fate of the military's controversial "don't ask, don't tell" policy, because the president expects to discuss it in Wednesday's address to Congress, the committee chairman said today.

"The Park," a sumptuous new original series from T - yep, we have those, see our T Takes - debuts next Monday. Directed by Poppy de Villeneuve and set within the majestic bounds of Central Park, the five-episode series stars Macaulay Culkin, Q'orianka Kilcher, and the vaunted stage actress Mary Beth Peil, who plays Chris Noth's mother on "The Good Wife."
The trailer for "The Park," a sumptuous new original series from T.

This week, A. O. Scott gets "mad as hell" with Sidney Lumet's 1976 film "Network," a satirical look at the inner workings of the corporate media. While the television landscape has changed in myriad and fundamental ways since "Network" was released, Mr. Scott argues that "the film's essential insights about the nature of mass communication in modern society are as fresh as ever." Investors who receive employer-provided help investing in their 401(k)s have better returns than those who go it alone, according to a recent study. That provides some support for the Obama administration's expected proposal, which would make unbiased investment advice available to workers who participate in these types of plans.
The Millburn Detective Bureau made an arrest Friday in connection with the theft of a fur coat valued at $18,000 from Saks Fifth Avenue earlier this month.

Beneath Brittany Lietz Cicala's porcelain skin and flowing blond hair are blemishes from nearly three dozen surgeries to remove cancerous moles, including an eight-inch scar across her back. The 2006 Miss Maryland title-holder, Ms. Cicala, 24, blamed an obsession with tanning beds for triggering the cancer.

Spike Jonze, objectively speaking one of the coolest dudes around, is mild-mannered and polite almost to the point of awkwardness. (We mean that in a nice way.) Mr. Jonze created a stir when he was at Sundance for a few days showing a 30-minute short, "I'm Here," which he made with money from Absolut. It's a robot love story with more human than computer-generated effects: square-headed Sheldon (Andrew Garfield) falls for sleek Francesca (Sienna Guillory), who's quirky and fun but prone to losing body parts.

In the collaboration-crazed world of men's wear, the hookup of Steven Alan and Michael Williams was only a matter of time. And geography. Every morning, Williams - who, as the man behind the blog A Continuous Lean, is pretty much the charismatic leader of the cult of Americana - makes the trek from his apartment in the Financial District to his office in SoHo. The designer and retailer Alan, meanwhile, commutes in the opposite direction to his office in TriBeCa. "I would walk north and he would walk south," Williams says. "The more that I saw him, the more we talked." The result of those discussions, two shirts ($168 each) that arrive today at Williams's newish A.C.L. & co. online shop, is both predictable and a little surprising.

Economists left, right and center have weighed in on Ben S. Bernanke's nomination to serve a second term as Federal Reserve chairman. Here are a few of their reactions:"I'm with Abraham Lincoln: don't swap horses in the middle of the stream." -- James Hamilton, University of California, San Diego

After interviewing for job at a New York magazine and completing the requisite editing test, Neal Hirshfeld waited and waited for a response from human resources. When Mr. Hirshfeld's patience expired, he decided to have his revenge by accepting an offer that he never received, calling the company's human resources department to tell them that he would report to duty on Monday morning. When he let the human resources director in on the joke, he didn't let her down easy.

A recent report published by BizBuySell -- one of the Internet's largest marketplaces for buying or selling a small business -- confirmed a hunch I've had for several months, namely that small business deals seemed to pick up during the latter part of 2009. While many business owners have put their exit plans on hold until the economy recovers, others are not only hanging on but enjoying growth and have a bright outlook for 2010.
