One sign that the television networks were suffering as a result of the economy was decisions by several to cut back or eliminate their annual presentations of coming fall shows to advertisers during several days in May known as the "upfront" week.

To most renters in New York City, it sounds like a modest, even enviable, rent increase: pay an additional $45 if your monthly rent happened to be less than $1,000 and you had been living in the same apartment for more than six years.

With the taste of World Cup defeat still lingering, Egypt will have a chance to face down its archrival Algeria -- again -- when the teams play in the African Cup of Nations semifinal Thursday in Benguela, Angola. The two North African teams played two fiercely contested matches late last year to determine the final spot in the 2010 World Cup in South Africa. The meetings were marred by violence and controversy.

Despite a still tricky, if rebounding, real-estate market, several luxury hotel brands are throwing caution to the tradewinds with splashy new Caribbean resorts. After a long delay, the Viceroy Anguilla finally made its debut last month, joining the sleepy little island's outsize collection of high-end hotels. (The Moorish-inspired Cap Juluca still reigns supreme, while the much-touted developments of Temenos and Rendezvous Bay have stalled.) At this latest Viceroy, situated on Mead and Barnes Bays, Kelly Wearstler has created ultradecadent penthouses suites, cabana-lined infinity pools and multiple lounges, among them the Half Shell, carved out of the side of a cliff.In the Turks and Caicos, where construction seems to continue unabated on Grace Bay Beach (for better or worse), the new Veranda Resort, managed by the company that owns the chic Grace Bay Club, begins accepting guests Feb. 1. It might siphon off some of the jet set who've been holing up at the nearby Gansevoort Hotel, but probably just a little - the chainlet's third outpost after New York and Miami has been going strong since last spring.

Gah. I hate, hate, hate it when people say that we have to do something, not on its merits, but because otherwise we would damage market confidence. Nobody really knows how the markets will react; the right thing, always, is to pursue policies that look right on the substance.

Two other catastrophes, both documented in dramatic photographs, displaced Haiti as the lead subject of Pictures of the Day for the first time since the earthquake. (This, of course, is exactly the concern of advocates for Haitian victims; that the story of their suffering will quickly fade from global consciousness.) In Baghdad, a coordinated bombing attack killed 36 people in and around the Ishtar Sheraton, the Babylon Hotel and the Hamra Hotel. Ayman Oghanna was among the photographers on the scene and produced one of the many unsettling pictures of the immediate aftermath (Slide 2). And in Beirut, an Ethiopian Airlines plane with at least 90 people aboard crashed into the Mediterranean shortly after takeoff.

It's a continuing conversation within households, and here on Motherlode, about how to make parenting feel less lopsided and more equal. A couple who spends a lot of time talking about this subject - first as a goal in their own life, and then as authors of the book "Equally Shared Parenting: Rewriting the Rules for a New Generation of Parents" - are Marc and Amy Vachon. I wrote about their book here a few weeks ago, and in the comments, many of you questioned whether parenting should be equal if the resulted would be constant weighing, measuring, dissecting and bickering about how to divide their time.

The Paris men's-wear shows just ended, and several key fall 2010 trends are already clear. I know - who's thinking about next fall when we're all freezing and pining for spring? Still, it's always good to be prepared, and you can always check your closet to try and get a jump-start on what everyone will be doing next winter. For example, you could tuck your pants into boots - pretty much every designer has shown a version of long johns tucked into rugged explorer footwear. Or, see if you already have a floor-grazing coat, like the ones at Dior Homme, or a cape like John Galliano's. It has been 179 days since three graduates of the University of California, Berkeley, were arrested and charged with illegally crossing the Iranian border during a hiking trip last summer. Friends and family of Shane Bauer, Sarah Shourd and Joshua Fattal, as well as the Kurdish government, say the border crossing was unintentional, a case of unfamiliar terrain. But the Iranian government has accused the three hikers of espionage, and said they will be tried.

Most of the day-to-day, minute-by-minute events in the fashion world are so random and implausible that nothing really surprises. Outside the Dior haute couture show, held in the house, where the pale gray walls are lined with portraits of the famous and (mostly) departed, a throng of photographers and onlookers waited behind steel barricades. It was a chilly gray day. I was greeted like a country mouse by the security man at the entrance. He pulled at the corner of my invitation to see if there was a seat assignment, and then waved me in. On the stairs to the salons, I saw more camera people and then roses galore. The displays were abundant and colorful enough, surrounded by puddles of fabric, to be camp. I said hello to one or two people from the house and then found my seat.
A discussion of wedding rings in advertisements.

A group of hedge funds filed a lawsuit on Monday against Porsche SE and two former executives, accusing the German sports car company of lying and illegally manipulating shares of Volkswagen A.G., thus costing the funds more than $1 billion in trading losses.

In breaking news Monday morning, the Quebec Major Junior League has suspended the Devils draft choice Patrice Cormier for the remainder of the season. Playing for Rouyn-Noranda Huskies on Jan. 17, Cormier elbowed Quebec Remparts Mikael Tam in the head, sending Tam sprawling to the ice and convulsing (video). Just to be totally clear -- and regardless of what any bandleaders for any other NBC late-night shows might say -- a publicist for Conan O'Brien said on Monday that none of the skits and stunts that Mr. O'Brien ran during his final week at the host of "The Tonight Show" broke NBC's budget or cost more than what was normally spent on the show.

As Brooks Barnes noted on Sunday, one of the unlikeliest must-see celebrities at Sundance has been Bill Gates. Mr. Gates was in town promoting a documentary, "Waiting for Superman," about the educational system, which Paramount Vantage bought even before the festival started. As Mr. Barnes also notes, "Viacom, Paramount's corporate parent, recently agreed to team with the Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation to promote education improvement; as part of the agreement, the foundation pays third parties that create such content for Viacom."
The city of Delhi, India, has announced that it will shut down all of its coal-fired power plants and switch to natural gas, according to an article in The Hindustan Times.

You need only watch the cable talk shows or read the political press to realize that "Game Change," the fly-on-the-wall political tome from John Heileman and Mark Halperin, is the book of the moment. It's hard not to talk to a politico and not hear gossip about the back story of the 2008 presidential race, from ill-worded remarks from Senator Harry Reid to the slow implosion of Senator John McCain's presidential campaign.

The Bay Area blog has been reporting daily from the federal courthouse in San Francisco on the case of Perry v. Schwarzenegger. That case is challenging the constitutionality of Proposition 8, the ban on same-sex marriage approved by voters in 2008. Among the lawyers on the plaintiffs' team are Theodore B. Olson, David Boies, Theodore J. Boutrous Jr., Christopher Dean Dusseault, Christine Van Aken, Danny Chu, Matthew D. McGill and Therese Stewart. The legal team for the defense includes Brian Raum, Charles J. Cooper, David Thompson, Andrew Pugno, James Campbell, Jordan Lorence, Nicole Moss, Howard C. Nielson Jr. and Peter A. Patterson.

On Saturday, the Invisible Dog, a burgeoning new art center in Cobble Hill, Brooklyn, opened its doors for large installation by the French conceptual artist Xavier Roux. An enormous ant built of steel and nylon balloons, with a porkpie hat suspended above its head, "The Ant" refers to the childrens' poem by the Surrealist artist Robert Desnos. The poem's refrain is well known in France: "An 18-meter ant/With a hat on its head/That doesn't exist, that doesn't exist!" The rhyming whimsy, however, conceals a dark history: Desnos was a resistance fighter, and the 18-meter ant refers to the 18-meter train cars used by the Nazis for transport.
The number and value of private-equity deals in Europe leveled off in the fourth quarter, after showing constant growth throughout last year, according to a new report released by Candover.

China, it can be safely said, has a complicated relationship with "Avatar." Last week it was reported that the 2-D version of the science-fiction epic, directed by James Cameron, was being pulled from many Chinese theaters; now a mountain there is being renamed for a peak seen in the film. In a ceremony on Monday, the Southern Sky Column in Zhangjiajie City, in China's Hunan province, was formally renamed the Avatar Hallelujah Mountain, Reuters reported, citing the local government's official Web site. The name change seemed to be an effort to stir up the interest of Chinese tourists, who have helped "Avatar" sell more than $100 million in tickets, breaking box office records in the country. Travel companies have already begun offering tours that emphasize the region's resemblance to Pandora, the lush alien moon depicted in the film. On its site, the municipal government wrote: "Pandora is far but Zhangjiajie is near. Welcome to Zhangjiajie to see 'Avatar's' Hallelujah Mountains and discover the real world of Pandora."

PARIS -- Retromobile may be Europe's best old car show. Housed in a hall here at the Porte de Versailles, Retromobile officially celebrates the bicentennial of Peugeot and urban transportation. But the eclectic nature of the exhibits means there's a little bit of everything spread around the immense pavilion.

Beacon Power has begun construction in Stephentown, N.Y., near Albany, on a plant that stores energy in flywheels -- essentially rotating wheels or cylinders whose inertia is used to store power or deliver it quickly.

The MTV reality series "Jersey Shore" isn't broadcasting any more new episodes, and yet it still finds ways to trouble its home state. On Friday night, a party at a New Jersey nightclub where the "Jersey Shore" cast members were scheduled to appear drew an unexpectedly large crowd, resulting in fights among clubgoers hoping to catch a glimpse of Snooki or the Situation, and forcing the police to temporarily close down the street. The Star-Ledger of Newark reported that the 501 Lounge in Montclair, N.J., hosted a "Jersey Shore" event on Friday night that drew an estimated 2,000 fans to the 800-person capacity club. "They had crowds much larger than they could control," David Sabagh, the police chief of Montclair, told The Star-Ledger. "They had 600 upstairs, 200 to 300 downstairs and 400 outside." He added: "There were fights inside and fights outside." Mr. Sabagh said four people were arrested on charges of disorderly conduct and drunken driving. On Thursday night, the season finale of "Jersey Shore" was watched by 4.8 million people.

Until the past few decades, universities like Harvard, Yale and Stanford relied heavily in their admissions process on a feeder network of headmasters, guidance counselors and principals at nearby prep schools and high schools, to say nothing of their alumni. But for a number of reasons -- not least the desire to diversify their classes -- these institutions and others began combing the nation in earnest in the 1960s and 1970s to assemble their freshman classes.

Think "custom car" and you're usually thinking about artists like Ed "Big Daddy" Roth or Von Dutch. The name Fornasetti does not come to mind. Seagate, the world's largest maker of hard drives, right, has started selling products directly to large customers in higher volumes than ever before because more companies with big data centers are trying to cut costs. ''We are seeing more and more of the direct purchases from companies with huge data sets,'' said Stephen Luczo, the chief executive of Seagate, in a recent interview.

The defeat of Martha Coakley in last week's special election to fill the Senate seat that was long held by Edward M. Kennedy has reignited the debate over whether there is a glass ceiling for women in Massachusetts politics. ''Welcome to liberal Massachusetts -- we're not,'' said Mary Anne Marsh, a Democratic political consultant. ''And if you didn't believe it before, anyone who thinks that Massachusetts is liberal in light of Tuesday's results need only look at the record and lack of success women have had in Massachusetts politics. That should just put it away for good.''
COHEN--Harris David. Jan. 25, 1967 - Aug. 13, 1985. We are a big family, but always one short. Love Unkie, Amy and Gaby

An eerie hush settles in at sundown on the Tohono O'odham Nation, which straddles 75 miles of border with Mexico. Few residents leave their homes. The roads crawl with the trucks of Border Patrol agents, who stop unfamiliar vehicles, scrutinize back roads for footprints and hike into the desert wilds to intercept smugglers carrying marijuana on their backs and droves of migrants trying to make it north.

James Bopp Jr. likes to begin speeches by reading the First Amendment. He calls opponents, including President Obama, ''socialists.'' He runs a national law practice out of a small office in Terre Haute, Ind., because he prefers the city's conservative culture. And for most of the last 35 years, he has been a lonely Quixote tilting at the very idea of regulating political donations as an affront to free speech.

Republicans are luring new candidates into House and Senate races, and the number of seats up for grabs in November appears to be growing, setting up a midterm election likely to be harder fought than anyone anticipated before the party's big victory in Massachusetts last week. Republicans still face many obstacles, not least a number of potentially divisive primaries in coming months that will highlight the deep ideological rifts within the party. But in the days since Republicans claimed the Senate seat that Edward M. Kennedy had held for decades, upending assumptions in both parties about the political landscape for 2010, they have seen not just a jolt of energy and optimism but also more concrete opportunities to take on Democrats.

His eyes weary, his body bruised, his lips pursed, Mark Sanchez walked through the Jets' locker room Sunday night carrying a red toiletry kit. He was on his way to cleanse himself of a disappointing loss, a 30-17 defeat to the Indianapolis Colts in the American Football Conference championship game, but he had another task in mind, too. When he returned, the beard he had spent the previous five weeks cultivating was gone. Sanchez looked as young as he did that day last April, when the Jets traded up to draft him, but he is hardly the same quarterback. His superb performance at Lucas Oil Stadium culminated a stretch that turned him from weak link to bona fide strength. Of all the reasons the Jets did not advance to the Super Bowl -- Peyton Manning's brilliance; the Jets' weakened secondary; an injury to Shonn Greene; two missed field goals by Jay Feely -- Sanchez did not even register.

CHICAGO UNDERGROUND DUO ''Boca Negra'' (Thrill Jockey) The Chicago Underground Duo is two jazz musicians, Chad Taylor and Rob Mazurek, a drummer and a cornetist. They don't only play in jazz groups; Mr. Taylor tours with the singer-songwriter Sam Bean, known as Iron and Wine, and Mr. Mazurek has a rugged, noisy, pop-leaning band called Mandarin Movie. Together they play a lot of semifree improvisation and electronics, shaping their music further in postproduction.

Peyton Manning dug into his film archives last week. Grinding, he said, was his word of the week and one of the golden oldies the ultimate studier bore into was a Colts-Ravens playoff game from 2007. The Colts won that game, 15-6, behind five Adam Vinatieri field goals in a moribund offensive day for Manning. And Manning had a feeling that Rex Ryan would recycle some of what he did with the Ravens that January to try and shut down the Colts' offense Sunday.

LADY ANTEBELLUM ''Need You Now'' (Capitol Nashville) The best song on ''Need You Now,'' the second album by the wildly successful soft-country trio Lady Antebellum, is ''When You Got a Good Thing,'' which oozes regret like a scraped-up 1980s Don Henley number. Except in one way: Lady Antebellum never gets to the hurt. As on many of its songs, a danger is looming -- ''Hold on to the love we're making/'cause baby when the ground starts shaking'' -- but it never arrives. It feels hypothetical.

SMITH--Ruth Proskauer. The Governing Council and Members of Quest, the CCNY/CWE Community for Lifelong Learning of the City University of New York notes with deepest sorrow the passing of one of our beloved founders and most active members. Ruth brought vitality to our peer-learning organization that is cherished by all who knew her. Ruth was active in many daily classes and was a coordinator responsible for the Supreme Court Course for many years. We will miss her strong voice and well formed opinions which always enriched our discussions. When asked in an interview in 2008 why she devoted so much time and effort to Quest she answered "...it's so positive, I guess you can tell by the number of years I have been coming. I don't think I would be myself without it, not having a focus for what you are going to do each day, means that you're sort of a couch potato." We at Quest, (www.questonline.org) wish to convey our sincerest condolences to her family, friends and all who were touched by her tireless efforts on behalf of Women's Rights and her advocacy for the rights of the terminally ill. Marc W. Deitch, MD, President Quest: Community for Lifelong Learning, Inc. The City College of New York CCNY/CWE

10 P.M. (Showtime) SECRET DIARY OF A CALL GIRL You know what they say about judging a book by its cover. Billie Piper, above, who plays Belle on this Showtime series, meets Brooke Magnanti, a k a Belle de Jour, the real-life prostitute and writer whose sex blog and best-selling books inspired Ms. Piper's character. Ms. Magnanti, a medical researcher who says she worked to pay for her Ph.D., revealed her identity in November. In this half-hour prelude to the series's Season 3 premiere on Feb. 1, she reflects on her former profession and some amusing encounters, ponders her best assets and divulges a few secrets of the trade. A new season of ''Tracey Ullman's State of the Union,'' at 10, finds Ms. Ullman channeling Chanel, an airport-security screener who leads a group of passengers in a dance production set to Michael Jackson songs. In another skit Penélope Cruz plays Salma Hayek playing the artist Frida Kahlo. And in the premiere of ''La La Land,'' at 11, the British comedian Marc Wootton, helped out by Peter Baynham, a writer of ''Borat,'' portrays an aspiring actor, a documentary filmmaker and a psychic who all dream of making it big in Hollywood. 6 P.M. (Hallmark) BRIAN BOITANO SKATING SPECTACULAR Mr. Boitano, the Olympic gold medalist, performs with Ryan Bradley, Yuka Sato, Kimmie Meissner and Steven Cousins to music by the band Chicago. Peggy Fleming joins Mr. Boitano as host.

BARRY MANILOW ''The Greatest Love Songs of All Time'' (Arista) Musical chicken soup for anxious hearts: that is the reliable pop panacea that Barry Manilow has been dispensing for nearly 40 years. His voice, at 66, is still boyishly eager (except for the faintest quaver) and conveys the same soothing message: ''I am your friend through thick and thin.'' It is convincing enough to have made him as critically indestructible as Johnny Mathis, a singer whose voice projects a more ethereal version of the same reassurance. Their longtime popularity attests to a persistence of a belief in true love and happy endings, despite all evidence to the contrary.

By the time the fourth quarter was ticking away, the Knicks-Dallas Mavericks game looked a bit like one of those old Harlem Globetrotters-Washington Generals games, with unconscious outside shots, uncanny inside flings, thunderous dunks and little resistance to the spectacular or the routine. The big difference Sunday was that the crowd at Madison Square Garden did not find this traveling basketball act very entertaining, filling the building with boos before and after the final buzzer echoed.

MTV and VH1 have a formula: VH1 gets the C-list celebrities; MTV gets the anonymous teenagers and 20-somethings who aspire to be C-list celebrities. ''My Life as Liz,'' Monday nights on MTV, breaks down the categories somewhat. Billed as the video diary of Liz Lee, a high school senior in Burleson, Tex., it registers more as a sitcom than a reality show -- it's so stylized and carefully planned and post-produced, it's the next best thing to scripted, if it isn't in fact a wholly scripted put-on. And that's the point. Ms. Lee and her producers have done an end run around teenage anonymity and preshaped her as Burleson's -- and soon, they hope, the world's -- own readymade C-list celebrity.

MOSBACHER--Robert Adam Sr.,Twenty Eighth United States Secretary of Commerce in the Administration of President George H.W. Bush, an accomplished oilman and industry leader, and a champion amateur sailor, died on Sunday, the 24th of January 2010, of cancer at the age of 82. Bob was born in Mt. Vernon, NY on March 11, 1927 to Emil and Gertrude Mosbacher and was the youngest of three children. He grew up in White Plains, NY before moving to Texas in 1948. He graduated from the Choate School in Wallingford, CT and Washington and Lee University. At a very early age, he established himself as one of the premier competitive sailors on Long Island Sound winning the 1939 Long Island Sound Midget Sailing Championship, and the 1941 and 42 Long Island Sound Atlantic Class Championships. He went on to amass a number of national and international titles. He was the only amateur sailor to win World Championships in three different Olympic classes. His sailing exploits and those of his brother, Bus, earned them a joint photo on the cover of the May 19, 1959 issue of Sports Illustrated. At the age of 21, and on the advice of his father, Bob moved to Houston with his first wife, Jane Pennybacker, to build an independent oil and gas company. The next decade would bring four wonderful children - Diane, Robert Jr., Kathryn, and Lisa. However, tragedy struck when his beloved Jane succumbed to leukemia in 1970. In the meantime, Bob built a highly successful energy exploration and production company with interests primarily in Texas, Louisiana, and Mississippi. At different times over the past 50 years, the company has had profitable investments in the Rocky Mountains, Michigan, Canada, Spain, the Philippines, Venezuela, India, and more. Since 1950, Mosbacher has participated in the discovery and/or development of hundreds of millions of barrels of oil, and almost a trillion cubic feet of natural gas. The business has had the good fortune of a very dedicated and loyal group of employees who have shared in the successes, as well as the disappointments over the years. Bob is deeply grateful to his Mosbacher Energy family, both past and present, for their support. His decades of oil and gas experience, coupled with his astute business judgment, led others to seek his counsel, resulting in his heading a host of industry organizations including the National Petroleum Council, The All-American Wildcatters' Association, the U.S. Oil and Gas Association and others. Bob was long considered a consummate dealmaker who was always willing to take risk, but within acceptable parameters. Out of a deep desire to give something back to his country, he got involved in elective politics in the 1960's. Although he served as Harris County Chairman of the 1968 Nixon Campaign, it was his loyal friendship with, and devoted support of George H. W. Bush that would lead him to the national political stage. In fact, Mosbacher managed the national fundraising operations for five different GOP presidential campaigns - from Gerald Ford in 1976 to John McCain in 2008. He was regarded by friend and foe alike as one of the most effective political fundraisers in modern history, partly because of the respect he commanded as a business leader, and because he never asked others to support a candidate or cause he was not supporting actively himself. Following the 1988 election, he was asked by then President-elect George H.W. Bush to join his Cabinet as the 28th U.S. Secretary of Commerce. He was honored by the opportunity to serve his country and on February 3, 1989, he was sworn in by his close friend, Secretary of State James A. Baker, III, with President Bush looking on. His principal accomplishments while at the helm of the Commerce Department from 1989 until early 1992 included laying the foundation for the North American Free Trade Agreement, helping shrink America's trade deficit with Japan and South Korea, and aggressively promoting U.S. exports through the strengthening of the U.S. Foreign and Commercial Service of the Commerce Department. His role in helping negotiate NAFTA prompted Mexican President Ernest Zedillo to present Mosbacher with the "Order of the Aztec Eagle," the highest decoration offered by the Mexican Government to non-citizens. He was particularly proud later in life to have served as Chairman of the Americas Society and Council of the Americas; on the board of the Naval Academy Endowment; and as founder and president of the board of the Odyssey Academy Charter School in Galveston. Just recently, he was honored to learn that the Robert A. Mosbacher, Sr. Institute for Trade, Economics and Public Policy is being created within the George Bush School of Government and Public Service at Texas A&M University. Bob had a quick, warm smile, a wonderful sense of humor, and a fun-loving way about him that was contagious. He was deeply devoted to his family and felt that he was one of the luckiest men in the world to have been mentored by his father "Pop" along with respected business friend Max Fisher, and to have lived such an incredible life with a family he adored and friends like fellow oilman Chesley Pruet and his dear friend and lawyer, Randy Smith. His survivors include his wife of ten years, Michele "Mica" Mosbacher; sister Barbara Susan Mosbacher; daughter Diane and her spouse Nanette Gartrell; son Rob; daughter Kathi and her spouse Michael Wheeler; daughter Lisa and her spouse Downing Mears; grandchildren Peter (and wife Lucy), Jane, and Meredith Mosbacher, Parker, Whitney (and wife Katie), and Bayly Mears; stepson Donald Cameron Duncan III and his spouse Brittanie Hoster Duncan; stepsons Robert and Lloyd Gerry; a step-grandchild; as well as numerous nephews and cousins. His older brother, Emil "Bus" Mosbacher, passed away in 1997. Services in Houston are with Geo. H. Lewis & Sons, The Funeral Directors Since 1936, www.geohlewis.com, 713-789-3005. A celebration of Bob's life is to be conducted at 10am on Wednesday, January 27, at Memorial Drive Presbyterian Church, 11612 Memorial Dr. in Houston, TX. In lieu of customary remembrances, donations may be sent to the University of Texas M.D. Anderson Cancer Center (mdanderson.org), the newly created Mosbacher Institute at the Bush School at Texas A&M University (http://bush.tamu.edu/mosbacher/memorial), or the Odyssey Academy Charter School in Galveston (odyssey-academy.com).

O'DONOGHUE--M. John, 89, died on January 22, 2010 in Princeton, New Jersey. Born September 26, 1920, the youngest of five children of Patrick and Elizabeth O'Donoghue, he grew up with his extended family in Philadelphia during the Depression. He was an excellent student who graduated from St. Joseph's Preparatory School and attended Yale University on a scholarship, but left college after his freshman year and had no other higher education apart from his participation in the Advanced Management Program of the Harvard Business School in 1974-75. He had a broad-based career as a business executive with companies headquartered mainly in New York City, concluding his career as a senior executive of Springs Industries. After his retirement in 1986, he was active in non-profit agencies in Princeton, NJ, to which he moved in 1950. He married Joan Watson in 1949 and they had five children, Mark, John, Philip, Carol and Elizabeth. After Joan's death in 1992, he married Polly Pratt Green, who survives him, as do his children and their spouses, and six grandchildren (Anna, Tim, Aidan, Noah, Lily and Claire). His funeral service will begin at 10:30am on Tuesday, January 26, 2010, at St. Paul's Church, 214 Nassau Street, Princeton, NJ.

It starts in Columbus, Ohio, and ends in Manhattan, on New Year's Eve 2011. The Merce Cunningham Dance Company on Wednesday will announce its final tour, meant to give the world a last chance to view the works created by its founder, as performed by the men and women he trained. The modern-dance tour begins on Feb. 12 and wends its way through 35 cities before a final performance at the Park Avenue Armory. Cunningham, who died on July 26, had approved the tour as part of a plan to wind down the company's activities and preserve his legacy. The company will disband afterward. The tour will take it across the United States, to Montreal and then to France, England, Germany and Spain. Eighteen works will be performed, including seven pieces that have long been out of the repertory, the company said. The final New York performances will cost $10 a ticket, according to Cunningham's wishes.

The $25 and Under review this week is of Szechuan Chalet on the Upper East Side. That's never been a neighborhood noted for its authentic Asian cuisine. Previous tenants in the restaurant's space had served the usual mild, gummy dishes that all too often passes for Sichuan cooking. But like a few other places in New York, Szechuan Chalet presents some real Sichuan flavor. Have you been there? Have you been to Sichuan? Do you have a favorite Sichuan restaurant or even a favorite neighborhood Chinese restaurant?

How do you get to Sundance? Perseverance, perspiration and, if possible, private jets: on Sunday Bill Pullman and Jessica Alba blew in from the left coast on a tiny aircraft to attend the premiere of Michael Winterbottom's "The Killer Inside Me," which was certainly one way of skirting the weather problems that kept many so many grounded in cities like Los Angeles and Phoenix. As a result, people have for days been trickling in to American cinema's annual indie bacchanal, and when they finally got here, they found more snow in Park City, Utah, than during any Sundance in years - a constant, muted downfall that didn't let up until Sunday but that certainly didn't stop the hordes of stockingless young women clad in miniskirts and stilettos from swarming into the mush-and-ice covered downtown. Mardi Gras beads were strewn all over Main Street on Sunday morning, which was probably a metaphor for something. But the fact that so much of the festival has nothing to do with movies is a pretty straightforward statement about what Sundance has become - namely, a brand to be readily exploited by whoever wants to set up shop and give away medicated lip gloss. Still, there are pearls among the swine.

To our minds, an Abba theme park should be an experience that's so ridiculously fun you're ashamed to tell your friends you actually enjoy it. The organizers behind Abbaworld, a new museum/theme park dedicated to the lives and work of that best-selling Swedish pop quartet, have something a little more reverential in mind: The Associated Press reported that Abbaworld, scheduled to open in London on Wednesday, will offer 25 rooms and more than 30,000 square feet of Abba-related fare, chronicling the ascent of Bjorn Ulvaeus, Anna-Frid Lyngstad, Benny Andersson and Agnetha Faltskog from their teenage years to the present day. Amid the displays of silk, satin and spandex costumes, visitors are also promised re-creations of the band's recording studio and the seaside cabin where Mr. Ulvaeus and Mr. Andersson composed many of the band's hits; an exhibition that allows aspiring performers to sing and dance alongside an animated version of the band; and an audio guide recorded by Stellan Skarsgard, the Swedish actor who starred in the film version of "Mamma Mia!" Magnus Danielsson, the president of Touring Exhibitions, the company behind the museum, told The A.P. that the guiding principle behind its design was,"How do we give the visitor a big hug in each room?" He added that he was a big Abba fan growing up, but switched to hard rock when he changed schools.

Bush will have to wait for memoir No. 2: on Tuesday, Ms. Rice, the former secretary of state and national security adviser, and her publisher, the Crown Publishing Group, said that the first release in a two-book deal signed by Ms. Rice last February would discuss her growing up against the backdrop of the civil rights movement. In a news release Crown said that the book, called "Extraordinary, Ordinary People," would chronicle Ms. Rice's childhood in Birmingham, Ala., from the "seemingly placid 1950s, when Birmingham blacks lived in a segregated parallel universe," through "the shockingly violent '60s when Rice saw girlhood friends lose their lives to the bloodshed." The book would also emphasize Ms. Rice's role models, including her parents, John and Angelena.

The claim, repeated in movies and sitcoms, convinced generations of women that if they weren't married by 40, it probably wasn't going to happen.

Rafael Nadal, the defending Australian Open champion, retired midway through the third set in his quarterfinal match against Andy Murray. Already down by two sets to love, Nadal injured his knee in the second game of the third set while running wide for a forehand. But Nadal's injury obscures the real story of the match, the brilliant all-court play of Murray. He had an answer for Nadal's best tennis, playing with a stunning blend of power, masterly defense and deft volleying.

Dance artists from around the world will converge in the bucolic Berkshires of Massachusetts for the 78th annual Jacob's Pillow festival this summer. This year's festival, which runs from June 19 through Aug. 29, will showcase more than 50 companies from nine countries and four continents. Highlights include three world premieres from the young choreographers Kyle Abraham, Monica Bill Barnes, and Camille A. Brown as well as the United States debut of the Goteborg Ballet of Sweden. The ballerina Nina Ananiashvili will help open the season at a gala event on June 19 with a performance of "The Dying Swan." That program will also include a world premiere by Karole Armitage. Dance Theater of Harlem, Shantala Shivalingappa, Bill T. Jones/Arnie Zane Dance Company, Trey McIntyre Project and Hubbard Street Dance Chicago are among the companies and artists also slated to appear throughout the season. In addition to performances, the festival also includes talks with the artists, film showings, exhibits and over 75 dance classes for the community.

Bob Dylan, Jennifer Hudson and Smokey Robinson are among the artists who will participate in the White House's first music event of 2010, the White House said on Tuesday in a news release. The concert, called "In Performance at the White House: A Celebration of Music From the Civil Rights Movement," will be on Feb. 10 in the State Dining Room, and is timed to celebrate Black History Month. Other performers on the bill include Natalie Cole, John Legend, John Mellencamp, Seal, the Blind Boys of Alabama, and the Howard University Choir. It will be hosted by Morgan Freeman and Queen Latifah, and will feature songs associated with the civil rights movement as well as readings from famous civil rights speeches. The concert is the latest event in the White House music series started last year by Michelle Obama, and will be broadcast on public television and streamed live online at whitehouse.gov.

Somehow this heady stew of African-inflected alt-rock managed to top two of the best-selling artists of the last few months: the late-blooming juggernaut Susan Boyle and the confectionery rapper Ke$ha.

Even among music fans whose tastes are omnivorous enough to include the Beatles and the Wu-Tang Clan, most people would not necessarily want to listen to both bands at the same time. Most people are not Tom Caruana, a 28-year-old music teacher and producer from Brighton, England, who spent about two months stitching together Beatles and Wu-Tang samples to create "Enter the Magical Mystery Chambers," a mashup album that unites the Fab Four and the fearsome hip-hop collective.

My sense from fielding reader comments on the Fifth Down is that a fair number of Giants fans supported the Jets during the playoffs, many were neutral, and a smaller percentage rooted against the Jets.

Making Sure More Students Get Degrees | On Wednesday, California State University's trustees will discuss a plan to boost graduation rates at its 23 campuses. The national graduate rate for a four-year university is 53 percent for entering classes who were freshmen in the fall of 2001, according to USA Today. The overall goal is an eight percent increase in the system's six-year graduation rate by 2016, the chancellor's office said. Those campuses already in the top quartile of national graduation rates are to increase their rates by six percent. For freshmen beginning in 2002, the East Bay campus had a 44 percent graduation rate. In San Jose, it was 41 percent and in San Francisco it was 44 percent. [California Watch]

The State Supreme Court voided charges against five of six former members of San Diego’s pension board who had been accused of casting votes that benefited them. Because of an editing error, an obituary on Saturday about Irwin Dambrot, the former City College basketball star, omitted a survivor. In addition to his sons, Stuart and Jonathan; his brother, Sidney; and three grandchildren, Mr. Dambrot is survived by a daughter, Donna.

A television review and a headline on Friday about “Caprica,” on the Syfy channel, misstated the time frame of that series and its predecessor, “Battlestar Galactica.” The events take place in the distant past, not the future, and the colonizers of the planet Caprica are ancestors of present-day humans, not their descendants.

She is president and chief executive, not president and chief economic officer.

Calandra Italian American Institute of Queens College on the MTV reality show “Jersey Shore” misstated the contribution of the playwright Mario Fratti to the Broadway musical “Nine.” Mr. Fratti, who took part in a question and answer session, is credited with the adaptation from the Italian version he wrote; Arthur Kopit, not Mr. Fratti, wrote the musical’s book.

An article on Monday about President Obama’s planned State of the Union proposals intended to help middle-class families described incorrectly nonrefundable tax credits, like the expanded child care credit Mr. Obama is expected to propose for families earning less than $85,000. Nonrefundable credits are those that do not result in cash payments for people who pay no income tax. They reduce the tax liability, and therefore may increase the refund, of households that do pay taxes.

“It can be hard to get past the pedigree when considering Charlotte Gainsbourg,” writes Jodi Rosen. But the daughter of the Gallic pop great and provocateur Serge Gainsbourg and Jane Birkin, the English actress and vocalist, is an artist to be reckoned with in her own right. She recently released an album, “IRM,” produced and largely written by Beck, and the stylish star, who took home the best actress award last year at Cannes for her role in Lars von Trier’s controversial “Antichrist,” is also the subject of a film retrospective at the French Institute Alliance Française. Today, catch a screening of “Happily Ever After,” which features Ms. Gainsbourg and her husband Yvan Attal in what Stephen Holden wrote is a “breezy, skin-deep sex comedy.”

In his new book, “I Am Ozzy,” the reality television star and former Black Sabbath frontman Ozzy Osbourne offers what might be, according to Amy Virshup, the most honest disclaimer ever from a memoirist: “Other people’s memories of the stuff in this book might not be the same as mine. I ain’t gonna argue with ’em. Over the past 40 years I’ve been loaded on booze, coke, acid, Quaaludes, glue, cough mixture, heroin, Rohypnol, Klonopin, Vicodin, and too many other heavy-duty substances to list in this footnote. On more than a few occasions I was on all of those at the same time.” Tonight, head to Borders at Columbus Circle, where the author will sign books and shed some light on how he kept track of his journey from working-class kid from Aston to animal-biting rock star.

“At his peak, in the 1550s, Bronzino was the most influential painter in Florence,” writes Holland Cotter. “Why, given his fame, this artist has had to wait some 500 years for a museum solo is a puzzle.” But finally that solo, called “The Drawings of Bronzino,” has arrived at the Metropolitan Museum of Art. Go to discover this artist, the son of a butcher who inspired Henry James and was “thoroughly embedded in Florentine high culture, with its weave of European urbanity and Tuscan particularity.” The show, which encompasses all but two of the 61 works on paper currently attributed to the artist, “is a scholarly tour de force.”

On Sunday at the Sundance Film Festival in Park City, Utah, Lionsgate paid an estimated $3.5 million for “Buried,” a Spanish thriller starring Ryan Reynolds as a civil contractor in Iraq who awakens to find himself buried alive in a wooden coffin. His captors have given him nothing but a lighter and a cellphone, which he must use to meet their ransom demand before he suffocates. Tagline: “170,000 square miles of desert. 90 minutes of oxygen.” “Buried,” sold by United Talent Agency, was a hot item for buyers going into the festival for several reasons. Genre films typically don’t have much downside — they are cheap to make and comparatively easy to market. And if that marketing is executed properly they can become phenomena with young audiences. (See: “Paranormal Activity.”) Although he has yet to show he can anchor a movie, Mr. Reynolds is a budding heavyweight. Warner Brothers recently hired him to play the lead in “Green Lantern,” a megapicture planned for summer 2011.

China, it can be safely said, has a complicated relationship with “Avatar.” Last week it was reported that the 2-D version of this science-fiction epic, directed by James Cameron, was being pulled from many Chinese theaters. Now a mountain there is being renamed for a peak seen in the film. In a ceremony on Monday the Southern Sky Column in Zhangjiajie City, in Hunan province, was formally renamed the Avatar Hallelujah Mountains, Reuters reported, citing the local government’s Web site (www.zjj.gov.cn/website/). The name change seemed to be an effort to stir the interest of Chinese tourists, who have helped “Avatar” sell more than $100 million in tickets, breaking box-office records in the country. Travel companies have already begun offering tours that emphasize the region’s resemblance to Pandora, the lush alien moon depicted in “Avatar.” On its site, the municipal government wrote: “Pandora is far but Zhangjiajie is near. Welcome to Zhangjiajie to see ‘Avatar’s’ Hallelujah Mountains and discover the real world of Pandora.”.

HARRINGTON--William F.,affectionately known as "BJ", passed away on January 23, 2010 at the age of 78. Born on December 3, 1931 in Yonkers, New York to William Patrick and Jane Harrington, he attended St. Joseph's Grammar School and Gorton High School in Yonkers. He received a degree in accounting from Manhattan College in 1953 and his law degree from Fordham University School of Law in 1959. He joined the law firm of Bleakley Platt and Schmidt in White Plains, New York in 1959 where he practiced law for 51 years and served as the law firm's chairman and managing partner for 35 years. He was an accomplished attorney in trust and estate litigation and oversaw the growth of Bleakley Platt into one of the premier law firms in the region. He served as Legislative Council to Lt. Governor Malcolm Wilson between 1964 and 1973 and Town Attorney of Pound Ridge from 1980 to 1985 and Town Justice between 1985 and 1991. A devout and dedicated Roman Catholic, BJ served his church and the Archdiocese of New York throughout his life. He was a Trustee of St. Joseph's Seminary and St. Patrick's Cathedral, a member of the Cardinal's Committee of the Laity and the Archdiocese's Inner City Scholarship Fund. He served as the Chairman of St. Agnes Hospital in White Plains, New York and as Vice Chairman of St. Joseph's Medical Center's Health Fund in Yonkers, New York. He was a proud member of the Friendly Sons of St. Patrick of Westchester County, serving as the Chairman of the Society's Board of Stewards for over 25 years. Mr. Harrington also served on the Board of Directors of his beloved Fordham Law School, where he was instrumental in the creation of the Cardinal John O'Connor Chair for Theological Studies. He also served as a founding member of the Boards of Directors of Pace Law School and The Ave Maria School of Law. He also served as a member of the Board of Directors of Sacred Heart High School, Iona Preparatory School and the School of The Holy Child. At the time of his death, BJ was the moving force behind the construction of the new Elizabeth Seton Pediatric hospital in Yonkers, serving as the Hospital's Capital Campaign Chairman. BJ was a Knight of Malta, Knight of the Order of St. Gregory the Great and humbly accepted various awards throughout his life including St. Thomas Moore Award, The Fordham Law School Medal of Achievement, the Charles Carroll Award from the Catholic Guild of Lawyers, The Cardinal's Committee of Laity Award, the Pro Eccelesia Et Pontifice Medal and the Humanitarian Award for Life. In addition BJ proudly served as Grand Marshall for the Yonkers St. Patrick's Day Parade. BJ is survived by his loving wife of 55 years Audrey (Kazimir), his sons William (Carolyn) Harrington of Pound Ridge, New York, Brian (Elizabeth) Harrington of Pound Ridge, New York, Peter (Danielle) Harrington of Waccabuc, New York and daughters Mary Pat McCarthy and Mary Beth Harrington of Pound Ridge, New York and nine grandchildren Caitlyn, Meagan, Emily, Luke, William, Finian, Caroline, Hanna, P.J. and Jill. He is also survived by his two loving sisters Mary Harrington and Jane Devlin. Visiting hours will be in Whalen & Ball Funeral Home on Tuesday from 2-4 and 7-9pm. A Mass of Christian Burial will be on Wednesday in St. Patrick's Cathedral at 10:15am. Interment will follow at Cemetery of the Gate of Heaven in Valhalla, New York.

Inspiration struck somewhere below 20,000 feet. The little propeller plane was descending through fluffy clouds after what must have been a bumpy flight. One of the passengers was staring out the window, and the clouds seemed to be cushioning the descent. And then it dawned on him: He and his business partner could market cushioning material for shipping.

The showdown between President Cristina Fernández de Kirchner and the nation's central bank president will shift to Congress on Tuesday, as lawmakers take up the fight over tapping the bank's reserves to pay the country's debts. The dispute between the nation's president and her central bank chief has shaken financial markets and has stirred new concerns about the policies of Mrs. Kirchner's government. Last year, her government nationalized Argentina's largest airline and seized $30 billion in private pension funds -- signs that the government is short of cash but unwilling to cut back populist subsidy programs.

Wall Street shares closed higher on Monday as investors tried to look beyond the blistering losses of the previous week. Talk of the potential for more steep declines lingered, however, as traders nervously studied data on the fragile housing market and reports of more layoffs.

Yemen's Houthi rebels offered a truce to Saudi Arabia on Monday, after three months of fighting on the remote border of the two countries. In an audio recording posted on the Internet, the Houthi rebel leader, Abdul-Malik al-Houthi, said the truce was intended to avoid bloodshed and civilian deaths. But he added that the rebels would wage ''open war'' if Saudi Arabia did not end its hostilities. Saudi Arabia has lost at least 113 soldiers in the conflict, according to Saudi officials. The Saudis became involved in early November, when Houthi fighters shot and killed a Saudi border guard.

With few exceptions, medical practitioners take a one-size-fits-all approach when prescribing drugs to adults, whether the patient is petite or extra large. That is a mistake, said two doctors writing in the medical journal The Lancet. They argue that dosages of antibiotics should be based on a patient's size, with higher doses for heavier patients.

GARFINKEL--Lawrence, 88, died in Seattle, WA on January 21, 2010. He was a prominent epidemiologist with the American Cancer Society (ACS) and led ground-breaking studies that proved the link between smoking and cancer and other diseases. He was a modest and kind person with impeccable integrity, and was devoted to his family. We will miss him. Born on January 11, 1922, he was a graduate of Morris High School and CCNY, and served in the Army Infantry during World War II. When he retired from ACS, he was its Director of Research Programs and Vice President of Epidemiology. Under his guidance, ACS initiated Cancer Prevention Study II, which is the largest contemporary study of tobacco and mortality. He contributed to many scientific articles on cancer and public health. Any donations in his honor should go to the American Cancer Society. A memorial service in Seattle is planned.

GREBIN--Burton. The Board of Directors and Staff of St. Mary's Healthcare System for Children are deeply saddened by the death of Burton Grebin, MD, our beloved President and CEO, on Sunday, January 24, 2010. Dr. Grebin dedicated his life to improving the health and quality of life for children with special needs and their families. A true advocate for the most vulnerable among us, he created programs for kids when none existed. Under Dr. Grebin's leadership, St. Mary's established the nation's first Palliative Care program for children; New York State's first long-term home care program for children; New York's first and largest home care program for children and families with HIV/AIDS; New York City's first certified Traumatic Brain Injury and Coma Recovery Program for children; and one of only nine interdisciplinary pediatric feeding disorder programs in the U.S. Dr. Grebin transformed St. Mary's from a 40-bed nursing home for children into a $100 million healthcare system that is the New York region's largest provider of post-acute care for children, serving more than 4,000 children in the hospital or in their homes every day. Children's healthcare has suffered a great loss with Dr. Grebin's passing. Our heartfelt condolences to the Grebin Family and Dr. Grebin's dear partner, Susan Gold.

Ali Hassan al-Majid, a symbol of the former government of Saddam Hussein who ordered a poison gas attack on a Kurdish village in northern Iraq, was executed Monday. An Iraqi court had sentenced Mr. Majid, 68, to death by hanging last week. Mr. Majid, known as Chemical Ali for his role in the 1988 attack on the village of Halabja, in which more than 5,000 Kurds died, was perhaps the most notorious figure from the former government to be executed since Mr. Hussein was hanged in December 2006.

New Jersey's new governor, Christopher J. Christie, wants the Nets to pay a $7.5 million penalty if the team breaks its lease at the Izod Center and moves to the Prudential Center in Newark next season. The suggestion was included in a 20-page document issued by the New Jersey Gaming, Sports and Entertainment Committee of the governor's transition team. The report, compiled before the governor took office last Tuesday, focuses largely on the state's casinos and horse racing, both of which, the committee said, were ''broken.''

Judi Chamberlin, whose involuntary confinement in a mental hospital in the 1960s propelled her into a lifelong leading role in the movement to guarantee basic human rights to psychiatric patients, died on Jan. 16 at her home in Arlington, Mass. She was 65. The cause was pulmonary disease, said Martin Federman, her companion since 2006.

BRENNAN--Len, died January 17, 2010 in New York City at age 91. Beloved husband of Helen Cleary Brennan, also survived by loving daughter Heidi Brennan, dear grandson Christopher Brennan and long time friend Robert Hayden. Born July 9, 1918 in Ripon California. Len graduated from Oakland's University HS, received a BA from UC Berkeley in 1940 and an EdD in 1971 from Columbia University's Teachers College. During WWII he served as Master Sergeant in England then as Second Lieutenant in Europe. Len was a Principal in Alameda County, worked for the U.S. Virgin Islands Department of Education and retired in 1977 after ten years as a professor in Brooklyn College's Department of Education. His joys included gardening, listening to classical music, becoming an Eagle Scout, working at Yosemite National Park, and overseeing the design and building of two homes, one in the Oakland hills and the other on the North Fork of Long Island. Len was the exemplar of the gentle man, kind, caring, and witty but never harsh. His many friends will miss the sparkle in his eye and the pleasure of his company over a glass of wine. Memorial contributions may be made to Pax Christi Hospice, 170 W. 12th Street, New York, NY 10011 or to Brooklyn Botanic Garden, 1000 Washington Avenue, Brooklyn, NY 11225.
Well Theresa Brown posted at nytimes.com/well.

SUMANIS--Helmuts "Monty," passed peacefully with family on January 19, 2010. Born on July 10th, 1926 in Riga, Latvia. He lived an adventurous life surviving German and Russian occupations of Riga during WWII. After being separated from family he traveled to Poland, Germany, Holland and eventually England where, thanks to the Red Cross, he was reunited with his mother Ida and brother Roland. He joined the Merchant Marines out of Holy Head Wales and sailed to Spain and Africa. He was seriously injured when a ship's scaffold collapsed, and was hospitalized for six months in Durban, South Africa. Returning to England, he worked driving a delivery van for Esposito Provisions, one of his stops was Italico Restaurant on Kingsland Road in London where he met young Rita Santucci. They wed on December 26, 1955 in London. He traveled to the United States and joined the US Army. He served in Europe where he performed the invaluable task of directing troop and equipment movements thanks in part to his practical abilities and fluency in several languages. He was honorably discharged and granted citizenship allowing him to bring his wife to the United States where they started a family. In 1958 he founded Jansons Associates, Inc. with another Latvian, Olgerts Jansons. They specialized in the construction of prefabricated chimneys starting with residential then moving into commercial and industrial. He was instrumental in the development of specialized handling and erection equipment and tirelessly worked with testing labs, city and state agencies, architects, engineers, building developers and contractors to create high quality safety and longevity standards for modern buildings, many of which are still in place today. Rita tragically passed in 1979. Together they had three children, Robert, Maria and Jacqueline. In addition he is survived by grandchildren Julie and Austen Sumanis and Erin and Daniel Moran. Throughout his life his enduring themes were survival, strength, honesty, love and compassion. "He always had a smile". A memorial service and reception to celebrate Monty's life will be held for family and friends beginning at 3:00pm Saturday, January 30, 2010 at the Brady Home, 510 Sicomac Avenue, Wyckoff, NJ 07481. For information please contact: Robert Sumanis, Phone: 201-206-1442, rsumanis@jansonsassociates. com. The family requests that in lieu of flowers, donations be made in memory of Monty Sumanis to the Presbyterian Hospice and Palliative Care, P.O. Box 33549 Charlotte, NC 28233-3349.

Dearly beloved, I have gathered you in this intimate venue of the Internet to bid farewell to "the Old Tavi." The shy, awkward preteen I first encountered almost two years ago has, as of yesterday's sighting at the Paris couture shows, officially gone to the great beyond.When we first met, she was a pocket-size child with Mom's-choice eyeglasses and a tiny helium voice who wore Converse sneakers and a thrifted skirt. When I saw a picture of her in Paris yesterday, I gasped. Newly dyed ice-blue locks, giant sunglasses (indoors, of course) and shocking red lips set in a "No pictures right now, please" pout. She is a confident and poised young woman, who now gets gifted couture hats by Stephen Jones (which received this oddly controversial wearing the day before) and sits front row at Chanel (no big deal). Tavi 2.0 has arrived. And she is major. Farewell, little suburban girl. You will be remembered fondly in the Blogspot archives.

Overview | What is the "choking game"? What dangers and long-term consequences are associated with it and with other ways that teenagers get high aside from using illegal drugs? In this lesson, students reflect on high-risk, readily available, often legal ways teenagers achieve a "high," using stories, facts and statistics to make connections and learn the risks and dangers associated with these activities. Then they go further by making skits or public service announcements to warn classmates or younger students about these dangers.

Anyone inclined to pin all the blame for last Tuesday's Senate outcome on poor hapless Martha Coakley should check out the numbers John Judis has compiled here, which compare Senate polling data to Barack Obama's approval ratings in Ohio, Pennsylvania, Missouri and Colorado. In each case, the trend is clear: As the president's ratings drop, the Democratic Senate candidate's number execute a nosedive as well, and the G.O.P. candidate pulls ahead. None of the plunges are as steep as the one that Coakley took, and none of these states are as solidly Democratic as Massachusetts. But I suspect that in the long run, she'll look less and less like the worst Senate candidate since Alan Keyes, and more and more like the victim of a national climate that was beyond any individual Democrat's control.

Eve Queler, the founder and longtime music director of the Opera Orchestra of New York, who has seen the institution through recent financial struggles, is preparing to step down from her post. The orchestra said in a news release that it had appointed Alberto Veronesi, the Italian conductor, to serve as its full-time music director starting with its 2011-12 season. Ms. Queler, who established the orchestra in 1971 to present concerts by established opera performers and emerging talents -- including Renée Fleming, Deborah Voigt and José Carreras -- will share the baton with Mr. Veronesi for the orchestra's 40th anniversary season in 2010-11. During that time he will serve as music director designate and conduct an opera-in-concert performance. The next season, Ms. Queler will become conductor laureate, and Mr. Veronesi will begin a five-year term. Mr. Veronesi is the music director of the Puccini Festival at Torre del Lago and the Orchestra Sinfonica Siciliana, as well as the artistic director of the Filarmonica del Teatro Comunale di Bologna. He will retain these positions during his time with the Opera Orchestra.

The Bay Area blog has been reporting daily from the federal courthouse in San Francisco on the case of Perry v. Schwarzenegger. That case is challenging the constitutionality of Proposition 8, the ban on same-sex marriage approved by voters in 2008. Among the lawyers on the plaintiffs' team are Theodore B. Olson, David Boies, Theodore J. Boutrous Jr., Christopher Dean Dusseault, Christine Van Aken, Danny Chu, Matthew D. McGill and Therese Stewart. The legal team for the defense includes Brian Raum, Charles J. Cooper, David Thompson, Andrew Pugno, James Campbell, Jordan Lorence, Nicole Moss, Howard C. Nielson Jr. and Peter A. Patterson.

Germany is still stuck in a financial slump, but judging from the nonstop revelry that took place at Mercedes-Benz Berlin Fashion Week, for the country's tastemakers, life is a cabaret. Hugo Boss got the party started on Thursday at the Hamburger Bahnhof museum, with a post-show soiree following its Boss Black runway presentation. Guests, including celebrities like Hillary Swank and Matt Dillon, filed behind the stage and into a massive tent with an L.E.D.-lit dance floor and high-tech digital projections, not to mention four full bars, servers circling with magnums of Champagne and - get this - an open invitation to smoke. Try getting that kind of treatment in New York these days, where austerity is the new black. Compared to the party, which left many guests nursing massive hangovers at the next day's shows, the collection was tame, working a high-end sexy secretary angle for women and a nerd-bird banker vibe for "Mad Men"-loving male clientele.

It was barely a week ago that the Bagger parachuted into Sundance, ready to gorge on movies and parties. Mission accomplished! Though only a few films have sold since then (most notably "Buried"), and a few more have drawn the kind of attention that suggests distribution is imminent, there has been another kind of contest at play: At nearly every post-screening Q.&A. and interview, filmmakers have mentioned how long (or short) their shoot was. It's a badge of honor in the indie film world to get a movie in the can in 24 or 26 days, an indication of how economically (fiscally and timewise) you work. By that metric, "Howl," the artsy feature about Allen Ginsberg, was a winner: it was shot in 14 days.

"Hope for Haiti Now," the download-only album of performances from the Haiti benefit telethon on Friday night, is No. 1 on this week's Billboard chart, outselling Susan Boyle, Lady Gaga and other hits by a wide margin despite being on sale for only part of the week. After going on sale through iTunes shortly before the show began on Friday, the album (released by MTV Networks, and for sale also through Amazon, Napster and Rhapsody) sold 171,000 copies in the United States through Sunday, according to Nielsen SoundScan. It is the first digital-only release to reach No. 1 on the Billboard album chart, and proceeds will benefit relief organizations.

The great 2010 Abba-thon continues: following the news that the best-selling Swedish pop quartet will be honored with its own museum in London, the New York Pops said on Thursday that it is planning an entire concert of Abba music to kick off its 2010-11 season. In a news release, the New York Pops said that it will open its coming season on Oct. 15 at Carnegie Hall with "The Music of Abba," featuring Rajaton, the Finnish vocal ensemble, performing hits like "Dancing Queen," "Mamma Mia" and "Take a Chance on Me." Other events on the Pops schedule include an 80th birthday celebration for Stephen Sondheim on Nov. 19; a holiday concert with Brian Stokes Mitchell on Dec. 10 and 11; a performance of "El Ritmo de la Vida," a new work of Latin music by Doc Severinsen, the former "Tonight Show" band leader, on Jan. 28, 2011; and a concert honoring the 50th anniversary of Judy Garland's Carnegie Hall debut, featuring Ashley Brown, Heather Headley and Karen Olivo, on March 11, 2011. The Pops performances will be conducted by its musical director, Steven Reineke.

The New York Times has run a couple of articles, including this one, in recent weeks about whether it makes sense to walk away from a mortgage that is bigger than the house is now worth. In a recent paper cited in an article on Sunday, a University of Arizona law professor, Brent White, explained that the vast majority of underwater homeowners continued to make mortgage payments even if it might make more financial sense for them to strategically default and walk away.

Carnegie Hall announced its plans for next season on Wednesday. The headlines: There will be a "Perspectives" series led by the singer-songwriter James Taylor and the violinist Christian Tetzlaff, along with a festival dedicated to Japan run by Seiji Ozawa. Valery Gergiev will conduct the Mariinsky Orchestra in most of the Mahler symphony cycle (the remainder of the symphonies will take place at Lincoln Center, with the London Symphony Orchestra).

Daniel Morel, a contributing photographer to Corbis Images, had every reason to be in Haiti when the earthquake struck on Jan. 12. It is his homeland. He was born there in 1951. Though he moved to the United States when he was 18, he returned to Haiti in 1982 and worked for 14 years as a photographer for The Associated Press. He also collaborated with Howard W. French, a Times correspondent, and his photographs of Haiti were published regularly in The Times from 1991 to 1994. Mr. Morel has been working on several book and movie projects. One concerns the band RAM, named for Richard A. Morse, the proprietor of the Hotel Oloffson in Port-au-Prince; another, the Orchestre Septentrional of Cap Haitien, the oldest band in the country. Robert A. Harris, a video journalist for The Times, spoke with Mr. Morel on Friday in Port-au-Prince. The interview has been condensed somewhat and edited for clarity.

The Saints' advance to the Super Bowl has been a lesson in patience. New Orleans has hosted the Super Bowl nine times, but the Saints have never played in one since entering the N.F.L. in 1967. Stocks erased gains in the session's final hour as concerns that the Federal Reserve may signal more plans to unwind stimulus measures overshadowed higher-than-estimated earnings and consumer confidence.

The Austrian banking regulator said Tuesday that it expected "massive write-offs" this year by the country's banks as they recognized more bad loans in Eastern Europe, Judy Dempsey reports in The New York Times.

Knowing there's a good, dependable Chinese restaurant just around the corner can alleviate some of the stress that comes with living in New York. (They should do a test and prove it.) So there's good news for those who live on the Upper East Side or at least willing to hop on a subway and visit. At Szechuan Chalet "there are pleasures to be had," writes Nick Fox. Like Sichuan pork dumplings with roasted red oil, braised flounder fillets perfectly cooked with napa cabbage in chili oil sauce and razor clams with scallion pesto, which has its own attention-getting device: The dish comes arranged in the shape of a peacock, "the bird carved from daikon and its comb made from a carrot. The clams fan out behind it, enrobed in a sauce of scallions, chilies and Sichuan peppercorns. Disneyesque but delicious." Go for these dishes and the ox tongue and tripe with roasted chili and peanut vinaigrette, the "thoughtful service," and a visit from Wei Lu, the chef and an owner who checks on the dining room to make sure everything is all right.

Jimmy Fallon, The Walkmen, Sondre Lerche, Eugene Mirman, The Wrens, Ted Leo and Pat Kiernan of NY 1. No, it's not some weird only-in-New-York fantasy team, but the partial lineup for "Strength Through Unity," a benefit for the victims of the Haiti earthquake at the Bell House tonight. Also on the eclectic bill will be Michael Showalter, Here We Go Magic, AC Newman of the New Pornographers and Rhett Miller of Old 97s, plus Nicole Atkins as a Seekers cover band, New York State Senator Diane Savino and many more. Go grab an Asian Dog, available all night for $2, and listen to the sets as well as the guest D.J.'s, including Au Revoir Simone, and a special two-hour edition of keyboard karaoke hosted by Joe McGinty and Sara Schaffer. Things get cooking at 6 p.m.

Sam Mendes's new take on Shakespeare's "As You Like It" suits the season. The "tough-minded, wintry" production, which opened Tuesday night at the Brooklyn Academy of Music's Harvey Theater, is the first show in the Bridge Project's second season. "Mr. Mendes's arrestingly somber staging of Shakespeare's pastoral comedy firmly favors adversity over sweetness," writes Charles Isherwood. "For all the spirited comedy of 'As You Like It,' true love arrives only after strenuous study and emotional hardship." Thankfully, comic relief does come in the form of the vagabond philosopher Jaques, played with "sly and subtle wit by the terrific British actor Stephen Dillane." Christian Camargo, Michelle Beck and Juliet Rylance also star in the play, which "makes clear that the human heart is fickle, easily deceived, sometimes perfidious. The mettle of love must be tried and tested, and tried again, before its sweet felicities can be safely indulged."

Readers who await Condoleezza Rice’s reflections on her years in the White House of George W. Bush will have to wait for memoir No. 2: on Tuesday Ms. Rice, left, the former secretary of state and national security adviser, and her publisher, the Crown Publishing Group, said in a statement that the first release in a two-book deal signed by Ms. Rice last February would discuss her childhood in Birmingham, Ala., in the 1950s and ’60s against the backdrop of the civil rights movement. The book would also emphasize Ms. Rice’s role models, including her parents, John and Angelena. In a statement Ms. Rice said: “After I left Washington it seemed important to write about how my very special parents, my extended family and so many mentors shaped me for the challenges that lay ahead. I decided that was the story I wanted to tell first.”.

Dance artists from around the world will converge in the bucolic Berkshires of Massachusetts for the 78th annual Jacob’s Pillow festival this summer. This year’s festival, which runs from June 19 through Aug. 29, will showcase more than 50 companies from nine countries. Highlights include three world premieres from the young choreographers Kyle Abraham, Monica Bill Barnes and Camille A. Brown, as well as the American debut of the Goteborg Ballet of Sweden. The ballerina Nina Ananiashvili will help open the season at a gala event on June 19 with a performance of “The Dying Swan.” The gala will also include a world premiere by Karole Armitage. Dance Theater of Harlem, Shantala Shivalingappa, Bill T. Jones/Arnie Zane Dance Company, Trey McIntyre Project and Hubbard Street Dance Chicago are among the companies and artists also scheduled to appear throughout the festival.

The real drama was offstage at Monday night’s rehearsal reading of “Much Ado About Nothing” at the Classic Stage Company, after an audience member rose and wandered toward the actors’ dressing rooms while the performers were working on the piece. According to executives involved with Classic Stage Company, an Off Broadway house in the East Village, the actor F. Murray Abraham, who was in the audience, noticed the man slipping out. Mr. Abraham, above, got up and spoke to the house manager, and the two of them went backstage and found the man hiding under a table in a dressing room. The house manager shouted that a robbery was under way, while Mr. Abraham and the man scuffled, with the intruder punching Mr. Abraham. Cast members ran backstage as the intruder fled; in the aftermath, company members discovered that a bag belonging to the actress Martha Plimpton — who was participating in the reading — was missing, as well as the wallet of another actress. The police were soon on the scene and are investigating. Mr. Abraham did not require medical attention, only a bag of ice.

The Broadway producer Ken Davenport and the director David Esbjornson are on the hunt for a star actor to play the lead in a planned revival of Aaron Sorkin’s breakthrough play, “A Few Good Men,” which they are aiming for Broadway next season. With an increasingly high premium put on casting stars for Broadway revivals to help sell tickets, an executive involved in the casting process said on Tuesday that Mr. Davenport (“Oleanna,” “13”) and Mr. Esbjornson (“The Goat, or Who Is Sylvia?”) had begun scouting star talent for the role of Lt. Daniel Kaffee, a Navy lawyer who investigates a murder at the Guantánamo Bay Naval Base in Cuba. Tom Hulce played the part in the original 1989 production — and was nominated for a Tony Award for best actor — and Tom Cruise played Kaffee in the 1992 film. This would be the first revival of the play since it closed at the Music Box Theater on Jan. 26, 1991.

Bob Dylan; Jennifer Hudson, near right; and Smokey Robinson, far right, are among the artists who will participate in the White House’s first music event of 2010, according to a news release on Tuesday. The concert, “In Performance at the White House: A Celebration of Music From the Civil Rights Movement,” will be held on Feb. 11 in the State Dining Room, and is timed to celebrate Black History Month. Other performers on the bill include Natalie Cole, John Legend, John Mellencamp, Seal, the Blind Boys of Alabama and the Howard University Choir. It will be hosted by Morgan Freeman and Queen Latifah. The concert is the latest event in a music series started last year by Michelle Obama, and will be broadcast on public television and streamed live online at whitehouse.gov.

Though it may be the only way forward for President Obama's domestic priority, it seems increasingly unlikely that House Democrats will be persuaded to pass the Senate health care legislation. GREBIN--Burton, M.D. The family of Burton Grebin, M.D. is deeply saddened by the loss of our father, grandfather, uncle, and partner. A man of determination, intelligence, and compassion, he was known professionally as a tireless champion of children with special needs. To us, his loved ones, he was a teacher and role model who instilled in us the virtues of integrity, dedication and humor. Burt was one of the funniest and wittiest people we knew, loving jokes pitched both high and low. His ability to spontaneously generate puns is unsurpassed. Burt was devoted to his family - his late mother Mary; son Perry; son Jason, daughter-in-law Lorie and their children Lucy, Zoe, and Millie; nephew Scott Cholewa; and dear partner Susan Gold. He was extremely proud of his three beautiful granddaughters, his partners in cake-baking and lesser crimes, as well as the happy subjects of his virtuoso photography. They will always remember his wild stories and their playful tugs on his beard. On all things medical, he was a font of wisdom and experience, the "go to guy" for advice, or an instant referral to one of his many brilliant colleagues and co-workers. A master tinkerer, Burt shared his many hobbies with us - photography, ham radio, electronics, computers - all self-taught to expert status. He was inveterately curious and a voracious learner. We will miss his sense of humor, his spontaneous puns, and his sunny disposition. But most of all, we will miss him. Funeral service is scheduled for Wednesday, January 27, 11:45am at The Riverside, 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave., NYC. The family requests that donations be made in his honor to St. Mary's Healthcare System for Children, 29-01 216th Street, Bayside, NY 11360, 718-281-8890, www.stmaryskids.org

FELTON--Edgar C. (Ned), died in peace on January 25th, 2010 at his new home in Falmouth, Maine after a brave 10 year battle with cancer. He was a loving and beloved husband, father, grandfather, father-in-law, brother, uncle, cousin and friend, and is survived by his wife, Molly, of fifty years. A memorial service to celebrate his life will be held on June 19th at 11am at St. Brendan-the-Navigator church in North Deer Isle, Maine. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to VNA Home Health and Hospice, 50 Foden Road, South Portland, ME 04106 or Opera House Arts, P.O. Box 56, Stonington, ME 04681.
