If you buy the old rumors that Disney animators sometimes slipped pornographic images into their artwork, then you can probably also readily imagine that writers of Disney teenage comedies like ''Jonas'' and ''Wizards of Waverly Place'' sit around after hours, knock back a few and concoct raunchy versions of their standard scripts. If that were true, ''The Inbetweeners'' is what they might come up with: filthy, hilarious and much truer to actual teenage life than anything they produce on company time. But Disney moonlighters can't take credit for this brash show; it comes from Britain via BBC America, the work of Damon Beesley and Iain Morris, who have a few ''Flight of the Conchords'' writing credits and a genuine feel for the awkward beast that is teenage life.

FEIEREISEN--Ruth. Park East Synagogue mourns the passing of Ruth Feiereisen, beloved mother of our devoted members Henry (Miriam) Feiereisen. Deepest sympathy to the entire family. Rabbi Arthur Schneier Herman Hochberg, President

SCANLON--Donald Patrick, Jr.,of Bronxville, NY, died peacefully at home surrounded by his family on January 25, 2010. He was 57. He was the son of Donald P. Scanlon, Sr. and Mary Anna (Connor) Scanlon. Don worked as a limited partner for Bear Stearns from 1977 to 1995 and as Senior Managing Director at Gordon, Haskett Capital Corporation from 1995 to 2009. He was co-founder of the Wall Street Charity Fund and was actively involved in the Lymphoma Society. He was a member of the State Trooper Foundation of New York. He was a graduate of Iona Prep and Villanova University. While at Villanova, he was captain of the Villanova golf team. He created and was president of the Irish-American Golf Scholarship Fund. Don also founded the Villanova Boxing Team and was a Golden Glove contender. On October 15, 1977 he married Daria C. Fugazy at St. Patrick's Cathedral in New York City. They have resided in Bronxville, NY for thirty years. Locally, he was a member of the St. Joseph's Roman Catholic Church and Winged Foot Golf Club. Don is survived by his parents, and his father-in-law, William D. Fugazy; by his wife, Daria, and his children, Donald Patrick Scanlon, III (Stefanie), Matthew, and Caitlyn; his siblings, Colleen, Michael, Eddie (Betty), and Luke (Stephanie); numerous other family members and friends. The family will receive visitors at McGrath Funeral Home, 20 Cedar, Bronxville, NY on Wednesday, 6-9pm, and Thursday, 2-4 and 7-9pm. Mass of Christian Burial will be held at 10am on Friday, January 29, at St. Joseph's Catholic Church, in Bronxville, NY. Interment will be at Greenwood Union Cemetery, Harrison, NY. Friends may send memorial donations to Calvary Hospital, Bronx, NY and Memorial Sloane-Kettering Hospital, New York, NY.

The United States ski team Tuesday announced the 22 Alpine racers who would compete in the 2010 Vancouver Olympics, and although there were no surprises, it did affirm that Bode Miller, barring injury in the next few weeks, would return for his fourth Games. Miller, who will compete in multiple events, was one of 12 men selected to the team. Lindsey Vonn, who will compete in five events, led the women's team. Two defending Olympic champions were also in the group: Ted Ligety, who won a gold medal at the 2006 Turin Olympics in the combined, and Julia Mancuso, who won the giant slalom in 2006.

If the name ''Mike'' is conjured on the Upper East Side, chances are that the incumbent mayor will come to mind. (Here he is on East 81st Street after voting in the mayoral election in November.) The city's streets, however, inhabit a scale of time far beyond any political cycle. Perhaps the otherwise anonymous ''Mike'' who wrote his name in wet concrete seven years ago has left an even more enduring mark, at least on this Upper East Side corner. Earlier pictures in the series are at nytimes.com/lens.

WILLSON--Rosemary. The Juilliard School community deeply mourns the death of Rosemary Willson, a special friend of the School who did so much to support our programs. Through her gentle personality, determination, and creative experience in the theater, Rosemary transformed Juilliard's programs through her support of the first residence hall in the School's history and the recent creation of the Rosemary and Meredith Willson Theater at Juilliard, which will provide a state of the art environment to bring together performing artists with the most recent technological innovations in the arts. We will miss her caring presence and special enthusiasm for Juilliard's students. Her legacy will live at Juilliard in the time ahead. Bruce Kovner, Chairman Joseph W. Polisi, President

SCHNEIDERMAN--Seymour. A true mensch, who personified family and all that is good in the world, passed away on January 25, 2010 at 82. He is survived and will be deeply missed by his devoted wife Sunny, his loving children, grandchildren and great-grandchildren as well as his many friends in New York City, Garrison and his extended family at Symphony Fabrics. Seymour was born on October 21, 1927 in New York. He graduated from Stuyvesant High School and then New York University. After serving in the Army he started working at Symphony. He eventually became the sole owner of Symphony transforming it into one of the most successful and respected names in the garment industry. Seymour was devoted to his family and charitable causes throughout his life including U.J.A., Shaare Zedek and Temple Emanuel. A funeral service will be held on Thursday, January 28th at Riverside Chapel, 76th Street and Amsterdam Ave., at 10am.

The Mets' options of pitchers to fill out their rotation are shrinking rapidly. On Tuesday, Jon Garland agreed to a deal with the San Diego Padres, and Ben Sheets went to the Oakland Athletics. The Mets were interested in each player. That leaves 42-year-old John Smoltz as the primary target, with 35-year-old Jarrod Washburn another possibility. The Mets have also shown interest in the Japanese left-hander Hisanori Takahashi, formerly of the Yomiuri Giants, who could be used as a long reliever and emergency starter.

SMITH--Ruth Proskauer. Compassion & Choices remembers Ruth Proskauer Smith - (1907 2010), an icon in the movement for freedom of choice at the end of life. Her death honored the extraordinary life she led. Her courage, advocacy and unfailing support for human liberty will enable millions who follow her to achieve the life, and the death, they choose.

MANDELL--Mel. Son of Sylvia (nee Burg) Ainsberg, 83. Graduated Bronx Science and Columbia with BS and MA. Navy lieutenant in WWII and Korea. Wrote ten books including "Being Safe," a Literary Guild Selection. Editor of many magazines, notably Computer Decisions. Wrote for The New York Times, New York Magazine, Popular Mechanics, World Trade and more. Loving father of Matthew and doting grandfather to Maya and Cayne. He will be missed. Funeral service 11:30am today at Plaza Jewish Community Chapel.

An article on Tuesday about the fallout from the failed deal for Stuyvesant Town and Peter Cooper Village, the two largest apartment complexes in Manhattan, misidentified one investor that stands to lose its entire stake. It is the Newcastle Investment Corporation, a public company managed by the Fortress Investment Group -- not Fortress itself. (The same error appeared in an accompanying chart in some editions.) The article also misspelled the abbreviation for another investor, the California State Teachers' Retirement System. It is known as Calstrs, not Calsters. And the chart also reversed the amounts invested by Calstrs and the Florida state pension fund. Calstrs invested $100 million, and the Florida fund invested $250 million.

BERRY--William Augustus: September 29, 1933, Jacksonville, TX - January 3, 2010, Columbia, MO. Artist, author, illustrator, Professor Berry's work was shown in 500 exhibits, awarded over 120 prizes. Innovative drawing, luminous color and unusual compositions earned invitations to artists' colonies: Altos de Chavon, Dominican Republic; Montalvo Center for Arts; MacDowell Colony; Lacoste School of Arts, France; Camargo Foundation, France; Rockefeller Foundation, Italy. Collections include: Boston Museum of Fine Arts, Addison Gallery; Stedman Gallery, Rutgers; Muscarelle Museum of Art; Glenn Lowry, Craig Lucas, Helen Hayes and Wanda Landowska. His book Drawing the Human Form (1977, 1994), cited as "excellent" by Ernst Gombrich, remains a classic text. In the 1960s, Berry's illustrations appeared in: Newsweek, Esquire, The New Leader, The Reporter, Harper's, John Hopkins, Holiday, Mid-East, Opera News, The NY Times, Sports Illustrated, TV Guide; and books: Kennedy Without Tears, Tom Wicker; Still Quiet on the Western Front, Gene Smith; On Firm Ice, Carter Wilson; and A Journey to the Arctic, Knud Rasmussen. He was the first Art Director of Texas Monthly and designer/consultant for art books, WS Benson Co. Trained at UT Austin (BFA), and USC (MFA) he taught at UT, Boston University, and University of Missouri-Columbia, where he was Director of Graduate Studies, Department Chair, and Curators' Professor of Art. Mr. Berry, son of William Lafayette Berry and Esther Cory, leaves his wife, Janet; sister, Dixie; nieces: Gay Lynn Sneed; Jaye Lynn Boyack; Faye Lynn Quast; and many friends and students who revered and loved him. Checks may be made to UMC Dept. of Art, memo FBO Rollins Scholarship/Memory Wm Berry. Send to: Univ. of Missouri, A126 Fine Arts Bldg. Columbia, MO 65211.

LAPID--Louis S.,MD on January 25 at the age of 95. Beloved husband of Lucille (Bobrow) for 68 years, devoted father to Linda (Steve Kates), Jeffrey (Susan Abraham) and Barbara Lapid (deceased). Adored Pop-Pop of Elizabeth Rothman (Joel), David Kates (Amy), Jennifer Ashkinaze (Alan) and Samantha Young, doting great-grandfather of Madeline, Alison, Matthew, Daniel, Jack and Ben. Louis Lapid born Chicago, received his medical degree at the University of Illinois, and served residencies at Mt. Sinai Hospital in New York and Harvard, then establishing an OB/GYN practice in New York City, which he maintained until his 93rd year. He was associated with the Mt. Sinai Hospital, professor at Mt. Sinai School of Medicine, president of the Associated Alumni of the hospital, recipient of the coveted Jacobi Medallion, and a member of the New York Obstetrical Society. A brilliant and caring physician, revered by his thousands of patients, he will be missed by all.

CLEMENTS--Edith, age 94, passed away peacefully in her sleep on January 26. She was preceded in death by her loving husband, Henry, to whom she was married for 70 years. She is survived by her children, Barbara Finkelstein and Peter Clements, as well as eleven grandchildren and great-grandchildren. Edith was a multi-faceted talent with exquisite taste. Her selflessness, generosity and devotion to her family will always inspire us. Barbara, Peter, Leslie, Hillary, George, Ross, Donald, MaryEllen, Paul, Jean, Richard, Suzy, Neil, Michael, Leah, Brad, Mikal, Jenna, Max, Noah and Natasha.

SCHNEIDER--Barbara. Our dear Barbara, lover of-- and loved by--her Greenwich Village community died of cancer at age 69 on January 25, 2010. She was a gifted teacher and teacher of teachers, and an even more gifted friend. Barbara is survived by her husband of 49 years, Ronald; son David and wife Patty; daughter Jennifer and partner Bill; grandchildren Molly, Max and Layla; brother Ronald and wife Helga, nieces and nephew and literally dozens of "honorary" family members who blossomed in the warmth of the Schneider home. She fed us, she laughed with us, and she nurtured us. New Year's Day will never be the same. You are gone too soon, Barb, and will never be forgotten. Funeral services will be private. Friends may call on the family on Friday, January 29 from 2pm-6pm and 7-9pm, and on Saturday, January 30 from 1pm-7pm. 90 Greene Street. (at Spring Street)--2nd floor. A memorial service will be held at a later date.

GREBIN--Burton. The Solaris Group is deeply saddened by the sudden untimely death of their 36-year friend, Dr. Burton Grebin. Burt's life service to special needs children and their families is reflected by the many lives he touched and made better. As the visionary and imaginative leader of St. Mary's Healthcare System for Children he was an unwavering advocate for improving health and quality of life for the most vulnerable among us. Thanks to him St. Mary's, a $100 multi-million healthcare system serving 4,000 plus children daily is internationally recognized for its new care strategies which revolutionized care for children. While his vision and leadership will be sorely missed, in St. Mary's his exemplar of care is a bright light for those of us who would follow in his large foot steps.

David Sarkisyan, a former physiologist and film director who became famous as the director of the Shchusev State Museum of Architecture here and for his campaigns to preserve architectural monuments against rampant post-Soviet development, died on Jan. 7 in Munich, where he had been hospitalized. He was 62. The cause was lymphoma, said Joseph Backstein, the commissioner of the Moscow Biennale of Contemporary Art and a friend.

Federal officials charged four men on Tuesday with plotting to tamper with the telephone system in the New Orleans office of Senator Mary Landrieu, Democrat of Louisiana. One of the men was a conservative activist who gained fame last year by secretly recording members of the community group Acorn giving him advice on how to set up a brothel. All four of the men arrested Monday in New Orleans, each in his mid-20s, were charged with entering federal property under false pretenses with the intent of committing a felony, according to the United States Attorney's Office for the Eastern District of Louisiana. They appeared in court on Tuesday, and a preliminary hearing was scheduled for Feb. 12.

I first read J.D. Salinger's "Catcher in the Rye" in the summer of 1960, when I was 12. I heard about it from an older boy who was an unerring guide to books that were racy. So I went to my local library, in Brighton, Mass., asked for "Catcher," and was told that I would need a note of permission from my parents. The librarian glared at me as she said this. My mother, who was not a big reader herself, wrote a note saying I should be allowed to read whatever I wanted, which now seems one of her greatest gifts to me. That little piece of paper got me into the other, grownup side of the library, where I found a lot of books that opened my eyes and, I suppose, led me eventually to become a writer myself. I have since read better books than "Catcher" but few that made a more lasting impression. I still recall reading the first paragraph and thinking to myself, "You can really do that?"

Let this be a lesson to budding filmmakers everywhere: if you make low-budget, scruffy comedies with a distinct point of view long enough, you will eventually attract other people who like low-budget scruffy comedies with a distinct point of view. At least that's what happened to the Duplass brothers, Jay and Mark, the Austin, Tex.-based auteurs of the mumblecore genre ("The Puffy Chair" and "Baghead"). They hit Sundance this year with their first mainstream film, "Cyrus," developed for and distributed by Fox Searchlight. The feature, their first to crack 90 minutes ("only because our credits are like five minutes long," Jay said) was largely improvised; it stars John C. Reilly and Marisa Tomei as a couple whose relationship is threatened by her adult son, Jonah Hill, in the title role. The Bagger liked it and so did many others at Sundance; it won unofficial best-of polls and even had some watchers talking Oscars - pretty heady stuff for a couple of dudes who made their Sundance entrée with what they called their "$3 movie" and cast their parents in the follow-up. The Bagger spoke with them in the plasticized courtyard of a hotel in Park City.

Fifty years ago, when the 26-year-old photographer Elliott Erwitt shot an advertising campaign for Puerto Rico, the island still held a sense of the exotic for American travelers. Nowadays, Old San Juan has a Marshall's discount store on one of its main plazas, and the island struggles to differentiate itself from other spots in the Caribbean - that is, as a place to hole up in a pool-side cabana between trips to the beach and the breakfast buffet. Which is why Puerto Rico tourism officials have commissioned Erwitt to reprise his 1950s shoot with a new portfolio of images intended to recapture some of the island's cultural allure (you can read about the campaign in Stuart Elliott's advertising column). It's yet more evidence - in addition to the recently revived grand-dame hotels and retro cocktails and velvety old-world passenger trains - that nostalgia is a powerful force in the travel world just now. Here's a look at Erwitt's photographs, then and now, the difference at times being poignantly hard to discern.

Jorge Silva of Reuters, who took the picture of the boy in Slide 5, crossed into Haiti from the Dominican Republic 36 hours after the earthquake. "Every day that passed we realized the dimension of the destruction was even greater," he wrote. "Every time I explored what was behind a wall, in a garden or a plaza, inside a field hospital or in the ruins of a house, there would be more children who urgently needed food and medicine." Mr. Silva's work has appeared here once before, on Sept. 25. It was also a picture of a young boy. The scene Tuesday afternoon at the TriBeCa offices of the Italian television network RAI International was, perhaps not surprisingly, a little like RAI's distinctive brand of programming: leisurely, charming, chatty, full of attractive personalities and, for English speakers anyway, slightly baffling. But not necessarily in a bad way. The event was billed as a send-off for "Roy Lichtenstein, Meditations on Art," an exhibition of more than 100 works by the late Pop artist opening that day at the Triennale museum in Milan. But the 50 or so men and women milling around a red-carpeted 25th-floor meeting room sipping Pellegrino and speaking fluent Italish were there for what proved to be bigger news: the official announcement that the Triennale - the impressive 87-year-old design-focused institution - will open a New York satellite exhibition space, Triennale NYC, this spring.A live closed-circuit TV hookup with the Triennale in Milan - think giant projection-screen Skype - yielded a series of disconnections, pixelated greetings back and forth across the Atlantic ("saluti a tutti!") and halting moments of unclear protocol, but the crowd took it all in with breezy bella figura. On the screen, there was the Triennale president Davide Rampello at the museum in Milan, and in the room an array of Italian-culture panjandrums, including the Italian Consul General Francesco Maria Talò, the RAI director Massimo Magliaro and Roberto "Bobo" Manzoni, a veteran Milanese businessman who has been guiding the Triennale's effort to scope out potential new locations, à la the Guggenheim, around the world. Manzoni said that a visit to MoMA in December 2008 gave him the flash of inspiration that allowed him to "follow a dream": to open Triennale NYC across West 53rd Street in what was the home of the Museum of Arts and Design (formerly the American Craft Museum) from 1986 until 2008, when it moved to new quarters in the remade 2 Columbus Circle.

There's been an ongoing attack on the credibility of federal climate monitoring efforts that has been partly inspired by Anthony Watts. In 2007, Mr. Watts, a former TV weather forecaster, began recruiting legions of volunteers across the United States to inspect the thousands of weather stations -- some in people's back yards or in parking lots -- that have for generations produced the raw data feeding into federal and independent efforts to track climate trends. The result was SurfaceStations.org. Its rogues gallery of photos of particularly suspect weather stations has been credited by many meteorologists and climatologists as a wake-up call for the need for better monitoring (an issue that affects many other realms, from monitoring acid rain to tracking flood risks):

If you'd like to plan a visit to the Hallelujah Mountains on your next vacation, your best option is to see "Avatar" for the seventh time. A Chinese city is backing away from reports that it renamed one of its mountains for those floating peaks from the James Cameron film, amid complaints that the city was caving in to Western cultural influences. On Monday, the government Web site of Zhangjiajie City in Hunan province said that it had changed the name of its Southern Sky Column to Avatar Hallelujah Mountains; the change was apparently an attempt to capitalize on the success of "Avatar," which has earned more than $100 million in China. But according to Reuters, a report in the state-run Xinhua news agency said that the decision was unpopular with city residents, who "accused officials of being money-oriented and blindly worshiping Western culture." A local tourism official told Xinhua: "We only added a way to call the mountain. The previous name is not abolished." China is historically wary of the effects of Western culture, and recently pulled the 2-D version of "Avatar" from many movie theaters, despite the film's popularity there.

"It's a little romance with the muck," the designer says of the anthracite chunks, which he buys 14 tons at a time from a mine in Pennsylvania and stores in the backyard of his upstate New York house. The coal's earthiness appeals to Zivic, but the irony of his situation doesn't escape him. "The same stuff my neighbors are burning for heat, Ralph is selling for thousands of dollars," he says, referring to Ralph Pucci, the owner of Ralph Pucci International, the company that is known for its fashion mannequins and its furniture by cutting-edge designers.

In 1971 John Baldessari made a print of a text-based artwork that has become legend. It said, "I will not make any more boring art," and the pioneering California conceptualist has been as good as his word. Baldessari's deadpan videos, paintings, photographs and assemblages, which he adapts from existing imagery, provoke laughter, puzzlement and admiration, often all at once. As both teacher and artist, he has inspired several generations of younger artists subscribing to his belief that anything goes in art and everything in the world can be fodder for making it. He ramps up his photographic works - photomontages juxtaposing multiple framed images drawn from television, advertising or film - by masking telltale noses, ears or eyes with floating, brightly colored dots. Museums and collectors have invested in his unique products for a very pretty penny. Now comes a complete compendium of his more affordable limited-edition works, of which a new book, "John Baldessari: A Catalogue Raisonne of Prints and Multiples, 1971-2007," is one.

Tonight, President Obama presented a compelling defense of his strategy to disrupt, dismantle, and defeat Al Qaeda in Afghanistan. Following my deployment to the northeastern region of the country in 2006-2007, I arrived at many of the same conclusions as he has over recent months. I believed that the faltering mission required a revamped approach, more troops, and more resources. Dealing with the dysfunctions of the U.S.-led effort, serving in an overstretched unit and suffering casualties in my platoon prompted my initial diagnosis. However, time, distance, and perspective from my experience have forced me to reconsider this assessment.President Obama's goals are sound. Training Afghan security forces, rewarding good governance, reducing corruption, supporting the rights of all Afghans, and strengthening the international coalition are vital to the fight against Al Qaeda. However, a fatal flaw plagues the counterinsurgency strategy adopted by the president: the more the U.S. and its allies deepen their involvement and commitment in Afghanistan, the more they undercut the Afghan sense of ownership, accountability and sustainability that will determine the long-term fate of the mission. Simply put, his strategy is directly at odds with his goals.

He had us before he said hello. It was, in part, the look. Blue suit, but not the usual blue -- subtler; red rep tie, white shirt, a skin color cosmetics and sun could never deliver, and, for much of the time, a big smile. It was the rock-star look in full Technicolor. Everyone else seemed to be in black and white. He dominated the screen and he did it with an ease that stopped just short of entitlement, an ease that said, in Chevy Chase fashion, "I'm the president and you're not."

"Mary & Max," the Australian stop-motion animated feature film by Adam Elliot, about the pen-pal relationship between a young girl and a man with Asperger's syndrome opens the second annual RealAbilities: NY Disabilities Film Festival tonight. The festival, which runs through Feb. 2 and is presented by the JCC in Manhattan, showcases films that "celebrate lives, stories and artistic expressions of people with disabilities." Nine films will be shown in 12 venues across the city, including Andrew Bujalski's "Beeswax," "Henry O!," about a blind baseball commentator, and "Zig Zag Love," which stars Robert Carlyle from "The Full Monty" as an overprotective dad of a girl with cerebral palsy. This is one of the most accessible festivals in the region, with ASL interpretation, live audio description, captions and Braille materials all available.

"A forceful presence on any stage," she appears at the Highline Ballroom tonight for two shows at 8 and 10:30 p.m.

“If the movie ‘Atonement’ had been rated NC-17,” writes Cintra Wilson, “Keira Knightley might have been ravished in the library wearing a silk blindfold and leather wrist cuffs from Kiki de Montparnasse, and it still wouldn’t have looked too Cinemax.” With Valentine’s Day just around the corner, now might just be the perfect time to pay a visit to the high-end lingerie store for similar cinematic inspiration or your own classy set of cuffs. The store’s atmosphere “has the effect of making its superbly made (and astronomically priced) fetish accouterments look respectable.” If bondage, however well-heeled, is still not your thing try Agent Provocateur, only a few of blocks away from Kiki de Montparnasse, but “considerably closer to the old 42nd Street in spirit.” The vibe is “more user-friendly for embarrassed guys shopping alone and packs of teenage girls; the lights are brighter, the music is dumber, louder and younger. Many items fall into a black and pink, rockabilly hot-rod style. It is, in essence, a vamped-up version of Victoria’s Secret by way of Johnny Rockets, the retro diner chain.” Either way, remember that “Valentine’s Day was originally a time to ritually exorcise evil spirits and restore one’s city to health and fertility,” so do your civic duty.

North Korea fired dozens of artillery shells on Wednesday from its shoreline into waters near its disputed western sea border with South Korea, and the South Korean military returned warning shots from smaller weapons, according to South Korean military officials and fishermen on a border island. Neither side reported casualties or damage. On Thursday, a South Korean official said the North fired several more rounds of artillery early in the morning, according to The Associated Press. In addition, North Korea's official KCNA news agency said Thursday that an unidentified American had been detained after crossing into the North from China, Reuters reported. The North has recently signaled a willingness to return to six-nation talks on ending its nuclear weapons program. In return for resuming the talks, North Korea has demanded talks on a peace treaty with the United States and the lifting of United Nations sanctions tightened after its two nuclear tests.

A bankruptcy judge on Wednesday approved a $45.6 million incentive program for top executives and managers of the Tribune Company, overruling objections by a union and the bankruptcy trustee that the payout was too high and unwarranted. The program for 2009 covers 10 top executives and 710 managers. Kevin J. Carey, the chief judge of the Delaware Bankruptcy Court in Wilmington, did not rule on two other incentive programs for 20 top executives that totaled about $20 million. In remarks before issuing his ruling, he suggested that the Tribune board consider rolling the remaining incentive plans into the reorganization plan under which the company would emerge from Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection.

ARONSOHN--Harry- proud father, proud veteran, good friend- died Tuesday at the Pine Rest nursing home in Paramus, NJ. He was 89. Born and raised in New York City, Harry left college to enlist in the U.S. Army Air Corps on December 14, 1941. He served three years until a near fatal accident led to his honorable discharge. He worked on Wall Street and following his retirement in 1989, Harry served as a stock exchange arbitrator. Harry is survived by his stepson Robert Zuckerman (Florida); three children- Leslie (Florida), Patricia (Florida), and Paul Aronsohn (New Jersey); daughter-in-law Marie DeNoia Aronsohn (New Jersey); two grandchildren-Anna and Luke (New Jersey); and close friend and niece Bette Aronsohn (Arizona). All loved him. All enjoyed him. All appreciated him. And all will miss him very, very much. A private family service will be held at Calverton National Veterans Cemetery in Long Island on Friday morning. In lieu of flowers, please do something nice for a veteran. Feeney Funeral Home, Ridgewood, NJ. wwwfeeneyfuneralhome.com

SCHNEIDER--Barbara. Our dear Barbara, lover of-- and loved by--her Greenwich Village community died of cancer at age 69 on January 25, 2010. She was a gifted teacher and teacher of teachers, and an even more gifted friend. Barbara is survived by her husband of 49 years, Ronald; son David and wife Patty; daughter Jennifer and partner Bill; grandchildren Molly, Max and Layla; brother Ronald and wife Helga, nieces and nephew and literally dozens of "honorary" family members who blossomed in the warmth of the Schneider home. Marie Violande Guerrier-Cavalier arrived in Florida from Haiti on Jan. 16, with little more than her feverish infant son, Marcley, his tiny legs in casts because of a birth defect. She left her husband and four other children behind, living in the yard outside their broken house. Because Marcley is a United States citizen, born here, his mother was allowed to evacuate with him after the earthquake, and can stay in the United States for six months. But Ms. Guerrier-Cavalier has few possessions, no money and no way of legally earning any. She can neither support herself and Marcley, nor send money back home at a time when Haitians are desperate for help from outside. And it is unclear where she will go when the six months are up.

The deposed former Honduran president, Manuel Zelaya, packed his guitar and flew into exile Wednesday as the country inaugurated a new president, who promised to try to repair the rifts left by months of political turmoil. After a good-bye lunch with his mother, Mr. Zelaya, his wife and his daughter left their refuge in the Brazilian Embassy and headed for the airport. They were accompanied by the new president, Porfirio Lobo, along with President Leonel Fernandez of the Dominican Republic, who last week invited Mr. Zelaya to the Dominican capital, Santo Domingo, last week.

GREBIN--Burton. The Board of Directors and Staff of St. Mary's Healthcare System for Children are deeply saddened by the death of Burton Grebin, MD, our beloved President and CEO, on Sunday, January 24, 2010. Dr. Grebin dedicated his life to improving the health and quality of life for children with special needs and their families. A true advocate for the most vulnerable among us, he created programs for kids when none existed. Under Dr. Grebin's leadership, St. Mary's established the nation's first Palliative Care program for children; New York State's first long-term home care program for children; New York's first and largest home care program for children and families with HIV/AIDS; New York City's first certified Traumatic Brain Injury and Coma Recovery Program for children; and one of only nine interdisciplinary pediatric feeding disorder programs in the U.S. Dr. Grebin transformed St. Mary's from a 40-bed nursing home for children into a $100 million healthcare system that is the New York region's largest provider of post-acute care for children, serving more than 4,000 children in the hospital or in their homes every day. Children's healthcare has suffered a great loss with Dr. Grebin's passing. Our heartfelt condolences to the Grebin Family and Dr. Grebin's dear partner, Susan Gold.
Just saying no to everything may be good short-term politics, but it's not leadership. We were sent here to serve our citizens, not our ambitions. PRESIDENT OBAMA.

Breaking a long-established pattern in labor negotiations, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg plans to demand that city teachers agree to a significantly smaller raise in their next contract or face the prospect of 2,500 job cuts. The threat, which the teachers' union immediately called unacceptable, promises to be one of the most contentious elements of Mr. Bloomberg's budget proposal for the next fiscal year, which begins July 1. The mayor is scheduled to deliver his budget address on Thursday, but his office released a few details on Wednesday night.The teachers are in the middle of contract negotiations. Over the last eight years, they have received a cumulative wage increase of 43 percent.

FLEISS--William S.,died January 24 at the age of 88, survived by his wife of 61 years, Phyllis Fleiss; also daughters, Nina (Chris) Brogna and Jane (Ivar) Brogger, granddaughter Isabelle Brogger, loving cousin Bebe (Ed) Orzac and family friend Helen Berlin. For 30 years Bill was a stock broker at Shearson Leahman American Express and a decorated WWII veteran: The Purple Heart for injuries on Normandy Beach, The Bronze Star with Oak Leaf Cluster for valor in Sicily and The Silver Star for valor in France. Bill's unique humor and love of family will always be remembered. Donations in his name can be made to: Children's Community School, 14702 Sylvan Street, Van Nuys, CA 91411 or Doctors without Borders. A Memorial service is being planned.

PALMER--L. Guy II, passed away quietly in his sleep on January 16 after a long illness at age 75. Guy is survived by his wife of 51 years, June Lawrence Palmer of Savannah, GA. Guy is also survived by his brother, five children, and twelve grandchildren. Guy graduated from Yale University in 1957, where he was a member of Skull and Bones. He was a founder and President of the investment management firm Davis, Palmer and Biggs, Inc. Later, Guy was Director of the Internal Pension Asset Management Group of General Motors. He was also a founder of Chatham Capital Group in Savannah. Guy was an active member on a number of corporate, charitable, and educational boards including those of the Charles A. Dana Foundation and the Williston Northampton School. An avid golfer, Guy was a member of the Pine Valley Golf Club. A memorial service is planned for this coming June in Pelham Manor, NY.

The Afghan government is set to unveil an ambitious, far-reaching plan to persuade the Taliban's foot soldiers to abandon their fight and to offer an opening for the movement's leaders to return to politics in the country they once ruled. The new program, which President Hamid Karzai will outline Thursday at a conference in London, seeks to avoid the problems that dogged earlier, more piecemeal approaches. This time it will be a comprehensive plan, operating at the district, provincial and national levels, according to his advisers, who describe it as ''bottom-up and top-down.''

8 P.M. (Sundance) MAN ON WIRE (2008) As a young man, the aerialist Philippe Petit, above, was flipping through a magazine in a doctor's office when he saw an article about plans to build the two tallest skyscrapers in the world side by side in Lower Manhattan -- and he became obsessed with walking between them. This documentary from James Marsh reminisces about Mr. Petit's daredevil (and illegal) feat on Aug. 7, 1974, when for nearly 45 minutes he danced back and forth on a metal cable strung between the towers of the World Trade Center. Writing in The New York Times, A. O. Scott called the film, which won the Oscar for best feature documentary, ''thorough, understated and altogether enthralling.'' 11 A.M. (ABC) THE VIEW Elisabeth Hasselbeck swaps jobs for the day with her husband, Tim. Andre Dawson will be inducted into the Hall of Fame as a Montreal Expo, despite his preference to go in as a Chicago Cub. The Hall announced its decision Wednesday. Dawson told WMVP-AM radio in Chicago that he thought Hall officials would discuss the issue with him in detail before the decision. He said he wanted a chance to tell them ''what really catapulted me to Hall of Fame status and pretty much what my preference was, but I think their decision had been made.''

Coach Geno Auriemma, whose United States women's national basketball team is made up primarily of W.N.B.A. players, said the league's summer season put the national team at a big disadvantage in preparing for this fall's world championships in the Czech Republic. The W.N.B.A. schedule allows few training opportunities before the competition, which begins Sept. 23. Auriemma said he hoped to have a few days in the spring -- before the W.N.B.A. season -- and a few days in early September with players whose teams are not in the playoffs.

Dressed in a black polo shirt and cap, and white slacks, Phil Mickelson was as unequivocal as his outfit on the subject that has brought together the worlds of golf and gossip. He was not here to talk about Tiger Woods. As Mickelson sat down in a lounge chair in the media tent Wednesday for his first interview session since Woods's personal life began its public unraveling on Thanksgiving weekend, he offered a pre-emptive strike.

The last time Roger Federer failed to make the semifinals of a Grand Slam tournament, Barack Obama was a state senator from Illinois. Gustavo Kuerten beat Federer in the third round of the French Open in May 2004, but since then Federer has been a model of consistency. His 15 Grand Slam titles may receive more notice, but a case can be made that reaching 23 consecutive semifinals in tennis's major championships is the more difficult record to break.

AUCHINCLOSS--Louis S. The Board of Trustees and staff of the Museum of the City of New York extend heartfelt condolences to his sons John, Blake, and Andrew and their families. Louis Auchincloss joined the Board of the Museum in 1966 and served as its President or Chairman until 1995, continuing on as Counsel on the Executive Committee before retiring from the Board in 2009 after 43 years. No one was more dedicated to the Museum of the City of New York; no trustee was more revered and beloved. In 2007 the Museum, in his honor, instituted the Louis Auchincloss Prize, given annually to distinguished artists whose inspiration springs from and enriches the five boroughs of New York City. He himself was the first recipient. An essential part of the life of the Museum for so long, Louis Auchincloss will be sorely missed. James G. Dinan Chair, Board of Trustees Susan Henshaw Jones, President and Ronay Menschel Director

Reading J.D. Salinger’s “The Catcher in the Rye” was a rite of passage for generations of teenagers who saw in Holden Caulfield, the high school truant, an enemy of adult phoniness and hypocrisy. The novel, as Charles McGrath wrote in Mr. Salinger’s obituary, attained cult status in mid-20th century America for its portrayal of adolescence and “its fierce if alienated sense of morality and distrust of the adult world.”
The old cobblestone boulevards look much as they did in the singer's youth.
Joshua Cohen, left, of Stanford University and Glenn Loury of Brown University debate President Obama's pledge to change Washington.

Amazon has pulled books published by Macmillan from its site in a disagreement between the online retailer and the publisher over the price of e-books. For the moment, Macmillan books are available on Amazon only when bought through third parties. Macmillan, like other publishers, has been wrangling with Amazon over the retailer's insistence that all e-books for its Kindle device be priced at $9.99. Many publishers want to charge more, or at least have more control over prices for individual books. The dispute hit a new level this week when Apple introduced its new iPad device, which will have an iBooks application through which publishers will have more control over e-book prices. The full story is here.
Update | 7:01 p.m. Amazon relents and is selling Macmillan books again.

When Rafael Nadal withdrew from Wimbledon last summer, the tennis world wondered who would emerge as Roger Federer's competition for major titles while Nadal healed his ailing knees. Andy Roddick came achingly close in his epic five-set loss to Federer at Wimbledon. At the United States Open, Juan Martin del Potro twice came back from a set down to take the title from Federer, proving that the world's best tennis player wasn't invincible. On Sunday in the men's final at the Australian Open, Federer will take on another challenger in Andy Murray, the shrewd and talented Scot.

"The United States economy grew at its fastest pace in over six years at the end of 2009," announces The Times's Catherine Rampell, "Gross domestic product expanded at an annual rate of 5.7 percent in the fourth quarter, after growing at an annualized rate of 2.2 percent in the previous quarter ... the strong growth in the fourth quarter capped a year of the biggest contraction since 1946, when the country was still cooling off from World War II."

If Democrats break down their major health care legislation into components that could be approved separately, the first bill up for consideration could be a proposal to end the exemption from federal antitrust laws that insurers have enjoyed since 1945.

HONOLULU -The Republican National Committee today approved a watered-down resolution designed to deal with a demand by conservative committee members that Republican candidates agree to support a list of conservative positions as a condition of receiving financial support from the party.

Sri Lanka's quarter-century-long civil war may have ended, but there is no peace between the two rivals in Tuesday's presidential contest. Police raided opposition candidate Sarath Fonseka's campaign headquarters on Friday, seizing computer equipment and arresting 15 members of his staff.

Repurposed pajamas, Janus-faced models and anti-Bolshevik iconography, oh my! Spring/summer 2010 couture collections weren't your grandmother's couture. Well, not quite. In Tokyo, ramen is more than a bowl of brothy noodles - it is an everyperson's staple that inspires passion among Japanese and foreigners alike. Matt Gross, who writes the Frugal Traveler column, slurps his way through the city's ramen joints in search of the perfect bowl.

When the Quaker Oats company decided its namesake logo - the behatted fellow who has been the face of its oat products since 1877 - was too heavy and pasty-faced for today's health-conscious consumer, the company hired the illustrator Robert Rodriguez to give their man a makeover.

MGM has gained additional concessions from its lenders to allow it to continue to seek a buyer. The studio, crumbling under the weight of almost $4 billion in debt, can now skip interest payments until March 31. This is the second time MGM has asked to skip payments. Initially, lenders had agreed to let the studio bypass September, October and November. Then it sought and won an extension until Jan. 31.

Another reason that the Academy moved to 10 best-picture nominees this year was to boost TV ratings, but if the sale of commercial time is any indication, it may not pay off. Ad Age reports that the price of commercials during the Oscar telecast is essentially the same as it was in 2009, between $1.3 million and $1.5 million for a 30-second spot. "Last year's Oscar telecast cost advertisers around $1.4 million for a 30-second ad, down significantly from 2008, when a 30-second spot commanded as much as $1.82 million," Brian Steinberg writes. (For comparison, a Super Bowl spot will cost up to $3 million this year, though its advertisers are also grappling with the economy.)
